camin cadarað /kaˈmɪn ˌka.daˈʀaθ/ [kɐˈmɪn ˌka.dɐˈʀah] primrose path, easy life, life of hedonism, the road to hell

that is, a deceptively easy or appealing decision of series of decisions, which however lead one astray or to damnation—especially choices offered by a malevolent actor

< 17C, coined by writer and philosopher Caðoval Thoitom in his 1641 allegory Through the Heghlant Forest, or the Ruin of Little Lady Alissa, literally meaning “distilled pathway”. The noun camin “way” is an Old Boral borrowing, either from Norman or Spanish sailors, from Late Latin cammīnus “way”, itself from Gaulish. Malgrað, piratary spas graç all'Abanc Novomondin ne 1471 eð all'Ascendanç vascon coherent. A Marsegl, la stan gazou frequent aðief por ig plusour ageurn com ða y citað fos occupað ; donc y risc fuyeurn heilant vars scurtað certanessem.

The aid requests presented to Rudolf VIII went largely unanswered. < 12C, now literally “to an event” but contemporaneously “to the falling”, with several competing theories as to its metaphorical origin. The noun is from Latin cadentia “fall, happening” or a later nominal derivation from Old Boral caire “to fall”.

    Jo so amoraçað a cainç dell'hom accaç.

    I have fallen completely in love with the postman.

    /ʒo zo ˌamoʀaˈtsaθ a ˈkents deˈlɔm aˈkats/

##

15m Juglot

    from a review in the Fiellas Dimenja (Sunday Leaves/Sheets), a Marsellan weekly newspaper incorporated in 1871. It focuses primarily on recreation and entertainment, unlike the older weeklies dating back to the sixteenth century, which were limited more to “high-brow” topics.

14th October, 1950

…welcomed back from the New Cambrick facilities; Captains Kerry and Montpiu landed safely at Fort daus Sanz early Friday morning.

REVIEW: Zachariah

A departure from Kiawaman's usual fare, this blacklair [horror] tale takes us back to the 1820s amid the disintegration of the Long Peace and the beginning of Reaction War. From the gaslit streets of independent Boxa [~Novi Sad, Serbia] to the recovering shell of Stamboul [Istanbul/Constantinople], this adaptation of Petcov's classic trevold [novel] Majat vCherveno (The Red Man) tries to recreate the dread and mystery of watching our four heroes slowly discover the true nature of the eponymous Zachariah.

Unfortunately, the beautiful landscape shots and the addition of a rich Tavancine tourist (whose plotline is mostly borrowed from the book's Elenor storyline) are the high points of an otherwise messy film. In an attempt to incorporate some of the more traditional aspects of vampire folklore, Kiawaman grants Zachariah mystic powers and has the heroes defeat him by means of a sanctified wooden stake (not, as in the book and in popular wisdom, by burning). These new powers, in the hands of a better writer, could have set up a dynamic between Zachariah and Vania as artists of the same craft—instead, we are given the tired trope of a woman torn between the affections of two men. It doesn't help that the audience barely believes there is any choice to make; Vania has no chemistry with either lead.

The symbolism of fire and butterflies that permeated the book is also entirely absent from this adaptation. Apparently afraid to present Zachariah as light or good in any way, we get a cold manor house and bat-infested (!) roofs. Never mind the rich history of the vampire as a figure clinging to life in all its forms, in the blood of the living, in the dancing flames and in the metamorphosis of the butterfly. The film relies heavily on gory fights (with what is clearly wine as a bad stand-in for blood, in a disappointing reversal) and a pounding orchestra who leave the few quiet scenes no room to breathe.

This will be no classic: come only for the views (of beautiful forests, and a bevy of handsome actors, I concede) and two hours of mindless tragedy. - Jacint Brunat

< regular nominal derivation from recoglir “to reap, to harvest”, from Latin recolligō “to collect, to gather again”. First used outside an agricultural context in the seventeenth century, with an uptick and entry into general usage in the nineteeth during the Global Workshop decades.

    Y scaðr tissour Tiong parmis recoglenç d'accostur laboriosessem.

    The Tiong loom allowed clothing to be produced more efficiently.

    /i ˈxa.ðʀ̩ tiˈsuʀ ˈtjong paʀˈmɪz ˌʀe.kɔjˈlɛnts ˌda.kɔsˈtɪʀ laˌbo.ʀjoˈzɛ.sɛm/

< from Old Boral (co)sumzon [ko.sʏmˈtsɔn] “use, usage”, either a synchronic nominal derivation from sumbre “to take, to use” (from Latin sūmō “I take, I acquire, I employ”), which gave Middle Boral sumir “to take, to use” before falling into disuse, or else a direct descendant from Latin nominalisation cōnsūmptiō “consumption, wasting”.

    Ac compt for sunçon e noc mandað.

18m Juglot

    the first few lines of a student's repsonse to 2013 Question 5, Paper 1 from the MSC standard course Alchemy Actual sou Contingent (Modern Alchemy in Context).

5. Descriað y sunçon (actual e ne histoir) de calamin.
5. Describe the usage, historical and modern, of calamine.

Calamin, nommað tan jast igniac, es matier reconnuð ne casc loy dy mont des antictað.
Calamine, or igniac jast [zinc oxide], is a substance known since antiquity across the world.

Ig inclus, ag siecr 3aN ja ern y Roman calamin benoçant por bras forgar, n'oc fondent con cuivr.
For example, as early as the 3rd century aN the Romans were using calamine to make brass, by smelting it with copper.

Plusour scet, y sestertius parmig (veyað y starç, un scet borlesc postimperial) fosn quinað ne bras posc y reform augustin de 23aN—il ig nommaurn orichalcum.
Several coins, including the sestertius (cf. the starce, an early Borlish coin) were minted from brass after the 23aN Augustine reforms—they called it orichalcum.

Calamin a y parsan d'orteyanç eð autr machy a piel soutenuð ny remed tras annað millener, eð ancour sarf i de nossy jorn com part ne crem a cavel.
Calamine has served as a treatment for rashes and other skin blemishes for thousands of years, and it is still used today as a component of hair creams.

Sur production atelier l'oc es matier hagr por gom faus fair, eð a mesur dell'eç dezein recent lamp a lumner PAD ant calamin afont son entrað ne benoç commun.
In workshop manufacture it is an essential part of pseudogum [synthetic rubber] production, and in the last few decades daplight lamps [LED lightbulbs] using calamine have entered common use.

20m Juglot

parsan /paʀˈsan/ [pɐːˈsan] recovery, healing

< from 12C Old Boral parsan “cure, act of healing”, deverbal noun from parsanar “to cure, to heal (someone)"—this later shifts to intransitive "to get better, to recover” and probably pulls the noun along with it. This verb is a direct descendant of Latin persānō “I heal (someone) thoroughly or completely”, intensive form of sānō “I heal, I cure”; see also sānus > san “healthy”.

    Por y lign de Natagl e Joseph, oy no fo la spien a parsan.

    For Natalia and Joseph's line, there was now no hope of recovery.

    /pɔʀ i ˈlajn de naˈtɛjl e ʒoˈzɛf | ɔj no ˈfo la ˈspɛm a paʀˈsan/

21r Juglot

    taken from A Politic Mapbook of Middle-Age Europe (4th edition), by various authors, published 2005 by Winchester Scholastic

Albion and Ireland, 1028 Nascentiæ

This year is the last in pre-Drengotian Albion. 1029 will bring the Kernovan Conjuring and Norman Accession, and the succeeding decades will see what might have been the new steady state of these islands disintegrate.

In the south, Kent under Rodulf is stable and much expanded from its position in the 9th and early 10th centuries, having subdued Wessex (minus Anglia, already lost to Markland in the Treaty of Oxford) but suffered renewed Dumnonian pushes from the west. Canterbury's most powerful vassals lie to the north in Essex across the Thames, ably run by Alfred the Tall. The elderly patriarch Rodulf of Kent lingers on his deathbed after eight decades of political manœuvring.

To the west we have the ever-fractious kingdoms of Ireland, lately unified as but four (with the breaking of the Ultagh in the north-east): Tyrconnal, Connaght, Lenster and Munster. The tales of Tyrconnal and Lenster are dominated by wars at once with the Norse to the east and the other Irish to the west, while the houses of Connaght and Munster vie for the position of High King of Ireland.

The north holds the confederate Kingdoms of the Danes, newly untethered from overseas rule. The once-mighty kingdom of Northumbria is rendered but one province of the whole, yet the city of Yorwick remains the richest city on Albion (thanks to economic ties in all directions). Still more northerly lie the two-minded Kingdom of Scotland and the last remains of Horther rule in Albion persist in Orkney and Shetland.

Between all these we find those bitter rivals, Markland and Wales. Cadwallan, erstwhile king of Wynneth, finds himself the unexpected ruler of all Wales—a fortuitous position of strength against equally formidable Markland under Oswin the Becoming.

Assurance, he had said, that if indeed the world was controlled by shadowy demons who could wipe themselves from the minds of those who saw them, he could at least find out about it.

Cos retenuð au Leonta y nom Erculaneo triað, sou motif ig l'er alchemy studiant a noc histoir, e donc l'ig bourg vole noc plausibr se cavir svoccað par hasart.
Leonta had privately chosen the name Erculaneo, on the grounds that she was studying alchemy, not history, so the town was unlikely to come up by accident.

##

2m Aost

    taken from the 2008 fourth edition of condensed study materials for New Vithor course Histoir Concorrent, s16 : Mort, Vascel eð y Motion Celest (in English, Concurrence History of the 16th Century: Death, Ships and the Movement of the Heavens).

…it is usual to consider the feudal system entirely defunct by 1550 N, at least outside of insular nations like Burgundy or Awry. There were a variety of reasons for this collapse, some more widely accepted than others.

Often cited is a labour shortage of serfs due to the Second Great Dying, allowing those peasants who remained to demand more favourable conditions from their lords. This is evidenced by the correlation [Iscombe 1967] observed between population loss and liberalisation (as well as how quickly the nascent middle class grew). For example, Borland under Joseph III lost over four hundred thousand people, one-seventh of its population; serfdom (already on its last legs) was legally abolished in 1564 N, but by that point it had not de facto existed on the island for a generation.

One counterexample to the above trend is Vascony, which, thanks to Novomundine profits in furs and other goods, actually saw in increase in population from 1500 to 1550 (excluding Portingale) due to immigration. The end of the Vascon Ascendancy with the War of the Two Queens would end feudalism in Vascony by the end of the century, however.

(It is worth mentioning that this was not the main factor in ending feudalism in the east, where the Islamic conquests of Kiew and Russian Cazany upended the nobility more directly.)

One, perhaps unexpected, effect of the decline of the feudal system was the strengthening of laws such as sumptuary codes. These were intended [Rone, 1988] to reinforce the social distinctions between serf, freedman and noble—although states had had similar laws almost since Classical times, enforcement of these rules became more stringent and draconian. There is even one account of an Emma Chasteron being executed in Dovres for wearing “silk in saphires purpel and petal embroderie” to church…

    We don't have enough money on hand to stay in a hotel like that.

that is, the southwesternmost part of Albion [Great Britain]

also dorogner from Devon, from Cornwall

< 12C in Old Boral as Doroȝne “Devon”, from earlier Donnoȝna, itself from Latin Dumnonia “land of the Dumnonii”, referring to the British group resident there in Roman times. The Latin comes from the Classical British root duβn “deep”, related to Cambrick dωvn “deep”. See also French Dourogne, Leon Domnòix with the same sense.

    Y preu havan y nogt passað la ne tar brittesc es Iscom, a Dorogn.

    The first British harbour we'll spend the night at is Iscom in Devon.

    /i ˈpʀaw haˈvan i ˈnɔjt paˈsaθ la ne ˈtaʀ bʀiˈtɛx ɛz iˈxɔm a doˈʀɔjn/

##

8m Aost

    taken from textbook Albic Medicine in the Workshop Decades, Part V: Alchemic Detaxion, written by Dr Harold Westcamp and published 1994 by the Conster Health Edifice, funded by the Markland Ministry for Health.

…as in the writing of physician Dr Mickel Cráyenschot, noted for being an early supporter of Deviance Theology and public tovarick in France even as it embraced the Modest Arrangement.

But the application of copper's counter-zoic [anti-microbial] manner with the furthest-reaching consequences can only be the stauron retainer [intra-uterine device]. Nonetheless it is important to separate our modern point of view from the contemporary. What seem to us like obvious components of the retainer often took dozens of years to innovate. For example, the T-cross of the modern retainer doesn't arise until the St. Agrippina Medical House 1877 patent—earlier designs included rings and helices!

The theoretical barrier to developing this kind of prevention was recognising that copper metal could kill sperm cases as well as zoia. Although copper's counter-zoic manner had been documented since 1789 (see the work of alchemist Suxúmawaca bint as-Sáffat), extending this observation to sperm would have to wait until 1824, in the aftermath of the Second German War. Former mozardisto and farm theorist Ricardo Ivarrachezurí wrote in that year that “the seed of the bull, the ram and the stallion alike are made impotent in storing them for some hours in a syringe of copper; in this we can suppose we see the same mechanism that dispels the cholera from water in a copper cauldron”.

In fact, Ivarrachezurí published these findings as a warning to other farmers and horse breeders not to use copper in their fecundation projects…

##

9m Aost

sar /saʀ/ [sɑː] net, fishnet, mesh, also in general a network, an interconnected system

in particular y sar (epistol), literally “the letter mesh”, referring to the global network of communication devices and other computers, known in English as “the mesh”.

< 12C, from Vask sare “net”, one of the many naval words taken from Vascon fishermen and later from their sea-traders: see hagr “mast” and bakilau “cod”, also from Vask. Extension to general networks first attested 1836; use for the mesh calqued from French mail épistre, itself a reference to 1968 parachthon tale Starsail, published in Rone by Ashford Pasquier.

    Posc pieç minut er y sar remorcað des y mar torvant.

    After a few minutes the net was pulled out of the troubled sea.

    /pɔx ˈpjɛts miˈnɪt ɛʀ y ˈsaʀ ˌʀe.mɔʀˈkaθ dɛz i ˈmaʀ toʀˈvant/

##

10m Aost

var souvr /var ˈsu.vʀ̩/ declare war, wage war

literally set war loose, release war

< expression from 16C in poet Drominir's work Verdur Roug, which drew on his experience fighting in the War for the Stavang Crown. The verb is a direct descendant of Latin solvō “I loosen, explain, break up, cancel, unfurl” (although it does not retain the full range of meanings!).

    All'yent de May Connagt sta prest a var souvr.

    By the beginning of May Connaught was ready to declare war.

    /aˈljɛnt de ˈme koˈnɛjt sta ˈpʀɛst a aˈbat ˈsu.vʀ̩/

11m Aost

    excerpt from and Borlish translation of New Skies, Old Stories (in Provincial French Novè Cial, Anzan Conte) by Simon d'Estiala, published 1980 by Prindor Marsillès.

Parcanç es i temerer, y decadenç a trevogt blasmar unic ag morostað n'Europ posc y var.
It is perhaps foolhardy to attribute the decline of Voidtale trevolds solely to the gloom of post-war Europe.

Nos posseu tan digr, parmig, l'idea de novel œcumen splorar e de novel cultur encontrar n'au plu attragnt ; l'ovartur caddicivenean laiscau pog “tar enigmatic” por descovrir,
We might say, for example, that the idea of exploring new lands and meeting new civilisations had lost its shine, with the opening of Caddicivene leaving few “mysterious lands” to discover,

In any case, when it comes to parachthon romance, the middle of the nineteenth century was somewhat of a nadir.

12m Aost

dromig /dʀoˈmaj/ blackberry, bramble, (sometimes in general) drupe

< 9C in Old Boral rommiȝ “bramble”, from early Borland Romance romige, from Vulgar Latin rumīce < Latin rumex, rumicis “sorrel”. Later influenced by druf “stone fruit”, from Latin drūpa.

    Y ci Nou Provençal son connuð par lour pantort a dromig.

    The New Provincials are known for their blackberry pies.

13m Aost

retenour stauron /ˌre.teˈnuʀ stoˈʀɔn/ IUD, intrauterine device, (in-setting) stauron retainer

informally, un stauron or (rarely) un retenour

< first used in Borlish in 1890s N, based on Vascon retenor stauròn or possibly Romish ritinore stauron; analogous terms had been in the scientific literature since the 1876 Sant'Agrippa publication. The noun is an agentive from retenir “to withhold, restrain, keep, preserve”, literally “hold again”, itself modelled after Latin retineō “I hold back, repress, protect”. The adjective, meaning “cross-shaped”, is from a mock-neuter form of Ancient Greek σταυρός (staurós) “stake,  crucifix”.

    Vossy preu stauron es cavibr n'un dy sanatoir a Ausbagn.

    You can get your first IUD from one of the Ausbagn clinics.

    /vɔstʀ‿i ˈpʀaw stoˈʀɔn ɛz caˈvi.bʀ̩ nɪn di ˌsa.naˈtɔjʀ a ozˈbɛjn/

##

14m Aost

y plurem /i ˈpli.ʀɛm/ [ɪ ˈpli.ʀɪm] for the most part, particularly, especially

< 14C in Middle Boral i plurm “mostly” (various spellings), literally “the greatest amount”. The determiner from Old Boral il “the”, from Latin ille “that”, probably via a vulgar form īle. The noun is a direct descendant of Latin adjective plūrimus “the most, very many”, suppletive superlative form of multus “many” (modern Boral mout “often”).

    J'am noc y plurem raðar a Ausçagm ; la son tombr demay.

    I don't for the most part like cycling in Ausçagm; it's too hilly.

    /ˈʒam nɔk i ˈpliʀɛm ʀaˈðaʀ a ozˈbɛjn | la sɔn ˈtɔm.bʀ̩ deˈme/

##

15m Aost

    from the collected study notes for the course 1471–1517: War, Peace and Exploration after the Novomundine Landfall, 37th avenue in Concurrence History at the Tremonnow Open School.

Of course, Vascony was not the only nearby state attempting to reach Asia by sea. Ambrose's nemesis Munir al-Hamdawi of Morrack had in 1463 established a rival marine enterprise in the New World Company (شركة العالم الجديد), and just five years later the ship Orion (الجَبَار) voyaged from Anfa [Casablanca] to Aden. They made port in Vascon Sant Adrian [Bioko] and encountered Chinese merchants in Mombasa, whose reports to the Southern Emperor would change the course of history forever (see 1524-1600: The Collision and the Fracture).

After the Landfall, the Company's efforts were swiftly redirected to the Novomund [the New World] (as were the naval efforts, however paltry, of most of Europe at this time). However, a notable exception was the relatively-new Kingdom of Britain, where Howel's ships had already set up resupply ports along the African coast. Having profited from the ongoing Wars of Fealty which raged across the rest of Albion [Great Britain], the king was convinced more opportunity lay in connecting the European market directly to Asia. Doubtless he also wanted to displace the Borlish supremacy in the northern trade (although this ambition would not be achieved in his lifetime).

In any case, the tale of the twin voyages of the Cynthia and the Phœbos (of Morrack and Britain respectively) remains to this day one of the greatest stories of exploration and discovery the world has ever known, measuring up to Homer's Odyssey and Quoming's Peoples of the Sea. Directed by Umanick and Chinese traders, mac Kellot's Phœbos sailed to Gurjat, Madray and eventually made port at Borune in 1516. This was at the time almost the south-eastern extremity of the known Vetomund.

Meanwhile, the Cynthia under al-Casmi (himself a Persian immigrant to Morrack) had no less interesting a journey…

##

16m Aost

raðar /ʀaˈðaʀ/ [ʀɐˈðɑː] to cycle, to ride a bike

< early 20C, shortened along with rað “bicycle” from 19C heverrað “bicycle, velocipede”. This borrowed from Saxon heverrath (retention of the fricative suggests a coastal source, perhaps) “bicycle”, from hevel “lever, pedal” and rath “wheel”.

    Un accaçour raðant tras l'icon, y film situant certan n'asc Bel-Jou.

    A cycling postman crosses the screen, fixing the film in the Grant-Jeu period.

    /ɪn ˌa.kaˈtsuʀ ʀaˈðant tʀaz liˈkɔn | i ˈfɪlm siˈtjant tsɛʀˈtan nax bɛlˈʒu/

17m Aost

    excerpted from the book Des Delt vars Dois : Y Stoir d'Educaçon (From Tablets to Slates: The Story of Education), in the style of an academic textbook but intended for a broad audience, written by Theign Roufler and released 2016 by Cordin Editions.

Durant y siecr catorç ençau nos a normalisation real parcevir dy model mitað-asc d'universtað tras Europ, de Galway a Gratz.
It is during the fourteenth century that we see true standardisation of the mediaeval university system across Europe, from Galway to Gratz.

Y Reyaum a Boral dell'oc hour triant parmig, Lyce Noccair addoceu sy studiant nell'eç Cinq Art Romannesc.
For example, in the Kingdom of Borland at this time, Noccair Lyceum taught its students the Five Romantic Arts.

L'eç stan de natur l'art prosequent dy set domain classic a studiar (e fort ern il tan connuð contemporane par nom d'art classic ben liberal).
These were in essence the descendants of the seven Classical areas of study (and indeed they were also known at the time as the Classical or liberal arts).

Y Cinq Art ern Literatur, Argument, Accont, Geometry e Music.
The Five Arts were Literature, Argument, Reckoning, Geometry and Songcraft.

Ag commet dy siecr cinqueç diminoy l'oc model paulatim; facultað nombrous addau souject novel, ig inclus histoir, lengaç eð alchemy.
The start of the fifteenth century saw the gradual decline of this system, with various institutions introducing new subjects, such as history, languages and alchemy.

18m Aost

delt /dɛlt/ tablet, esp. of clay; more generally document, record

< attested from 17C, originally from Greek δέλτος (déltos) “writing-tablet, piece of writing” (cf. Imperial delton “book”), possibly of Semitic origin. Probably via Napolitan delto “tablet”, leading some to argue that it is a post-Classical borrowing.

    Y parol sur y delt stan febr demay; jo poðe noc lou leir.

    The writing on the tablet was too faded for me to read.

    /i paˈʀɔl sɪʀ i ˈdɛlt stanˈfɛ.bʀ̩ deˈme | ʒo poˈðe nɔk lu ˈliʀ/

##

19m Aost

prosequent /ˌpʀo.zeˈkwɛnt/ descendant, progeny, something proceeding from a source, accompaniment

< 15C in various European languages, from Scholastic Latin prōsequēns “following, escorting, accompanying”, from prō- “forward, in front” + sequor “I follow, I pursue”. Use extended to harmony in music by 18C, and soon after to supporters of a cause or person.

    Sell'abiltað ne clavir es grant aðief por prosequent fair, e bogr tan may.

    His keyboard-playing ability is good enough to accompany, and no better.

    /seˌla.bɪlˈtaθ ne klaˈvɪʀ ɛz ˈgʀant aˈðjɛf pɔʀ ˌpʀo.zeˈkwɛnt fɛʀ | e ˈlɔn tan ˈme/

##

20m Aost

       from the collected study notes for the course 1471–1517: War, Peace and Exploration after the Novomundine Landfall, 37th avenue in Concurrence History at the Tremonnow Open School.

…the south-eastern extremity of the known Vetomund.

Meanwhile, the Cynthia under al-Casmi (himself a Persian immigrant to Morrack) had no less interesting a journey. First making port at the various Arcabil and Meridian outposts, already a significant source of wealth, the ship continued along the Cappatian coast*. Here in al-Casmi's logbooks we read of the Dowahin straits and island (from the Arabic for “smoke”, after the many smoke-towers the captain writes of seeing the inhabitants of the island build, and which dissuaded him from making landfall thereon).

(*Remember that the continent would not be so named for several more decades yet.)

But the bulk of the Cynthia's journey would come next, as the ship entered the southern Horizic Ocean. At first they sailed north along the jagged coastline, possibly as far as Maboutian lands, although al-Casmis records are unclear. In any case they eventually sailed west into the blue. It is not entirely clear which Horizic Isles the Cynthia encountered on this part of the voyage. What is known is that on midsummer of 1515 they alighted on Jazirat Asnam (the encounter being infamous for its acrimony), and that on 11 Shaban 921 the crew began to perform the salat forward, not aft, as the astronomer aboard—one Taisir as-Sadik—predicted they had passed the longitude of the antipode of Mecca.*

(*Further recall that truly accurate longitude measurement would not be achieved until the invention of the timehold in the mid-seventeenth century.)

The next spring the Cynthia finally arrived in a place almost recognisable as Asia, though the inhabitants were as dark-skinned as anyone in the Arab world. This archipelago was hence named Asia Cahal (or in modern parlance Cahalla), and in the records of al-Casmi's time on Bijai (the largest island thereof) there is an account of an old folktale; one which will explain why the Cynthia, on leaving Bijai, went not west, but south…

##

21r Aost

triant parmig /tʀiˈant paʀˈmaj/ for example, as an example

< 17C, literally “choosing among them”, existing alongside and eventually displacing several similar constructions. The verb triar “choose, pick” is from Old Boral tri(ð)ar “sort, sift”, with pronunciation at least influenced by Old French trier, with the same meaning. This from late Latin trītō “I chop, rub”, with meaning shift through use in granum terere “beat the corn from the chaff”. The adverb parmig derives from parmy “among, alongside”, literally “by the middle”, from Latin per medium.

    Lour y pas faus triant parmig, cossireð y Semman a Tonneðr.

    As an example of what they did wrong, consider the Week of Thunder.

    /luʀ i ˈpaz foz tʀiˈant paʀˈmaj | ˌko.siˈʀɛθ i seˈman a toˈnɛ.ðʀ̩/

##

22m Aost

dois /dɔjz/ touchpad, touchscreen, smartphone; in-universe English tach or slate

< late 20C, clipping of ardois “slate, slab”, also “screen, display”, referring to touchscreens originally in the brandname TachArdois (evoking Greek τᾰχῠ́ς • takhús “swift, quick”) and the generic term ardois tactil “tactile slate”. The noun ardois is from Old Boral ardoise, ardosc, ardesc “slate”, borrowed at various points from Old French ardoise < Late Latin ardesia, probably of Gaulish origin.

    J'oyeu l'ig connart fatuous rompoy trey dois n'un monð.

    I heard that clumsy idiot broke three tachs in one month.

    /ʒoˈjaw laj koˈnaʀt faˈtjuz ʀɔmˈpɔj tʀi ˈdɔjz nɪn ˈmɔnθ/

23m Aost

    story excerpt from Callot Rhig's 1834 collection of short stories Aur Nercow (Fool's Gold), exploring the disconnect between what we say we want, and what will truly make us happy.

Diabr sta i feliç a se trovar ac, ða meðes oy passau i jorn sou perigl d'applatiscenç par col livr.
He was damned lucky to be here, even if he now lived in danger of being crushed by a book landslide.

Arthur fo vas ag var ogtoç eld, e fo reuluð posc nouf annað descovrent i sta l'ivan extrane d'un famigl lon gravitað mendrem.
Arthur had gone to war at eighteen, and come back nine years later to find himself the extraneous child of a family of little import.

Sur mar ben ne Madray er i vis com cim forgað, un ven dont slança experiç vocationner cordamn fruyant e tout souvant.
At sea or in Madray he'd been a forged expert, a wellspring of professional expertise who knew the ropes and had seen it all.

Cas luy a Carvantel, i fo denuð ancour joun segr, hom a pog addoçment eð a alcun histoir empley.
Back in Carvantel he'd become a young man again, one with little training and no experience.

Pre y var un atelier carpenter au le benoçað un apprendent, ma l'ig parisce remotessem a jouneç.
He'd been apprenticed to a carpenter's shop before the war, but that felt like a lifetime ago.

For sarve i ac a hom occir, stant dissuas.
All he was good at now was killing people, which was discouraged.

##

24m Aost

romannesc /ˌʀo.maˈnɛx/ [ˌʀo.mɐˈnɛç] civilised, popular, folk, romantic, quaint

< 10C in rumanesc etc. “of the Roman peoples”, which is to say of Borland, Italy, Iberia and France, from roman “Roman” with adjectival suffix -esc < Germanic -iskas. Soon (by late 11C) used to denote popular or folk stories, music and so on, as opposed to Classical or ecclesiastical works, or any works in Latin. Already by 17C it means “quaint, old-fashioned, charming”, but more positive senses returned in the late 18C with the Romantic Revival of the Long Peace.

    L'eç cont mi-mythos a rey e volour son nommað stoir romannesc.

    These semi-mythical stories of kings and thieves are called romantic tales.

    /lɛts ˈkɔnt mi.miˈθɔz a ˈʀi e voˈluʀ sɔn noˈmaθ stɔjʀ ˌʀo.maˈnɛx/

##

25m Aost

diminoir /ˌdi.miˈnɔjʀ/ [ˌdi.mɪˈnɔ.jɐ] to weaken, shrink, decline, diminish

< 12C in Old Boral diminoer “lessen, weaken”, a semi-learned borrowing of Latin dīminuō “I shatter, weaken”. Along with attriboir “assign”, its verbal conjugation changed by analogy with verbs descending from Latin -struō. However the past participle remains diminuð, rather than the expected *diminoit.

    Y luissoir d'aur diminois for posc y pouvranç a Daclont fo treblað.

    The lust for gold only weakened once Dackland's population had tripled.

    /i lajˈsɔjʀ ˈdoʀ ˌdi.miˈnɔjz fɔʀ pɔx i puˈvʀants a dakˈlɔnt fo tʀeˈblaθ/

26m Aost

    questions taken from the January 2003 N scitation documents for the course 1471 - 1517: War, Peace and Exploration after the Novomundine Landfall, 37th avenue in Concurrence History at the Tremonnow Open School (formerly the Brethin Mesh Institute). [continued from 13m Avril]

Question 3 (sixty minutes)

(i) Answer the following short questions on the Vascon Ascendancy in under 100 words each.

    (α) Who is the most probable out of the many people who are claimed to have been lovers of King Ambrose III?
    (β) What caused the infamous sinking of the Estellas daus Sanz, which would have been the second lone ship to make the Atlantic crossing?
    (γ) Why did the War for the Barcelon Succession last for only 4 days?
    (δ) Where did Vascony trade for the oranges and other citrus fruits required by the Sandrine Design?
    (ε) When was the strict iamb 5' first used in Vascon poetry?

(ii) To what extent did the fact that the northern parts of Mendeva were less immediately profitable than the East lead to the end of the Vascon Ascendancy?

Question 4 (forty minutes)

EITHER

(i) Summarise the arguments for and against the veracity of al-Casmi's account of the tale of the Great Southern Island, including recent hereditarian findings and their implications for patterns of migration, and contemporary Tecamaw accounts of the decline of star navigation.

OR

(ii) Discuss the societal effects of the reintroduction of long-distance boating and sail on the Tecamaw nation and the Bijai, with evidence taken from the various written records of the Borunesk Great Meeting of 1517.

27m Aost

coul tar /kul taʀ/ [kuː tɑː] landslide, rockslide, avalanche (both literally and metaphorically—a deluge of tasks or other unwanted things)

> 15C, literally “flow of earth”, from coul “flow” (now obsoleted by newer colanç), a deverbal of colar “to flow” < Latin cōlō “I strain, filter” plus tar “earth”, directly from Latin terra “ground, soil, dirt”. The word coul is nowadays used only in this expression and, lately, one-time formations such as coul livr “book-slide”, etc.

    Posc je sy nascenç la's un coul tar desig plou lort.

    After his birthday there was a landslide due to heavy rain.

    /pɔx ʒe si naˈxɛnts laz ɪn ˈkul ˈtaʀ deˈzaj ˈplu ˈlɔrt/

##

28m Aost

cim forgað /ˈtsɪm fɔʀˈgaθ/ [ˌtsɪɱ.fʊːˈgah] seasoned expert, person well-versed in their field

> 18C, literally “forged top”, where here cim “top, point, cap” uses an archaic sense of “expert, authority”, the word coming from Latin cȳma “sprout (as of cabbage), hollow sphere”, from Greek. The adjective is the past participle of forgar “to make, to forge”, from Latin fabricō “I build” (presumably via dialect forms in Old Boral, or perhaps early Norman French? See attested foircare).

    L'eç defy farraun de mey un cim forgað.

    These challenges will make me a seasoned expert.

    /lɛts deˈfi faˈʀon de ˈmi ɪn ˈtsɪm fɔʀˈgaθ/

29m Aost

    Extract taken from the Borlish version (translated by Benjamin Rocquot in 1923) of Dutch biography Lát os Danse: De Hartoin 'n Avosche (Let us Dance: The Duchess d'Avosche), chronicling and dramatising the life of sixteenth-century noblewoman Adaillé d'Avosche (1524-1608), a duchy in southern Willemy. 

    She was infamous during her later life for her great influence in the court of David of France, with rumours that she was in fact his mother persisting for the rest of his reign. The 1589 scandal involving her eldest grandson Déricque temporarily cost her some capital, and although she soon regained her position, King David took the opportunity to continue the centralisation policies typical of contemporary Europe.

De Roger e Carolin d'Avosc nascoirn ogt ivan, dont Adagle sta tressem.
Roger and Caroline d'Avosche had eight children, and Adaillé was the third.

Sy dou fraðr antir moroy com sugtour (un certan desig Scon Grant Morrenç), tan con sy fraðr postir Peðr, e sy jounessem sour Anna.
Her two older brothers died in infancy (at least one in the Second Great Dying), as well as her younger brother Peter, and her youngest sister Anne.

Cossy sta i durant y grant plurem ag jouneç l'heriter appos dy ducað.
Thus she was for the great majority of her childhood the heir presumptive of the duchy.

L'eç prefaction, toglað afont coll'eç condoçment de preu sy noðriç Elisa Arnoutszen (cosvour dy sanat parnommað)
These expectations, combined with the instructions of at first her nurse Elisa Arnoutszen (cousin of the renowned physician)

e soulor sy ci aðelent, animaurn sy natur entrovant eð ingenious.
and later her tutors, encouraged her inquisitive and intelligent nature.

30m Aost

condoçment /ˌkɔn.dɔtsˈmɛnt/ [ˌkɔn.dʊsˈmɛnt] training, education, instruction, apprenticeship

> 14C Middle Boral nominal derivation from condocir “to train, to instruct, to take as an apprentice”, possibly a direct descendant of Latin condoceō of the same meaning, but more likely a borrowing (any earlier attestations are uncertain).

    Jo porray noc le stikettar prest a condoçment porsevir.

31r Aost

dissuadir /ˌdi.sjaˈdɪʀ/ [ˌdi.sjɐˈdɪː] to dissuade, to discourage, to oppose

< 16C, borrowed from Latin dissuādeō “I urge differently, advise against”, from prefix dis- “apart, reversal” with the verb suādeō “I recommend, advise, persuade”. Inherits past tense and participle forms in -s (dissuas etc) from Latin and retains them by analogy with similar verbs, mostly in the third declension.

    Nos deyeu vos dissuadir de l'eç monc a Golfhaun fascar.

    We must advise you not to anger the Gulfhaven monks.

    /no diˈjaw vo ˌdi.sjaˈdɪʀ de lɛts ˈmɔnk a gɔlfˈhon faˈxaʀ/ 

##

1r Septembr

    short extracts taken from Y Stoir d'Istr Boral (The Story of Borland), second edition, a school history textbook published 1993 by Cordin Editions, one of the foremost guilds producing educational books for national schools.

…we will perhaps never know if the conquering Romans called our land īnsula boreālis “Island in the North” before they arrived in force at the daybreak of the first millenium, or if the name is a post hoc creation after the native Kelt name, enis borag “Island of the Dawn” (so called for its easterly position with respect to Albion and Ireland)…

…there remains little outside contemporary Roman accounts of the Bora Ale, the Borland Kelts, bar geographical features such as the river Duðam (from du dammo “at the river”) and, possibly, personal names such as Ivocq and Haðr (though for most of these we also have alternate explanations)…

…in Ptolemy's description of the Pritannoi we can understand he referred to the entirety of the Insular Kelts as a whole; this grouping was later divided, first by the English Strait at some point before Caesar's first invasion of Albion, and later by the Irish Sea, although of course this neat partition is confused by the Scots and by the Welsh communities along the Rustigh…

…the latter years of the eighth century, as the Viking Age dawned. The last purely English war of the time was the Merch subjugation of East Anglia, simultaneously establishing the Great Border between the mouths of the Severn and the Thames (see the Oxonian 796 N chronicle), and inciting a renewed influx into the petty kingdoms of Angland and Southbar…

##

2m Septembr

sugtour /sajˈtuʀ/ [sɐjˈtʊː] toddler, infant, very young child

also sapling, young plant

< 13C in late Old Boral suȝtour “suckler, one who breastfeeds”, nominal derivation from suȝtar (modern sugtar) “suckle, breastfeed”, a direct descendant from late Latin sūgitō “I suckle”. This is a derivation apparently exclusive to Borland from sūgō “I suck, take in” (see also issugt “dried, boring”, from the same root).

    Y joun segr entrau ny varous, sugtour fassað ag peitrin.

    The young man entered the shop, an infant swaddled on his chest.

    /i ˈʒun ˈsi.jʀ̩ ɛnˈtʀo ni vaˈʀuz | sajˈtuʀ faˈsaθ ɛj piˈtʀɪn/

##

3m Septembr

cosvour /koˈsvuʀ/ [kʊzˈvʊː] cousin, relative, in general similar thing

< Unclear. Attested in late 8C in a bewildering variety of forms—suer, cossorn, sourin, cusoondre, among many others. Presumably somehow related to Latin cōnsobrīnus “first cousin”, whence Norman quosin, Vascon cotrì and Romish coginne, for example. However, influence from Old English swēor “father-in-law, cousin” is almost guaranteed.

    Vos derreð sona luïr de cosvour febr n'y duc acconnoscent.

    You will have to pose as distant cousins when you are introduced to the duke.

    /vo deˈʀɛθ soˈna lajˈiʀ de koˈsvuʀ ˈfɛ.bʀ̩ ni ˈdɪk ˌa.koˈnɔ.xɛnt/

##

4m Septembr

    from the 1914 short lovetale Chargez-moy Garir (Command that I be Healed), written by longtime author and Millstone veteran (serving in the Second Medic Force of Valois) Honorine Maignard. She was the daughter of Grant-Jeu Lombard diplomat Audace Saviano, who was instrumental in the establishment of the Italian Concert in 1891.

I no's dur a continuar soll'apres dy mort de sy marið.
It isn't difficult to go on in the wake of her husband's death.

Parveg sent Claire l'ig sey ne bon mont.
Sometimes Claire feels like it should be.

Ig l'au y cainç tan toccað, ig l'au parmis tan direct all'aðombracer Mr Becond le dirisc n'ouvr sug, y mort aus le fragnt.
Considering her hand in things, that she'd let herself be so readily manipulated into doing Mr Becond's dirty work, it should have taken her apart.

L'aus l'incendiað toð a tar.
It should have burned her down to the ground.

Ma a loy—a loy i le refay.
But instead—instead it remakes her.

Y celebr Claire Robiquet pren martel por aïðar con y recostroinç, Auscapel stant cicatricið ja ancour pall'abat dy Grant Centuir, acr a farm laiscað crous, blazað ;
The illustrious Claire Robiquet steps up to help with the reconstruction,  scarred all over again by the Grand Army's fight, acres of farmland left a burned-out husk;

e Claire se pon avant un grauf e resaif y signfianç d'un objectif aïr.
and Claire stands at a grave and rediscovers what it means to have purpose.

##

5m Septembr

parnommar /ˌpaʀ.noˈmaʀ/ [ˌpɑː.nʊˈmɑː] to celebrate, make famous, idolise, canonise, worship

< 12C parnomar “to canonise” but probably earlier, seen especially in religious contexts as a vernacular translation of Latin canōnizō “I recognise as a saint”. Formed from par- “through, thoroughly” < Latin per- with nommar “to name, to call, to recognise as”, a verbal derivation from nom “name”. Extended to secular use by 15C. Nowadays most common as the participle parnommað “famous, celebrated”.

    Cascif fout vossy cognit un parnommað ?

    Why the fuck are you undercover as a celebrity?

    /kaˈxɪf fut vɔsˈtʀ‿i kɔjˈnɪt ɪn ˌpaʀ.noˈmaθ/

##

6m Septembr

aðelent /ˌa.ðeˈlɛnt/ [ˌa.ðɪˈlɛn(t)] tutor, teacher (especially privately-employed)

< 11C in later Old Boral, participle derivation from aðelir “to grant land” (> modern “to improve”), first referring to the stewards in the royal court responsible for granting land to lower nobles, such as barons. Later shifted along with the verb to guardians and tutors of the aristocracy, and by 18C also to privately-employed tutors in general.

    Y position d'Anscon com aðelent ag joun heriter apporta magn advantaç.

    Anscon's position as tutor to the young heir brought many advantages.

    /i ˌpo.ziˈtsjɔn  danˈxɔn kɔm ˌa.ðeˈlɛnt ɛj ʒun ˌe.ʀiˈtɛʀ ˌa.pɔʀˈta mɛjn ˌad.vanˈtats/

##

7m Septembr

    start of a letter sent in 1828 via steeplepost from Pentrose (a port town on the south coast of Borland) to Axton (a rapidly-growing industry town which at the time was located in French Guillenne [1], in the duchy of Avosche, known to Paris as Grand-Aix).

    The Rustigh Strait postal crossing from Ausbagn to Texel was not yet connected with air-steeples. In fact, the eventual connection only lasted a generation or so before a barrick line [electric telegraph cable] was laid down—one of the first such lines, beaten by Dovre-Caleis, which were successfully joined in 1852.

To the inestimable Niklás de Fecht,

Or should I be saying Nicolas Defechet, perhaps? You will at the very least do me the service of not moving to Paris, city of greed and carrion [2], even if you must learn some Proper French for the sake of your wife. (I have always preferred the Roun standard on aesthetic grounds, although I cannot entirely forget politics even here!) As Hortense is certainly reading, I shall pass on Clara's well-wishes and reiterate that you are welcome to make use of the Vauhan lencorve [line of credit]; just ask for Marduth at the Tyche Bank.

Pether's lot are also destined, it seems to leave fair, perfidious Albion. Despite my continuing assurances of welcome here they are determined to sail the great Mendevan river to whatever future they can find in Hasiny [3]. I must admit the prospect of being thousands of miles from any Dutchman has its appeal. (Forgive me! The last decade has made provincials of us all—mayhap even Provincials! [4])

The library has finally provided me with Dümmeyer's treatise on collection and delivery; I will not appease you by pretending to have read it, but be assured I will find the hours for it this very week…

——————–
[1] Corresponding approximately to Alsace, Lorraine and the Netherlands.

[2] The Kingdom of France was seen to have profited unjustly from the Second German War, gaining significant territory while (according to many) not investing much manpower or material resources.

[3] A Mendevan [North American] state now legally separate from Britain [a state comprising Wales, Devon, Kernow and parts of northern Ireland and Albion], corresponding roughly to East Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas, Oklahoma, and western Mississippi.

[4] This pun on “inhabitants of Provence” and “rural, sheltered people” is not uncommon in letters at this time, but not well understood in retrospect.

##

8m Septembr

martel prendr /maʀˈtɛl ˈpʀɛn.dʀ̩/ to step up, pitch in, help out

< attested from 15C in Kigman's poetry, an idiom literally meaning “to take the hammer”. The noun is from later Latin martellus, diminutive of a variant of marculus “hammer”. The verb is a direct descendant of Latin prehendō “I take, grasp, seize”.

    Y rey Eustasc meðes pris martel posc y quagment 1755 a Lisbon.

    King Eustace himself stepped up after the 1755 Lisbon earthquake.

    /i ˈri awˈstats meˈðɛz ˈprɪz marˈtɛl pɔx i kwagˈmɛnt seˈtɛtsɛnt ˌtsɪnkwanˈtsɪnk a lɪzˈbɔn/

##

9m Septembr

varous /vaˈʀuz/ shop, store, warehouse, stock, especially for non-food items

< 14C as varhous “warehouse, storage place”, from some Germanic compound, most probably Horther or Low Saxon. Earlier attestation of an Old English *wærhūs are disputed. In any case, from Classical German roots varō “goods, wares” and hūsam “house”. Meaning “shop, place to buy things” since late 18C.

    Jo fo yent tost demay eð y varous cociner no sta ovart.

    I had arrived too early and the kitchen store wasn't open.

    /ʒo fo ˈjɛnt ˈtɔst deˈme e‿ˈði vaˈruz ˌko.tsiˈnɛr no ˈsta oˈvart/ 

##

10m Septembr

    from academic textbook In Context: The Vascon Ascendancy by Katrin Hindman, contributing to the In Context series, published by Nottinger University Primers through the 1980s and 90s.

Y Reyaum Vascon a Navarr eð Aquitain asseyeu ag commet dy regn d'Ambrosc III un eðegl moneter vital.
The Vascon Kingdom of Navarre and Aquitaine at the start of Ambrose [Ambròix] III's reign inhabitated a key economic position.

Y païs sta l'onc entr y ci gran magl trocant republican ny Miterran (particuler posc Port Calè redugnt a mesur dy fenç 1449)
It was the link between the great republican trade networks of the Middlesea (especially since taking Port Calè in the 1449 partition)

eð y colanç marcer accelerandessem des Albion goineð e des, aust ancour, y citað colluïsc Theudesc e bautesc.
and the accelerating flow of goods from Welsh Albion and, further east, the Dutch and Graven guild cities.

Cant Andalus abattoy insorgenç politic—dou cris a succession e l'abansanc 1457 ne Lisbon, com eç primer—
While Andalus struggled with political unrest—two consecutive succession crises and the 1457 Lisbon Massacre, to start with—

Ambrosc careu influyenç vascon spandr de star un mojol dy magl trocant vars denir un font de recoglenç mejan per se.
Ambrose sought to extend Vascon influence from being a trade-mesh hub to becoming a seat of resource production in itself.

Dominanç brittesc sull'Atlantic au lontemp famigl pescour vasq frustrað,
British [Celtic] dominion over the Atlantic had long frustrated Vask fishing families,

dont ci sodal prepondraurn ja parmy l'aristocracy e posseyeurn forç politic remarcabr ny cort a Ambrosc.
members of which still predominated in the aristocracy and held significant political power in Ambrose's court.

Pall'oc façon sta y stabliscment dy Novel Enterpris Navarran un manouvr treblað :
In this way the founding of the New Navarre Enterprise was a three-fold manœuvre:

primer, oc reitfiau y position de Vascony com forniscour e porçonnour suprem de març trocað par Europ enter ;
first, it solidified Vascony's position as supreme supplier and distributor of trade goods throughout Europe;

dovem, oc dau a sy vassal y possendessem un rout vars autortað e risceç y thron noc menaçant ;
second, it gave his most powerful vassals an avenue to power and riches that did not threaten his position,

treim (ig degnant i poðe bogr savir), oc mis Vascony ne plaç por y descovart y signfiandessem ny siecr cinqueç acavar…
third (though he could not know this), it set up Vascony to make the most important discovery of the fifteenth century…

11m Septembr

quagir /kwaˈgɪr/ [kwɐˈgɪː] to tremble, shiver, quake

also quagment /kwagˈment/ a trembling, a shiver, an earthquake

< 9C in Old Boral, attested in various forms: quagiar, kegar, cokir among others. From Old English cwacian “quake"—eventually settled into -ir¹ conjugation with past participle quait /kwEt/. Noun from 14C, first seen in reference to the 1348 Furlain earthquake.

    "Jo poð noc oc sgardar,” dis i, vois quagent.

    “I can't watch this,” she said, her voice trembling.

    /ʒo ˈpɔθ nɔk ˈɔk sgarˈdar | dɪz ˈi | ˈvɔjz kwaˈgɛnt/

##

12m Septembr

eðegl /eˈðijl/ [ɪˈðijʊ] nook, alcove, niche

also position, controlled territory, strategic holding

< first attested 10C as edeȝl “small room, defensive cover”, showing that the martial meaning was a very early semantic extension. Descends directly (though presumably from a northern form, given the incomplete lenition of stressed /d/) from Latin ædicula “small temple, chapel, house, or room”, diminutive of ædis “temple, room”. No religious sense is confirmed in the Boral; compare Lombard edicola “kiosk, stand < shrine, alcove”.

    Jo slançau all'eðegl, attenent a respirar calmessem.

    I rushed to the alcove, trying to breathe more quietly.

    /ʒo slanˈtso a.leˈðijl | aˈtɛ.nɛnt a ˌrɛs.piˈrar kalˈmɛ.sɛm/

13m Septembr

    remainder of a letter sent in 1828 via steeplepost from Pentrose to , from the mathematician Darren Brodus (of the Vithor New University but at the time in convalescence at his family home) to his brother-in-law Niklás der Fecht, himself a professor at the  Benet School.

(Pentrose in red,  in blue)
image

…library has finally provided me with Dümmeyer's treatise on collection and delivery; I will not appease you by pretending to have read it, but be assured I will find the hours for it this very week! Dear Johan insists it is all atmospherical and futile nonsense, but then Johan trusts no mathematics since Craddock's book on distance room. Honestly I'm surprised he consents to use even the mechanical methods, but I suppose he isn't quite bone-headed enough to make his workshop designing more difficult for himself.

Have you any plans to go south this summer? I hear they shall reopen the arena in Verona to performances—they say Bruno's Wings Afire will be the first shown there since the war! I had the pleasure of knowing her brother Jacom before she was ever known to the wider world (apparently they are astonishingly similar in appearance, even for twins); we fought together at Hulm in 21. That was an astonishingly-mismanaged offensive and in all honestly prolonged the war for months, but I mustn't start this rant, or I will never end.

Jacom had nothing but praise for his sister and their parents, in any case (although the desire for a warm bed and the call of peacetime Furlain no doubt inflenced his recollection), so I cannot do anything but recommend the opera to you. If in the end you hate the singing you will at least have the pleasure of restored Roman architecture!

Your friend,
Darren Brodus

14m Septembr

redugr /reˈda.jr̩/ [ʀɪˈda.jɐ] to quell, subdue, subjugate; to diminish, reduce, bring down

< 9C in Old Boral reduȝre /reˈdʉɣ.rə/ “to quell (as of military resistance)”, semi-learned borrowing from Mediæval Latin redūcō idem, patterning after conduȝre < condūcō. Non-miltary senses a common Romance development and may reflect evolving use in Scholastic Latin; attested in Boral by 15C.

Y novel rout vil y burden redugr de març portar a Damborn.

The new road will make it easier to ferry goods to Dambourne.

/i noˈvɛl ˈrut vɪl i bɪrˈdɛn reˈda.jr̩ de ˈmarts pɔrˈtar a damˈbɔrn/

15m Septembr

març /ˈmarts/ [ˈmɑːs] goods, wares, products; things to sell, produce or trade

also adjective marcer /marˈtsɛr/ [mɑːˈtsɛː] commercial, relating to trade
commarç /koˈmarts/ [kʊˈmɑːs] trade, commerce, exchange

< first attested 10C in Old Boral març “wares”, seen used as the equivalent of Old English ƿara “wares”. This comes from Latin merx “merchandise, commodity”. Abstract noun commarç < commercium may have had influence on the specific sound changes. Adjective marcer in use from 14C, with ending -er < Latin -ārius, which forms adjectives from nouns and verbs.

    La sera març foyer ag marcað je Lun ne Haukirç.

    There will be small wares at the Monday market in Haukirch.

    /la seˈra ˈmarts fɔˈjɛr ɛj marˈkaθ ʒe ˈlɪn ne hoˈkɪrts/

##

16m Septembr

    extracts from Medic, Cur Tey: Y Preu Siecr de Santrafeu (Physician, Heal Thyself: The First Century of Santrafew), a Borlish-language history of one of the earliest New Provincial settlements, located at the mouth of the Becouin River [Charles River, Massachusetts]. The book focuses mostly on diary extracts from various settlers.

Y reverend Carol Zancoud sta cos plausibr y parson l'influyendessem vars y defas moneter dy bourg.
The reverend Carol Zancoud was possibly the most important factor in the town's economic development.

I luïsceu l'ig sona por y bourg des 1584 fin a morir 1630, untal possenç politic aðoint
He ministered to the town from 1584 until his death in 1630, gaining such political power

ig Sauveir d'Orz (bourgmer 1620–26) dis lonc tesmoin “Un parol soul dy reverend sceus y stif animar a me mortfiar.”
that Sauveir d'Orz (mayor 1620–26) reportedly said “One word from the reverend could have had me executed by the mob.”

Pre lugnt de siecr settoç ja l'au autortað emposseïð sur ci accaçað marcer de Provenç.
By the dawn of the seventeenth century he had already assumed authority over what Provence sent to trade.

Oc sevent vien strait des y quayer a sy figl primer, Natagl :
What follows is an extract from the diary of his eldest child Natalie:

Tant con y carc usual de març calscon desirað dy Concert Mastoiset sbolognar con
Along with the usual bevy of whichever goods the Concert wishes to foist upon the Mastoisèt

(bon Paðr crey nien aðerraun nostrell'amicabiltað tal com eramn e far may accaçant,
(Father believes nothing will do as much good for our diplomacy as sending more bronze and iron,

ben sinoc trevaglour demay por ig effojar e forgar nossy cavibr),
or at least more men to mine and smith any we can dig up for ourselves),

Marco sta vellig aðief por y ci hebdomader Marseglan accomblar, donc eu nos novel de veil mont y preu veg dell'annað.
Marco was good enough to stockpile the Marsella weekly papers, so we have news of the old country for the first time all year.

##

17m Septembr

fenç /fɛnts/ split, division, breakup; cleft, rift, crack

< 6C, first attested in very early Old Boral/late Vernacular Latin fenza /ˈfen.tsɐ/ “cutting, splitting, cleaving”, developing through the Middle Ages to Old Boral fenç “splitting, division”. Presumably a haplologised form of Latin findentia “a cleaving, a splitting” (stress shifted in Borland Latin to initial, as in all third-conjugation verbs), nominalisation of findō “I split, cleave, break up”. The extension in meaning to the concrete “a cleft, rift, crack” evidenced from 12C.

    Vos pouð noc for pegntar sur un fenç ny mur.

    You can't just paint over a crack in the wall.

    /vo ˈpuθ nɔk fɔr pinˈtar sɪr ɪn ˈfɛnts ni ˈmɪr/

##

18m Septembr

abansanc /ˌa.banˈsank/ [ˌa.bɐnˈzaŋk] massacre, bloodbath, rout

< 14C, slightly irregular derivation from abagn sanc /aˈbaɲ sank/ “bathes in blood”. The verb is from (now obsolete) abagnar “to bathe in, to submerge under”, verbal derivation of bagn “bath” < Latin balneum “bath(room)”. The noun is from Vulgar Latin sanguem “blood”, an alteration of sanguis, sanguinem (but forms like sangre do survive into Old Boral and later in some dialects).

    Y siesc eð abansanc sevent a Wackefell denommau Rey David.

    The siege and subsequent Wackefell massacre destroyed King David's reputation.

    /i ˈsjɛx e‿ˌða.banˈsank seˈvɛnt a ˌva.keˈfɛl ˌde.noˈmo ri daˈvɪd/

##

19m September

    excerpted from 1997 academic textbook Del Christianizamento dell'Isole Norroveste (On the Christianisation of the Northwestern Isles), written by historian of mediæval religion Dijaca Rofotto, working as a researcher and archivist for the Librario Soprano (Sovereign Library) of the Autonome University of Saint Marinus.

…survived, however, in those few remaining monasteries spared from the Danish raids (note in particular the Chronicle of Carlile, which survives only in copy at the Tremonnow Brethin House, having presumably been ferried across the Irish Sea before the monastery at Carlile burnt down in around 1013 N).

But to understand the final years of Wulfstan the Younger of Northumber, we must look two centuries earlier, to the very first Viking raids on the shores of Albion and Ireland. The tales of similar raids on Borland towns—and on monasteries in particular—would surely have been common knowledge by the time they spread westward, sacking Halgrive in the summer of 764.

Nonetheless, the English kingdoms were prepared for these raids (and eventually, invasions) to vastly different degrees. Compare the fates of Merch Lincon to Northumbrian Yorwick: the former never fell, and in fact became the most heavily-fortified town in Markland for the several decades it served as the de facto border of Danish rule. In part this was the inevitable result of tensions along the Welsh border; even during the relatively-long period of peacetime both Theodric the Awefast and Owain of Brochwel maintained ever-more levy forces to police the long Severn Line.

By contrast, Yorwick almost gave itself over to Dane rule. Though convincing records are either fragmentary or clearly biased (even Brethin writing in this period cannot be entirely trusted), it is generally believed that the alderman's court threw him out pre-emptively as a sop, hoping to offer enough treasure freely to the invaders that they could avoid a total destruction of the city. Yorwick's key economic position within Dane-ruled Albion in the next century certainly suggest these efforts were not unsuccessful…

20m Septembr

influïr /ˌɪn.flajˈjɪr/ [ˌɪɱ.flɐˈjɪː] to influence, to affect, to manipulate (someone)

also influyenç influence, power

< 15C, Middle Boral borrowing from Latin īnfluō “I flow in, crowd in, insinuate, invade”, with conjugation modeled after that of luïr “to play” < lūdō (itself an analogical development).

    Vostrell'yam poð gent influïr ne ci Palaç Jagovin meðes.

    Your uncle can influence people in even the Jacobin Estates.

    /voˈstɾɛˈljam pɔθ ˈʒɛnt ˌin.flajˈjɪr ne tsi paˈlats ˌʒa.goˈvɪn meˈðɛz/

21r Septembr

spandr /ˈspan.dr̩/ [ˈspan.dɐ] to expand, broaden, spread out, extend, widen

variant in -s of -r conjugation (past participle spas)

< 10C in Hostilian's Histories in reference to increase of territory. Straightforward derivation from Latin expandō “I spread out, expand, explain”, from ex- “out” and pandō “I spread, unfold”. Remote past forms in -oy by analogy with similar verbs.

    Saveð vos cascif aug span ne gelant ?

    Do you know why water expands when it freezes?

    /saˈvɛθ vo kaˈxɪf oj ˈspan ne ʒeˈlant/

##

22m Septembr

    excerpted from Paç Mondial Accommettent (Waging World Peace), written by Neuvort writer Dion Becolla and published in 1968. Unlike many so-called giftales, this tale owes more to the masquira genre of a century before—it is even set in the late 1880s, the height of the Grant-Jeu period.

“Lucas Marcuszen ?” dis Sr Barracat, posc l'ouçon de novel associað a Benjamin oïr.
“Lucas Marcuszen?” Mr. Barracat said, when he heard Benjamin's choice for his new partner.

“Bon trianç. Ma la's uncos vos valent savir pre decidr final.”
“Good choice. But there is something you should know before making a final decision.”

“Jo connosc deja l'es dannesc, bossir,” dis Benjamin. Certan des autr agent vascon scanen reclam cas y nation a Lucas,
“I'm already aware he's Danish, sir,” Benjamin said. A number of the other Vascon agents took issue with Lucas' nationality,

suggernt ig, com outem, i no'r for comfiabr tandic y ci envou a JY no fosn y ci a Collujon combattent sou ciel ovart.
suggesting that, at best, he could only be trusted as long as JY's interests weren't in open conflict with the Collusion's.

Parveg s'entrova Benjamin carraçon il apponen tout ig, s'y Bel Joy denoy violent, JY vel obligað sociar con Vascony.
Benjamin sometimes wondered why they assumed that, if the Good Game became violent, JY would automatically side with Vascony.

I sta un organisment tras tarm, cas final. Calscon parmy pos fieltað descovrir sevrað.
It was an international organisation, after all. Any of them could face divided loyalties.

“Eð i retien comport allagr con, donc i sera nominal un souject, ða nien autr.”
“And he's still on good terms with them, so he must at least nominally be a subject.”

Barracat ig ignorau agil. “Oc son casc agent dannesc. Marcuszen, soul, es tan kinæd admis.”
Barracat brushed that aside. “All of the Danish agents are. Marcuszen, however, is also an admitted thayen.”

23m Septembr

mojol /moˈʒɔl/ [mʊˈʝɔw] hub; centrepoint, midpoint; common ground

< attested 10C as mojol “hub of a wheel” (metaphorical senses seen much later but the semantic leap is clear enough), from Latin modiolus “hub” < modius “a measure of grain or dry volume, being about 2½ gallons” (compare modern Boral moisc, a similar unit). Justification for the derivation well-attested but unclear.

    Yorvic ne siecr deg denoy mojol commarç poll'eiðel dannesc.

    Tenth-century York became a trade hub for the Danish lands.

    /jɔrˈvɪk ne ˈsjɛ.kr̩ dij deˈnɔj moˈʒɔl koˈmarts po.liˈðɛl daˈnɛx/

##

24m Septembr

sodal /soˈdal/ [sʊˈdaw] member (of a group), family member, element, component

< 16C across Romance languages in Revitalism texts, directly borrowed from Scholastic Latin sodālis “member of a group or association”, influenced in meaning by sodālitās “group, association, fraternity” (the original Latin sodālis means “companion, mate, fellow, comrade”). Used for objects as well as people from 18C, but popularised in mathematics by its use in the Borlish translation of Dümmeyer's seminal work on set theory.

    Implausibr sta l'oc amigtað entr soldart e sodal dy cort a Rey David.

    This friendship of a soldier and a member of King David's court was unlikely.

    /ˌɪm.ploˈzɪ.br̩ sta lɔk ˌa.majˈtaθ ɛn.tr̩ sɔlˈdart e soˈdal di ˈkɔrt a ˈri daˈvɪd/

##

25m Septembr

    excerpted from David Huhn's economic history textbook Stadstahten: Sichrer Haven (City-States: Safe Harbor), a treatise on the role of independent trade cities in the development of mercantilism. The book was published in 1923 with funding from the Lunburg Schazhaus.

…close of the thirteenth century as a convenient cutoff. The fiction of a surviving German Empire was laid to rest with the corpse of the first Kingdom of Saxony, with the domain of the Hoghbrocken dynasty reduced to their core lands upstream in Lepzi and Magdeburg. The newly-reduced Margrave Baldur of Saxony, being only 4 years old at the time, was understandably outmanœuvred by the nascent Stadbund.

But the guild-states known variously as the Stadbund, the Samslutning or the North Collision (we see in Latin documents usually collisio theodisc) did not, of course, appear fully-formed at the dawn of the fourteenth century. We can trace the roots of intercivic contracts restricting tariffs, tolls and other fees back to the early twelfth century. Indeed, even at the height of the Mediæval Imperia, traditionally portrayed as a world (or a least a Europe) of central authority, mayors of the towns in the low Elbe and its tributaries were collaborating independently of their respective lieges.

We must look at early Bardwick, which along with Hamburg and Lunburg comprised the founding core—and later the trading heart—of the Stadbund. Its particular interest stems from its dual position as court of the Hoghbrocken kings and as a highly mercantile trade city. King Ruprecht II in particular will serve as a useful…

##

26m Septembr

prepondrar /ˌpre.pɔnˈdrar/ [ˌpʀe.pʊnˈdʀɑː] to preponderate, be in the majority, outnumber, outweigh

< late 15C, from Latin præponderō “I outweigh, preponderate” and modelled synchronically as pre- with pondrar “to weigh down, sag, be heavy, encumber”. This is from Latin ponderō “I weigh, ponder, weigh up”, a verbal derivation of pondus “weight” (see also modern Boral pendr “to hang, drape”, a cognate).

    Alor deum nos raccular, dec l'enmig nos prepondra.

    Then we had to retreat as the enemy outnumbered us.

    /aˈlɔr dawm no ˌra.kiˈlar | dɛk lɛnˈmaj no ˌpre.pɔnˈdra/

##

27m Septembr

manouvr /maˈnu.vr̩/ [mɐˈnu.vɐ] tactic, manœuvre, turn (of a game), act

< from Old Boral manowre “labour, handiwork”, from Mediæval Latin manopera, manuopera “work done by hand”, from manu “hand” plus operor “I work”. The semantic shifts to military action by 12C, possibly following (or leading) similar shift in French etc. Used in sport and games from 15C.

    Il porraun bogr y manouvr paregl repeðir souscen.

    They can hardly just try the same manœuvre again tomorrow.

    /ɪl poˈron lɔn y maˈnu.vr̩ paˈrijl ˌre.peˈðɪr suˈxɛn/ 

##

28m Septembr

    extract from the first chapter of the Borlish translation Hom ne Gahað e Diamant (Men of Jet and Diamond, or Dynnon o Vuhuð a Diamont in the original Cambrick) released in 1952 by the publishing arm of the Peujon Rous media guild. The original masquira tale was published in 1890, but achieved little notoriety in Europe before the New Provincial film adaptation Blanc Sabaje (Jet White) in 1951.

“Soð vos ac por l'avent dy Rey novel a Nadacou veir ?” Un hom haut e slanc colluïsc Zoe sur y pladisc, remplisc peðent all'hontarn con saluð.
“Are you here to see the new King arrive in Nadacow?” A tall, slender man joins Zoe at the bar, signalling the tender for a refill.

“Noc ig Sy Nobiltað veir, per se,” demorau Zoe, se sarvent dell'occasion por tornar avars e sy novel soiç sgardar fort. Cavel fosc e coutrað cort ; oc no stant usual parmy gent ant lonc caðen ancestral veunt proism, ma dy tegnt visacer val le pesar noc enter foran.
“Not to see His Grace, per se,” Zoe demurs, taking the opportunity to turn and look properly at her new companion. Dark hair, closely-shorn—not typical among those with long family ties in the area, though his complexion suggested he wasn't entirely foreign.

“O, clar comoscon!” Y soury prolongant tras y visaç dy segr es delicat e curious. Un hom raut par enigma, parcanç, ben toð cas oc volent le supportar por gra de collocq. “Vos conjuraçonnað se pondr sull'un rout deur nossy tragres souscen, j'appon ?”
“Ah, of course!” The smile that spreads across the man's face is charming and curious. Someone delighted at mystery, perhaps, or at least someone willing to humour it for the sake of conversation. “You plan to stand one street over from tomorrow's parade, I take it?”

29m Septembr

reitfiar /ritˈfjar/ [ʀɪtˈfjɑː] to solidify, strengthen, fix in place

< in Middle Boral from 14C, verbal derivation from reit “rigid, stiff, solid” with factitive suffix -fiar < Latin -ficō. The adjective comes regularly from Latin rigidus “stuff, rigid, inflexible”. Some semantic bleed from rectifiar “to straighten out, put to order, rectify” seems likely.

    Y majon mandaðer borallesc no'r reitfiað pre siecr ogtoç.

    The location of the Borlish legislative building was not fixed until the eighteenth century.

    /i maˈʒɔn ˌman.daˈðɛr ˌbo.raˈlɛx nɛr ritˈfjaθ pre ˈsjɛ.kr̩ ɔjˈtɔts/

30m Septembr

voutaç /vuˈtats/ witch, sorcerer, warlock

< first attested in 11C voutaç “witch”, nominal derivation of voutir “to bewitch” (modern Boral also “to ensnare, captivate, engross”), This is a semantic evolution from earlier vou(l)tir “to mislead, deceive” < “to turn around, to divert”, originally from Vulgar Latin volvita~volta “a turning”, from Latin volūta “spiral”, feminine passive participle of volvō “I roll, tumble”.

    Trou mey un voutaç possent mell'heir sanar.

    Find me a witch who can cure my son.

    /ˈtru mi ɪn vuˈtats poˈsɛnt meˈlir saˈnar/

Granted, not many were so blatant as Cráyenschot (son of physician Mickel), who in 1814 published Ad Pentaculum, an opera marked entirely in five. ##

2m Octobr

y mont se creir /i ˈmɔnt se ˈkrir/ to be arrogant, think highly of oneself, think the world of oneself

< 17C, literally “believe oneself (to be) the world”, survivor from a host of similar expressions floating around at the end of the seventeenth century. The noun is a direct descendant of Latin mundus “ornaments, decorations” via a Mediæval Latin sense “universe, world, mankind”. The verb is also straightforwardly from Latin crēdō “I believe, trust”.

    L'eç jammel se crein y mont aðief por ty cognit noc doutar un moment.

    The twins think so highly of themselves that they won't doubt your cover for an instant.

    /lɛts ʒaˈmɛl se ˈkrin i ˈmɔnt aˈðjɛf pɔr ti kɔjˈnɪt nɔk duˈtar ɪn moˈmɛnt/

##

3m Octobr

auvorn /oˈvɔrn/ [ʊˈvɔːn] a lot, broadly, copiously, to a great extent

< attested from 11C in Old Boral aworne /awˈwoɾnə/ (among other forms) “generously, with plenty, abundantly”, presumably from Latin phrase ab ūrnā “out of a vessel/water jar”. Irregular lowering of long <ū> not completely explained but long vowels were in any case rare before <rC> clusters. The adverb became obsolete by 15C but was reintroduced to common speech by its use in popular historical trevolds in the late eighteenth century.

    Jo spiau ty femn beint auvorn ag tarn floy.

    I saw your wife drinking copiously at the riverside pub.

    /ʒo ˈspjo ti ˈfɛmn bint oˈvɔrn ɛj ˈtarn flɔj/

##

4m Octobr

    taken from 1946 Saxon trevold Die Demrung Üverholn (Outrun the Dawn), one of the more lasting works from the Spring Tide of masquira works. Written by Bronswick native Elke Hannawald, the book is notable for subverting the trope of the masked hero, exposing the identity of spy Tristan Zettelmann to the public in the second chapter.

Sy veðr a autun ancour tenent, Tristan flannau cos leger atras a ci port rollant polið parlocað de vriðel a broccat lort e stant all'un cost dy roum fruy, eç ovrent vars y gardin floriscent dy hostel.
Still holding his glass of autune, Tristan strolled casually over to the polished sliding doors framed by heavy brocade curtains at one side of the ballroom, which opened out onto the lush hotel gardens.

L'un cost rollant atras, i sorteu furtif e kieð e seveu y camin peyan corvant com picq ny verdur.
Sliding one side open, he slipped out quietly and followed the gently winding cobblestone path into the greenery.

Y nogt ac sta fresc gentil, e certan autr gent—par eç dou, grant part—ern tan flannant atorn, y gardin bel compos splorar.
It was a pleasantly cool night out, and a few other people—couples, mostly—were also strolling around exploring the beautifully landscaped gardens.

Posc raut sgardant por ascurar alcun hom no fos cur particuler luy dant, i vayau vars un folker pot e, n'y cla seyon volað tostessem de Crahl des sy cromn,
Taking a quick look around to make sure nobody was paying particular attention to him, he wandered over to a potted fern and, slipping the key he'd taken from Crahl earlier out of his pocket,

le laiscau cair ny pot, le prement fix ny moð por y lousc trayent a metal no sey vis.
dropped it into the pot, pressing it firmly into the dirt so nobody would see the telltale glint of metal.

5m Octobr

eiðel /iˈðɛl/ [ɪˈðɛw] realm, lands, territory, demesne

< 10C in Old Boral eðel, eiðl [ˈeːðɛl] “homeland, home territory” (poetry evidence indicates stress must have shifted to the final syllable by the fifteenth century at latest). This comes from Old English ēþel with the same meaning, originally specifically in reference to English-ruled Borland.

    L'eiðel Avosc trocau pogn cinq veg ny siecr settoç soul.

    The Avosche lands changed hands five times in the seventeenth century alone.

    /liˈðɛl aˈvɔx troˈko pɔjn tsɪnk ˈvij ni ˈsjɛ.kr̩ seˈtɔts sul/

jammel /ʒaˈmɛl/ [ʝɐˈmɛw] twin, couple, identical pair

< 12C in late northern Old Boral jamel “twin” (note the characteristic opening of pretonic /ɛ/ and possible southern form ?gemr, though this is disputable), from Latin gemellus, diminutive form of geminus “twin, double, paired”

    Com er jo voluð savir i vole jammel cavir ?

##

7m Octobr

    excerpted from Borlish book Lugnt Ros Sur Ont Lugnt (Rosy Dawn on Glittering Waves), a popular account of the development of seafarers since the 1471 Landfall. Written by amateur historian Descard Ausogn in 1929, it was criticised for its uncritical view of pirate culture, and in particular his depiction of their role in the Romantic Wars.

…example of early international cooperation, the Bordew-Audaz canal was finally completed in 1679, following over a decade of delays due ultimately to Vascony's losses to Andalus in the south.

These great infrastrusture projects characterise the Romantic period, although these decades would not gain that appellation for another century. The name is first used after the Democratic Wars, when the latter half of the seventeenth century was seen, nonsensically, as the last golden age of refinement and civilisation. It is hard not to contrast these insular, squabbling European states of the 1660s with, say, the great geoscopic voyages of mac Kellot and al-Casmi of the previous century, or the renewed Novomundine interest of the next.

Nonetheless, it is in this time that we can see the familiar modern map begin to emerge across Europe. The shape of Vascony begins to stabilise at last, and to the east the German marksmen and great mayors contemplate, perhaps, the idea of cooperation. Even the fractious religious politics further south threaten to give way to the more secular animosities of popular unrest and land grabs.

In particular, Naples finally finds itself unshackled, neither from defunct Greek imperial rule, nor from the heathens of Sicily, nor from the Papal embrace of Rome. With this context King Ladislau's obsessive focus on military strength, and in particular the Marina Ottima, seems entirely reasonable…

8m Octobr

sou y blau /su i ˈblo/ worthwhile, relevant, of importance

especially in uncos sou y blau “something worth talking about”

< First attested 16C, of uncertain etymology. Often thought to refer metonymically to the sky, although soll'azur would perhaps be more expected in that case. Another popular theory claims that the phrase denotes the throne of the Saulestran kings, which (supposedly) stood beneath the moon-cut twilight banner of that dynasty.

    nien sou y blau n'a se prodoit posc my lettr derran.

    Nothing of importance has happened since my last letter.

    /ˈrjɛn su i ˈblo na se proˈdɔjt pɔx mi ˈlɛ.tr̩ deˈran/ 

##

9m Octobr

gahað /gaˈaθ/ jet, lignite; a brilliant black colour

< 11C in Old Boral gaað “jet”, directly from Latin gagātēs “hard, black asphalt”, from Greek. Use for colour probably via heraldry; gaað (and its cognates, including Norman gais) contrasted with sabl in referring to a shining black, as in enamel. Later also used mostly for a connotation of value.

    Gahað es connuð de scarçour sanat par nom “glair neir”.

    Jet is known to medical fraudsters by the name “black amber”.

    /gaˈaθ ɛz koˈnɪθ de xarˈtsur saˈnat par ˈnɔm gler nir/

10m Octobr

    taken from Fable dew Reillour Mut (The Parable of the Mute Bookbinder), written in 1743 by Rachel Desselut, daughter of explorer and infamous libertine Lord Bouvoin of Mascon, as a response to Vallakis on the problem of self-duplication. Her work would go unrecognised for nearly two decades (due predominantly to the disruption of the Democratic Wars), during which time she would be forced to flee first to Norman Kent and later to Provence, via Portingale. 

E portant i poðe noc condoçment beudar a Marcuccio, dec com vole i un studiant instroir coll'art de libronexion ? Ma ig degnant Ignazo fos mut, ancour fos i abr a scaur.
And yet he could not take Marcuccio as his apprentice, for how was he to instruct a pupil in the art of bookbinding? But although Ignazo could not speak, he could write.

Un annað eð un jorn scaus i, cascun de sy method e sell'art descrint ; untal stemn d'ovegl por y pagrmen, untal eld de casner poll'encost.
For a year and a day he wrote, describing all his methods and arts, from the pedigree of sheep for the parchment, to the age of the oak tree for the ink.

Cossy l'educau Marcuccio, y production d'un livr detaglant oc stant jammel exact l'un seyon fait, for ig y facsimile vel nien aïr scaut afont.
In this way he taught Marcuccio, detailing the production of a book exactly like the one he had himself written, save that the copy would be utterly blank.

Sur y fougl dereðr, Ignazio scaus sy commant final : Et omnia hic scripta scribas illic—E tout ac scaut, scaureð vos afont.
Upon the last page, Ignazio wrote his final instruction: Et omnia hic scripta scribas illic—And all that is written here, you shall write therein.

Alor Marcuccio recevoy y livr, eð en studiau. E posc monð larc retornau i a Ignazio, livr jammel ne sell'embraç.
And thus Marcuccio received the book, and studied from it. And after many months did he return to Ignazio, twin books in his arms.

##

11m Octobr

por gra de /pɔr ˈgra de/ for the sake, benefit of, on behalf of

< late Old Boral 12C, unchanged in meaning. Development as a fixed expression continued until by 15C we see primarily por gra de mey over por my gra (for my sake). The word gra “need, benefit” does not retain those meanings in modern Boral (keeping only “extent, degree, importance”), and is itself probably a contamination of Latin gravis “heavy, serious” by grātus “pleasing, agreeable, beloved” (which gives modern grað “will, wont, way”).

    Ke oc farreð vos toð cas, façað oc por gra dy Segr.

    As you will act thus regardless, act in the name of the Lord.

    /ke ɔk faˈrɛθ vo tɔθ ˈkaz | faˈtsaθ ɔk por ˈgra di ˈsi.jr̩/

##

12m Octobr

demorar /ˌde.moˈrar/ [ˌde.mʊˈʀɑː] to demur, delay, put off, postpone

< 12C in early Middle Boral, taken from Church Latin dēmorāre “to detain, hold up, delay”, a regularisation of deponent Latin verb dēmoror “I detain, linger”, itself derived from mora “delay”. Used especially of evasive speech, with connotation of nefarious motive.

    Jo vey alcun raçon por nos demoreu.

    I see no reason we should delay.

    /ʒo ˈvi aˈgɪn raˈtsɔn pɔr no ˌde.moˈraw/
