37.2: seucq "footpath"

seucq /sawk/
- footpath, trail, a way set intentionally for people to walk along;
- trail, tracks, footsteps, those marks left by an animal or vehicle after it has passed by and which can be followed;
- legacy, aftereffects, impact, the consequences of a person's life and the ways in which they have changed the world;
- (in particular) descendants, progeny, one's children and their children etc. as opposed to one's forebears

37.3: svattour "scout"

svattour /svaˈtur/ [zvɐˈtʊː]
- scout, a person or group of people sent out to perform reconnaissance or otherwise bring in information (especially in a military context);
- investigator, private detective, an agent hired by a person for the purpose of evidence gathering;
- harbinger, failsafe, early warning, a person or thing which gives advance notice (especially of danger or other unwanted occurrences)

also svattar /svaˈtar/ [zvɐˈtɑː] to scout, investigate, act as an early warning

Etymology: agent noun and verb from Middle Boral svat, svet "reconnaisance, scouting" (now obsolete), from synonymous early Saxon sweat /zvɛːt/. The word was borrowed in the thirteenth century, during the various conflicts subsequent to the German Secession. Extension from military contexts is attested in the eighteenth century, with its use by the svattour pavar private detectives of Damvath.

Nos nolau hur dar for an svattour noscon confiabr.
/nɔz noˈlo hɪr dar fɔr an svaˈtur noˈxɔn kɔnˈfja.br̩/
[nɔz nʊˈlo hɪː ˈdɑː fɔː‿ʀan zvɐˈtʊː nʊˈxɔn kʊɱˈfja.bɐ]
1p not.fut-imp.1p hire give only to=indef PI 1p.ins trust-pot
We were only going to hire a PI we could trust.

37.4: fouceur "handsome"

fouceur /fuˈtsawr/ [fʊˈtsa.wɐ]
- handsome, pretty, having a pleasing appearance and especially (of a person) being physically attractive;
- charming, charismatic, exuding personal charm and inducing people around to like one;
- (archaic or affected) wily, sneaky, full of clever tricks making one difficult to keep up with or predict

Etymology: from Middle Boral, originally in the last sense as an attributive use of the (now-obsolete) noun fouceur "rascal, trickster". This reflects Old Boral fo(r)cevr "rogue, blackguard", a direct descendant of Latin furcifer "scoundrel, (derogatory) slave", literally "yoke-bearer". The shift in sense from "deceptive > wily > charming > handsome" is somewhat extreme, yet every stage (occurring over approximately two centuries from 1650 to 1850) is well-attested in the historical record.

Cain Celest e Marca un per fouceur.
/ken tseˈlɛst e marˈka ɪn pɛr fuˈtsawr/
[kɛn tsɪˈlɛst e mɐːˈka m ˈpɛː fʊˈtsa.wɐ]
fall-3p Celest and Marca indef pair pretty
Celeste and Marca make a handsome couple.

38.1: Scandal Abroad

excerpt in translation from an article in the 14th October 1950 edition of the Fiellas Dimenja (Sunday Sheets), a Marsellan weekly newspaper focusing primarily on recreation and entertainment. 

NOVEL ALLORS: SCANDAL! PRINÇ HASINIC ADMET 3⅊ MIL MURDON DEUT
NEWS AFIELD: SCANDAL! HASINICK PRINCE ADMITS 30⅊ MILLION OF DEBT

Prinç Peðer Tamaha, heir men connuð des y dynasty hasinic famous, a admis por y nonçamen trey mil murðon de pois deïr (oc dou mil myriad de tron surcontant) com sculd a colluy speculatour e tan a tesoir païsal tras y tarmagn des Mascic vars Ambrosia.
Prince Pether Tamaha, lesser-known son of the illustrious Hasinick monarchy, has admitted to the press that he owes thirty million poise (over twenty million trone) in debt to speculation companies and to national banks across the continent from Mashick to Ambrosia. 

Par surcresc, sy granpaðr y Rey a refusað le sauvar de decoxion, stant jainç a dað lon preluïscment.
Furthermore, his grandfather the King has declined to bail him out, in an unprecedented move.

Postulation jaçol es convencuð ig y joun prinç (oc ayent un jubilation opulent de nascenç trentem receut ny Davarn Heul fevruer nuverrem, ant may de cinq mil d'assistour) no's lon hiat sy redon despardent eð y scurtað dell'askouð parent confiant.
Longtime speculation has held that the young prince (who hosted a lavish thirtieth birthday celebration in the Davarn Heul this February, with over five thousand attendees) has been regularly running through his funds and relying on his family's coffers.

38.2: teir "to number"

teir /tir/ [tɪː]
- number, be, to consist of some number of people or things in a group;
- come to, cost, be worth some amount of money;
- be (at a distance of), be located, to exist at some specified distance from or height above a reference point;
- (obsolete except in certain idiomatic expressions) be had by, to be in the possession of somebody

Etymology: from Old Boral teir "to span, to cover (an amount of land), to stretch (a distance)", from Latin tegō "I cover up, I clothe". Extended to many contexts in which the object of a copular phrase is a quantity or amount of substance.

Y centuir de vossy fraðr tein dou lau dy castel.
/i tsɛnˈtajr de vɔstri ˈfraðr̩ tin du lo di kaˈstɛl/
[i tsɪnˈtajɐ de ˌvɔstʀɪ ˈfʀa.ðɐ tin du lo di kɐˈstɛw]
def army of 2p.gen def brother be.at-3p two league from-def castle
Your brother's armies are 4 miles from the castle.

38.3: quic “active”

quic /kwɪk/
- active, working, on, having the power of acting (especially, of moving or of functioning as a person or machine);
- in progress, ongoing, presently being undertaken;
- conscious, awake, up, (of a person) not asleep and especially being out of bed

Etymology: from Old Boral quic “alive, awake”, a borrowing from Old English cwic “living, live; intelligent, keen”. Formerly also used of plants for “thriving, growing well” which likely represents an intermediate meaning between its original sense and the more common modern usage.

    Hau, ty diac no’s quic!
    /ho | ti djak nɔz kwɪk/
    hey | 2s.gen mic neg=be.3s active
    Hey, your mic’s off!

38.4: hiat “pause”

hiat /hjat/ [çat, jat]*
- pause, lull, a period of reduced activity;
- gap, break, an interval in space or time which interrupts an otherwise-continuous object or process;
- (theatre, film) intermission, interval, the break between two parts of a drama;
- (music notation) rest, a symbol indicating that one’s instrument is not to be played

Etymology: sixteenth-century borrowing reflecting Norman hiat, Lombard hiato or another similar cognate, originally in the musical sense. These are taken directly from Latin hiātus “opening, gap, aperture, cleft”, a noun derivation from hiō “I yawn, gape, am open”.

    Nos benoçaum y hiat por douçur acatar.
    /nɔz ˌbe.noˈtsom i hjat pɔr duˈtsɪr ˌa.kaˈtar/
    [nɔz ˌbe.nʊˈtsom i çat pɔː dʊˈtsɪː‿ˌʀɐkˈtɑː]
    1p use-pst-1p def gap for dessert buy-inf
    We used the interval to get sweets.

*both pronounciations (and even the misspelling yat) are widespread in the modern period, though the latter is in some quarters proscribed.

##

38.5: Steeplepost

Steeplepost refers to any of a group of similar technologies (flag-lamp, barrick, longform, gyre, etc.) used for transmitting messages over long distances.

Development
The very earliest incarnations of the steeplemesh arose during the Democratic Wars of the mid-eighteenth century, but these tended to be single lines of temporary signal towers set up to span terrain that made it too costly to simply send a rider with a message. Moreover, these were set up only to transmit simple messages; for example, an hour to launch an attack.

These early wartime towers usually relied on lampfire and thus were reliable only at night, or else a collection of patterned flags, which were usable at day but required a shorter distance between watchtowers. The two-arm system, allowing up to nine separate states to be transmitted, was first tested in Thynen (a town in Willemy), where the church's weathervane was reportedly commandeered to send the first lines of the Pater Noster to the neighbouring town Bost. (Hence, probably, the name “steeplepost”.)

By 1820 Ambrosia had unveiled its Steeplepost Tapestry in Aiga d'Angoixa, which promised to allow the (very slow) transmission of images along the lines by communicating the brightness of each pip in an enormous grid, in the manner of a cross-stitch. It was on the Tapestry that the infamous Lies of 1824 were first displayed.

The very first cross-sea steeplepost lines were established around the same time, with air-steeples in the Rustigh Strait connecting Borland to Willemy during the 1830s. This link would last only until 1854, however, when it was replaced with a barrick line.

The middle of the nineteenth century saw the flag-lamp system gradually superseded by barrick lines generally. Uptake was uneven owing to the twin constraints of geography and vested interests; for example, Mendevan powers tended to embrace the new technology more enthusiastically than their similarly-situated Vetomundine counterparts.

The new lines made partially-automated transmission much easier to develop. A prototype wired tachygraph, the Vilmanas Teleclavia, first succesfully sent a message via the steeplemesh in 1859.

Encoding
Steeplescripts, or methods by which a message is translated into a transmissible form, have many forerunners in secret codes used for spycraft and warfare. For example, Markland under King Andrew III during the Wars of Fealty employed "Thieves' Script" to send secret messages, converting each letter or common word into a series of three symbols.

One early line in Andalus (from Cordova to Málaga, usually given as the first line connecting two major cities, and essentially just formalising the signal system that had existed for the duration of their conflict with Morrack) used a variant of the ancient Polybius square adapted for Arabic script.

The first modern steeplescript was developed in Cracow by engineer Sigmund Adamich and his son Andrei as part of the royal initiative to connect Cracow to Bitom, using a set of four symbols, traditionally referred to as "dot, dash, bar and hook".

Cultural Detaxion
The spread of the steeplemesh reduced overland communication times extremely rapidly (by the end of the nineteenth century some places boasted thrice-daily post delivery, not to mentioned the nascent wired tachygraphs), and undersea barrick links would further connect the world.

Steeplemesh may have contributed to the decline of the voidtale fashion, demystifying formerly-unknowable distant lands and weakening the cultural narrative of the pioneering documentarian explorer.

39.1: The Pinprick Eden

excerpt from The Pinprick Eden, a work of parachthon romance released in 1911 Zangathy by Mica Lus, the first trevold from that Mendevan polity to be published in translation across the Vetomund.

Forn pog may a deg meis sceut des l'annihilaçon dy mont, e caye je sy nascenç.
It had been just over ten months since the end of the world, and it was her birthday. 

Kimmela au l'un je nascenç jubilað abord dy kenonaut deja, durant y gyr por mantien.
Kimmela had celebrated one birthday on board the voidsailer already, during the maintenance gyre. 

L'ig au un jorn teut con allagrtað e spien, e lor un sorty souvr no'r parið tesqual a bas a respirar.
That had been a day of happiness and hope, and throwing a party had seemed as natural as breathing. 

L'oc annað i poðe alcun jubilaçon vray dijarr lon jant.
This year she couldn't stomach any real celebration. 

Kimmela gasau pall'oscbou veðr vars y vogt semnað de stel atras.
Kimmela stared out of the viewport at the star-strewn void.

L'oc sta bel, de façon freit e mortal, ant stel noc lougent yon parmig splendisce y Sol ja briglandessem for com picq.
It was beautiful, in a cold and deadly way, with untwinkling stars among which already the Sun shone only slightly brighter. 

Se poðe y Tar foscað de fum fos visibr pall'appragl ny kenonaut, ma i douta.
The smoke-blackened Earth might yet be visible with the voidsailer's equipment, though she doubted it.

39.2: sovragl "belt"

sovragl /soˈvrɛjl/ [sʊˈvʀɛjʊ]
- belt, girdle, a band worn around the waist to hold clothing (usually pants) to one's body;
- sash, cummerbund, a decorative band of cloth worn across the body;

Etymology: direct descendant from Latin subligāculum "loincloth, kilt" exhibiting l-r dissimilation (attested from as early as c8 in Old Boral sovreiaȝle "waistband, overskirt") likely reinforced by the etymologically-unrelated prefix sovr- "over, above". Synchronically analysable as sovrar "pass, go over" + -agl, an unproductive nominal suffix producing words for tools or other instruments.

Y sovragl seyon me dað er adornað par fylau.
/i soˈvrɛjl siˈjɔn me daθ ɛr ˌa.dɔrˈnaθ par fiˈlo/
[i sʊˈvʀɛjʊ ˌsjɔm.mɪˈdah ɪˌʀa.dʊːˈnah pɑː fɪˈlo]
def belt 3s.ins 1s.obl give-p.pst cop.imp decorate-p.pst by crow
The belt she gave me was decorated with crows.

39.3: laur mettr coll'un man "take matters into one's own hands"

laur mettr coll'un man /lor ˈmɛtr̩ kɔˈlɪn man/ [loː ˈmɛ.tɐ kʊˈlɪmˌman]
- take matters into one's own hands, to deal with a problem alone especially if due to others responsible having failed to tackle it;
- shoulder responsibility, to accept that one is responsible for something bad or difficult;
- (more generally) get to work, to start doing a (usually lengthy or otherwise-challenging) job;
- (jocular or self-effacing) masturbate, to stimulate oneself with the hands

Etymology: Idiom in use since the Middle Boral period, literally "to put work with the one hand". It is an extension of preexisting laur mettr "to tackle an issue, to take a job", from now-rare laur "work" < Latin labor (or a deverbal from laurar "to work") and mettr "to put" < Latin mittō "I send". In the last sense, first attested in writing in 1883 (possibly; more certain usages by the early c20), via a lewd reinterpretation of the literal sense of the idiom.

Ða vos nouð l'occeir jo met laur coll'un man!
/ða vɔz nuθ lɔkˈsir ʒo mɛt lor koˈlɪn man/
/ða vʊzˈnuh lʊkˈsɪː ʝo mɛt loː kʊˈlɪmˌman/
if 2p won't-2p 3s.acc=kill.inf 1s put work with.def=one hand
If you won't kill him then I'll do it myself!

39.4: ençar voug "be completely wrong"

ençar voug /ɛnˈtsar vuj/ [ɪnˈtsɑː vuj]
- be completely wrong, to miscalculate or misjudge entirely so that one's answer or action does not resemble the correct one in any respect;
- do something incorrectly, to perform an action (especially to operate a machine or to attempt an artistic endeavour) with absolutely nothing approaching expertise or skill;
- be utterly useless at, to have no talent whatsoever for a particular skill

Etymology: Idiom attested from the sixteenth century, literally meaning "to start incorrect". The verb ençar "to begin, start" is a direct descendant of Latin initiō "I begin, originate", while the adjective voug "wrong, mistaken, incorrect" is a medieval borrowing from Old English wōh "wrong, crooked, bent" (giving modern Merch ough /uːf/ "bad").

Il ençan y dou voug cas toriot luïr.
/ɪl ɛnˈtsan i du vuj kaz ˌtoriˈjɔt laˈjɪr/
[ˌi.lɪnˈtsan i du vuj kaz ˌtʊˈʀjɔt læˈʝɪː]
3p begin-ipf.3p def two home.of torriot play.inf
They're both useless at playing torriot.

##

39.5: Andalus

Andalus is a polity in the south of the Spanish peninsula. The languages of Morrove Arabic and Mostara Spanish are both widely spoken in the region.

History
Ninth-century Andalus saw the flowering of theoretic advancements; in particular, glassmaking techniques accelerated rapidly due to a cut-off of supply from the east, leading to the prodigious export of so-called "jackdaw glass".

The Brethin religious order spread into the Christian-majority areas of Andalus from the north during the eleventh and twelfth centuries. Around this time Andalus lost significant territory in the north and east to Christian polities, such as the newly-established Kingdom of Barcelon.

In the fifteenth century, while its neighbour Vascony was ascendant, Andalus was beset by struggles. Controlled from across the straits by Morrack, its issues included two successive succesion crises as well as the 1457 Lisbon Massacre.

Vascony was forced to cede Portingale, its economic heart, to Andalus after a series of military successes in the Romantic Wars of the mid-seventeenth century.

Andalus was embroiled in conflict with Morrack (as its neighbour attempted a reconquest) for a prolonged period in the eighteenth century; some but not all of the involved skirmishes are traditionally grouped with the concurrent Democratic Wars unfolding globally. A signalling line from Cordova to Málaga set-up at this time would develop into the world's first steeplepost connection between two major cities.

People
Abdul Raman IV (fl. 1188), ruler of the Admiralty of Cordova under the Single Caliphate
Joan Bensaíd (fl. 1951), author of the 1951 scholastic quire 'The Communication Toolset' (El Herramente de Communicazón)
Jorala (fl. c18-19), landscape artist born in Cazris whose later work was influenced by the voidtale craze
Judeta Barracin (fl. 1919), author who helped pioneer the genre of social comedy with her work 'Flaxen Hearts'
Tal of Murcia (fl. 1211), medieval scholar who in 1211 wrote 'On Unknown Areas Scribed by Arcs'

40.1: Vikings in Northern France

excerpt in translation from reference quire On the Dane Supremacy in Kernow [Brittany] and the Creation of Normandy, written by deixist historian Professor Jockin Abiscander.

Y premendessem sta l'aðoinç de commovenç viking lonc y rimmot.
Most pressing was the inexorable rise in Viking activity along the coast. 

Gazou ag banc dy Sein e l'Orn ern inceut ci meis paravant, ma dagormay il spanoirn ag vest; y monastir a Landvennick meðes se cof incendiað a cainç l'an 888 N. 
Raids along the Seine and the Orne had begun in earnest some decades prior, but now spread west; even the monastery at Landvennick was burned to the ground in 888 N. 

Necun no'rn y commovenç dy dannesc vecinað com piglment; ag dou cost dy Canal caf batman benoçaurn l'instabiltað politic (oc a digr y sfondranç Wessaxon ag norð eð y ci querel lombard ag souð) por eðegl concarr e fragossau instançar.
Nor were the Danes' activities confined to looting; on both sides of the Channel war leaders took advantage of political instability (the collapse of Wessex in the north and the Lombard disputes in the south) to conquer territory and settle. 

Scey evidenç ig gent dannesc reseyen doutr meðes y flou Vir, oc stant part lonc y tarm fransc e domnon com l'er traitað nell'Accord Catumagin dy siecr ogt,
There is evidence of such Danish settlement even past the Vire river, part of the Franco-Dumnonian border as agreed in the eighth-century Catumagin Accords, 

e portan posc y Fransc concedoirn solemn l'oc feu ny siecr deg e cossy corporalisaurn Normandy, y Vir remaneu y tarm.
although when this fiefdom was officially ceded by the Franks in the tenth century to form Normandy, the Vire remained the border.

##

40.2: batman "vigilante"

batman /batˈman/
- vigilante, one who acts outside the law to right a perceived wrong (often to avenge a murder or similar act of violence);
- mercenary, hitman, one who enacts violence (especially assassinations) for hire;
- warfarer, warrior, combatant, one engaged in warfare as a member of a band of soldiers

Etymology: seventeenth-century clipping of earlier abatman "combatant, mercenary", which descends from Old Boral abat manc/ç "mercenary (band), hired soldier", literally "war-seller". The first element abat "war" is a deverbal noun from abatr "fight, make war" (modern abattr), while the second manc/ç "seller, stall, booth" is of unclear origin.

The status of the final consonant in manc/ç (since lost) is disputed. If palatalised /mants/, the word is thought to reflect Insular Latin manentia "shop, household, inn", nominal derivative of maneō "I stay, remain, spend the night" (compare fenç "split, break" from Latin findentia < findō "I cleave, split"). The alternative theory that it descends from Latin merx "goods, wares" (modern març) is semantically tempting but phonetically implausible.

If instead the word is unpalatalised /mank/, it is generally agreed that it reflects Latin mangō "dealer, seller (of slaves)", either directly from the Latin—although one would expect to see also *mangon < mangōnem—or via the Old English descendant mangian "to trade, traffic in". In either case, the final consonant does not appear anywhere after the eleventh century, perhaps due to influence from the English suffix -man "person, man".

Se poðe noc l'eç rumour d'un batman corroular.
/se poˈðe nɔk lɛts riˈmur dɪn batˈman ˌko.ruˈlar/
[se pʊˈð3 nɔ lɛs ʀɪˈmʊː dɪm bɐtˈman ˌko.ʀʊˈlɑː]
rfl can-ipf neg def-p.px rumour of-indef vigilante verify-inf
The rumours of a vigilante were unsubstantiable.

40.3: oscbou "porthole"

oscbou /oxˈbu/
- porthole, gunport, a window set into the hull of a ship for cannons to fire through (or in modern use simply for the view);
- hatch, an (often internal) opening in a wall for people to pass things such as prepared food through

Etymology: Middle Boral borrowing from contemporary Vascon ox (de) buy /ɔʃ de bwi/ "gunport", literally "ox's eye". The word ox "eye" descends from Latin oculus and is cognate with Boral ogl /ɔjl/, while the word buy "ox" was adapted to the Boral bou "ox", both from Latin bōs, bovem "cow".

    Pront jo vis pall'oscbou my sour cocinant.
    /prɔnt ʒo vɪz ˌpa.lɔxˈbu mi sur ˌko.tsiˈnant/
    [pʀɔn ʝʊ ˈvɪz ˌpa.lʊxˈbu mi ˈsʊː ˌko.tsɪˈnant]
    immediate 1s see.pst by-def=porthole 1s.gen sister cook-p.prs
    I immediately saw my sister cooking through the hatch.

40.4: nell'eutað "trendy"

nell'eutað /ˌnɛ.lawˈtaθ/ [ˌnɛ.lɐwˈtah]
- fashionable, trendy, à la mode, in, up to date with the latest fashions and allowing one to display having good taste, a refined aesthetic sense or simply ample wealth

Etymology: adpositional phrase literally meaning "in the current fashion", attested since the late eighteenth century originally among the aristocratic melle of Borland's major cities. The noun eutað "mode, fashion, vibe, zeitgeist, style" is a nominal derivation from the verb eir "to go" (compare the past participle eut "gone"), which descends directly from Latin eō "I go".

Y cambr ayen pieðry nuaç nell'eutað.
/i ˈkam.br̩ ɛˈjɛn pjɛðˈri njats ˌnɛ.lawˈtaθ/
[i ˈkam.bʀ‿ɪˈʝɛm pjɪˈʀi njas ˌnɛ.lɐwˈtah]
def bedroom have-ipf-3p stonework nude in-def-mode
The bedrooms had fashionable exposed stonework.

##

40.5: Albion

Albion is the largest of the Northwestern Isles, situated directly north of Gaul. To its west and east lie Ireland and Borland, respectively.

History
Germanic migration from the continent into Albion took place through the fifth and sixth centuries, leading to the establishment of Markland, Kent, Wessex, Anglia, Northumber and several smaller and short-lasting kingdoms.

The westward encroachment of Saxons drove a emigration of Kelts from (what would become) Devon to Kernow, and for the period between the Battle of Gaulford (656) and Vigo the Magnificent's reconquest the entire peninsula was under the sole authority of Wessex.

The original calling of the Brethin religious order, founded in the eighth century, was to chronicle the Christianisation of Albion and Ireland.

Vikings raids began in Albion with the destruction of Halgrive in 824, although news of Dane incursions would have travelled west from Borland for some years by that point. While Northumber would fall completely to Dane rule, neighbouring Markland withstood (due perhaps to a fortunate lull in its perennial conflict with the Welsh kingdoms) even as much of its eastern territory was settled by the Danes.

The Guithle kingdom of Scotland was established in the ninth century with the help of Harald the Blue of Sodrick, displacing or merging with the existing Pict culture and language.

Sodrick lost much of its territory to the kingdom of Dunclothe in the tenth century, as it had been weakened by extended vikings to the east and the short-term decline in the Dane Supremacy.

By the turn of the second millennium, the south of the island is dominated by an expanded Kent (having recently subdued the remains of Wessex) below Markland and a now-unified Kingdom of Wales. To the north lie the confederate kingdoms of the Danes and then a Scotland even now influenced by Norse and English peoples.

Much of southern Albion was conquered in the eleventh century by Normandy (with the aid of Devon in the form of the Kernovan Conjuring), consolidating the island bar Wales as far north as Edinbrough into what would become the First Drengot Empire.

The kingdom of Wales began to expand in the thirteenth century, conquering Devon after a long campaign. Tensions with Markland remained high (as they had done for almost a millennium), with the reignition of the Mallor Wars and the sack of Car Vantel/Rexam in 1301.

The late fifteenth century saw much of Albion (and some of its neighbours) embroiled in the Wars of Fealty, which lasted for forty-six years. While other polities in Europe sought to expand their trade meshes (either westward following the Novomundine Landfall or exploiting new routes to Asia), the majority of the wealth and armies of Albion was dedicated to war.

The polities of Albion were still recoving from the Wars of Fealty in 1519 and thus were extremely vulnerable to the Second Great Dying.

Albion saw many changes in the aftermath of the Democratic Wars of the eighteenth century. Long contested between Markland and Kent, the city of London found itself newly independent for one final, lasting time.

The Long Peace around the turn of the nineteenth century saw the Deviance movement take root across Albion, initially via the mesh of Promethean clubs that had arisen over the preceding decades. The movement flourished perhaps due to Albion's many religious minorities and the strong association of the Church with local authority.

Polities

41.1: A Baptism of Fire

excerpt in translation from A Baptism of Fire: Christianity and the Graven, written by Agata Naziunas and published in 1988 by Leidéiai Givatés.

Ant captanç particuler scey y ducað carniol, oc cos remarcabr y citað abondant de Veron gournant, tan eð eiðel uvrautr austessem.
Of particular interest is the duchy of Crain, which importantly controlled the prosperous city of Verona, as well as fertile lands further east.

Ig i declarau sy promotion dy Papacy Roman er plausibr nastiðessem des faibiltað a des farvour religious vray, ma toð cas final l'aye un eðegl parfait por contriboir ag Batesm dy Norð.
Their declaration in support of the Roman Papacy was likely more pragmatic than out of true religious fervour, but in any case they were perfectly positioned to contribute to the Baptism of the North.

Degnant ig l'Ordr de Sagnt Hemma all'Aug Calm (y Convey Australier) fosn y Batesm condugnt con soutien moneðer de Taxon a Hongary par dezein plusour, sou contingent dy Secession German denoy y Batesm un accommission prement.
Though the Order of Saint Hemma of Still Water (the Convoy Australier) had been leading the Baptism with monetary backing from Taxon of Hungary for several decades, it is in the context of the German Secession that the Baptism became an urgent project.

Con Hermene II stant un novel pap totalistessem, sceye hougr ig Augsbourg sceus heresy respandr rapidessem a vel Rom y Norð parvenir.
Along with a new, more totalist Pope in Hermeneus II, it was feared that Augsburg might spread heresy faster than Rome could reach the North.

41.2: batesm "baptism"

batesm /baˈtɛ.zm̩/ [bɐˈtɛ.zɐm]
- baptism, christening, the Christian rite in which a person (usually a child) is received into the church and given a name;
- (more generally) naming, the act of giving a person or thing a name;
- induction, hazing, any ceremony whose purpose is to introduce new members to some association, especially if the process if unpleasant or even dangerous

Etymology: via Old Boral batesme "baptism, christening" and synonymous Late Latin baptisma from Ancient Greek βάπτισμα (báptisma, "dipping in water, baptism"). Used outside of a Christian context from as early as the late thirteenth century; in the last sense it arises in the student culture of Vithor in the eighteenth century.

Scerraun doç batesm ac fait l'oc jorn.
/xɛˈron dɔts baˈtɛ.zm̩ ak fet lɔk ʒɔrn/
[çɪˈʀon dɔs bɐˈtɛ.zɐm ak ˈfet lʊˈʝɔːn]
there.be-fut.3p twelve baptism here do-p.pst def-s.px day
Twelve baptisms will be performed here today.

41.3: orn "order; rowan"

orn /ɔrn/ [ɔːn]
1.
- order, ordering, arrangement, programme, a particular sequence or way of setting out a collect of people, objects or events;
- order, group, troop, band, a number of people in a formal arrangement towards the furthering of some agenda (in particular, playing music or purveying violence or similar aid);
- command, captaincy, power, the position of having authority to require people to do something;
- recipe, program, instructions, algorithm, a list of steps itemising the proper method for achieving some task

Etymology: either from a native Old Boral orne, ordne, "ordering, arrangement" or borrowed from contemporaneous Old French orne, ordre, both reflecting (as a direct descendant or an early semi-learned loan) Latin ōrdō, ōrdinem "arrangement, rank, group, troop, rite". Extended senses almost definitely adapted directly from the Latin reflex in the Middle Boral period (cf. short-lived later borrowing ordin).

Nos luïsceu primer nell'orn.
/nɔz ˌla.jiˈxaw priˈmɛr nɛˈlɔrn/
[nɔz ˌla.ʝɪˈxaw pʀɪˈmɛː nɪˈlɔːn]
1p play-1p first in-def=order
We're first on in the programme.

2.
- mountain ash, rowan, any of several trees in the genus Sorbus, found across Europe and Mendeva;
- (proscribed) ash, tree of the genus Fraxinus (prescriptively, frasn);
- javelin, lance, a light spear thrown with the hand and used as a weapon

Etymology: Direct descendant of Latin ornus "mountain ash, rowan" via the synonymous orne in Old Boral. In the last meaning, a conscious revival of an Old Boral usage which had vanished for centuries.

L'ivan asseye sur y ranscel dell'orn.
/liˈvan aˈsje sɪr i ranˈxɛl dɛˈlɔrn/
[lɪˈvan ɐˈsje sɪː‿ʀi ʀɑnˈçɛw dɪˈlɔːn]
def=child sit-ipf on def branch of-def=ash
The child was sat on the rowan's branch.

##

41.4: soçavau "aside"

soçavau /ˌso.tsaˈvo/ [ˌso.tsɐˈvo]
- aside, sidenote, comment, remark, an incidental statement made quietly or in such a way that most people cannot hear it;
- (theatre, film) nondiegetic dialogue, dialogue said by characters or a narrator directly to the audience, so that the (other) characters cannot hear it;
- afterthought, a post-hoc idea or comment that only occurs after the time when it might have been a useful contribution

Etymology: eighteenth-century borrowing from Vascon soza-vau "aside, commentary, lit. under-voice", originally in the context of theatrical performance. The preposition soza "under, beneath" descends from Latin adverb subta, with influence from the form soz < subtus; the noun vau "voice" is an alteration of earlier vou, from the synonymous Latin vōcem.

Y scuir dau un soçavau losc ne parmanent a pie.
/i xajr do ɪn ˌso.tsaˈvo lɔx ne ˌpar.maˈnɛnt a pje/
[i ˈxa.jɐ do ɪn ˌso.tsɐˈvo lɔx ne ˌpɑː.mɐˈnɛnt a pje]
def boy give-pst indef aside rude in keep-p.prs at foot
The boy muttered a rude remark and kept walking.

##

41.5: Gurjat

Gurjat is a polity on the western coast of India.

History
The medieval period saw a flourishing of mathematics across India, and Gurjat was no exception. For instance, the now-familiar angle addition identities for vatre and arrhumb [sine and cosine] were first noted by the mathematicians of the city of Ujén.

Gurjat was one of the stopping points for the British ship the Phœbos under Captain mac Kellot during its famed voyage in the early sixteenth century. The ship spent several months at port there in 1512, after having circumnavigated Africa and before continuing on to Madray [Madurai] and thence to the Great Borunesk Meeting of 1516.

Gurjat enjoyed a significant trade empire in the seventeenth century, spanning from African ports like Ungotia [Zanzibar] and even Vascon-controlled Sant Adrian [Bioko] in the west to Cathay (and eventually New Leudong) in the east. Gurjat traders made up a good fraction of those merchants expelled from Moscat in 1652, several months before the fall of the Ibadine Imamate to Hadramot forces.

People
- Manesh Camdar (fl. 1813), life theorist whose research on fecundation in marine sponges provided the first proof that it comprises the union of sperm and egg cases

42.1: Flight of the Bluejay

excerpt in translation from Flight of the Bluejay (in Borlish Vol dy Gay Azur), a trevold written by Carl Kajoçman and originally released serially from 1931 to 1935.

Michæl flaðrau l'immoubr yert vars y routel dessou, casc broit minuscr oyent com menaç.
Michael clambered down the building to the alley below, conscious of every tiny noise.

I save lon alcot vole Sara hour passar pre smarcr; sell'attent surcayen tor veint minut teir, e posc y fin parvenent den sy deit ern gelað e l'aye se convencuð ig y costojan ayent y rout follað trottant sta a pognt de retornar an moment calscon por l'accusar d'emboscment a flannar.
He had no idea how long it might take Sara to emerge; in the event it was about twenty minutes, by the end of which his fingers were icy and he was convinced that the policeman who had strolled along the street would be back at any moment to accuse him of lurking with intent.

Ma cos final i sta yent, accappelað e fassað de rob, con y valigs.
But at last she was there, in hat and coat, with the suitcase.

I l'oncau par pas plusour fin a Michæl smargoy deull'ombr e le prenoy de sy man.
She lugged it a few paces until he slid out of the shadows and took it from her hand.

42.2: lon-lembic "teetotaller"

lon-lembic /ˌlɔn.lɛmˈbɪk/
- teetotaller, non-drinker, one who abstains from drinking any alcoholic beverages;
- alcohol-free drink, a beverage which has been altered so as not to contain any alcohol

Etymology: first attested 1902 as a univerbation of phrase lon lembic "without alcohol", probably adapted from slightly earlier French and Dutch compounds. The word lon "without" reflects Latin adverb longē "far away". The noun lembic "ethanol; (more broadly) alcoholic drink" descends from Scholastic Latin lembīcum "alembic, still; (later) distilled spirits", which is borrowed via Arabic from Greek ἄμβῑξ (ámbīx) "cup with a spout; alembic".

Cascif eð vos un lon-lembic convoccað ac?
/kaˈxɪf ɛθ vɔz ɪn ˌlɔn.lɛmˈbɪk ˌkɔn.vɔˈkaθ ak/
[kɐˈçɪf ɛ vɔz ɪn ˌlɔn.lɪmˈbɪk ˌkɔɱ.vʊˈkah ak]
Why have.2p 2p indef teetotaller invite-p.pst here
Why did you invite a teetotaller here?

42.3: murðon "ten thousand"

murðon /mɪrˈðɔn/
- myriad, the number ten thousand;
- countless, a very great number

Etymology: from Old Boral murð, mirð "countless, very many; ten thousand" with the addition of then-productive augmentative suffix -on (from Latin nominal derivational suffix -ō, -ōnem). In turn this word is a semi-learned form via Late Latin mȳrias, mȳriadem from Ancient Greek μῡρῐᾰ́ς (mūriás) "ten thousand, countless".

The forms with <u> (reflecting [ʏ]) instead of expected <i> is unlikely to be any remnant of Hellenising Latin <y> /y/ (which was never common as far afield as Borland). More plausible is a sporadic labialising effect from the preceding /m/, also seen in words like mug < Latin mīca "crumb".

In the Old Boral period it is most often used indeterminately for any large quantity; its more specific sense returns to common use (initially in merchant accounts) in the thirteenth century.

Y gent ne Safford Outr tein 440 murðon.
/i ʒɛnt ne saˈfɔrd utr̩ tin katr̩ kaˈrɛnt mirˈðɔn/
[i ʝɛn ne sɐˈfɔːd ˈu.tɐ tin ˌkat.kɐˌʀɛm.mɪːˈðɔn]
There are 4.4 million people in Utter Safford.

42.4: nervous "confident"

nervous /nɛrˈvuz/
- confident, assured, optimistic, having confidence in one's ability to accomplish something;
- bold, fearless, daring, showing a willingness to take risks or acting without reservation;
- vigorous, robust, energetic, being healthy and strong and characterised by lively activity;
- (dated or humorous, of meat) sinewy, stringy containing tough fibres and thus being difficult to eat

Etymology: from Middle Boral nervous "sinewy; vigorous", borrowed from synonymous Latin nervōsus along with noun nerf < Latin nervus "nerve, sinew; vigour". The extension in meaning from "vigorous" to "bold" and then to "confident" had taken place by the start of the nineteenth century.

Son il nervous d'issaur ny cors?
/sɔn ɪl nɛrˈvuz diˈsor ni kɔrz/
[sʊˈni nɛːˈvuz dɪˈsoː ni ˈkɔːz]
be.3p 3p confident of-great.success in-def contest
Are they sure they'll win the contest?

42.5: Two Pens

collected notes on a couple of the many famous people from across the history of this alternate world.

Ezio Carvallo (fl. 1860) was a Portingale author most remembered for his contributions to the development of the genre of masquira romance.

Works
Tejan de Masquira ou Jalico (In Either a Mask or a Suit), a 1860 work which would be the first in a twelve-strong series of tales following the vigilante thief Matthias o Grallon.
The book was released in Kentish in 1865 as 'We Arive in Unwemmed [Immaculate] Clothes', translated by Christopher Wood; Anscon Polgat translated the book into Boral under the title 'Cuscon Reðr Cognit' (Whoever [We Are] Behind [Our] Disguises)

--

Catrin of Kernow (d. 1233) was an influential figure in Tetrarchic Borland.

Family
Catrin of Kernow was the elder sister of King Alan VI of Greater Devon, who orchestrated the Realignment of Devon in 1225. Their uncle was Damian the Wise, the first (Roman) Pope to be elected from among the Brethin religious order.

Legacy
In 1292 the chronicle 'Y Við a Catrin de Cornou' (The Life of Catrin of Kernow) was written, detailing her early life, marriage into Borlish noblility and eventual assassination in 1233. The chronicle is particularly important for being the first longform work written in Borlish (as opposed to Latin) about a lay-person.

43.1: Mysarnos

excerpt in translation from 1943 history book The Mysarnos Problem: the Enigma of an Inconvenient Codex, written by classicist Theodora Riphæna.

Ma neðan carrug mettr avant naumagl, retorneu ag citað yon a nossy racont sy commet.
But lest we get ahead of ourselves, let us return to the city where our saga begins.

Y citað a Mysarnos es l'ançan cafloy ny Principaltað de Mystra, un stat mordether stant vassal sou Rom des y siecr onç fin a sy dissolution com issent parmy ci dy Rix Romannesc dy siecr settoç.
The city of Mysarnos is the former capital of the Principality of Mystra, a Roman mordether vassal state from the eleventh century until its dissolution as a result of the Romantic Wars in the seventeenth.

L'oc nom es tan denuð cos janual l'ig benoçað por y bourg grec vecin ja sceint (stant tardessem corporalisað cos solemn com un muncef de Mysarnos) connuð nell'asc antic com Pylos.
The name has retrospectively also been applied to the nearby preexisting Greek town (which was later officially incorporated as a municipality of Mysarnos) known in antiquity as Pylos.

A sy sommet ny siecr seç sta Mysarnos un mojol por y commouð revitalist, ant un pouvlanç teint pres trey murðon.
At its height in the sixteenth century Mysarnos was a hub for the Revitalist movement, with a population of nearly thirty thousand.

43.2: janualtað "hindsight"

janualtað /ˌʒa.njalˈtaθ/ [ˌʝa.njɐwˈtah]
- hindsight, retrospection, an understanding of the significance and nature of events after they have occurred;
- perspective, unblinkeredness, the ability to see a situation from a sufficiently uninvolved position that one can understand it without distraction or bias

Etymology: Middle Boral borrowing alongside adjective janual "retrospective, backward-looking" from Scholastic Latin iānuālitās "hindsight", both derivatives of iānua "doorway, entrance" or Iānus "Janus, two-headed god of transitional spaces".

Me valois noc y fabr assistr con my maðr.

43.3: mordeth "expedition"

mordeth /mɔrˈdɛθ/
- expedition, an often-military undertaking involving travel either into enemy territory or some analogous target;
- raid, foray, incursion, a short-term and violent move into a region to ransack it for spoils or to inflict damage;
- jaunt, adventure, a short excursion for diversion or pleasure especially involving some (possibly planned) excitement;
- (historical) crusade, conquest, any of the military expeditions undertaken in the medieval Middlesea under varying degrees of Papal authority

Etymology: early Middle Boral borrowing from contemporary Welsh mordeith "sea voyage, raid, conquest by sea", corresponding to a compound of modern moωr "sea" and teith "journey, trip". Originally used in particular for the various wars of conquest in the Middlesea conducted at a significant distance during the eleventh to thirteenth centuries. While some of these had ostensible religious authority motivating them, many (especially further from the Masreck [Levant]) were more transparently opportunistic.

Il feirn mordeth amont por y poið dy Nil trovar.
/ɪl firn mɔrˈdɛθ aˈmɔnt pɔr i pɔjθ di nɪl troˈvar/
[ɪw fɪːn mʊːˈdɛθ ɐˈmɔnt pɔː‿ʀi pɔjθ di ˈnɪw tʀʊˈvɑː]
3p do-pst.3p foray upstream for def well of-def Nile find-inf
They went on an expedition to find the source of the Nile.

43.4: toxen "alarm"

toxen /tɔkˈsɛn/ [tʊgˈzɛn]
- alarm, klaxon, a sound intended to give notice of approaching danger or an upcoming deadline;
- (more genereally) warning, alert, signal, any means of informing someone of a new (especially a problematic) development

Etymology: early Middle Boral borrowing from Old French tocsin, tocseing etc. "alarm, ringing of a bell" (originally in a military context), itself from Old Vascon toca-segn "alarm", literally "strikes (a) bell". These reflect respectively Vulgar Latin toccāre "to touch" and Latin signum "signal, mark".

Da mey toxen pront la Yam Olau veir.
/da mi tɔkˈsɛn prɔnt la jam oˈlo vir/
[da mi tʊgˈzɛn pʀʊnˈla ˌʝam ʊˈlo vɪː]
give 1s.dsj alarm immediately there uncle Olau see-inf
Alert me as soon as you see Uncle Ollie.

##

43.5: Barcelon

Barcelon is a Middlesea polity in the east of the Spanish peninsula.

History
In its early existence from the ninth to the thirteenth century, the county of Barcelon (soon to be the duchy and indeed from 1067 the kingdom) was ruled by the House of Barcelon. It had perennial skirmishes with Tolose to the north, so that even when Tolose became a vassal state to the First Drengot Empire in the eleventh century, it maintained a standing army for protection against Barcelon.

By the late twelfth century, the Kingdom of Barcelon controlled significantly more territory at the expense of Andalus, including the population centres of Saragossa, Valencia and (briefly) Toledo.

Barcelon conquered the region of Tolose from Ascendant Vascony in the first decade of the sixteenth century, thereby (along with territorial gains by Burgundy) depriving it entirely of its Middlesea coastline. In the same period, the War for the Barcelon Succession took place, although notably it only lasted for four days.

The early sixteenth century also saw Barcelon rattle sabres with the newly independent Provence, involving piratical raids on Provincial cities (and especially Marsella) supported financially by Barcelon. Part of the resolution involved the region of Narbona having double obligations to King James III of Barcelon and to Lord Amigòt in Provence.

The longest-reigning monarch of the Kingdom of Barcelon is James VI (Jaume VI), who ruled into the eighteenth century for 58 years and after whom is named the famous jaumetia, a whitefish stew.

People
Monarchs
Martha II (Marta II, crowned 1186)
James III (Jaume III, fl. 1517)
James V (Jaume V, fl. 1670), who spent much of his childhood in a Cordin wardship in Borland
James VI (Jaume VI, reigned 1691–1749), longest-reigning monarch in the history of the Kingdom of Barcelon
Other
Raymond al Mustafa (fl. 1750), mathematician who worked with Rachel Desslut on the nascent field of methodics while he was under the patronage of the Duke of Aragon

44.1: Borrowings from Borlish

excerpt in translation from Daughters of the Sea: The Northwestern Isles, written in 1956 by Merch author Challow Huddresfell.

Nossy vecin all'aust n'aun jamay y pinnacr mont respanent acavar dy gent Breðon cas asteller e foyer.
Our neighbours to the east have never matched the globe-spanning workshop and household vanguard of the British.

Nentamen, ða meðes par proximtað soul, y lengaç anglesc son cos parmanent vanagl borallesc adaptant de jaçol com y Mitað-Asc.
Nonetheless, if only by virtue of proximity, the English languages have been adapting Borlish terms even from the medieval period.

Com bustr, degnant ig nos ligau y ci siecr tost nell'Istr posc-roman con migration des Albion vars Istr Boral (cos particuler, par issent dy reduction markesc d'Anglia Auster ny siecr nouf),
For example, while we associate the early centuries of the post-Roman Isles with migration from Albion into Borland (in particular, after the Merch subjugation of East Anglia in the ninth century),

eç parol com danny "un treublant, applattiscent", bather "baðr con fil" e parren "sojornour, un alandað, corrovað" entraurn Veðr Anglesc des Veðr Boral ny siecr deg soul (lonc lour y preu yenç ne chronic de monastir).
words like danny "a nuisance, an irritating person", bather "stringed musical intrument" and parren "traveller, newcomer, novice" enter Old English from Old Borlish in the tenth century alone (according to their first attestations in monastic chronicles).

44.2: jou follant "on the fence"

jou follant /ʒu fɔˈlant/ [ʝu fʊˈlan(t)]
- on the fence, undecided, weighing pros and cons, not having chosen between one of many (especially two) options;
- between a rock and a hard place, facing a dilemma, being in a difficult situation with no obviously good options

Etymology: idiom first attested in the seventeenth century, literally meaning "walking on a balance beam", with the image of an acrobat balancing on a seesaw. The noun jou "yoke, carrying pole, balance beam, seesaw" descends directly from Latin iugum with the same meaning, while the verb follar "to walk along, to tread" reflects Old Boral follar "to stamp, crush, tread on", from a Latin noun via Late Latin fullō "I trample, I full (cloth)".

L'er jou follant cas l'empley all'ambit acceptar.
/lɛr ʒu fɔˈlant kaz lɛmˈpli ˌa.lamˈbɪt ˌak.sɛpˈtar/
[lɛː ʝu fʊˈlaŋ kaz lɪmˈpli ˌa.lɐmˈbɪt ˌak.sɪpˈtɑː]
3s=cop.ipf yoke tread-pt.p wrt def=job at.def=bureau accept-inf
He was on the fence about taking the job at the bureau.

44.3: carrug mettr avant naumagl "get ahead of oneself"

carrug mettr avant naumagl /kaˈraj ˈmɛtr̩ aˈvant noˈmɛjl/
- get ahead of oneself, count one's eggs before they hatch, jump the gun, to start on some activity without being adequately prepared;
- put the cart before the horse, make a mountain out of a molehill, to mix up one's priorities and treat minor things as being disproportionately important (or vice versa)

Etymology: idiom used since the medieval period in various languages but first seen in its modern form in Boral in the sixteenth century. The phrase literally means "to put the cart in front of the oxen", in which the noun carrug "cart" descends via Old Boral carruȝ from synonymous Late Latin carrūca (from Gaulish).

Meanwhile, naumagl "ox, castrated bull employed as a draught animal" enters the language in the early Middle Boral period from Norman un naumail /nawˈmaʎ/ "an ox/a steer", rebracketed from earlier un aumail, itself a masculine variant of aumaille "cattle, livestock". This comes from earlier almaille, armaille, from Latin neuter plural animālia "animals" reinterpreted as a feminine singular.

Mettau noc carrug avant naumagl; ja n'eu nos y muncef meðes saut.
/mɛˈto nɔk kaˈraj aˈvant noˈmɛjl | ʒa naw nɔz i mɪnˈtsɛf meˈðɛz sot/
[mɪˈto nɔk kɐˈʀaj ɐˈvan nʊˈmɛjʊ | ʝa naw nɔz i mɪnˈtsɛf mɪˈðɛz sot]
put-1p.sbj neg cart in.front ox | yet neg-have.1p 1p def area even leave.p.pst
Let's not get ahead of ourselves; we haven't even left the borough yet.

44.4: hurstar "equip"

hurstar /hɪrˈstar/ [hɪːˈstɑː]
- equip, be supplied with, to obtain something necessary (especially weaponry or similar tools) in order to carry out a specific action or task;
- don, put on, to clothe oneself with some article of clothing or accessory;
- be taught, self-teach, train oneself in, to learn a particular skill in preparation for some specific situation

Etymology: descendant of Old Boral hurstar "decorate, adorn" with a shift in argument structure (the patient changing from the thing receiving ornament to the items used to adorn) in evidence from the fourteenth century onward. This itself is a borrowing from synonymous Old English hyrstan; compare Merch hirstend /ˈhɪːsən/ "decorative, extra, superfluous".

Dou xiphar hurstaurn glay e me lou svingaurn.
/du ksiˈfar hɪrˈstorn̩ gle e me lu svɪnˈgorn̩/
[du ksɪˈfɑː hɪːˈstoːŋ gle e me lu zvɪŋˈgoːn/
two merc equip-pst.3p sword and 1s.obl 3p.acc wield-pst.3p
Two mercenaries picked up swords and brandished them at me.

44.5: Cordin and Brenna

collected notes on a major population centre on Borland, as well as the last queen of the First Kingdom of Borland.

Cordin is a city in Borland. It is known for its prolific press Cordin Editions, which from the late twenthieth century on has provided textbooks to schools nationwide. Its name is usually considered to be unrelated to the Borlish word cordin "string".

History
In the late 1660s the young James V of Barcelon was a ward in Cordin.

By the Long Peace period Cordin had become one of the largest cities on the island, with a thriving high society to rival that of the capital in Damvath.

People
Professor Marc Jeichey (fl. 2019), lecturer in concurrence history at the University of Cordin who spent some years working in peripatetico at the Dijon New School
Theign Roufler (fl. 2016), scholar and author of book 'From Tablets to Slates: The Story of Education' (Des Delt vars Dois : Y Stoir d'Education)

---

Brenna of Barrow (fl. 898) was the cousin of King Roderick of Dunclothe. She married the young King Jothey of Borland shortly before the First Kingdom of Borland fell to the Danes in 898. Subsequently she fled with her husband to Sothbar, where she bore several children.

Two decades later Sothbar surrendered to Dane Borland and the family were forced to flee once more, this time to Kent. Much of our knowledge of the remainder of her life is preserved through the Brethin copies of her correspondence with her aging uncle in Dunclothe.

##

45.1: Early Methodics

excerpt in translation from 1999 scholastic quire The Grimmer Hall: Developments in Early Methodics (originally published in Cambrick as Łys y Grymrageð: Dasplygad nhy Methodig Kysevin), written by New Leudong historian and methodist Cai Sonquo during his tenure at the University of Mehannin (Brisbane).

Obligað no's un sautel lonc demay cas figuration por y despley ondatim benoçar por regest exactessem augrimar dy gyr de corp cisjovial.
It does not take too great a conceptual leap to use the waveform display to compute more accurate records of the gyres of cisjovial bodies.

Vray, pre y siecr novoç tost ja encontrau nos prefaction magn tranq de conjonction planeter Ixion envount ny scaunç dell'astronom ambrojan Fabian Mostàf,
Indeed, already by the early 1800s we see very precise predictions of planetary conjunctions involving Ixion [Ceres] in the writings of Ambrosian astronomer Fabian Mostàf,

granfigl dy mathematurg Raymond al Mustafa oc meðes ayent aïðað a y fondamen de methodic defassar deur cinquant annað.
grandson of the mathematician Raymond al Mustafa who himself had helped develop the foundations of methodics a half-century earlier.

Nell'oc asc er Mostàf laurant all'observatoir de Paratzon ne Brasil auster e noc obstroint y sar campaner parvasiscent se cous progression,
At this time Mostàf was working at the observatory at Paratzon in eastern Brasil [Newfoundland] and despite advancements in the spreading steeplemesh,

collaboration tras l'ocean atlantic remanen lent, descovart plusour sceint fait cos istrað ny Novomont e Vetomont y dou.
collaboration across the Atlantic remained slow, with several discoveries made separately in the Novomund and Vetomund alike.

45.2: sortir ag vousc "to tryst"

sortir ag vousc /sɔrˈtɪr ɛj vux/
- to tryst, rendezvous, to meet somebody in private to be intimate with them;
- to hook up, to have a casual sexual experience with someone

Etymology: idiom attested from the late eighteenth century but probably older, literally meaning "to go out to the strawberries". The verb sortir "to go out" is a descendant of Latin sortior "to draw by lots, to distribute" with an unclearly-motivated but very early semantic change (compare cognate forms across Gaul and northern Italy).

The noun vousc "strawberry" reflects Old Boral baȝ vousc (cf. modern Boral bag /bɛj/ "berry"), presumably a calque of Old English’s synonymous stréawberȝe "strew-berry", so called for its plant growing low down, the fruits appearing to have been strewn across the ground. The putative verb ?voscar/vojar "to strew, scatter" is otherwise unattested, however—it is tempting to postulate a borrowing from Borland Kelt.

Nos venau de retornar posc sortir ag vousc.
/nɔz veˈno de ˌre.tɔrˈnar pɔx sɔrˈtɪr ɛj vux/
[nɔz vɪˈno de ˌʀe.tʊːˈnɑː pɔx sʊːˈtɪː‿ʀɛj ˈvux]
1p come-ipf.1p from return-inf after go.out-inf to.def strawberry
We had just got back from a tryst together.

##

45.3: ollem "elm"

ollem /ɔˈlɛm/ [ʊˈlɛm]
- elm, (especially) wych elm, tree of the genus Ulmus with asymmetric leaves and small petalless flowers;
- (slang, sometimes derogatory) person from Pentrose, a port town on the south coast of Borland, especially in the context of regional rivalry or applied to someone of British descent

Etymology: via Old Boral olem "elm", apparently reflecting an unattested Insular Latin ulēmus as a variant of ulmus "elm" influenced by Kelt *lēm "elm". We also see forms such as olmair in the Old Boral period with the addition of suffix -air to denote a type of tree.

Use of the word as a demonym for Pentrose is in evidence from the nineteenth century (cf. the banner and nickname of the local lineball team) but likely predates it, given the historical prevalence of elm trees in the area.

Bosc d'ollem sarf a bog fair.
/bɔx dɔˈlɛm sarf a bɔj fer/
[bɔx dʊˈlɛm sɑːf ɐ ˈbɔj feː]
wood of-elm serve to bow make-inf
Elm wood is used to make bows.

45.4: birgasq "apricot"

birgasq /bɪrˈgask/ [bɪːˈgask]
- apricot, pale orange-coloured fruit of a tree in the Prunus genus which spread throughout the Roman Empire by way of Armenia;
- a pale yellow-orange colour like that of the fruit;
- something or someone considered particularly admirable or coveted;
- a particularly contented or satisfied emotional state;

Etymology: from the Middle Boral period, a borrowing from northern Portingale o birgasque "the apricot", variant of earlier obirgoque apparently influenced by synonym damasco, literally "from Damascus". This in turn comes from Arabic الْبَرْقُوق (al-barqūq) "apricots, (later) plums", probably via the form albercoc in Barcelon.

Its figurative extension is in evidence from the eighteenth century, originally used to describe particularly attractive women; compare similar uses of various words for fruits in other languages.

Tu a birgasq oc aubon—te cay cal fallout?
/ti a bɪːˈgask ɔk oˈbɔn | te ke kal faˈlut/
[tsja bɪːˈgask ˌɔ.gʊˈbɔn | tɪ ˈke kaw fɐˈlut]
2s have apricot s.px morning | 2s.obl fall what venture
You look happy this morning—what're you up to?

##

45.5: Willemy

Willemy is a polity in northern Europe, situated east of Norman Kent and France.

History
The Duchy of Willemy was a minor polity within the German Empire during the Second Tetrarchy of the eleventh and twelfth centuries. Forming much of the empire's border with the First Drengot Empire to the west, defence against the marksmen of Willemy led Drengot Emperor Roger II to spend greatly on castle fortifications from Flanders to the Alps.

The Great Flie Flood of 1171 swept away much of Lower Frisia in Willemy, creating several new islands in the Rustigh Strait (such as Texel) and killing then-ruler Lovis the Tall, who was in Amstel at the time. The devastation in the region is thought to have allowed Borlish Axbane to flourish as a trading post in the following century.

In the Revitalist Period and for some time afterwards, Willemy was split between neighbouring powers and portions of its territory changed hands regularly. The duchy of Avosche was unusually stable and held by France for over a century.

Trading operations from Willem and its cities in the Stadbund (the Bróderrat) contributed to staddomains in Atlantic Cappatia, most notably Neuwillem, whose Bróderratcronike (comprising a record of its activities from 1561 to 1597) is an important first-hand account of conditions in the region at the time.

Willem was the focal point of the seventeenth-century Blue Trans-Willem War, usually numbered among the Romantic Wars. This war led incidentally to the dissolution of the Kingdom of Burgundy and the creation of the Duchy of Far Suebia in Bavaria.

The two-arm system for sending steeplepost was first deployed in Willem in the early nineteenth century, to send the first lines of the Pater Noster from the church in the town of Thynen to neighbouring Bost. This event is likely what led to the name 'steeplepost' being applied to the technology.

People
Rulers
Duke Lovis the Tall (d. 1171), who perished in the Great Flie Flood
Adaillé Nassow, Duchess d'Avosche (1524-1608), infamous during her life for her influence at the court of David of France
Other
Carlyn van Stede (fl. 1965), author of parachthon giftale 'While Gold Yet Runs in My Veins' (Zolang Gout dór myn Ádren Noh Vlóye)
Dr Mickel Cráyenschot (fl. c19), noted early supporter of the Deviance movement and public tovarick even as France embraced the Modest Arrangement.
Niklás der Fecht (fl. 1828), a mathematician in the city of 
Tewis Camigner (fl. c16), theorist who noted the high sugar content of beet syrup, though betraver sugar would not be produced commercially for another two centuries

46.1: Wearing a Mask or a Suit (cont.)

continued excerpt from Portingale author Ezio Carvallo's 1860 trevold Tejan de Masquira ou Jalico, pioneer of the masquira genre of stories.

Y porrujon cercondaurn y preu taug enter ny palaç, e donc au Matthias prudenç fait por y cogn reconnoscr ant asmuth vars y rugment dallottað.
The balcony ran around the entire first storey of the palace, and Matthias had been careful to note which corner faced the rugged uplands.

L'aer sta fresc e clar, eð y porrujon sta pres vogt d'alcun hom.
The air was fresh and clear, and the balcony was almost deserted.

Caye freit demay por y plurem dell'host cas Escriva vinn sou y ciel ovart eð admirn la y sigt, eð y ci autr hom pog sur y porrujon stan haft demay ne collocq por y corp angost ne rob fosc parcevir dimeyant lonc y mur.

46.2: bro "dude"

bro /bro/ [bʀo]
- (vocative) dude, bro, mate, term of address for a (usually male) friend used generally in an admiring or appreciative context;
- macho, jocky, masculine (person), a person typified by the impression of physical strength and other male-associated characteristics

Etymology: often conflated with synonymous Willem broe or Merch brow /bru/ (both clippings of words for "brother") and likely influenced in usage by these, but thought to be otherwise unrelated. In the Middle Boral period we primarily see the spelling brau "hero, worthy man", suggesting a connection to braf "brave, heroic" from Italian via French.

Early and uncertain attestions of a word ?prau "poss. fighter, warrior" constitute an alternative etymology; this word may reflect the Latin adjective pravus "perverse, vicious", although the semantic connection is tenuous.

Nos aum issaur magn je ados, bro!
/nɔz om ɪˈsor mɛjn ʒe aˈdɔz | bro/
[nɔz om ɪˈsoː mɛjn ʝɐˈdɔz | bʀo]
1p have-pt.1p success many day.of behind | bro
We won so much yesterday, bro!

46.3: descorçar "peer"

descorçar /ˌde.xɔrˈtsar/ [ˌde.xʊːˈtsɑː]
- peer at, eye, to look at deliberately as if with difficulty or apprehension;
- inspect, scrutinise, to examine something with great care or detail;
- (rare, literally) peel, shell, to remove the bark or peel from the surface of a tree or plant

Etymology: originally in the last sense, either a native formation in the Middle Boral period from noun scorç "bark, peel" and prefix de- indicating reversal or movement away, or else a calque of Latin dēcorticō "I remove the bark or peel" formed in the same way.

Metaphorical use is seen almost immediately and by the eighteenth century the verb has almost entirely been supplanted in its literal sense by periphrastic construction scorç delir de "to remove bark/peel from".

Il ern l'imascry descorçant ag cogn jagerrem.
/ɪl ɛrn ˌli.maˈxri ˌde.xɔrˈtsant ɛj kɔjn ʒaˈgɛ.rɛm/
[ɪlɛːn ˌli.mæˈxʀi ˌde.xʊːˈtsant ɛj kɔjn ʝɐˈgɛ.ʀɐm]
3p cop.ipf-3p def=sculpture eye-p.prs at.def corner far-comp
They were peering at the sculpture in the far corner.

46.4: gevou "watch out!"

gevou /geˈvu/ [gɪˈvu]
- (exclamation) watch out, beware, be careful, exhortation to remain safe by acting in a cautious manner;
- forewarning, heads-up, alert of upcoming danger given ahead of time;
- caveat, proviso, stumbling block, an exception or other awkward condition that is worth knowing about and may need working around

Etymology: first in exclamatory usage, borrowed in the seventeenth century from French phrase a gué vous "look out!" (later written together as gué-vous and used as an ordinary noun), literally "to (the) lookout, you!". The noun gué "watchman, vigil, lookout" descends from Old French, borrowed from the Frankish descendant of Classical German vactuō "watch, vigil".

The word's phonetic resemblance to the English word "careful" is coincidental.

Deð lour gevou cant y rafayat revin.
/dɛθ lur geˈvu kant i ˌra.feˈjat reˈvɪn/
[ˈdɛ.lʊː gɪˈvu kan‿ti ˌʀa.fɪˈjat ʀɪˈvɪn]
give-imp.p 3p.obl watch.out while def tailor come.back.sbj
Give them a heads-up if the tailor comes back.

##

46.5: Channels

The Rustigh Strait (Borlish: Naur Rustig /nor rɪˈstaj/, Frisian Nao Rustig /nɑw ˈrʏ.stɪg/, literally "calm strait") is the channel of water separating the southern coast of Borland from the northern coasts of Flanders and Willemy.

The strait's position often gave it great strategic importance, in terms of both military and trade. For example, coastal cities on the strait like Axbane and Amstel [Amsterdam] were natural stopping points for ships trading between Dane lands to the east and the Welsh and Vascon trade meshes to the west.

During and following the Albic Wars of Fealty, British communities of immigrants spread along the cities on both sides of the Rustig, such as Pentrose.

An air-steeple connection was set up in the 1830s across the Rustig from Nausçod on Borland to Laicouche in French Guillenne (now Lagcóch), where the strait was less than seven leagues across. In 1854 this was superseded by the creation of an undersea barrick cable.

--

Methodics is the field of study pertaining to the discovery, development and improvement of methods. In this scholastic context a method is any series of instructions that may be unambiguously and repeatably followed to produce some result.

History
For millennia methods were developed sporadically without much awareness of general methodical principles. For example, an early method in the historical record is Euclid's procedure for finding the coarsest scale common to two whole numbers. Later we find methods involving tables of pre-computed values, such as Nadim's Method for multiplication by means of the Trapolitan identity for arrhumb [cosine].

Methods with more immediate practical use were continually developed; by the sixteenth century the threepoint method [triangulation] for calculating distances was vital in creating accurate maps for the explorations of the Intertwining Century.

One the first major results in abstract methodics came from the study of life, with Rachel Desselut's 1743 work Parable of the Mute Bookbinder, which argued that in order for living matter to duplicate, it must contain within itself an explicit method describing its construction. Although heredian acid [DNA] would not be discovered for another century, her work accurately predicted the necessary separation of Form and Method that would become the bedrock of the study of heredity.

An incresingly-important category of method from the eighteenth-century onward has been procedures for encrypting text, either to conceal it or else simply to convert it into a suitable form for a given steeplepost.

References
Drawing in the Sand: the History of Calculation, a collaborative reference book originally published 1954 in Napolitan as Scheme ne Rene: a Storia d'Amiradanza by the Agenza Scholaria Fodgesa

47.1: King James Stew

excerpt in translation from 1880 mealbook Pasti Mezziterreni, written by traveller Josforo Sant'Angelo.

De toð y ragost a pescot meyon provað lonc y rimmot solary ne Barcelon e Provenç (noc obstroint y desc unic a pallort eð olif me sarvið sur y ci play ne Mayorca), alcun den poð acavar ag Rey Jagm.
Of all the fish stews I sampled along the solarium coasts of Barcelon and Provence (not to mention the singular mussel-olive dish I was served on the beaches of Mayurca), none compare to the King James.

Surnommað cos vecin eð ant tendreç y jaumetia "picq Jagm", l'oc ragost pren sy nom de Jagm VI (1691-1749), y monarch de regn y stendiscendessem ne Barcelon des stablir a 1067.
Locally and affectionately called the jaumetia “little James”, this stew is named for James VI (1691-1749), the longest-ruling monarch in Barcelon since its establishment in 1067.

Degnant ig sceusn ragost comportant ny region pre sy regn, y majortað sarven for toð y mansc consumir oc remanent des y vanc d'un jorn.
Although similar stews existed in the region before his reign, most simply functioned to use up whatever seafood remained from a day’s catch.

Y Rey Jagm es parcanç y preu desc untal cogt por gra de sey, e certan val por issent l'ottem luç ben hus benoçar, ben untal pescot blanc.
The King James is perhaps the first such dish made for its own sake, and indeed should for best results use hake or haddock, or a similar whitefish.

47.2: un tarç dagr "neither fish nor fowl"

un tarç dagr /ɪn tarts dɛjr̩/ [ɪn ˈtɑːs ˈdɛjɐ]
- neither fish nor fowl, something or someone not easily categorised, not fitting into the established roles of a given situation;
- grey area, ambiguity, a situation intermediate between more familiar states that is not clear or where the rules are not known
- maverick, renegade, iconoclast, law unto oneself, a person refusing to be bound by societal conventions

Etymology: clipped form of earlier proverb no plom ben aur ja tarç dagr "neither lead nor gold but [a] secret third [thing]". This has itself been frozen in an archaic dialect due to its appearance in the evergreen plays of Kinollesau—in Modern Boral we might instead see necun plom ben aur, aglon un treyem scos.

The word tarç "third" descends directly from synonymous Latin tertius and now exists in complementary distribution with later derivation treyem < trēs "three". The disused adjective dagr "secret, hidden, unknown" comes via Old Boral daȝl, daȝr from Old English deagol "secret, obscure, dark".

L'eç aldr aun ja un tarç dagr me rent.
/lɛts aldr̩ on ʒa ɪn tarts dɛjr̩ me rɛnt/
[lɪˈtsaw.dʀ‿on ʝa ɪn ˈtɑːs ˈdɛjɐ me ˈʀɛnt]
def-p.px parent have-3p yet idf third secret 1s.obl make-p.pst
With these parents I've been neither fish nor fowl.

47.3: haft "busy"

haft /haft/ [haft]
- busy, occupied, engaged in activity to a sufficient extent that one would have difficulty doing something else at the same time;
- in use, occupied, active, currently being used in a way that prevents others from using the same thing;
- full, booked out, having been reserved for use entirely so that there is no space for anyone new

Etymology: via Old Boral haft "seizure, capture, imprisonment", apparently a deverbal of an unattested *haftar which would reflect Old English hæftan "to seize, capture, imprison". Its use in apposition as an adjective is seen from the fourteenth century, originally in the sense "captive, unfree" and soon after in its modern senses.

Quisteu raut neðan y davarn sey haft.
/kwiˈstaw rot neˈðan i daˈvarn si haft/
[kwɪˈstaw ʀot nɪˈðan i dɐˈvɑːn si ˈhaft]
call-1p.sbj quick lest def hotel be.sbj busy
Let's call now before the hotel's fully booked.

47.4: pallort "mussel"

pallort /paˈlɔrt/ [pɐˈlɔːt]
- mussel, any of several groups of bivalve shellfish with long asymmetric shells;
- halfwit, dullard, someone perceived to be lacking in intelligence

Etymology: from Old Boral palorde "clam, mussel", from synonymous Vulgar Latin *palorda, itself an alteration of Classical pelōris, pelōridem "large clam or mussel". The word has been used as an insult since at latest the sixteenth century.

Jo comprene noc sceye pallort ny farrago.
/ʒo ˌkɔm.preˈne nɔk xiˈje paˈlɔrt ni ˌfa.raˈgo/
[ʝo ˌkɔm.pʀɪˈne nɔk çje pɐˈlɔːt ni ˌfa.ʀɐˈgo]
1s understand-ipf neg there.be-ipf mussel in-def hash
I didn't realise the hash would have mussels in.

##

47.5: The Modest Arrangement

The Modest Arrangement was a social movement in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries characterised by more stringent enforcement of morality codes, especially with respect to familial powers.

The Arrangement saw a resurgence in the regions of Gaul and Spain in the early nineteenth century after something of an ebb during the Long Peace. This has been attributed to the rising popularity of the Deviance movement inspiring a backlash among its opposers; certainly Modest ideology depicts itself as less secure and more embattled in its later incarnations.

One of the most salient aspects of the Modest Arrangement from the modern perspective is its propensity to censorship, particularly of works deemed contrary to decency. Famously, author Antòin Herrel (latterly Tony Smith) was forced to flee Vascony to Kent after attempting to publish his blasphemous work 'Earthly Scene' (Vista Terrena).

The Second German War of the 1820s saw the grip of the Modest Arrangement weaken in many places, if only incidentally—as faith in existing power structures waned so too did people's trust in those powers' enforcement of the law. The days of Modest Vascony were numbered almost as soon as its interests in Mendeva and the East were threatened and the Vallabrì administration under King Hernand declared an alliance with the Convoy.

Although the Modest Arrangement would not survive the 1850 Laic Declarations in Belgrade in any official capacity, polities like Vascony, (New) Provence and Morrack would retain some hallmarks of the Arrangement well into the twentieth century.
Proponents

    Ruvien Baume, Marquis de Caillat (fl. 1810), noted for his fervence in opposition to Deviance Theology
    Diana Theodora Queiroz, considered to have laid the groundwork for the later Blue Marian movement

excerpt in translation from the condensed study materials for the New Vithor course Concurrence History of the 16th Century: Death, Ships and the Movement of the Heavens.

Un bustr l'oc eutað dessur contradignt es Vascony; l'oc a graç a profit Novomondin des pelur eð autr enascment un aðoinç cas pouvlanç souvað de 1500 vars 1550 (Portingale noc ig inclus) com issent d'immigration.
One counterexample to the above trend is Vascony which, thanks to Novomundine profits in furs and other goods, actually saw in increase in population from 1500 to 1550 (excluding Portingale) due to immigration.

The end of the Vascon Ascendancy with the War of the Two Queens would end feudalism in Vascony by the end of the century, however.

One, perhaps unexpected, effect of the decline of the feudal system was the strengthening of laws such as sumptuary codes.

48.2: flottisc "fleet"

flottisc /flɔˈtɪx/ [flʊˈtɪç]
- fleet, flotilla, convoy, a group of ships or occasionally of other vehicles;
- (by extension) navy, the collective naval force of a country;

48.3: pernix "nimble"

pernix /pɛrˈnɪks/ [pɪːˈnɪks]
- nimble, dextrous, deft, agile, skillful with one's hands and able to make very precise movements;
- swift, fleet, rapid and graceful in motion;
- subtle, crafty, insidious, manipulative, being able to direct someone else's decisions without their knowledge

Etymology: learned borrowing in the Middle Boral period from Latin pernix "nimble, agile, swift", thought to be connected with perna "ham, haunch, gammon" (cf. inherited Boral parn "bacon"), although the expected Latin form would be *pernāx.

Its latter sense develops in the eighteenth century under the malign influence of unrelated perniçous "harmful, pernicious, deleterious", from synonymous Latin perniciōsus, a derivative of pernecō "I kill, slay, annihilate".

L'eye doutr y verroil ant deit pernix.
/liˈje ˈdutr̩ i vɛˈrɔil ant dit pɛrˈnɪks/
[lje ˈdut.ʀ‿i vɪˈʀɔjʊl‿an dit pɪːˈnɪks]
3s-go-ipf past def lock with finger deft
She picked the lock with nimble fingers.

48.4: 1st Lexember

coðelostað "caution"

coðelostað /koˌðe.lɔˈstaθ/ [kʊˌðɛ.lʊˈstah]
- caution, wariness, vigilance, watchfulness, the state of begin alert to potential dangers or mistakes;
- anxiety, alarm, pessimism, an unpleasant condition of mental unease or concern about the uncertain future

Etymology: nominal derivative of coðelous "cautious, wary; attentive, aware" first attested in the fifteenth century. This adjective is itself a derivative of noun coðel "caution" (now obsolete, but compare French choile "lie, deceit" and various learned forms across Romance), from synonymous cautēla in Latin. Extension to more negative emotional states is seen from the eighteenth century.

Sy coðelostað er ençant a nos tardir.
/si koˌðe.loˈstaθ ɛr ɛnˈtsant a nɔz tarˈdɪr/
[si kʊˌðɛ.lʊˈstað‿ɛːʀ‿ɪnˈtsant a nɔz tɐːˈdɪː]
3s.gen caution cop.ipf start-p.prs at 1p slow-inf
His caution was starting to slow us down.

48.5: 2nd Lexember

sarzin "buckwheat"

sarzin /sarˈzɪn/ [sɐːˈzɪn]
- (obsolete) Muslim, Saracen, a person who is a follower of Islam;
- (archaic or dialect) non-Christian, pagan, practioner of a religion other than Christianity and especially one performing practices associated with pre-Christian peoples or peoples not yet exposed to Christianity;
- (historical) cairn, a conical heap of stones placed by the pre-Roman Kelt people around Borland or a modern such heap resembling these;
- (historical, by extension) milestone, a pillar or pile of stones placed at the side of a road to mark distance;
- buckwheat, an originally Asian plant whose fruit is widely used in cooking as a pseudocereal

Etymology: in its only surviving modern sense, a clipping of the earlier bla sarzin "Saracen wheat" which is first attested in the fifteenth century, in reference to its eastern origin (the plant having been brought to Europe via the Turkish Riyalid Sultanate or possibly via Russian Cazany).

Likewise, in the senses "cairn, milestone" it is a clipping of pieðr sarzin "Saracen stones", from the perception that these piles of stones were pre-Christian monuments to pagan gods.

The word itself is a borrowing from Old French sarrazin "Muslim, Saracen" reflecting Late Latin Saracēnus and Ancient Greek Σᾰρᾰκηνός (Sarakēnós). These originally referred to an Arabic or para-Arabic people of North Arabia.

Y cociner ença voug cas hojol ne sarzin.
/i ˌko.tsiˈnɛr ɛnˈtsa vuj kaz hoˈʒɔl ne sarˈzɪn/
[i ˌkɔ.tsɪˈnɛːʀ‿ɪnˈtsa ˈvuj kaz hʊˈʝɔw ne sɐːˈzɪn]
def cook start-ipf wrong wrt pancake in buckwheat
The cook was terrible at buckwheat pancakes.

---

excerpt from The Delicious Story of Dough and Oil, a work of popular history detailing the history of many related foods across the globe. Published (originally in Awrish as Tésta Olaivan Vláxerte "A World of Dough in Oil") in 1963 by first-time writer and famed chef Shomoji Taxon, who in his later years would go on to present the first cooking programme shown simultaneously on both sides of the Atlantic.

…see its eastern origins by its names in the languages of Europe—whether in Horther møurick ("Moorish wheat") or Bavarn creshke (originally from a Russian word meaning "Greek"). Nonetheless, sarzin [buckwheat] flour has since its introduction become a key component of diets across the continent.

We turn first to a dish which originated in Vallack communities and spread west upriver as the region was united politically under the Kingdom of the Danaw [Danube] during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Even after the kingdom's collapse and the rise of the Riverine Cities in the nineteenth century, farama dry-pottage has remained an important tradition from Pojon [Bratislava] to Gollamo [Ruse].

Farama seems originally to have been associated with wedding anniversaries, as an inexpensive (at least, before the recipe was augmented with unseasonal berries or spices like dallasine [cinnamon]) of celebrating each passing year. Over time the traditions around farama have shifted; in many places the sarzin dish is now served on birthdays.

Along with the area's distinctive hodgel-cakes [in this case, blini], farama enjoyed an explosion in popularity worldwide (usually divorced from its vicine traditions) after their prominent inclusion in the film…

48.6: 3rd Lexember

gallaið "galaxy"

gallaið /gaˈleθ/ [gɐˈleh]
- galaxy, collection of stars all orbiting a common centre;
- seemingly-uncountable collection of people of things conceptualised as comprising a vast variety;
- (dated) the Milky Way, the galaxy in which the Sun and Earth are found and which is most readily visible in the night sky

Etymology: from late Old Boral galaix, galais "the Milky Way", learned borrowing from synonymous Latin galaxiās and Ancient Greek (κύκλος) γᾰλᾰξῐ́ᾱς, literally "milky circle". Altered in the early Middle Boral period under the influence of laið "milk", from Latin lac, lactem "milk" (or possibly from a Borland Kelt form; compare Cambrick łaeth "milk").

Used as a proper noun until the discovery of other galaxies in the Good Game period of the late nineteenth century. Metaphorical use for other vast collections of things is seen since the seventeenth century, especially in poetry.

Postulað es l'oc roc vien d'un autr gallaið.
/ˌpɔ.stiˈlaθ ɛz lɔk ˈrɔk vjɛn dɪn ˈotr̩ gaˈleθ/
[ˌpɔ.stɪˈlað‿ɪz lʊ ˈʀɔk ˈvjɛn dɪn ˈo.tɐ gɐˈleh]
suppose-p.pst be.3s def-s.px rock come of-indf other galaxy
There's speculation that this rock comes from another galaxy.

48.7: 4th Lexember

orin "homeland"

orin /oˈrɪn/ [ʊˈʀɪn]
- homeland, hometown, origins, the place where one was born or which one considers to be home;
- pedigree, ancestry, heritage, lineage, one's family background and the traditions and customs one has as a virtue of the place and people one was born to;

Etymology: via Old Boral orin, oriȝn "breeding, heritage" from Latin orīgō, orīginem "commencement, origination, (particularly) birth", from which also comes the later reborrowing origin "source, origin, beginning". Used metonymically to refer to the place of one's birth since the fourteenth century.

Jo kigla reuvr a mell'orin pre oc annað.
/ʒo kajˈla ˈraw.vr̩ a ˌmɛ.loˈrɪn pre ɔk aˈnaθ/

I hadn't been back home until this year.
