67.3: stovir "be necessary"

stovir /stoˈvɪr/ [stʊˈvɪː]
- (archaic or elegant) be necessary, be needed, be obligatory, to be logically or legally required;
- lack, be missing, to (potentially) suffer from not having;
- be wanted, be desirable, to be desired by someone

Etymology: from Old Boral istover "be necessary", a verbal derivation of istof "obligaton, necessity, need". This is a univerbation of Latin phrase est opus "there is need". The shift to less urgent wants is relatively recent, occuring over the course of the nineteenth century. Stovir still connotes stronger desire than the alternative construction desirar "to want" (colloquially 'sirar), which sees more use for polite requests.

67.4: jougl "knock-out blow"

jougl /ʒujl/ [ˈʝu.jʊ~ˈʝwɪw]
- knock-out blow, haymaker, sockdolager, a punch that renders one's opponent unconscious, insensible, or otherwise unable to continue to fight;

The hotel's price would be the clincher.

##

67.5: Romantic Wars

The Romantic Wars were a loosely-circumscribed collection of wars, uprisings and other conflicts across Europe which took place through the middle of the seventeenth century. As a whole they are sometimes considered the last truly localised conflicts, since by the next century wars of similar scales would begin to involve the Novomund, and would feature alliances between the powers of Europe, Africa and Asia alike. The years 1640 to 1670 cover the 'central' conflicts of the Romantic Wars, although some more peripheral fights may spill earlier or later.

The Romantic period (to wit, the decades during with the Romantic Wars took place) were characterised by great corrogation projects. For example, the Bordew-Audaz canal was completed in 1679, connecting the Atlantic and the Middlesea without having to pass through Morrack-controlled seas.

Perennial adversaries Vascony and Morrack continued their protracted fight through the seventeenth century. Having been on a marked decline for a century, Vascony was forced to cede its economic heart in Portingale to Andalus, which at that time was controlled by Morrack.

Several polities and vassal states did not survive the Romantic Wars; for example, the Principality of Mystra in Greece, which had existed as a vassal of the Second Roman Empire since the eleventh century, was formally dissolved in the aftermath of the Romantic Wars.

Willemy was the focal point of the Blue Trans-Willem War (not to be confused with the White Trans-Willem War), which indirectly led to the dissolution of the Kingdom of Burgundy and the creation of the Duchy of Far Suebia in Bavarn.

Borland's involvement in the Romantic Wars was restricted to a failed invasion (culminating in the Hawkirch Surrender of 1623), along with unstable arrangements with neighbouring polities regarding military aid in their conquests.

Much has been made of the involvement of pirates (to a greater or lesser extend endorsed by political powers) in the Romantic Wars, although recent historiography tends to downplay how much impact these factions really had.

The Roman conflict in Armenia of the 1640s is contemporaneous with the Romantic Wars, but its inclusion within them is a matter of scholarly dispute. Opponents point out that this fight was merely the latest in a series of essentially-identical conflicts between the Second Roman Empire and Arab (and later Turkish) peoples over control of the Hazaran Sea.

68.1: Early Medieval Borland

excerpt in translation from The Story of Borland, published (originally in Boral as Y Stoir d'Istr Boral) for use in classrooms in 1982 by Cordin Editions.

Cay confluyenç dy ci pouvr germannesc ny souð e nell'ovest con y pouvr romannesc nell'aust e ny norð se produgnt for lent, interim, tras y plusour siecr sevent.
The mixing of the Germanic peoples of the south and west with the Romans of the east and north would proceed only slowly, however, for the next couple of centuries.

The question of fealty vexed the land, with conflicts leading to temporary alliances between Boral and Sothbar or Boral and Angland depending on the political climate.

Tandem, ny siecr novem joun y rey roman Stiglan dau sell'heir Marc ne mariðaç ag dottr soul a Alfey d'Anglont, cossy lorry reyaum unfiant e Sothbar sforçant a vassalaç eunovir posc y Battagl a Fendal n'atorn 810 N.

But at the same time as the tripartite situation of Borland was finally showing signs of stabilisation, Danish raids on the island's coast towns were increasing in frequency and strength.

68.2: ne ðougl "rushed"

68.3: teissir "weave"

teissir /tiˈsɪr/ [tɪˈsɪː]
- knit, weave, spin, to form something by passing lengths or strands of material over or through themselves;
- plait, wreathe, braid, interweave, to weave together the strands or locks of;
- devise, plot, scheme, concoct, to come up with a plan or similar undertaking;

68.4: jug "continually"

jug /ʒaj/ [ʝaj]
- continually, ever, still, remaining in a given state or continuing on a given course;
- immediately, instantly, now, starting at this exact moment;

Etymology: from Old Boral iui /dʒyj/ "always, forever, without stopping", which descends directly from Late Latin iūge "constantly, all the time". Replaced in the "always" sense by tojorn < toð jorn "all day" by the Middle Boral period. The expected modern spelling juy was over time altered to jug under the influence of the Latin form. In modern spoken usage the word is confined mostly to imperative constructions.

Ag port penoy sign scaunt 'Abseïr Jug'.
/ɛj pɔrt peˈnɔj sajn xont ˌab.siˈjɪr ʒaj/
[ɛj pɔːt pɪˈnɔj sajn xont ɐbˈzjɪː ʝaj]

The sign on the door read 'Keep Out'.

68.5: The German Secesssion

The German Secession was a schism in Christendom which took place in the first half of the thirteenth century. Often considered on of the most influential religious developments of the second millennium, it led to the permanent formalisation of the Ausburg See as independent from Rome with its separate papal line beginning with Paul I/XI.

The Secession generally refers to the period from Paul I/XI's Denunciations and declaration of the sedes sanctissima in Augsburg in 1225 to the capitulation of Rome in 1251, although religious strife due to the schism would wrack the polities of Germany and surrounding regions for centuries to come.

The 1210 declaration of a renewed crusade for Jerusalem by Pope Just, and the military catastrophes that occurred in the course of this push, were a major source of discontentment in Rome. Further, Europe was at the time in the throes of the First Great Dying, a plague that would be surpassed in severity only by the Second Great Dying of the early sixteenth century. (These events are related, in that the plague is thought to have arrived in Europe carried by returning crusaders).

The decades after the Pauline Denuncations saw each individual duchy (and in some cases each county!) declare either for Rome or for Augsburg, in an unstable patchwork of allegiances that would lead to the collapse of the German Empire in spectacular fashion.

The ongoing Baptism of the North (the project to fold the northeasternmost part of Europe into Christendom) was inflamed by the Secession. Along with a new, more totalist Roman Pope in Hermeneus II, it was feared that Augsburg might spread heresy faster than Rome could reach the North.

The events of the Secession have been a perennial subject of dramatisation, most famously (and perhaps most innacurately) in 1961 historical epic 'With the North Star to Guide Us'.

References
'A Mapbook Compendium of Europe, from the Division of Rome until the German Secession (450 - 1250 N)', published by the Tommarth Open School of History in 1997
'A Baptism of Fire: Christianity and the Graven' by Agata Naziunas, published 1988 by Leidéiai Givatés
'Comparing the German Secession to the Great Fracture; how the Final Antipope emerged from a popular reaction to the Failed Crusade, and how to understand his successors' reactions to Rome in the sixteenth century', scholastic writing in the 1901 publication of theological journal 'Proclamatio Divior'

69.1: Gingerbread

abridged extract in translation from reference work Folk Customs and Holidays of the North: a Compendium, published in 1876 by Safford University Primers.

Magn comoscon Istr Boral—tan e largeç allors—vel se contentar n'auteç declarar sull'idea de pan vastel aromað douç, y method sengr (ja pos oc no star lon y form a jonnovar faïð par Istr Boral) vien tostessem meðes all'innascment lað de zucar n'Europ.
Much as Borland—and many other places—might like to claim ownership of the concept of sugar-spiced cakebread, the basic recipe (though perhaps not Borland's preferred buttefly shape) predates even the mass import of sugar into Europe.

Gingembrað apparisc ne siecr doç tandic abatment continu ag Masrecq augta gingembr eð autr març vars l'ovest, eç mout zucarrað par miel.
Inchbread [1] arrives in the twelfth century as ongoing warfare in the Masreck [2] brought inchroot [3] and other goods west, often sweetened with honey.

Postulað cos usual es ig jonnovar son y symbol primer de Naðal sur Istr Boral com un parsonfianç de metamorphos e de við alcheðr tandic y mont mort dell'yarn reflorisc vars y prinvir.
It is usually supposed that butterflies are the primary symbol of Christide on Borland as a representation of metamorphosis and new life as the dead world of winter grows again into spring.

Degnant ig l'oc intermain un fabr starc, eð ig a mesur dy siecr a y symbol dy jonnovar se caut adoptað par commouð divers por l'oc bers meðes complir, y tesmogn historic no's idone antal racont sengr.
While this makes for a good story, and while the symbol of the butterfly has over the centuries been adopted by various movements for this very purpose, the historical record is more ambiguous.

[1] gingerbread, [2] the Levant, [3] ginger

69.3: auteç "ownership"

auteç /oˈtɛts/ [ʊˈtɛs]
- ownership, possession, control, having something at one's disposal;
- responsibility, duty, obligation, liability, being able to be held to account for something;
- fault, culpability, being responsible for some state of affairs or some particular occurrence

Etymology: from Old Boral afteç "possession, ownership", used predominated in a legal context and reflecting a parallel formation to synonymous habititia in Medieval Latin: it is a nominal derivation from aft (modern aut), past participle of aeir "to have" (modern aïr). ##

69.5: Avosche

Avosche (Paris French /aˈvɔːʃ/, Willem Dutch /ˈa.vusx/) is a political subregion of Willemy centred on the city of Axton (Grand-Aix /gʀãˈdɛiks/, Aughen /ˈɔ.ɣn̩/), with a strong regional identity. At various points a county, a duchy and a march, it has seen both continual territorial instability (situated between French and Dutch powers) and major urban development into the modern period.

Etymology
The region Avosche is named for its first ruling house, which in turn takes its title from its founder Cuonrat Aihuosc (seen in Latin as Corradus Aevoscus). The name is of obscure origin; the first element presumably reflects Classical German ehu- "horse", while the second may be from suffix -iscas "-ish" (though the vowel is problematic).

Compare the English surname Davush (Merch /daːʃ/, Kentish /ˈdaː.vɪʃ/), which derives from an illegitimate branch of House Avosche.

History
The County of Avosche emerges shortly after the split of the Kingdom of the Franks and the concomitant creation of Willemy. The founding house of Avosche was soon after superseded by marriage by the neighbouring House Nassow (which originated in Francony).

The county was elevated to a duchy in the early sixteenth century, with Roger d'Avosche becoming the first duke. At this time the region was ruled by France. Roger's daughter, Adaillé Nassow, succeeded him and went on to rule for many decades until her death in 1608.

During her reign Adaillé accrued significant influence over her liege David of France. This was punctured by the scandal of her grandson and heir apparent Déricque fleeing to New Provence in 1589.

After a century of stability as a vassal of France, the seventeenth century was particularly eventful for Avosche; it changed hands as the result of various wars and peacetime treaties on five separate occasions. Especially bloody was the Blue Trans-Willem War, which also dissolved the Kingdom of Burgundy.

References
Lát os Danse: De Hartoin ‘n Avosche (Let us Dance: The Duchess d'Avosche), biography published in 1919

70.1: Review: The Ascendant

excerpt in translation from a review of the 1934 film The Ascendant appearing in Marsellan newspaper Fiellas Dimenja.

Domaget se sarf dy sgart angost por y lað illuminar par casc taug ny forganç a sy film, e vray veim nos l'eç advantaç n'un tal eðeglment ac dessur.
Domaget uses the narrow view to illuminate the broad in every aspect of his filmmaking, and we really see the benefits of such an approach here.

Ða y belem ern grivlað a se produgr ny palaç e castel a Huzatr e Cartau, defagl all'auditoir vel y comport vistar entr y glonscel cambresc n'Albion ag scon nuçal d'Alexandra a Vascony e sy veyaç famous.
If the scenes were confined to the palaces and castles of Huzatre and Cartaw, it would be hard to connect the Welsh tangles in Albion to the second marriage of Alexandra of Vascony and her famed voyage.

Aglon poum nos y sensation a sculd parental sentir all'abat contr gam sgarant lonc y dou cainç secuð nell'oc caðen filmer.
Instead we can feel the sense of parental obligation warring with wanderlust in both threads of this filmic tapestry.

L'Ascenent vil lon fregn denir siemprtað sull'icon stival, e l'oc merit fort l'ig sign a ðoranç.
The Ascendant will doubtless be a staple of the summer screen, and it well deserves the honour.

Poll'ottem souvanç cavir jo rannuð vos passeð y ralley ne vin empordan beint e n'y plurem cantant a cançon de gloir voscon figurabr.
For the best experience I recommend you spend the afternoon drinking Empordan and singing as many songs of glory as you can think of.

70.4: nacleu n'oc ort "looking up"

70.5: Monks and Metropoleis

The Jacobin Fraternity (Borlish Fraterntað Jagovin), historically also known as the Order of Saint James, is a religious organisation based in the city of Axbane on the south coast of Borland.

The Fraternity were founded in tenth-century Flanders under the patronage of Amelia of Bruges. In the eleventh century they were implicated in a local popular uprising against Drengot Emperor Geoffry II and forced to flee over the sea to Borland. There they built the Peninsular Monastery which still overlooks Axbane.

Funds from the Fraternity contributed to the Jacobin Estates on the outskirts of Damvath, which on their completion in the late eighteenth century became the fixed location of Borland's parliament.

Today the organisation is known mostly for the guild they own, Jaibos Breweries, as well as for owning significant lands in the city (including the site of one of the ancient Roman bathhouses there).

---

The Riverine Cities were an alliance-federacy of small independent states along the Danaw River and its tributaries linked by treaty and trade in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Each state consisted primarily of a single urban area and the surrounding rural hinterland, though the enforcement of territorial borders was often rather nominal.

The political structure of the Riverine Cities grew out of the ashes of the Kingdom of the Danaw, which had collapsed in spectacular fashion after the Second German War of the 1820s.

The Cities were a hotbed for underground or subversive organisations, including the Deviance movement, and were host to several semi-public tovarick communities. This environment was likely fostered by the presence of significant religious minorities and the strong ties between the Church and the local urban authorities.

Members of the Riverine Cities included Belgrade, Boxa, Gollamo and Pojon.

71.1: Atomic Theory

excerpt in translation from Lux Æterna: The First Century of Threshold Force, written in 2002 by Cawen ba Dirxen at the Varonøw Higher Edifice.

Des posc y preu enombranç corporal d'an 1840 er venuð all'idea oc orn dar a corporal cos naðeu lonc pondranç mena vars coglenç fatuous ða volir nis prestar a lorry natur alchemic
Since the first periodic tables in the 1840s it had been realised that naively ordering elements by atomic weight led to inelegant groupings when chemical properties were taken into account

(y celeberrem ig stove de raçon starc janthin inquillir parmy sy confraðr detaxional com muria),
(most notably the strong motivation to place iodine with similarly-reacting substances like chlorine),

eð alcun motivation theoretic por eç tal per de corporal trocar nell'orn nole soumission cavir pre dezein.
and no scientific basis for swapping such pairs of elements in the order would be proposed for decades.

A veg temporane, l'occorrenç pariscent lon conjogntur yonoscon ig lonc mesuranç y corporal y legeressem teyen tout pondranç atomic monfiað pres exact com l'ig a aquifex,
At the same time, the apparently-unrelated phenomenon wherein the lightest elements had all been measured to have atomic weights almost exact multiples of that of hydrogen,

cant oc se mantene bogr cas y ci lordessem (corporal tal cojan meðes com es cuivr!), flagita expostion cavir.
while this was not true at all of heavier ones (even such prosaic substances as copper!), demanded explanation.

##

71.5: Threshold force

Threshold force [nuclear fission power] is the force derived from splitting the nuxes [nuclei] of atoms. The name 'threshold' refers to the so-called 'threshold heft [mass]' of an unstable substance like killdark [uranium], above which one has a self-sustaining detaxion [1].

History
The story of threshold force begins in 1902, with the discovery of the atomic nux—that is, the discovery that almost all of the heft of an atom is located near its centre. This took place at the Nÿstad Atellier (then privately owned and run by substantial theorist [2] Lohic Courvoisier de Nÿstad) in the Cappatian city of Warnøw [3].

The first threshold mills capable of supplying force for general use were in operation by the 1960s. These, and the unsettling martial applications of threshold force which had already been demonstrated on a small scale, brought the concept of harmful shortform luxes [gamma rays] into the popular consciousness. Many a blacklayer [horror movie] of the period and thereafter features unstoppable invisible rays inflicting horrors on the characters.

The corporal used in the vast majority of threshold mills, killdark, was first isolated in the early nineteenth century in the Irish shire of Killdara (whence, via Welsh kildárc 'from Killdara', the substance's name).

Portingale was a pioneer of threshold force, funding research into its effectivity in the 1950s in a bid to reduce their dependence on astraphor [electricity] exported by the Drengot Collusion. The polity's efforts were repaid in full; Portingale became a net exporter of astraphor in the 1970s.

References

Lux Æterna: The First Century of Threshold Force, written in 2002 by Cawen ba Dirxen

---
[1] a generic term describing any process involving the change of one thing into another; synthesis, reaction.
[2] a chemist focused on the properties and structures of atoms and single molecules.
[3] from a *Dutch rendering of *Guaraní + øw 'island', located where Vitória (ES), Brazil is.

72.5: Markland

Markland is a polity of Albion, situated east of Wales, north of London and Kent, and south of Northumber and Sodrick.

Markland 2000.png
(The approximate extent of Markland proper in 2000 N.)

History
Markland originates with Saxon settlements in sub-Roman Britannia, which in the west formed (what would go on to be named) mearce land "borderland". Compare the related demonym Mierce "people of the border", whence the Latin name Mercia and native Merchman "man from Markland".

The petty kingdom of Anglia was annexed by Markland with the Treaty of Oxford in the late eighth century, at the dawn of the Viking Age. This established the persevering border between the mouths of the Severn and the Tames, and incited renewed influx of people into the petty kingdoms on Borland.

Markland weathered the Viking Age much more successfully than neighbouring Northumber, though much of its eastern coast was settled by Danes; the city of Lincon served as the de facto border of Danish rule for several decades. In part this was the inevitable result of tensions along the Welsh border; even during peacetime Theodric the Awefast maintained substantial levy forces.

The tenth-century Elved Marriage (which took place near the modern city of Leeds) ended hostilities between Markland and Dane forces in the east for almost a century. It is said to have been solemnised over a sandstone block later inlaid into the Redstone Chair, a low-backed wooden throne on which many subsequent monarchs were crowned.

Around the turn of the second millennium, Markland was conquering territory from the northern reaches of Wales (incidentally leading to Pope Agatho's canonisation of the Welsh St David). The perennial conflicts between Markland and Wales would come to be collectively referred to as the Mallor Wars.

The First Drengot Empire of the eleventh and twelfth centuries counted Markland as a major vassal, conquered from the south following the subjugation of Kent by Normandy and Greater Devon in 1029.

The Mallor Wars were reignited after a quiescent period by the martial-minded King Andrew II, with the Sack of Rexam in 1301 during which the original St Brigid's Abbey burned to the ground.

Markland was embroiled in the Wars of Fealty in the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries. Tensions over the location and possession of the Redstone Chair boiled over into a conflict that would last forty-one years. Markland conceded several battles to the young Kingdom of Britain in the early years of the wars, culminating in the 1483 Battle of Rexam which expanded the borders of Wales in the north and killed the last Duke of Chestre.

In the final years of the Wars of Fealty, a code known as Thieves' Script was employed by the forces of King Andrew III, apparently adapted from similar systems used by gangs of housebreakers in Nottingham. It is remembered today as a very early precursor of codes like steeplescript or modern one-zeffre encoding.

The poor economic conditions and population displacement in Markland following the Wars of Featly led it to suffer almost twice as many deaths per capita from the Second Great Dying compared to polities like Willemy.

Long contested between Markland and Kent, the city of London found itself independent for one final, lasting time following the Democratic Wars of the mid-eighteenth century.

The spellings of various towns and cities in Markland were rationalised during the Long Peace period of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries (for example, Conster for former Colncester /ˈkɔn.stə/).

The 2010 Œcumen Count, a regular census, recorded that Utter Safford was the secondmost populous city in Markland proper with 4.4 million inhabitants, after the capital of Tommarth.

People
Monarchs
Theodric the Awefast (fl. 800), repeller of several attempted vikings into Merch territory
Oswin the Becoming (fl. 1029), last ruler of an independent Markland before the First Drengot Empire
Andrew II (fl. 1301), who reignited the Mallor Wars with the Sack of Rexam
Andrew III (fl. 1500), ruler of Markland during the latter years of the Wars of Fealty
Authors
Ferris Bewly (fl. 1942), alchemist responsible for the quire 'Modern Developments in Benjamine Detaxion'
Laurent Burnows (fl. 2015), famous for children's series 'Back to Front' and later for the more mature series 'An Inconvenient Armageddon'
Anna and Ralph Highwater (fl. 1930), cowriters of the series of books 'Games for Sorties and Excourses'
Challow Huddresfell (fl. 1956), historian who wrote 'Daughters of the Sea: The Northwestern Isles'
Jason Ridley (fl. 1967), who with others wrote the quire 'A Handbook of Natural Theory'
Dr Harold Westcamp (fl. 1997), who wrote the series of textbooks 'Albic Medicine in the Workshop Decades'
Others
Sarzan Dawkinholm (fl. c19), long-serving and much-lambasted Outland Minister

Jo nil for vertað—opportun es l'oc edition tan brey posc y solstiç neðan jo pos noc parcanç y ci sodal haubrjorançasterrem ovart concedr ny fabr cortal e historic nuverrem de Dormaget.

73.3: ronç cadarað "distillate"

ronç cadarað /rɔnts ˌka.daˈraθ/ [ʀɔns ˌka.dɐˈʀah]
- distillate, the liquid that has been condensed from a vapour during distillation and thereby purified;

- (specifically) diesel, a heavier fuel derived from petroleum (also informally just ronç)

73.4: stuðant "student"

stuðant /stiˈðant/ [stɪˈðan(t)]
- student, pupil, a person enrolled in an academic institution;
- disciple, devotee, enthusiast, someone who actively follows or admires a philosophy or similar construct;

Etymology: Old Boral stuðant "student", present participle of stuðar "excel, shine, be skilled; learn, practice, improve, train" influenced by Latin studēns "dedicating oneself to, studying". The verb stuðar is a derivative of stuð "clever, intelligent, skilled; interested, engaged, paying attention" (now obsolete outside of fixed expressions), from Latin ā̆stūtus "crafty, cunning, tricksy", and was quickly conflated with shortlived semi-learnèd studiar "to study (in the Church)", from post-Classical Latin studiō "I study" (compare earlier synonymous studeō).

[çjɛn tɔː dɔs stɪˈðan ni ʀaw]

73.5: Ambrosia

Ambrosia (Vascon/Vask Ambroxa) is a polity of north-eastern Mendeva, comprising several islands and much of the mainland up to the Five Seas. It borders New Provence to the south.

History

The story of Ambrosia begins with the Novomundine Landfall of 1471, when Vetomundine travellers encountered Mendeva for the first time since sporadic visits by the Norse. A Vask fishing expedition (part of the New Navarre Enterprise) landed on the island of Brasil, which would go on to host the first European settlements in Mendeva.

The parts of Mendeva first explored by (and whose trade was monopolised by) Vascony—to wit, the island of Brasil and the lands westward thereof—was named Ambrosia in honour of Ambrose III of Vascony.

Ambrosia achieved political and economic independence from Vascony in the early nineteenth century as part of the continent-wide phenomenon of the Mendevan Unmooring.

The first long-distance transmission of an image took place in Ambrosia in 1820, employing the so-called Steeplepost Tapestry (consisting of a wall of tiles painted black and white on each side). This device would soon go on to be the subject of the infamous Lies of 1824.

By the 1880s the most urbanised parts of Ambrosia were connected by wired tachygraph, allowing messages to be sent from home to home.

In 1950 the Japetos submarine Atlantic link conveyed its first messages. It was laid down between Gadire in Morrack and eastern Brasil.

Places

Aiga d'Angoixa, a major city on the Oxagre River and location of the original Steeplepost Tapestry

Illa de Vinna Salvatge, a built-up island in the Oxagre

Paratzon, a town in eastern Brasil

People

74.2: tascban "vanilla"

Etymology: seventeenth century, borrowed into Borlish (via Vascon taxbàn or French tacheban) from Morrove Arabic تشبان (tashbān) "vanilla plant, vanilla flavouring". This is an early sixteenth century borrowing from the Thebevan [Totonac] tałpán "vanilla plant" (possibly via Nawat [Nahuatl]).

##

74.5: The Pistol Mesh

The pistol mesh (Borlish sar pistol), also referred to simply as the mesh, is the global system of long-distance communication which employs a single normalised method for transmitting messages from one endpoint augrimmer to another.

Etymology
The phrase "pistol mesh" (in the Roun French form mail pistre) was first used by writer Ashford Pasquier in his 1968 parachthon work Starsail, describing technology that could transmit written messages, sounds and moving images between people in different star systems.

The phrase literally means "network for messages": the word pistol reflects post-Classical Latin pistola "epistle, written decree", aphæretic form of synonymous epistola; the word mesh descends from Old English masc "net".

History
The pistol mesh grew out of several earlier technologies, all the way back to the first flag-lamp steeplepost lines in the eighteenth century allowing short texts to be sent between signal towers.

A century later sees the emergence of tachygraphs, devices allowing one to type text directly onto the barrick steeplepost from the comfort of one's home. However, it was only with the rise of general augrimmers in the twentieth century that we start to recognise the modern pistol mesh.

By the late twentieth century, the pistol mesh was sufficiently mature that whole enterprises could be conducted using it as a medium. For example, at this time the Tremonnow Open School (formerly the Brethin Mesh Institute) offered history courses across Albion entirely via mesh. Another impactiful development was the blossoming of 'distributed bookhouses', repositories for free-to-access information (much of it lifted from books out of withholding) to which anyone could contribute.

##

75.5: Burgundy

Burgundy (Burgund French Borgogne /bɔgˈgɔɲɛ/) is a polity in Gaul, situated south of France, west of Bavarn, north of Provence and east of Vascony. It has for most of its history been ruled from the city of Geneva.

History

During the Second Tetrarchy period of the eleventh and twelfth centuries, Burgundy was a major vassal of the First Drengot Empire. Following the Emergency at Dijon in 1170, which presaged the collapse of said empire, Burgundy became a de facto autonomous kingdom.

In the early fifteenth century with the Vascon Ascendancy, Burgundy lost its Middlesea coast to Vascony. Burgundy managed to wrest the territory of Provence back from Ascendant Vascony in 1494. This would however be a very temporary state of affairs: the region seceded with the 1497–99 War of Provincial Independence, ending in Burgundy's defeat at the Battle of Margès.

No longer having any coastal territory, Burgundy weathered the Second Great Dying, which began in 1519, comparatively well; the principal vector of plague transmission was via naval trade. This relative stability may be related to the kingdom's (unusually late for the region) formal retention of the feudal system until the dawn of the seventeenth century.

The title of King of Burgundy was dissolved after severe losses to neighbouring Bavarn in the Blue Trans-Willem War of the late seventeenth century. The former capital Geneva became a subordinate city in the Duchy of Far Suebia.

A polity named Burgundy was formed once more (now without a monarch) in the nineteenth century, as part of the diplomatic process leading to the formation of the Drengot Collusion.

76.2: caum "piece"

caum /kom/ [kom]
- (obsolete) prayer, psalm, canticle, a religious text when set to music;
- hymn, any song of praise or worship;
- (more broadly) song, piece of music, an individual work of musical expression with or without lyrics;
- poem, artwork, piece, any artistic creation and especially one which is written;
- article, story, report, piece of nonfiction writing as might be published in the press;
- (mesh) post, any original work (prototypically writing) published to the mesh

Etymology: disputed. Semantically it should derive from Latin carmen "poem, incantation, prayer", but the phonological development is troublesome. Vocalisatio of /r > u/ is otherwise only attested in the presence of following /r̩/, as in Maucr "Wednesday" < *Marcre < Mercuriī; this has led some scholars to postulate an Insular Latin variant *carmus, carmera, but this is unattested.

Reanalysis of the plural carmina as a feminine singular is, however, not out of the question. One might then suppose that dissimilation produced *carmira, but again this is unattested.

The word has seen significant semantic bleaching over time; the sense "poem" is first seen in the fifteen century, the sense "article" in the eighteenth, and the sense "(mesh)post" in the late twentieth.

Jo componoy l'oc caum por cinq baðr.
/ʒo ˌkɔm.poˈnɔj lɔk kom pɔr tsɪnk ˈba.ðr̩/
[ʝʊ ˌkɔm.pʊˈnɔj lɔ kom pɔː tsɪŋk ˈba.ðɐ]
1s compose-pst def-s.px piece for five instrument
I arranged this piece for five musicians.

##

76.5: The Workshop Period

The Workshop period, or the Global Workshop, refers to the middle decades of the nineteenth century. It is characterised by the rapid expansion and development of industry across the world. Usual historiography places the Workshop period between the Long Peace and the Good Game.

The Workshop period brought prosperity to parts of Europe which had been devastated by the Second German War of the 1820s, such as the Riverine Cities.

The impact of the Workshop period can be seen in artistic trends, with the shift away from voidtales and towards (on the one hand) realistic portrayals of the industrial working class and (on the other) optimistic speculation on future material advancements.

The guild VS (Vindrons Sairzaus), which sold the first widely-sold aphlox wine, would in this period expand its scope to other high-pressure and sealing components in manufacture, securing a very profitable niche.

The late Workshop period saw many barrick breakthroughs, concentrated in eastern Europe and Lower Mendeva.

The Drengot Collusion arose among the French polities of this period. The contemporaneous New Urban Mesh (including London and Axbane, among others) was subsumed by—or took control of—the nascent Collusion.

Many items of vocabulary were innovated in the Workshop period, including recoil "manufacture", underwrit "logo", counterzoic "anti-microbial" and retainer "IUD".

References
Albic Medicine in the Workshop Decades, a series of volumes by Dr Harold Westcamp published by the Conster Health Edifice, funded by the Markland Ministry for Health.

77.2: egreir "disembark"

- disembark, get off, go ashore, to leave a vehicle;
- step out, to exit a place on foot;

##

77.5: Continents and Conjugality

The Novomund, also called the New World, refers to the lands to the west of the Atlantic Ocean. Inhabited for over a myriad years, the history of these lands comes together with that of the Vetomund following the Novomundine Landfall of 1471.

The Novomund is composed of the two great landmasses of Mendeva and Cappatia [North and South America], along with over a dozen major islands (such as Brasil [Newfoundland] and Cocain [Cuba]) and innumerable lesser ones.

Many crops now cultivated worldwide were first farmed in the Novomund, including shadome fruit, tartover, shockle and mikecorn [tomatoes, potatoes, chocolate and maize]. Products such as coshow [rubber] and kistmaw [tobacco] also derive from plants native to the Novomund.

---

The Household Renovation of the late nineteenth century was an attitudinal shift towards non-traditional familial structures, the institution of marriage, and the social role of children.

It was prefigured by the deemphasis of religion in government in those countries party to the 1850 Laic Declarations of Belgrade, as well as contraceptive medical innovations of the time like coshow bed-sleeves [latex condoms] and stauron retainers [IUDs].

The popularity of the masquira [~heist/vigilante] literary genre, with its hidden identities and lampooning of upper-class mores, is usually understood to have come hand in hand with the Household Renovation (not to mention the enduring popularity of masquira in tovarick [queer] circles).

Early embracers of the Household Renovation included Britain, the Riverine Cities and New Leudong [a polity in south-eastern Australia]; the ethos would spread (especially via Britain's cultural cachet in Gulf Mendeva) elsewhere over the subsequent decades.

excerpt in translation from the condensed study materials for the New Vithor course Concurrence History of the 16th Century: Death, Ships and the Movement of the Heavens.

L'ustol es y model feudal stimar defonct cos enter posc 1550 N, ben toð cas deur polity insoler com Borgogn eð Avry.

For example, Borland under Joseph III lost over forty myriad people, one-seventh of its population;

sarvaç (deja a pognt d'exeunt fair) er abolið cas ley d'an 1564 N, ma ant l'ig hour yent i n'er existant veraçter sull'istr tras un generation.
serfdom (already on its last legs) was legally abolished in 1564 N, but by that point it had not de facto existed on the island for a generation.

78.2: scaðr "square"

scaðr /ˈxa.ðr̩/ [ˈxa.ðɐ]
- square, a plane figure with four sides of equal length and four right-angled corners;
- square number, a number that can be expressed as the product of some number by itself;
- rack, frame, shelving, a wood or metal grid in which one can store things;
adj.
- right-angled, forming an angle of 90 degrees;
- aligned, not crooked or leaning;
- tidy, having everything in its expected position

Etymology: from Old Boral iscaðre, iscarre, carre "square", from Vulgar Latin (ex)quadra "square", variant form of post-Classical quadrus "square". Adjectival usage is attested from as early as the eleventh century.

Me stou for savir ig nos seim scaðr den.
/me stu fɔr saˈvɪr aj nɔz sim ˈxa.ðr̩ dɛn/
[me stu fɔː sɐˈvɪː‿ʀaj nʊˈsim ˈxa.ðɐ dɛn]
1s.obl want only know-inf comp 1p be.sbj-1p aligned thereof
I want to know we're on the same page.

78.3: joivr "frost"

joivr /ˈʒɔj.vr̩/ [ˈʝɔj.vɐ]
- frost, rime, cover of ice crystals on objects that are exposed to the air analogous to dew;
- cold, cold weather, conditions below the freezing point of water when frost is liable to form;
- (telecommunications) noise, static, any part of a signal that reduces the fidelity of its transmission

Etymology: descendant of Old Boral givre, guivre "frost", borrowed from Old French and thought to originate in a Frankish form like gibara cognate with Willem gever "saliva".

Nos targoim y fenestr de joivr ne spaiðant.

78.4: dijarbr "decent"

dijarbr /diˈʒar.br̩/ [dɪˈʝɑː.bɐ]
- decent, acceptable, fine, OK, of a sufficiently-high quality but not particularly impressive;
- manageable, doable, feasible, not daunting in scope or difficulty;
- wieldy, handy, able to be handled with grace while not being overly heavy or awkwardly shaped
- (rare) digestible, edible, capable of being eaten and digested

Etymology: adjectival derivation from dijarr "to bear, cope with, deal with, stomach". This verb descends from Middle Boral dijarr "parse, classify, sort out; digest, stomach", a borrowing from Latin dīgerō "I disseminate, disperse, arrange" altered by analogy with now-archaic verb enjarr "to eat" < ingerō "I carry in, pile up".

Servið son quelt dijarbr all'ig tarn.
/sɛrˈvɪθ sɔn kwɛlt diˈʒar.br̩ aˈlaj tarn/
[sɪːˈvɪh sɔŋ kwɛlt dɪˈʝɑːb‿ʀɐˈlaj tɑːn]
serve-p.pst be.3p dinner decent at-def=s.dt inn
They do a decent dinner at that inn.

##

78.5: The Good Game period

The Good Game period refers to the final decades of the nineteenth century, especially when construed as a time of rising global powers formed of alliances and meshes of trade and technology binding the world together. It conventionally follows the Global Workshop period of spreading industry and ends with the outbreak of the Millstone War.

The same Laic Declarations of Belgrade in 1850 which prefigured the social and moral shifts of the Household Renovation also set the stage for the political realignment of the Good Game decades, which new alliances between states that could not have countenanced such ties even a generation earlier.

This period sees the establishment of several alliance-federacies that would go on to define the geopolitics of the twentieth century, such as the Drengot Collusion in north-western Europe (whose expansion concluded in 1894 with the accession of Borland).

The perception of the Good Game period as a time of glamorous espionage and political machinations behind closed doors is not entirely deserved—compare the popular perception (via books and film) of the 1887 Desarden affair involving a London ambassador and the king of Nackon Day with the tawdrier reality. Nevertheless, the period has cemented itself as a popular setting for spycraft and masquira stories.

The kevler romance arose as a distinct subgenre of masquira in this period, featuring elaborate plans and schemes usually aiming to steal some priceless item.

The 1880s saw a brief fad for 'Morrack fashion' in countries across Europe and the Novomund, in areas such as dress, architecture and food. There was, for example, a trend of incorporating exposed stonework draped in tapestry and curtains in contemporary buildings.

Scientific and technological advances of the Good Game period include discovering other galaxies, determining the normal speed, the first household mesh-linked tachygraphs, and stauron retainers.

79.1: The Welsh Viking

excerpt in translation from scitation questions in the January 2014 Tremonnow Open School concurrence history course 844–900: Early Dane Kingdom-Building across the Northwestern Isles.

(i) Deut ag ci havan stapr e ci instançment dannesc entr Dublin e Yorvic, ben ceter, aye y principaltað ne Guineð meyon suffignt por primaltað sur Poves condensar? Souvin ne soumoin y porçonment de Mondovel stant concordað entr Guineð e Sodric, oc stant tesmognað cos parey ny chronic d'Oltogn e de Carleul.

Include reference to the partition of Mondwell [Anglesey] agreed between Wynneth and Sodrick, as mentioned in both the Ulstre and Carlile chronicles.

(ii) Dell'asc vecuð d'Owain ap Blethen—luy rent legender com Ovan de Jolliad, l'amig stival eð enmig yemal por y çaucr arthuric—cal poum nos savir de mout alcot segr cambresc de nascenç ern droughant de gazou viking tandic y fragossau dannesc denen kintaðessem con lorry vecintað?
(ii) What can the life of Owain ap Blethen—rendered into legend as Owen of Jolliad, sometime-friend sometime-foe of the Arthurians—tell us about the extent to which Welsh-born men participated in viking raids as the Dane settlements became more enmeshed with their vicinities?

(iii) Descreyað ant detagl toll'actour connuð abord dy Reconcarnç a Castr d'an 887 N, tan con y contingent politic yon cascun parmy se troven eç ayent menað vars y faction idiosyncras y battagl parlocant.
(iii) Describe in detail the known actors party to the Reconquest of Chestre in 887 N, along with the political context each found themselves in which led to the idiosyncratic alliances on either side of the battle.

79.2: jagottað "jagged"

jagottað /ˌʒa.gɔˈtaθ/ [ˌʝa.gʊˈtah]
- jagged, notched, serrated, rough, being unevenly cut or having a similar texture to something so cut;
- craggy, rugged, (of landscape) characterised by unpredictable changes in elevation;
- abrasive, harsh, disagreeable, being overly agressive in one's manner and causing irritation

Etymology: past participle of jagottar "to notch, serrate", from noun jagot "notch, snag, sharp projection", of uncertain origin. Likely a diminutive of a form *jac, jag, which must be related somehow to the synonymous jag in Merch—the direction of borrowing is however unclear since the Merch is only attested from the fifteenth century. Attempts have been made to connect the words to Borland English çagge "shrub" but the semantics are doubtful.

Orruð l'occijon commettr con pujoncr jagottað.
/ɔˈrɪθ ˌlɔk.siˈʒɔn kɔˈmɛ.tr̩ kɔn piˈʒɔn.kr̩ ˌʒa.gɔˈtaθ/

seem def=murder commit-inf with dagger jagged

79.4: cay seg a veðerrem "elephant in the room"

cay seg a veðerrem /ke sij a veˈðɛ.rɛm/ [ke sij a vɪˈðɛ.ʀɐm]
- (int.)  tactful acknowledgement of a lie or secret everyone knows about but nobody will call out;
- (n., usually hyphenated) elephant in the room, such a lie or secret

Etymology: idiom first attested in this form in the late eighteenth century but having many variants beforehand; literally "it takes six (months) for the eldest (child)". This refers to a couple's first child being born only six months after the wedding, a situation where it is clear to everyone what happened but to mention it explicitly would be impolite.

Quippe alcun hom nil y budr de cay-seg-a-veðerrem svoccar.
/kwɪˈpe alˈkɪn ɔm nɪl i ˈbi.dr̩ de keˌsi.ja.veˈðɛ.rɛm svɔˈkar/
[kwɪˈpe ˌa.gɪˈnɔm nɪl i ˈbi.dɐ de kɪˌsi.jɐ.vɪˈðɛ.ʀɐm zvʊˈkɑː]
surely no person won't def harbinger of elephant.in.the.room bring.up-inf
Surely nobody will mention the looming elephant in the room.

##

79.5: Voidtale

Voidtale (Borlish trevogt /treˈvɔjt/, portmanteau of trevold "novel" and vogt "outer space") is a subgenre of parachthon romance which focuses on voyages through outer space visiting alien worlds.

The genre was pioneered by Saxon author Elsebeth Sneider with her 1795 work Through a Black Mirror, which sparked a three-decade long fashion for the subject known as the "voidtale craze". This first period is characterised by a strongly pre-empirical understanding of conditions on other worlds: no particular attention is paid to the details of breathable air or bearable gravity, and each bustling planet is peopled by very human societies. Indeed, more than anything else these stories resemble the "geoscopic voyage" tales of the previous century, which depict sailors exploring unknown corners of the Earth and encountering the peoples there.

The voidtale craze is usually said to end with the Second German War in the 1820s, although later works like Narayanan's landscapes (which portray barren and inhospitable surfaces of the other planets orbiting the Sun) are generally counted as part of the same tradition.

It has been claimed that the voidtale craze inculcated an enthusiasm for astronomy in its generation, and contributed to the cosmic discoveries of the mid-nineteenth century—including the discoveries of the planet Janus and the speed of light.

References

New Skies, Old Stories, 1980 work written by Simon d'Estiala and published by Prindor Marsillès

80.1: Uneventful Alburg

excerpt in translation from the collected correspondence of Absolon Mortenszen, playwright and commentator in Alburg, Denmark.

J'ay spien vos seyað fort parsanað des y mephit dont scavoist vos ne vossy pistol derran;
I hope you are well recovered from the ague of which you spoke in your last missive;

Me stou bogr vos soumonir a cossirar y citað salir fin a fis sera y prepondranç a commarç.
I need not remind you to consider leaving the city until the bulk of the trading has ended.

Inconnuð tojorn es cal contamen foran posn marcant galar, com sceus my granpaðr tesmognar.
One never knows what foreign ills merchants may bring, as my grandfather could have attested.

Y bourg reman cojan equal des vossy sgaranç com sceye pre nossy acconnosc, vos plaç d'oïr.
The town remains as dull since you departed as it was before we met, you will be pleased to hear.

Ja galað, y casatabr dijarbr sull'ig rif meðes surcay issugtessem posc toð gent de nis nell'oc bourg ablegar;
In point of fact, even the decent lodging-house on the strand is poorer for having banned all the interesting people in town;

parcanç ig il me parmet jug d'entrar es mal me desconent, malgrað jo vil toð mod me sarvir dy ci sigt la tandic possibr.
perhaps it speaks poorly of me that they yet allow me entrance, though I will at least avail myself of the views while I can.

80.2: bojar "move"

bojar /boˈʒar/ [bʊˈʝɑː]
- move, shift, bump, budge, to cause to be displaced from a position;
- dislodge, free, extricate, to remove from a position in which something was firmly set
- reconsider, to change one's mind

Etymology: from Old Boral bojar "move, shift", originally in both intransitive (it moved) and transitive (I moved it) use but by the Middle Boral period only in the latter. This is a borrowing from synonymous Old French bougier, from Vulgar Latin bullicō "I boil, bubble up", a frequentative from bulliō (whence Borlish boglir "to boil").

My granmaðr noloy se bojar cas scadom pascr.

My gran wouldn't reconsider eating tomatoes.

80.3: exeunt fair "go away"

exeunt fair /ɛkˈsawnt fer/ [ɪgˈzawnt fɛː]
- go away, leave, depart, exit, to go out from a place or situation;

80.4: rif "riverbank"

rif /rɪf/ [ʀɪf]
- bank, riverbank, the area along the sides of a river or stream;
- shore, seashore, strand, a stretch of coastline (especially when stony as opposed to sandy);
- beachfront, seaside, promenade, terrace, esplanade, a walkway between land and sea often lined with shops

Etymology: uncomplicated descendant via Old Boral rif from Latin rīpa "riverbank, seashore". By the Middle Boral period we see a clear semantic separation between sandy play "beach, bay" and stony rif, although some place names like Volandry (from dialect volan "gull" and rif "beach") fail to fit this dichotomy.

Nos erau flannant lonc y rif, ig carnt yon beller acatar.
/nɔz eˈro flaˈnant lɔnk i rɪf | aj ˈka.rn̩t jɔn bɛˈlɛr ˌa.kaˈtar/
[ˌno.zɪˈʀo flɐˈnan lɔŋk i ʀɪf | aj ˈka.ʀɐnt jɔn bɪˈlɛː‿ʀɐkˈtɑː]
1p ipf-1p stroll-p.prs along def bank | s.dt seek-p.prs where sweet buy-inf
We were walking down the strand, looking to buy sweets.

80.5: Tavancy

Tavancy (Merch /təˈvan.səi/, Run'allo [Quechua] Tawanden /taˈwan.dɛn/), formerly the Tavancine Empire, is a political in western Cappatia [South America] occupying the coast between the Isthmus [of Panama] to the north and Maboutian [~Chilean] lands to the south.
Toponymy

The name Tavancy (Latin Tavantia) is a back-formation from the adjective Tavancine (Latin tavantīnus). This comes from the earliest Latin name imperium tavantīnum first attested in the sixteenth century, which was borrowed via Morrove [Morrocan] Arabic as a somewhat-mistaken partial calque from the Run'allo tawantin-suyu "the quartet of provinces".
History

The first Vetomundine people to document the Tavancine Empire were Morrack [Morroco] traders with the New World Company (شركة العالم الجديد), who had already begun dealing with Arcabil [Caribbean] peoples and with Mashick [the Aztec Empire]. Through the sixteenth century several wayports along the west Cappatian coastline were established by said traders, some of which would grow into substantial staddomain [~export colony] settlements.

The death of Tavancine Emperor Cariwasari in 1660 is suspected to have been an assassination carried out on Morrack orders, purportedly to allow for more profitable trade in silver—Morrack was at the time running low on funds to support their ongoing wars in Vascony and Libya.

In the early 1930s, a collaboration between alchemists at the Branwen Sanatory in New Leudong and the University of Rimack in Tavancy led to the discovery of cozebdo-diamaschal benjamine [ibuprofen] (in pill form familiarly called "CD" or, in Markland, "Tommy pills") as an effective hebetant [painkiller] without significant adversions [side effects].

81.2: ajoutaçar "be fun"

ajoutaçar /ˌa.ʒu.taˈtsar/ [ˌa.ʝʊ.tɐˈtsɑː]

    be fun, entertain, divert, engage, to be interesting in an enjoyable way;
    charm, please, delight, to receive pleasure or satisfaction from something

Etymology: eighteenth-century verbal derivation from ajoutaç "gratification, enjoyment, satisfaction", itself derived from ajoutar "gratify, help out, please" with the somewhat-pejorative or diminishing suffix -aç (from Latin -āceus "shaped like"). This root verb descends via Old Boral aioftar from post-Classical Latin adiuvitō "I help out, assist, am useful", from earlier synonymous adiuvō with a frequentative derivation.

    Y fabr nou scenað t'ajoutaç ou?
    /i ˈfabr̩ nu xeˈnaθ ˌta.ʒuˈtats u/
    [i ˈfa.bɐ nu çɪˈnah ˌta.ʝʊˈtas u]
    def play new stage-p.pst 2s=be.fun q
    Do you think the new play's fun?

81.3: flaut "boating"

flaut /flot/ [flot]

    boating, sailing, the activity of going out onto water in a vessel;
    fleet, armada, a collection of sea-going or river-going vessels

Etymology: direct descendant from Old Boral flaut "fleet, group of ships", a borrowing from Old English flēot "ship, group of ships" (related to float).

    Il faun flaut casc juglot.
    /ɪl fon flot kax ʒajˈlɔt/
    [ɪl fon flot kax ʝɐjˈlɔt]
    3p do-3p boating each July
    They go boating each July.

81.4: vis "in fact"

vis /vɪz/ [vɪz]

    evidently, of course, manifestly, as you know, used to introduce information which one feels is sufficiently obvious that it should have come up by now;
    in fact, actually, in reality, indeed, used to introduce a statement which corrects some part of a previous understanding;
    it transpires, it turns out, apparently, used to introduce surprising new information

Etymology: extracted in the late Middle Boral period from expressions like vis es… "it is seen that…", as the past participle of veir "to see" < Latin videō "I see". Speculation that it is instead a retention of Old Boral ivis "sure, certain", a borrowing from synonymous Old English gewiss, is unsupported by any intermediate attestations (though cf modern Merch awice /əˈwəis/ "indeed, yes").

The word is often found in the collocation Or vis… "Well, actually…", especially when it is used at the start of sentences.

    Vis no som nos jamay eið a Duncloð.
    /vɪz no sɔm nɔz ʒaˈme iθ a dɪnˈklɔθ/
    [vɪz nʊˈsɔnnʊz ʝɐˈme iθ a dɪŋˈklɔθ]
    in.fact neg be.1p 1p never go-p.pst to Dunclothe
    We've actually never been to Dunclothe.

##

81.5: Madray

Madray is a polity in the southeast of India governed from the city of the same name [Madurai].

The British ship Phœbos in the early sixteenth century stopped at the port of Romeswarm [Rameswaram] in Madray on its geoscopic voyage around Africa and on to Borune [Borneo] (where it would meet the Morrack [Moroccan] ship Cynthia travelling in the other direction).

The death of King Rahulamathavan in 1735 is thought to have been due to an early outbreak of pennackit dysentery [cholera] (although global outbreaks of the disease would not begin in earnest until 1753).

As part of the general Democratic Wars period in the mid-eighteenth century, many states quarrelled for control over parts of India, including Madray. Both relatively nearby powers like China and distant trade interests like Britain became embroiled.

The eighteenth century also saw many technological developments out of this region. For example, the use of pedal holes in musical instruments was pioneered by the peria nadaswarm (the apex of arms races to widen pitch ranges and increase volume) which would influence instruments like the torriot into their modern forms.

The voidtale craze begun by Elsebeth Sneider in 1795 reached as far as Madray; the renowned landscapist Narayanan is especially remembered for his series of works depicting the planets from their surfaces.

82.1: Dane-ruled York

Naðusc sta l'oc un issent incoïbr de commouð lonc y tarm cambresc;

durant meðes l'epoc paçous stendiscent a comparaçon, Theodoric l'Auvast eð Owain de Brochwel y dou aurn jug centuir corrovað magn surfaint por y Lign Severn defendr.

82.2: vogt dy foscur "dead of night"

vogt dy foscur /vɔjt di foˈxɪr/ [vɔjt dɪ fʊˈxɪː]
- pitch blackness, inky blackness, a particularly deep darkness;
- dead of night, small hours, witching hour, the part of the night conceived of as the darkest and farthest from day

Etymology: idiom first attested in the poetry of 15C writer Drominir, literally "emptiness of darkness". The noun vogt descends from Vulgar Latin *vocitus "empty", a variant of the synonymous vacuus in Classical Latin. The noun foscur is a noun derivative of adjective fosc "dark" which descends from Latin fuscus "dimly lit, black".

Y lamp se quïsceu, y coloir augtant ne vogt dy foscur.
/i lamp se ˌkwaj.iˈxaw | i koˈlɔjr ojˈtant ne vɔjt di foˈxɪr/
[i lamp sɪ ˌkwa.jɪˈxaw | i kʊˈlɔjɐ‿ʁʊjˈtan nɪ vɔjt dɪ fʊˈxɪː]
def light rfl turn.off-pst | def hall send-p.pst in void of-def darkness
The light went out, plunging the hall into darkness.

82.3: cas sar "online"

cas sar /kaz sar/ [kɐsˈsɑː]
- online, available over or accessed via the Internet;
- cyber-, pertaining to the Internet or to activities conducted on the subject of or via the Internet

Etymology: phrase first attested in the 1980s, from the preposition cas "pertaining to, on the subject of, at the home of, with respect to, when it comes to" (via Old Boral cas from Latin casa "house") and the noun sar "fishnet, mesh, network" (from the synonmous Vask). The noun sar in this usage ("the Internet") is shortened from the phrase sar pistol "lit. the message mesh", itself translating Roun French mail pistre /maʒ piːtə/ in the same sense. This was first used in 1968 work of fiction Starsail, by Ashford Pasquier.

Nos som gran sviðour a conemir cas sar.
/nɔz sɔm gran sviˈður a ˌko.neˈmɪr kaz sar/
[nʊˈsɔm gʀan zvɪˈðʊː‿ʀa ˌko.niˈmɪː kɐsˈsɑː]
1p be.1p big fan at shop-inf wrt mesh
We're big fans of online shopping.

82.4: scenar "stage"

scenar /xeˈnar/ [çɪˈnɑː]
- stage, put on, produce, perform, to put together a theatrical production as an acting troupe;
- orchestrate, undertake, arrange, direct, carry out, to plan and go through with some scheme or undertaking with many moving parts

Etymology: Middle Boral verbal derivation from scen "(theatre) stage; platform, soapbox" (formerly sometimes re-classicised as scæn), borrowed from Latin scæna "stage, scenery" from Ancient Greek σκηνή "tent, stage". In metaphorical use seen from the eighteenth century.

The weavers have staged a walkout.

##

82.5: London

London (Borlish /ˈlɔn.dr̩/) is a city and polity on the island of Albion. The city is downstream on the River Tames, and the polity comprises much of the Tames' watershed. It is bordered to the north by Markland, the south by Kent, and the west by Britain.

History
London was established by the Romans shortly after their invasion around 50 N, named from a Kelt placename referring to the local floodplain.

After time as a secondary city in Albion, London became the imperial capital of the region once more during the Second Tetrarchy as part of the First Drengot Empire.

The First Burning of London took place in 1290; at least 400 people were killed in the ensuing week-long disaster. This was one of several conflagrations in the first half of the second millennium, many due to the city being perennially conquered from the north or south.

The Democratic Wars of the mid-eighteenth century saw London finally gain lasting independence from its neighbours in 1748 under Queen Margaret, who could trace her ancestry to the royal families of both Markland and Kent. The office of Lord Mayor remained politically powerful enough to rival that of the new monarch, however.

London is home to the New Lyceum, a preeminent research university established in the late eighteenth century.

Seventy-fifth anniversary celebrations in 1823 saw significant infrastructural investments in the region, with a great deal of building along the south bank of the Tames.

London's population grew rapidly during the Global Workshop period of the mid-nineteenth century. It became a lead member of the New Urban Mesh of several major cities in the region, and spearheaded the Mesh's takeover of (or submission into) the larger Drengot Collusion.

The independent polity of London has been long associated with spycraft, with events like the 1887 Desarden Affair (involving the London ambassador to Nackon Day) and the many Londoners in the Roun Red House (the intelligence centre for the Drengot Collusion) implicated in the Furore of 1961 cementing this image in the popular imagination.

Places
Sowbruck, a borough south of the Tames
Ebbasham, a minor spa town
People
Monarchs
Matthew Drengot (fl. 1120), younger brother of then Drengot Emperor Roger II; Matthew ruled the northern half of the Empire in his brother's name
Margaret (fl. 1748), first ruler of an independent London
Other
Clarissa Bellamy (fl. 1920), author of many lovetales and the parachthon work A Door, Once Opened
Heleth Bellamy (fl. 1920), researcher at the New Lyceum specialising in the Democratic Wars
Gunna Despath (fl. 1920), translator who was born Gonnilt Dispað in Borland

83.3: eir sauf a "all but"

##

83.5: Loveless Lepzi

Lepzi is the capital city of Saxony, located on the Bleak Alstre.

History
Lepzi first acted as political centre for the First Kingdom of Saxony, very briefly just prior to its collapse at the close of the thirteenth century. The Houghbrocken dynasty ruled from there for some years before being removed to Magdeburg when the house was reduced to the four-year-old Marksman Baldur.

With the conclusion of the First German War in 1770, Saxony was ascendant and controlled more territory than it had at any point in its history. Lepzi was subject to attendant early urbanisation and trebled in population in just fifty years. It was one of the vanguards of the Global Workshop period, exploiting vast amounts of locally-mined coal power.

The Blue Marian Society, which agitated for inheritance and suffrage law reforms, was founded in the nineteenth century in Lepzi.

People
Albert Siegert (fl. 1744), owner of a leatherworking and cobbling industry based in Lepzi
Elsebeth Sneider (m. 1772, d. ~1830), author and originator of the voidtale craze with her 1795 work Through a Black Mirror
Otto Sneider (m. 1772), scholar at the Leipzi Sterncundhaus

---

Rachel Desselut (fl. 1743) was a French philosopher. She is best remembered for her 1743 work The Parable of the Mute Bookbinder, which discusses problems of infinite regression and of identity.

She was born to Maurice Desselut, eighth Lord Bouvoin, who was a writer and explorer. Fittingly he was also an infamous libertine (the house name Desselut deriving from an Old French word meaning dissolute, philandering).

She was the first to lay out in our modern terms the philosophical distinction between Form and Method, which allows an entity to self-replicate (constructing its Form from the Method's instructions, then transcribing the Method blindly). These concepts would go on to be vital in the study of methodics and to general augrimmer practice.

Desselut inferred from her work the existence of a vital language, now known to be composed of heredian acid.

84.4: jagat "setting"

jagat /ʒaˈgat/ [ʝɐˈgat]

84.5: Lower Mendeva

Lower Mendeva (Borlish Mendeva Bassem /ˌmɛn.deˈva ˈba.sɛm/) is a geographical region comprising the southern section of the continent of Mendeva, located west of the Mendevan Gulf. The term sometimes also includes the islands of the Arcabil, which are located within said Gulf.

Contact between Lower Mendeva and the Vetomund began in the late fifteenth century with merchant ships from the Morrack New World Company (established by Malik Munir al-Hamdawi in 1463). In turn, traders therefrom encountered the peoples of the Arcabil, the Mashick Empire in Lower Mendeva, and further south the Tavancine Empire in Cappatia.

The region is predominated by the polity of Mashick, which stretches from coast to coast and so far north as to border Mivock in the west and Taisha in the east.

Many barrick innovations of the late Workshop period came out of Lower Mendeva, likely due to practical concerns around the rapid spread of wired post (there being little previous adoption of the flag-lamp steeplemesh in the region to displace).

By the late twentieth century, this region had become major exporters of foods such as mause and amback.

Many trade goods originated in Lower Mendeva, including billrod dye, shockle, shadome and tashban.

85.1: The Jacobin Fraternity

excerpt in translation from Y Gið Scos por Ausbagn (The Secret Guide to Axbane), sold for 1⍚ in the Calder Museum of Health's leavingstore.

Benoçabr por seucq historic (ben toð cas por y cromn dy bon leyour!) son l'Orn a Sagnt Jagm, ant nom dont costroit er y Monastir Peninsoler nossy citað surplombant.
More relevant to history (or at least to the good reader's moneypurse!) are the Order of Saint James, in whose name was built the Peninsular Monastery which overlooks the city.

Fondað ny siecr deghem sou y patronisment de Domn Amegl a Brug, l'orn ern envoluð par un smout pouvlancer contr Geoffry II eð ern forçað a enfugr vars Istr Boral d'an 1067.
Founded in the tenth century under the patronage of Amelia of Bruges, they were implicated in a popular uprising against Geoffry II and forced to flee to Borland in 1067.

Oy es l'Orn (sy nom modern dignant, y Fraterntað Jagovin) cos majortaðer reconnuð por sell'yeustmandry Jaibos e por bempart dell'eiðel atorn dy citað posseyent, ig inclus y loy d'un parmy y ci bagn roman antic yon Ausbagn recief sy nom.
Today the Order (with its modern name, the Jacobin Fraternity) is in the main known for its Jaibos breweries and for owning much of the land around the city, including the site of one of the ancient Roman bathhouses for which Axbane is named.

85.4: yeustman "brewer"

- brewer, someone whose occupation is to prepare alcoholic beverages like beer
- inciter, firebrand, rabble-rouser, someone who instigates unrest or other trouble

##

85.5: Laic Declarations

The Laic Declarations were a series of diplomatic documents produced by an international committee of delegations from several dozen polities in Belgrade in 1850. These documents outlined procedures for uncoupling established religions from administrative state functions, and the legal status of people with minority faiths.

At this time, Belgrade was one of the Riverine Cities, an alliance-federacy of small independent states along the Danaw River and its tributaries. These cities had risen from the ashes of the Kingdom of the Danaw, which had collapsed in spectacular fashion after the Second German War of the 1820s. As such, Belgrade was an early hotbed of new religious and legal thinking, with a renowned Promethean club associated with the Deviance movement and a semi-public tovarick community.

Notable non-signatories of the Declarations included New Provence (at the time probably the most Vetomund-oriented polity in Mendeva) and Persia.

In some respects the Declarations were prefigured by the waning of the censorious and moralistic Modest Arrangement. They laid the groundwork for the Household Renovation of the late nineteenth century, which comprised further shifts in social attitudes around family and marriage. The fact of such major international collaboration in writing the Declarations also prefigured the dawn of the subsequent decades' Good Game period, characterised by alliances and espionage.

Laic adoption would go on to spread globally; for example, in Gulf Mendeva the persistent social prestige of Britain is thought by some to have expedited the contemporary social changes of the region.

The hundred-and-twentieth anniversary of the Laic Declarations was celebrated in academia with the Long Future project, including the synchronised publication of dozens of popular works chronicling the Declarations' origins, course and aftermath.

References

Conjugation, Operation e Diabolica in Musica: The Early Deviance Movement, 1970 work by Borlish popular historian Catrin Veçount

The Deviance Incorporation of Folk Tales, 1970 sociological work by Dr Tanasio Capretti

##

86.1: Letter to the Editor

excerpt in translation from the collected correspondence of Michæl Bervisson (17th June 1799–12th January 1849), political historian and social reformist. This exceprt is from a letter to his editors concerning proposed alterations to his magnum opus Roma Æternal: Eç Vascel a These (An Eternal Rome: Ships of Theseus).

Dovem, m'ajoutabr vel improbation redirigir tan com sera parcanç nos prevenibr (cos particuler l'un bougr aquilin nolent my plum teurfiar) eð y ci argument refutar cos direct ny scrit.
Second, I would like to divert as much criticism as we might possibly anticipate (in particular one aquiline fellow who shall not sully my quill) and rebut those arguments directly in the text.

Nell'oc spien, posseu nos y capparol Caf Jammel prolongar por caglou irrayar a comoscon l'Empir Constant drengoçan all'ovest eð y Roman malchassian all'aust y dou issaroirn y Cligs (tras y siecr derran yon unið) por lorry pretension vars continuitað con Rom basfiar?
To this end, might we extend the chapter Twin Keys to emphasise the ways both the Drengotian Constant Empire to the west and the Malchassian Romans to the east used the Church (in the last century of its unity) to support their claims to continuity with Rome?

Jo vil aïr toð y fougl recas pre Reveglon, jo vos aiç.
I shall have written the requisite pages by Revillon, I assure you.

Vacilleð bogr pre respondr jug; Scholer Michæl Bervisson.
Do not hesitate to reply forthwith; Professor Michæl Bervisson.

##

86.2: improbar "disapprove of"

improbar /ˌɪm.proˈbar/ [ˌɪm.pʀʊˈbɑː]
- disapprove of, condemn, blame, to think badly of someone for their actions;
- criticise, critique, find fault with, censure, to enumerate things one disapproves of;
- scold, rebuke, reprove, tell off, to speak harshly to due to disapproval of someone's behaviour

Etymology: backformation from improbation "criticism, critique, condemnation, censure, blame, disapproval" (originally in legal use for "official reprimand for immorality"), from synonymous improbātiō in Latin.

Y maðr improbau sell'heir posc l'ig fo reuluð.
/i ˈmaðr̩ ˌɪm.proˈbo sɛˈlir pɔx laj fo rawˈlɪθ/
[i ˈmað‿ˌʀɪm.pʀʊˈbo sɪˈli.jɐ pɔx laj fo ʀɐwˈlɪh]
def mother scold-pst 3s.gen=son after def-s.dt be.pst come.back-p.pst
The mother scolded her son when he got back.

##

86.3: hapr "groceries"

hapr /ˈha.pr̩/ [ˈha.pɐ]
- groceries, produce, commodities, shop-bought foodstuffs and sometimes other household supplies;
- (loosely) shopping, recently-bought goods that are relatively inexpensive and characteristic of daily or weekly purchases;
- (strictly) fruit and veg, goods which may be bought at a greengrocer's

Etymology: direct descendant of Old Borlish happle "fruit, collectively; yield of a fruit harvest" (since displaced by native frugt < Latin frūctus), borrowed from Old English æppel "apple, fruit; sphere". The appearance of the initial h- is unexplained, but may be a hypercorrection; at this point /h/ was absent in native Borlish vocabulary and was being reintroduced via Germanic loanwords. Its modern sense is influenced by the compound haprman "greengrocer; (later) wholesaler".

J'eye sauf a aïr y hapr yent.
/ʒiˈje sof a ɛˈjɪr i ˈha.pr̩ ˈjɛnt/
[ʝɪˈje sof a ɪˈʝɪː‿ʀi ˈha.pɐ ˈʝɛnt]
1s=go-ipf except to have-inf def groceries get.p.pst
I'd nearly got all the groceries.

##

86.4: bougr "fellow"

bougr /ˈbu.gr̩/ [ˈbu.gɐ]
- fellow, chap, cove, bloke, guy, a man and especially an ordinary man of the street;
- (archaic) scoundrel, rogue, cad, blackguard, someone (usually a man) without honour or virtue

Etymology: only recently (early twentieth century) ameliorated from an insult, via Middle Boral bougr "villain, criminal, enemy; pagan, apostate, non-believer" from Old Boral bougre "heretic, evildoer". This reflects Medieval Latin Bulgarus "from Bulgaria", from Old Slavonic, and was probably introduced via contemporary French legal codes.

Un bougr insuet vien de laurar cas y haprman.
/ɪn ˈbu.gr̩ ɪnˈsjɛt vjen de loˈrar kaz i ˌha.pr̩ˈman/
[ɪm ˈbug‿ʀɪnˈsjɛt vʝɛn de lʊˈʀɑː kaz i ˌha.pɐˈman]
indf guy novice come of work-inf wrt def grocer
A new guy's just started at the grocer's.

##

86.5: Bavarn

Bavarn (Bóarn /ˈpoː.ɑːn/) is a centrally-located German polity of Europe. Among others, it borders Bohemia, Burgundy, Furlaine, Saxony, and Willemy.

History

During the Second Tetrarchy, the Kingdom of Bavarn was one of the two main players in the German Empire; the Empire was for some time ruled jointly by the Houghbrocken and Andex dynasties of Saxony and Bavarn respectively.

Thirteenth-century Bavarn was the epicentre of the Pauline Denunciations and the German Secession, leading to the establishment of the Augsburg See. The concomitant strife saw each vassal in Bavarn declare either for Rome or for Augsburg, in a powderkeg patchwork of allegiances that would collapse the Empire entirely. Bavarn itself would never regain as much Adriatic coast as it had enjoyed just prior to these events.

In the fifteenth century, Bavarn was embroiled in an extended series of conflicts with Burgundy. By this time it had also become a technological centre, with workshops developing entirely new glassmaking techniques.

Following the Blue Trans-Willem War of the late seventeenth century, Bavarn gained significant territory from the Kingdom of Burgundy, which subsequently dissolved. As result, then-king Frederick created the Duchy of Far Suebia, ruled from Burgundy's former capital Geneva.

In the eighteenth century, famine and a shortage of grain led to popular unrest that threatened to destabilise the state; the examples of Venise and Crovatia to the south demonstrated how badly things could go for the current regime.

The Second German War embroiled Bavarn, allied with (among others) Borland and the Northern Concert; a particularly significant event during this war was the disastrously mismanaged Battle of Hulm in 1821.

People

Monarchs

Conrad II (fl. 1120), who ruled from Regensburg

Adalmar (fl. c12), who was succeeded by Empress Katharina of Germany, the last ruler of a united Germany for over five hundred years

Frederick (fl. c17), who created the Duchy of Far Suebia

Nobility

Elias Villingen, second Duke of Far Suebia

Others

Wilhelm Bruez (fl. 1225), mayor of Augsburg

Paul von Burchardt (fl. 1225), writer of the Pauline Denunciations and instigator of the German Secession

Marian Siegert ~ Miller (1725-1756), illegitimate daughter of Elias Villingen

87.1: Deviance Exam

scitation questions in translation from the 2007 course Religion in the Second Millenium: Belief, Community and Division, set by the  University Faculty of Domain History.

(ii) Nell'istr Albion eð y reyaum Danau y dou temporane sceyen mendranç moulous cas religion eð y Cligs (e lorry gendr calscon) stan ligað cos starc accougl con autortað vecin. Desig l'eç qualtað commun ben ceter denoirn il amaçgat ðescant por cogtaçon Contr-Paradis?
(ii) In both Albion and the Danaw kingdom at this time there were significant religious minorities and the Church (of whichever stripe) was strongly associated with local authority. Was it these commonalities that made them fertile ground for Anti-Paradise thought?

(iii) Diçr alcot sta y resmargenç dell'Apprestanç Modest ne Spagn e Gaul com effeit dell'eç novel idea religious? Compareð y farvenç de cuidour modest ig inclus y Marchis de Caillat ben Diana Theodora Queiroz y pro-Marian Azur contr y philosoph de commouð preluïscent cosvour a Modest.
(iii) To what extent was the resurgence of the Modest Arrangement in Spain and Gaul in reaction to these new religious ideas? Compare the fervence of Modest thinkers like the Marquis de Caillat or proto-Blue Marian Diana Theodora Queiroz to the philosophers of earlier Modest-like movements.

(iv) Lonc vossell'opinion, cu scavoy (ben scavoirn) cos incaindessem l'edition incendier d'an 1799 Et Nous Amerons les Fux (E Nos Amareu ci Foy), un ouvr tarromour cas Theology a Desveyanç? Tesmogneð vossell'apponment con poið modern e temporane, e hasmeð dou ben may autr ouçon cas plausibiltað.
(iv) In your opinion, who is, or are, the most likely author(s) of the incendiary 1799 publication Et Nous Amerons les Fux (And We Will Love the Fire), a seminal work in Deviance Theology? Back up your theory with modern and contemporary sources, and contrast the likelihood of at least two other candidates.

87.2: teurfiar "sully"

teurfiar /tawrˈfjar/ [ˌta.wɐˈfjɑː]
- tar, blacken, to coat with tar or otherwise cause to become black;
- soil, stain, dirty, sully, to make something unclean or less pure (physically or morally);
- defame, tarnish, smear, besmirch, slander, to damage the reputation of

Etymology: Middle Boral derivation from noun teur "tar" with the suffix -fiar (< Latin -ficō) which forms verbs meaning "to make/render _". The noun teur is an Old Boral borrowing from Old English teoru "tar, resin, earwax", which is related to "tree". Almost immediately we see use of the verb, particularly in contemporary legal cases.

Follastr ne vrugheç a mell'accostur teurfiað.
/fɔˈlastr̩ ne vrajˈɛts a mɛˌla.kɔˈstɪr tawrˈfjaθ/
[fʊˈla.stɐ ne vʀɐˈʝɛs a mɪˌla.kʊˈstɪː ˌta.wɐˈfjah]
frolic in moorland have 1s.gen=clothes sully-p.pst
A moorland frolic has got my clothes dirty.

87.3: amaçgat ðescant "breeding ground"

amaçgat ðescant /ˌa.matsˈgat ðɛˈxant/ [ˌa.mɐsˈgat ðɪˈxan(t)]
- breeding ground, fertile ground, epicentre, a place seen as creating large quantities of a stated thing or type of person;
- hotbed, hotspot, an environment that is ideal for the growth or development of something

Etymology: collocation first attested in the late nineteenth century, literally a "nourishing nursery". The noun amaçgat "nursery, childcare" is borrowed via Mostara amazgato "flowerbed; nursery" from Morrove Arabic اَلْمَسْقَى‎ <al-másqa> "seedbed". The adjective is the present participle of ðescar "nourish, feed, fuel", which descends directly from Latin adēscō "I feed, fatten up".

Cay l'ig muncef un amaçgat ðescant vars huyaç.
/ke laj mɪnˈtsɛf ɪn ˌa.matsˈgat ðɛˈxant varz haˈjats/
[ke laj mɪnˈtsɛf ɪn ˌa.mɐsˈgat ðɪˈxan vɑːz hɐˈʝas]
fall def-s.dt district indf nursery feed-p.prs towards organised.crime
That district is a hotspot of mob activity.
