110.5: Redstone Chair

The Redstone Chair (Merch Redstoan Sete /ˈɾɛd.stoːn ˈsiːt/) was a wooden throne used by the monarchies of Albion during the medieval period.

History

The Redstone Chair was fashioned in the late tenth century around a block of sandstone; the name of the carpenter is forgotten. This block was (allegedly) the block upon which the Elved Marriage between a princess of Markland and the ruler of Dane Northumber was solemnised, ending hostilities between the two polities for almost a century.

Many subsequent monarchs of Albion, and especially of Markland and Northumber, were crowned on the Redstone Chair. During the Second Tetrarchy of the eleventh and twelfth centuries, most of the Drengot Emperors sat upon the Chair, and as such it was relocated to London. After the Empire's collapse, this placed the Chair in the politically turbulent region between Markland and Kent. Some historians have conjectured that the First Burning of London in 1290 was in part motivated by a plan to acquire the Chair; the responsible party varies in the telling.

According to the traditional account, it was a dispute over the location of the Redstone Chair which sparked the Wars of Fealty, which lasted almost fifty years over the turn of the sixteenth century and which embroiled almost all the polities of Albion.

Unfortunately, the Chair was lost in the tumult of the wars at some point between 1505 and 1509. Despite several searches and at least two hoaxes, the Chair has never been recovered, and the modern understanding of its appearance rests entirely on depictions in a few portraits and coronation scenes.

##

111.1: Early Santrafew

notes in translation on the subject of the New Provincial city of Santrafew [~Boston].

Innascment primal vars Santrafeu abrangen stemn a coval e hopr metal, ec vençað com troc contr pelur e vigt insuet.
Early imports into Santrafew included horse stocks and metal tools, traded in exchange for furs and new foodstuffs.

D'an 1590 Derek Nassow, y heriter imminent por y Ducað a Avosc ne Willemy, enfugheu tras mar vars Santrafeu deut a raçon inconnuð. 
In 1590 Derek Nassow, the heir apparent to the Duchy d'Avosche in Willemy, fled overseas to Santrafew for unclear reasons.

L'oc menau vars un scandal incendier cort soccoðent tras Europ ovester e cos particuler l'oç un de Rey David a Franç.
This led to an incendiary scandal that rocked courts across Western Europe and especially that of King David of France.

Y Travodað Becouin d'an 1621 motivau y comport cas ley entr Santrafeu eð y gent Mendevan ny region fin a pieç generaçon apres.
The 1621 Becouin Treaty outlined the legal relationship of Santrafew to the Mendevan peoples of the region for some generations.

Ne souc dy Gazou Breðonnesc a Santrafeu, yon rumorað er ig y Mastoisèt cos propr soloirn droug entarn, y travodað er broyað par mejan dy coyenç marcer effectuað de Bourgmer Alexandre fi Marco tan con sell'exiglment dy Mastoisèt a verb (eð autr tribu Mendevan a gest).
Following the British Sack of Santrafew, in which the Mastoisèt in particular were alleged to have collaborated, the treaty was broken by Mayor Alexandre fi Marco's embargo and ten-league exile of the Mastoisèt in particular (and other Mendevan groups in practice).

111.2: guy "guinea pig"

guy /gaj/ [gaj]
- guinea pig, mammal of the genus Cavia;
- (obsolete) fool, simpleton, a mindless person;
- (archaic) greenhorn, novice, beginner, an inexperienced person;
- dude, bloke, chap, a man and especially a younger man

111.3: bonaventur "happenstance"

bonaventur /ˌbo.na.vɛnˈtɪr/ [ˌbo.nɐ.vɪnˈtɪː]
- happenstance, accident, chance, coincidence, the chance or random quality of an event or circumstance

Etymology: a borrowing via a French language (in which the semantic shift occurred) from Lombard bunaventura "good fortune, luckiness".

Cayen orðenjanç theoretic plusour descovart par bonaventur.
/kɛˈjɛn ˌɔr.ðɪnˈʒants ˌθaw.reˈtɪk pliˈzur ˌdɛs.koˈvart par ˌbo.na.vɛnˈtɪr/
[kiˈʝɛn ˌɔː.ðɪnˈʒans ˌθaw.ʀɪˈtɪk plɪˈzʊː ˌdɛs.kʊˈvɐːt pɐː ˌbo.nɐ.vɪnˈtɪː]
fall-3p.ipf invention scientific several discover.p.pst by chance
Many scientific inventions were discovered by chance.

##

111.4: a gest "de facto"

a gest /a ʒɛst/ [ɐˈʝɛst]
- de facto, in practice, in fact, regardless of official or legal status;
- actually, in fact, used to introduce a contradictory remark

Etymology: a Middle Borlish borrowing from legal Latin ad gestum "de facto", literally "to the deed", along with parallel formation a verb < ad verbum "de jure", literally "to the word". In general contexts it is seen from the sixteenth century.

A gest, aucel son progenies jug dez dragon.
/a ʒɛst | oˈtsɛl sɔn ˌpro.ʒeˈnjɛz ʒaj dɛz draˈgɔn/
[ɐˈʝɛst | ʊˈtsɛl sɔn ˌpʀo.ʝɪˈnjɛz ʝaj dɛz dʀɐˈgɔn]
at deed | bird be.3p descendant still out.of dinosaurs
In fact, birds are descended from dinosaurs.

##

111.5: Battle of Rexam (1483)

The Battle of Rexam (Merch Feight at Rexam /fɛʃt ət ˈɾɛksəm/, Cambric Brwydr Car Vanteł /ˈbɾuː.də kaː vənˈtɛɬ/) was a major combat between Markland [~Mercia] and the Kingdom of Britain [~Wales+] which took place in 1483 during the Wars of Fealty.

Rexam (formerly in the Merch language spelt Wrexham) had been a contested town on the border of Wales and Markland almost from the moment the latter was founded. In 1301, in an act which reignited the Mallor Wars, King Andrew II sacked the town.

The relatively-new Kingdom of Britain (formed of Wales and its outlying tallaths [provinces], along with Kernow [Brittany] and Sodrick [Man and the Hebrides]) started from a position of strength, and managed to extract many concessions from Markland in the early years of the wars. This culminated in a decisive victory at the Battle of Rexam, where the last Duke of Chester was killed.

After this battle, Britain was able to take lasting control of the area around Rexam (though the attack on the city of Chester shortly thereafter was rebuffed). The polity then managed to recuse itself from the continued conflicts of the Wars of Fealty; the rest of the polities of Albion would remain embroiled for another thirty years.

The battle and its aftermath were portrayed in 1931 work "Children of the Battle of Rexam" (released originally in Cambric as Pa Ðywdon y Plant Car Vanteł "What the Children of Car Vantel Said"), a fictionalised account of the three orphaned children of the Duke of Chester written by schoolteacher Jon Paldreth.

112.1: In the Ballroom

excerpt in translation from Ezio Carvallo's 1860 work Tejan de Masquira ou Jalico (In a Mask or a Suit).

Ny salon caye zoum dy murmuranç nievrous d'un murðon a collocq, parfis atras con bau sporadic d'hom ricottant.
The salon hummed with the indistinct murmur of myriad conversations, punctuated by occasional barks of laughter.

Matthias eye sarpentin entr haçot de jolleyour, y hal parcorrent a gas doutr plumaç remeyaçant e caliç ne crystal.
Matthias weaved between knots of revellers, his eyes scanning the room over bobbing plumes and crystal flutes.

Bojay minç vacillan ne candellabr adornað, y tapeçment eð y paið trave bagnant con splendiscment quemant.
Tapers flickered in ornate candelabras, casting a warm glow over the wall-hangings and the parquet floors.

Sur un los ny cogn jagerrem, un party a raspour luyen ne coutrant un xivol nervous cant per trasen y hal ne voltiscent, lorry cottegl e mantel faint souvolar capaç.
On a dais at the far end, a coterie of string players sawed through a sprightly xivola as couples whirled around the room, their skirts and capes sweeping widely.

Matthias cave parcevet de visaç seyon connuð; y nas aquilin all'ambasctour Cantesc, y sourey polið a Domn Gassola, un bevey diamantin relugnt seyon vis nuverrem sur y col ag Duches a Astorga.
Matthias caught glimpses of familiar faces; the Kentish ambassador's aquiline nose, Lady Gassola's polished smile, a sparkling diamond parure he'd last seen adorning the Duchess of Astorga.

112.2: imminent "prospective"

imminent /ˌɪ.miˈnɛnt/ [ˌɪ.mɪˈnɛnt]
- projecting, overhanging, suspended above;
- prospective, anticipated, likely or expected to happen;
- newly elected, (of a candidate) voted in but having not yet taken office;
- apparent, (of an heir) having a claim to a title that cannot be superseded by the birth of anyone else

Etymology: Middle Boral borrowing from Latin imminēns, present participle of immineō "I overhang; I am intent upon, I am near at hand". The verb imminir was briefly current but had obsolesced by the end of the seventeenth century. Its original use in Borlish was in the phrase heriter imminent "heir apparent", as opposed to heriter provisoir "heir presumptive".

My paðr es collocquant con y gournour imminent.
/mi ˈpa.ðr̩ ɛz ˌkɔ.lɔˈkwant kɔn i gurˈnur ˌɪ.miˈnɛnt/
[mi ˈpa‿ʀɪz ˌkɔ.lʊˈkwant kɔn i gʊːˈnʊː‿ˌʀɪ.mɪˈnɛnt]
1s.gn father be.3s converse-p.prs with df governor prospective
My father is interviewing the governor-elect.

112.3: sou teneur covart "in secret"

sou teneur covart /su teˈnawr koˈvart/ [su tɪˈna.wɐ kʊˈvɐːt]
- in the dark, under the cover of darkness, without any light;
- in secret, secretly, out of view, sub rosa, concealed from any eavesdroppers or spies

Etymology: idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally "under covered darkness"; probably formed by analogy to preexisting sou ciel ovart "in plain view", literally "under open sky". The noun teneur is an uncomplicated descendant from Latin tenebrae "darkness"; the adjective covart is the past participle of covrir "to cover", from Latin cooperiō "I cover, overwhelm, clothe".

Il son se rajognent sou teneur covart pieç semman.
/ɪl sɔn se raˈʒɔj.nɛnt su teˈnawr koˈvart pjɛts sɛˈman/
[ɪˈsɔn se ʀɐˈʝɔj.nɐnt su tɪˈna.wɐ kʊˈvɐːt pjɛs sɪˈman]
3p be.3p rfl meet-p.prs under darkness cover.p.pst some week
They have been meeting in secret for a few weeks.

112.4: abrangir "include"

abrangir /ˌa.branˈʒɪr/ [ˌa.bʀɐnˈʝɪː]
- include, comprise, comprehend, to consider a part of some set of things;
- span, cover, contain, to extend sufficiently so as to include

Etymology: via Scholastic Latin abrangeō "I include" from Portingale abranger "include", itself of obscure origin. Possibly related to Old French rengier "to line up, form rows", from Frankish (either hring "ring" or ranc "upright"); otherwise perhaps an unconventional descendant of Latin vergō "I bend, am situated".

Y pascman abrange zaquesc e desc assovent y dou.
/i ˌpaxˈman ˌa.branˈʒe zaˈkwɛx e dɛx ˌa.soˈvɛnt i du/
[i ˌpaxˈman ˌa.bʀɐnˈʝe zɐˈkwɛç e dɛç ˌa.sʊˈvɛnt i du]
df eatery include-ipf snack and meal sate-p.prs df two
The eatery had both snacks and full meals.

112.5: North American History Quiz

from the 1930 book Prove your Knowledge!, a part of the series Games for Sorties and Excourses. This was a collection of casual party games compiled and published by Merch couple Anna and Ralph Highwater through the Royal Tommarth Castinghouse.

History XI: The Novomund (answers on sheet 236)

1. Which emperor of Tavancy [~the Inca], whose 61-year reign from 1599 until 1660 is the longest of any monarch in Cappatian history, is suspected to have been assasinated by Morrack [Morrocan] agents in order to be able to increase the volume and decrease the price of silver exports?

2. For whom were the Sturgovan [Appalachian] Mountains named?

3. With which Mendevan people did the nascent polity of New Provence principally trade during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries?

4. In what year was the Steeplepost Tapestry in the Ambrosian city of Aiga d'Angoixa [~Quebec City] erected, the first device capable of displaying an image communicated via the steeplemesh?

5. What astronomical event inspired the naming of the major Mashick city of Moshtar [~San Francisco] in 1780?

6. What property of matter was discovered by the Cappatian city of Varonøw [~Vitória, ES]'s Nÿstad Atellier in 1902?

7. Which was the first of the staddomains [colonial tradeposts] along the eastern Cappatian coast to be established, with an official chronicle dating to 1561?

8. A predecessor to the Lineball Global Tourney, what was the name of the international lineball competition first held in Awasúconda [~Paraná] in 1909 between twenty teams?

9. Which was the only Novomundine polity to have a delegation present at the signing of the Laic Declarations in Belgrade?

10. What was the name of the first Chinese ship to alight in the Novomund?

113.2: raspar "scrape"

raspar /raˈspar/ [ʀɐˈspɐː]
- scrape, scratch, graze, grate, rasp, to draw a sharp or rough object along a surface while exerting pressure;
- play, bow, to create sound on a string instrument by means of drawing a bow across a string

Etymology: twelfth-century borrowing from Old French rasper "scratch, grate", itself from synonymous hraspōn in Frankish. The extension to string playing, as well as the noun raspour "string player", is seen from the late sixteenth century.

J'yemoy scið aïr kes raspað demay sad.
/ʒjeˈmɔj xɪθ eˈjɪr kɛz raˈspaθ deˈme sad/
[ʝɪˈmɔj çɪ‿ðɪˈʝɪː kɛz ʀɐˈspɐh dɪˈme sad]
1s=get-pst known have-inf cheese scrape-p.pst too.much gravely
I realised I'd grated far too much cheese.

113.3: parcorrir "scan"

parcorrir /ˌpar.kɔˈrɪr/ [ˌpɐː.kʊˈʀɪː]
- scan, examine, go over, skim, to look at sequentially or from one end to the other;
- traverse, cross, to go through;
- rehearse, to practise by acting out

Etymology: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin percurrō "I run through; I look over", modelling on inherited par- "through" and corrir "to run". In the last sense it is attested from the eighteenth century.

Nos erau y fabr parcorrent set hour.
/nɔz eˈro i ˈfa.br̩ ˌpar.kɔˈrɛnt sɛt ur/
[ˌno.zɪˈʀo i ˈfa.bɐ ˌpɐː.kʊˈʀɛnt sɛt ʊː]
1p imp-1p df play rehearse-p.prs seven hour
We'd been rehearsing for seven hours.

113.4: souvolar "sweep"

souvolar /ˌsu.voˈlar/ [ˌsu.vʊˈlɐː]
- sweep, be swept, to be caused to rise up into the air from the ground (as of the clothing of a person spinning, or of dust);
- glide, to move through the air gracefully and unpropelled;
- go along with something, play along, to cooperate in continuing something by passively allowing it;
- (in a performative context) yes-and, commit to the bit, take things in stride, go with the flow, stay in character

Etymology: borrowing from Latin subvolō "I fly upwards from below", adapted to existing sou- "under" and volar "fly". In metaphorical use the word is attested from the eighteenth century; in a theatrical context it is seen from 1888, originally in use by a specific school of acting in Axbane.

Y rimband ag fruyour souvolaurn apar.
/i rɪmˈband ɛj fraˈjur ˌsu.voˈlorn̩ aˈpar/
[i ʀɪmˈband ɛj fʀɐʝʊː ˌsu.vʊˈloːn ɐˈpɐː]
df ribbon at.df dancer sweep-pst-3p through
The dancer's ribbons swept through the air.

113.5: Delicious Etymology

excerpts in translation from the Rotcham Veriloquy, the premier etymological dictionary of Merch. It has been published in several editions since the late nineteenth century via the press of the university of Rotcham [Rochdale].

- mikecorn n. /ˈməik.kɔːn/ [maize] a cereal grass of Lower Mendevan [Central American] origin. 1530 compound of mike alt. mayk, makee and corn < Morrove [Moroccan Arabic] ميك · maik (1502) < a language of the Arcabil, poss. Veonic [Wayuu] maiki "mikecorn".
- shadome n. /ˈʃa.duːm/ [tomato] a plant of the nightshade kind having edible fruits; the fruit of this plant. 1570 < Vascon xadoma (1534) < Morrove شطم · shed'oma (1510) < Normal Nawat [Classical Nahuatl] shitomatl, denoting a kind of fruit used in stews and sauces. This is thought to be a derivative from the verb tomāwi "to swell".
- shockle n. /ˈʃɔ.kəl/ [chocolate] a drink or later a foodstuff prepared from the quattle [cacao] bean. 1623 backwards from shockled adj. /ˈʃɔ.kləd/ "containing shockle" < Vascon xoc(o)lat (1596) < unknown root, poss. Nawat chicol "wooden stick" or Mayattan chocol "hot".
- tartover n. /taːˈtuː.ə/ [potato] a plant of the nightshade kind with starchy underground tubers. 1583 alt. tartove < Vascon tartova (moresca) "(Moorish) truffle" (1555) < Tuscan tartuvo alt. tartuva "truffle" < Latin terrae tūber "truffle, lit. tuber of the earth". See also familiar and hypocoristic forms like tover /tuː.ə/, tattow /təˈtuː/ and tatter /ˈta.tə/.
- tashban n. /ˈtaʃ.ban/ [vanilla] a plant of the orchid kind bearing podlike fruit whose seeds yield a extract used for flavouring and perfuming. 1608 < Vascon taxbàn (1567) or French tacheban < Morrove تشبان tashbān (1518) < poss. Nawat tashpān, or directly < Thebevan [Totonac] tałpán, denoting a specific variety of the tashban orchid.

114.1: A Transit of Venus

Answer any number of the following questions in the next three hours.

2. Soumoin jaint vars Bensaíd ne L'Appragl de Communeyaçon, argument fair sur y gimmolt mondial d'an 1677 por y trasson de Maucr parcevir com bustr primal de collaboraçon theoretic tars tarm.

114.2: xivol "waltz"

xivol /ksiˈvɔl/ [ksɪˈvɔl]
- waltz, xivola, a style of dance originating in Vascony during the Long Peace (1770–1815) characterised by triple time and a rapid tempo;
- metaphorically, the state of many people simultaneously carrying out independent tasks and moving around each other without getting in each other's way

Etymology: via French xivole from Vascon xìvola /ˈʃi.vo.la/ "waltz". This itself is a borrowing from the earlier and slightly different Italian dance scivola "waltz, word stressed on the third-from-last syllable", from verb scivolare "glide, slip". This is plausibly a descendant of Latin exsībilō "I hiss forth".

Although the original xivola dance had a rather restrained tempo, the average performance speed of xivola music has greatly increased over time. Xivola is usually conceived of as a crowd dance, in which an entire roomful of people participates.

Sy xivol aye tug aglon de skisteç.
/si ksiˈvɔl ɛˈje taj ɛjˈlɔn de skɪˈstɛts/
[si ksɪˈvɔl iˈʝe taj ɪjˈlɔn de skɪˈstɛs]
3s.gn waltz have-ipf passion instead of elegance
He waltzed with more passion than grace.

##

114.3: trave "parquetry"

trave /traˈve/ [tʀɐˈve]
- parquetry, the technique of using wooden tiles to create geometric patterns especially as used in flooring;
- jigsaw, tangram, a puzzle in which the aim is to reconstruct a picture or shape that has been cut into small pieces

Etymology: from a specialised use of Middle French travé "crossed with wooden beams", via noun traf, tref "beam, mast" from Latin trabs "timber, beam, rafter". The puzzle sense is attested from the late nineteenth century.

Il son y trave costroint toð y jorn.
/ɪl sɔn i traˈve koˈstrɔint tɔθ i ʒɔrn/
[ɪˈsɔn i tʀɐˈve kʊˈstʀɔint tɔðɪˈʝɔːn]
3p be.3p df jigsaw build-p.prs all df day
They've been doing the jigsaw all day.

##

114.4: soumoin jair "reference"

soumoin jair /suˈmɔin ʒer/ [sʊˈmɔin ʝeː]
- reference, cite, to quote the words of another with attribution;
- credit, shout out, acknowledge, to publicly mention someone especially in order to thank them

Etymology: idiom meaning "to throw reference" attested from the seventeenth century. The noun soumoin is a deverbal of soumonir "prompt, remind", which descends from Latin summoneō "I privately advise, give a hint". The verb jair comes from Latin iaciō "I throw, fling".

Nos veleu soumoin jair a nossy conemour.
/nɔz vɛlaw suˈmɔin ʒer a nɔˈsi ˌko.neˈmur/
[nɔz vɪˈlaw sʊˈmɔin ʝeː‿ʀa nʊˈsi ˌko.nɪˈmʊː]
1p will.sj-1p reference throw-inf to 1p.gn regular 
We'd like to shout out our patrons.

##

114.5: On the Bookshelf

In Sickness and in Health: Medicine in pre-Arnoutszen Europe is a quire chronicling the development of medical practice in Europe from antiquity until the time of physician Laurz Arnoutszen in the sixteenth century (the adoption of whose techniques constituted a sea-change in the effectiveness of medicine). It was written by Andrew Knowles in the mid-twentieth century. It was published in Kent by Winchester Scholastic Primers in multiple editions; the second edition was released in 1961 with a foreword by Dr Laura Norris, a lecturer in Heredity at Canterburgh University.

New Skies, Old Stories (originally published in Provincial French as Novè Cial, Anzan Conte) is a work of popular history detailing the origins of the various threads of parachthon fiction. It was written by Simon d'Estiala and published by Prindor Marsillès in 1980. Its thesis is that many of the tropes often considered to have been invented by particular parachthon authors are in fact simply examples of existing tropes used in new settings.

Men in Black (originally published in Parisian French as Hommes en Noir: une Étoire d'Espionnage) is a layperson's account of the history of spycraft across the world. It was written by Agathe Bisset and published by Paris University Editions in 2003.

The Alphabetical Albion is an encyclopaedia of the political history of Albion. It was written by a consortium of authors including Lucas Osborne and published by Winchester Scholastic Primers in 1920. The book organises itself into twenty-six sections, one for each letter of the English alphabet in order, with varying levels of contortion required to justify the conceit. Headings include "F: The Wars of Fealty", "Q: Unanswered Questions" and "X: The Necessity of Xenia".

115.1: The Numeric Week

excerpt in translation from the 14th October 1950 edition of the Roxa Comba, in their regular column called The Numeric Week. The Roxa Comba is a weekly paper based in the Groin [A Coruña] and affiliated loosely with the Russet Dove media guild.

Y Semman cas Nombr - Sambað 14 Octobr 1950
The Numeric Week - Saturday 14th October 1950

1500: Y lonctum par lau de Japetos III, y novel conjogntur Atlantic oy depos des Morrac vars Ambrosia eð ayent sy preu boðanç augtað je Maucr derran. Vellisquað cos original pall'eç administraçon a catr man d'an 1943, l'accommission dene demorað veg monfeyað deut ag confluyenç de hey cas bors e, lon digr, y sounç dy var. Y snar conjogn y citað de Gadir ag floy Soux e Paratzon ne Brasil auster.
1500: The length in leagues of Japetos III, the new Atlantic link laid down between Morrack and Ambrosia which conveyed its first messages this last Wednesday. Originally conceived by the two administrations in concert in 1943, the endeavour was delayed several times due both to budgetary concerns and, of course, the outbreak of war. The cable connects the cities of Gadire on the river Soux [Agadir, Morocca] and Paratzon in eastern Brasil [St John's, Newfoundland].

3: L'enombr de vouð dessur dell'opposson ny cambr Yansief yon y soumission dy clou Zachet por interrogment sull'effectualtað de molin a forç sougl se cof yer eligt, ne souc d'un veðrvent imprefait cas y jure suajonnant dy Minister a Ðar. Partejan aun (ða lorry nosthubr sey visant vars y Collujon ben contrig) caglou irrayað cos divers sull'eç advantaç cohernt a men basant a astraphor Drengoçan e sull'occasion de l'Andron a Alchemy ne Lisbon extollir com mojol ny doujug mondial.
3: The number of votes by which the Mortar coalition's proposal to fund effectivity research into threshold force mills [nuclear power plants] passed in the Yansieve chamber yesterday, after a surprising volte-face from the Ministry for Farming advisory board. Proponents have (depending on their sympathies or lack thereof regarding the Collusion) pointed variously to the benefits of relying less on Drengot astraphor [electricity] and of elevating Lisbon's Faculty of Alchemy to a hub on the world stage.

##

115.2: trasson "transit"

trasson /traˈsɔn/ [tʀɐˈsɔn]
- transit, crossing, an instance of something moving across or through something else;
- transition, change, the process of change from one state to another;
- link, bridge, connection, anything placed between two distinct sections

Etymology: formerly trasçon, either a Middle Borlish noun derivation from trasir "to cross, traverse", or a direct borrowing from Latin trānsitiō "transit, transition". In the last sense the word is attested from the seventeenth century, originally applied to parts of musical compositions.

Jo passau y trasson nell'exedr a quarvol.
/ʒo paˈso i traˈsɔn ˌnɛ.lɛkˈsɛ.dr̩ a kwarˈvɔl/
[ʝo pɐˈso i tʀɐˈsɔn ˌnɛ.lɪgˈzɛd‿ʀa kwɐːˈvɔl]
1s pass-pst df transit in-df=lounge at airport
I spent the layover in the airport lounge.

##

115.3: exedr "waiting room"

exedr /ɛkˈsɛ.dr̩/ [ɪgˈzɛ.dɐ]
- antechamber, anteroom, forecourt, vestibule, entrance hall, a room between the outside and the main interior of a building;
- (historical) exedra, a small room for discussion lined with benches;
- waiting room, lounge, a space inside a public for people to sit and wait (especially a particularly well-appointed or luxurious such space);

Etymology: an early modern borrowing from Latin exedra "discussion hall with seating", itself from Greek ἐξἕδρα "an exterior sitting place". In the last sense it is attested from the nineteenth century, originally in reference to such rooms in train stations.

L'exedr n'a alcun vivirc por asseïr.
/lɛkˈsɛ.dr̩ na alˈkɪn viˈvɪrk pɔr ˌa.siˈɪr/
[lɪgˈzɛ.dɐ na ɐˈgɪn vɪˈvɪːk pɔː‿ʁɐˈsjɪː]
df=lounge neg=have no leeway for sit-inf
The waiting room has nowhere to sit.

##

115.4: quarvol "airport"

quarvol /kwarˈvɔl/ [kwɐːˈvɔl]
- airport, an area designed for landing and takeoff of commercial passenger aircraft

Etymology: early twentieth century, portmanteau of quarvet "(bus, taxi, ferry) station, a stopping place for transportation" and vol "flight". The noun quarvet is a diminutive of quarf "docks, harbour", borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English hwearf "embankment, wharf". The noun vol is a deverbal from volar "fly", from Latin volō "I fly".

Cay l'oc convey visað ag quarvol?
/ke lɔk kɔnˈvi viˈzaθ ɛj kwarˈvɔl/
[ke lɔ kʊɱˈvi vɪˈza‿ðɛj kwɐːˈvɔl]
fall df=s.px train bound to.df airport
Is this the train to the airport?

##

115.5: Turbulent Times

collected notes on various events and periods which took place at the time of the Long Peace (ca. 1770–1815).

The Decadence of Belgrade refers to the Kingdom of the Danaw [Danube] in its final decades before the Second German War (1815–23) and the subsequent dissolution of the state. The Decadence also represents the territorial maximum of the kingdom, having wrested Bulgary [Bulgaria] from the suzerainty of the Second Roman Empire [~the Byzantines] after the latter's final collapse in the seventeenth century, and more recently having consolidated control over lands at the northwestern border with Bavarn [Bavaria].

The Mendevan Unmooring (Borlish Deshormejanç Mendevan /deˌzɔr.meˈʒants ˌmɛn.deˈvan/) is the collective name for the various wars and diplomatic developments at the turn of the nineteenth century which led to the weakening and sometimes severing of formal ties of polities in Mendeva [North America] from those in the Vetomund [Old World]. The more explosive conflicts such as the War for Ambrosia [~east and north of the Great Lakes] and the Hasinick Revolution [~lower part of the Mississipi watershed] (against Vascony and Britain, respectively) often overshadow quieter events like the Departure of Mashick [~Mexico].

The Romantic Revival (Borlish Resorgenç Romannesc /reˈzɔr.gɛnts ˌro.maˈnɛx/) was an artistic and political movement which arose towards the end of the eighteenth century. It was characterised by optimistic portrayals of heroism, and especially a belief in a 'brighter past' in the seventeenth century that could be recaptured. It is due to this movement's depiction that a loose congeries of wars in the mid-seventeenth century have become known as the Romantic Wars.

116.1: Fun-loving Firefighter

excerpt in translation from Mescainç ben Delit? "Accident or Crime?", one of a series of episodic stories about first responders in Damvath, published since the 1990s by a collective of Borlish authors.

Zaf er denuð quïscour dec apar l'aye l'occajon a foyaçar eð a gent aïðar veg temporane.
Zaf had become a firefighter because it let him show off and help people at the same time.

L'oc no sta bogr autrað; sull'oc, toð cas, aye i jamay y vertað dis.
That hadn't changed; that, at least, he had been truthful about.

I cof ancour l'ig ðougl meðes des y toxen oïr, des y vagn viglar con sy balis briglant e sy vagiscour hurlant, des port caugtrant deur lorry sougl—souvanç y gahaðasterrem de gent feirn sy cour battr. 
He still got the same rush from hearing the alarm, from driving the engine with its brilliant lights and screaming noisemakers, from kicking in doors—people's worst days made him feel alive.

L'ec sceusn solcið inquillir n'un hom incaindessem vars cuidanç de sey.
Someone more prone to self-reflection might have felt qualms about that.

A sgart calscon, y squadron encontraurn noc veram mort tal mout.
In any case, the crew didn't actually see deaths that often.

Nentamen, incoïbr sta cos sporadic ern y grabattour haft an pognt remot allors ny citað, ben ig un armanç cojan surcou un belem mortal.
Nevertheless, it was inevitable that sometimes the stretcher-bearers were occupied halfway across the city, or that a routine call turned deadly.

116.2: ðar "farming"

ðar /ðar/ [ðɐː]
- farming, farmwork, agriculture, tilth, the business and activity of cultivating land and raising livestock;
- (in certain idiomatic expressions, more generally) work, toil, labour, drudge, any particularly strenuous activity;
- (colloquially) sex, intercourse, the act of having sex with somebody

Etymology: Middle Borlish deverbal from ðarar "plough, till; farm; labour", originally restricted to crop production and not animal husbandry. This descends uncomplicatedly from Latin adarō "I plough, till". In the last sense it is attested since the early twentieth century but is thought to be much older; cf. Tuscan arare "to plough; to have sex with".

Whether or not the namers of the Minister a Ðar "Ministry for Agriculture" were aware of the slang usage, many caricaturists have since seized on the pun.

L'a un sgart mallovicher de ðar.
/la ɪn sgart ˌma.lo.vɪˈkɛr de ðar/
[la ɪn zgɐːt ˌma.lʊ,vɪˈkɛː de ðɐː]
3s=have indf view overly.optimistic of farming
He's very naïve about farmwork.

116.3: veðrvent "vane"

veðrvent /ˌvɛ.ðr̩ˈvɛnt/ [ˌvɛ.ðɐˈvɛnt]
- vane, weathervane, weathercock, a  mechanical device rotating around one axis and attached to an elevated object such as a roof for showing the direction of the wind;
- anemometer, windmeter, a more sophisticated device for measuring and recording the speed and direction of the wind;
- (metaphorically) volte-face, about-face, U-turn, flip-flop, a sudden reversal of opinion or strategy

Etymology: folk-etymological alteration of Old Borlish veðrevit "vane" under the influence of vent "wind" < synonymous ventus in Latin. The Old Borlish is a borrowing from Old Norse veðrviti "vane", literally "weather knower". Synchronically interpretable as "wind-glass"; though they are not normally made of glass, the word has been analysed as referring to glassware used for measurement. In metaphorical usage the word is seen from the eighteenth century.

Y torvegl indugs ec mesuranç suprem de veðrvent tras istr.
/i tɔrˈvijl ɪnˈdajz ɛk ˌme.ziˈrants siˈprɛm de ˌvɛ.ðr̩ˈvɛnt traz ˈɪ.str̩/
[i tʊːˈvɪjl ɪnˈdajz ɛ ˌme.zɪˈʀans sɪˈpʀɛm de ˌvɛ.ðɐˈvɛnt tʀaz ˈɪ.stɐ]
df storm induce.pst p.px output supreme of vane across island
The storm led to record windspeed measurements nationwide.

116.4: clou "segment"

clou /klu/ [klu]
- clove, segment, one of the parts (as of a fruit or bulb) into which any body naturally separates or is divided;
- sector, piece, slice, part of a circle bounded by two radii and an arc they subtend (also of any circular object);
- faction, party, bloc, a political organisation of voters and/or politicians who share common goals

Etymology: from Old Borlish clou /klu(v)/ "clove (of garlic)", borrowed from synonymous clufu in Old English. The meaning was extended to other portions of things in the Middle Borlish period; in the phrase clou politic "political party" it is attested from the seventeenth century.

Il aun cascun dou clou a vastel ja paut.
/ɪl on kaˈxɪn du klu a vaˈstɛl ʒa pot/
[ɪˈlon kɐˈçɪn du klu a vɐˈstɛl ʝa pot]
3p have.3p each two piece at cake already eat.p.pst
They've eaten two pieces of cake each.

##

116.5: Kernovan Conjuring

The Kernovan Conjuring (Borlish Conjuraçon Cornovan /ˌkɔɲ.ʒɪˈrants ˌkɔr.noˈvan/) was a collaboration between the Kingdom of Greater Devon and Roger Drengot, Duke of Normandy to press the Duke's claim to the throne of Kent. This plot is considered the proximate cause for the creation of the First Drengot Empire across Gaul [France] and southern Albion [Great Britain].

The Conjuring was carried out in 1029, following the death of King Rodulf of Kent. Kent under the long-reigning Rodulf had prospered, with recognised supremacy over the rump Wessex (albeit not uncontested by Devon) and over Essex to the north. After eight decades of political manoeuvring, Rodulf lingered on his deathbed and the succession was deeply uncertain.

Although no references to a written treaty have survived, it is presumed that the House of Kernow aided Normandy in their bid for the Kentish throne in exchange for support in becoming the new ruling dynasty of Greater Devon. This bargain was upheld, but it only took a couple of decades for Greater Devon to become a vassal of the First Drengot Empire.

In what was either impressive long-term strategy or merely opportunism, the victorious Roger of Normandy would go on to conquer Kent's neighbours, including Essex and Markland, and then venture south to annex much of the rest of Gaul. He was crowned Emperor Roger I in the midst of this territorial expansion in 1038.

The recently-unified Wales under Cadwallan (erstwhile King of Wynneth) managed to remain mostly free of Drengot control. This was likely achieved by steering a course between Greater Devon and the Drengot, neither of whom wanted to other to have dominion over Wales.

## 

117.1: New Urban Mesh

notes in translation on the subject of the New Urban Mesh.

Y Nou Sar Urban intermane un alleyanç de citað autonom naðusc n'Europ norðovester durant y siecr novoç.
The New Urban Mesh was an alliance of somewhat autonomous cities in Northwest Europe in the nineteenth century.

Parmy sy sodal stan Londr, Conster, Ausbagn, Pentros, Amstel, Anvers e Gant.
Among its members were London, Conster [Colchester], Axbane, Pentrose, Amstel [Amsterdam], Anvers [Antwerp] and Gant [Ghent].

Y Sar smargoy cos contemporane e parallel a apprestanç politic comportant allors, tal com y Citað Floyan lonc y Danau.
The Mesh emerged contemporaneously with similar political structures elsewhere, such as the Riverine Cities along the Danaw [Danube].

Plusour parmy y citað ag Sar stan cos simoltane part de polity ja sceint (com bustr, Ausbagn e Pentros no stan jamay sovran a verb deur Istr Boral).
Several of the Mesh's cities were simultaneously part of pre-existing polities (for example, Axbane and Pentrose were never legally independent from Borland).

L'oc ort de tal federaç de stat citaðer se caf ascreut all'aðoinç pouvlancer eð y crescenç de citað rapid tras l'approism dell'epoc all'Atelier Mondial.
This rise of such federacies of city-states has been attributed to the rapid population growth and expansion of cities in the run-up to the Global Workshop period.

Y Sar cos particuler sta ag rostr de machinaçon cas vascel costroinç, eð i poðe un ronç remarcabr cavir dy recoglenç de carbon mondial.
The Mesh in particular was at the forefront of shipbuilding technology, and had access to an appreciable fraction of the world's coal production.

117.2: mallovicher "naïve"

mallovicher /ˌma.lo.viˈkɛr/ [ˌma.lʊ.vɪˈkɛː]
- naïve, rose-tinted, ingenuous, overly optimistic or blind to obvious pitfalls and downsides;
- chipper, bubbly, pert, peppy, cheerful in an annoying way

Etymology: 19C, adjectival derivation from mallovic "someone who is naïve and cheerful to a ridiculous or irritating extent". This is a borrowing from synonymous Merch mallowick or directly from the character Mall-Lowick /ˈmal ˈlu.ɪk/ and her eponymous novel, in which she is a young girl subjected to various travails but never losing her hopeful demeanour. Her name is a compound of Mall, a hypocoristic form of Mary, and Lowick, which comes via Old French Loïc from Frankish Hloðwig (cf. Vascon Luixa and Napolitan Ludgia [and IRL Louise]). The name was applied almost immediately in a mocking way to a person seen as similar to Mall-Lowick.

J'osc sy cigl novel; i's mallovicher sad demay.
/ʒox si tsajl noˈvɛl | ɪz ˌma.lo.vɪˈkɛr sad deˈme/
[ʝox si tsajl nʊˈvɛl | ɪz ˌma.lʊ.vɪˈkɛː sad dɪˈme]
1s=hate 3s.gn SO new | 3s=be pert gravely too
I hate her new girlfriend; she's far too chipper.

117.3: grabattour "paramedic"

grabattour /ˌgra.baˈtur/ [ˌgʀa.bɐˈtʊː]
- paramedic, EMT, a person trained to medically stabilise injured people on-site before they can be transported to a hospital;
- (historical, esp. Millstone War) stretcher-bearer, a soldier or auxiliary serviceman who carries the wounded away from the battlefield on stretchers

Etymology: 20C, agentive derivation from grabat "stretcher, gurney; emergency medical transport". This is a borrowing via another Romance language from Latin grabātus "cot, pallet, camp bed", from Greek. Transfer from the military context to peacetime healthcare is attested from the 1950s.

J'addoceu my sour d'ig j'er grabattour parsiscent.

1s=inform-pst 1s.gn sister of-comp 1s=cop.ipf EMT study-p.pst
I told my sister I was training to be a paramedic.

extollir /ˌɛk.stɔˈlɪr/ [ˌɛk.stʊˈlɪː]

117.5: Sound Changes from Vulgar Latin to Borlish

The dialects of Borlish are the only surviving descendants of the Insular variety of Vulgar Latin, which comprised Borlish Latin and British Latin. This variety was not overly divergent from the contemporary (ca. 3rd to 5th century) Latin of the continent, with the following exceptions:

    The loss of intervocalic  /w/, as evidenced in inscriptions by e.g. clam "key" (continental clavem) and denio "I reach" (continental devenio).
    The loss of wordfinal  /s/, probably preceded by a period of debuccalisation where final  was pronounced /h/. The dating of this sound change is controversial; cf. fifth-century *a femna* "the women (acc.)" (Classical hās fēminās "these women").

The second of these local changes was grammatically significant, as it weakened the distinctions between forms in noun declensions. Indeed, already by the Old Borlish period all number and case distinctions in nouns have been lost.

    Posttonic vowel loss
    V > ∅ / "VC_CV
    Final syllable simplification
    m > n / _# if stressed
    m s > ∅ / _# otherwise

e.g. amictate /ˌa.mikˈta.te/ "friendship" < amīcitātem

    Palatalisation part 1
    [t k]j [d g]j > tʃ dʒ
    k g > tʃ dʒ / _[i e]
    k > j / _C except [r l w j]
    Fortition
    w > β /#_
    j > dʒ / #_, V_V

e.g. iazo /ˈdʒat.tʃo/ "I lie down" < iaceō

    Consonant lenition part 1
    p t k b d g s > b d g β ð ɣ z / V_[V m l r n j w]
    Palatalisation part 2
    nj lj > ɲ ʎ
    Cj > Cʲ > jC except w or word initially
    Final vowels reduce to schwa (unless stressed)
    V > ə / _# unless stressed

e.g. sabe /ˈsa.bə/ "he knows" < sapit; saibe /ˈsaj.bə/ "I know" < sapiō

    Weak consonants lost
    [β ð ɣ] > ∅ / V_V
    Mid-vowels break in stressed open syllables
    ɛ e ɔ o > je e o ow / stressed open
    ɛ ɔ > e o / elsewhere
    Lenition part 2
    p t k b d g > b d g β ð ɣ / V_V
    C: > C
    Loss of much final schwa
    ə > ∅ / except after consonant clusters

e.g. liei /ljedʒ/ "halt" < Insular laedicum "collision"

    Affricate shift
    tʃ dʒ > ts ʒ
    sk palatalises (fills gap with ʒ), β shift
    sk β > ʃ v
    Vowel u is fronted
    u > y
    Mid-vowel rhotic shift
    e > a / _rC
    e > i / _r#
    Full loss of schwa
    ə > ∅
    Epenthesis before r
    ∅ > d / [n ɲ]_r
    ∅ > b / m_r

e.g. cendre /ˈtsen.dr̩/ "ash" < cinerem; puðir /pyˈðir/ "rot" < pūtēre

    Vowels become lax in closed syllables
    i e o y > ɪ ɛ ɔ ʏ / closed syllables
    Final consonants devoice
    b d g v z ð ʒ > p t k f s θ ʃ / _#
    l-vocalisation and y-diphthong shift
    [l y] > w / _[C #]
    Front vowels merge in weak position
    [ɛ ɪ ʏ ɛj] > ɪ / #_sC
    [ɛ ɪ ʏ] > ɛ / _w[C #]
    Diphthong shift part 1
    ai ɛi ɪi > e i əj
    aw ɛw ɔw > o əw u
    Palatals and ɣ are lost (regenerating some diphthongs)
    ɲ ʎ > n l / #_
    ɲ ʎ ɣ > jn jl j

e.g. aut /ot/ "had" < awt < ayt < ayd < aud < aˈβu.də < aˈbu.tə < aˈbu.to < Vulgar *habūtus;
ismargre /ɪsˈmar.gr̩/ "arise" < ɛjsˈmar.grə < ejsˈmer.grə < ɛksˈmɛr.gre < Vulgar *exmergere

This is the stage, around the turn of the thirteenth century, usually referred to as late Old Borlish:

    …sovravnt il deft nostre saȝntaðesem eð atavalesem n iȝ atrevre golfhavn seȝ hamar dont y verb divin ismetre ac povre paian. peðev soul ez font istovent por vn nov cliȝs d istroienz istablir…
    /soˈvront ɪl dɛwt ˈnostr̩ ˌsajn.taˈðɛsɛm ɛð aˌta.vaˈlɛsɛm nəj aˈtrəwr̩ gɔlfˈhon sej haˈmar dɔnt i vɛrb diˈvɪn ɪsˈme.tr̩ ak ˈpovr̩ paˈʒan ‖ peˈðəw sul ets fɔnt ɪs.toˈvɛnt pɔr yn nu cləjs dɪsˈtrɔjənts is.taˈblɪr/
    …uphold our most sacred and ancient duty to let Gulfhaven be the centre from which we will send the Word of God to pagan lands. We ask only for the necessary funds for a new teachinghouse…

Moving into the Middle Borlish period:

    Rhotacisation of syllabic l
    l > r / C_# except [j w]_#

This gives Borlish its signature pairs like capabr "competent"; capablessem "more competent".

    Aphæresis of initial isC
    ɪ > ∅ / #_sC

Like IRL Italian, this means that many words gain an initial vowel only to lose it a millennium later: Latin stannum "tin" > Old Borlish istan "tin" > Modern Borlish stan "tin". However, this process also deletes initial vowels that were there from the start: Latin historia "story" > Old Borlish istoir "story" > Modern Borlish stoir "story".

    Break-up of sr clusters and hiatus
    ∅ > t / s_r
    ∅ > v / [ɔ o u]_V
    uv > ov

The second of these rules is particularly interesting, since it regenerates some <v> which had been lost in the time of Insular Latin. For example, Latin novellus "new" had Insular form noellus "new" > Old Borlish noel "new" > Modern Borlish novel "new"

    Front rounded vowels are lost
    y ʏ > i ɪ

This provides Borlish with another of its signature features, namely <u> /i ɪ/: tu /ti/ "you (sg)"; prun /prɪn/ "plum". The loss of front rounded vowels led to some homophonous pairs like lun lin /lɪn/ "moon; flax". In many cases this led to one of the pair falling out of use (in this case the latter was replaced with the competing form linsc).

    Voicing of final s
    s > z / _#

The precise timing of this sound change is hard to determine, since it does not interact with any nearby sound changes. Likely this originated as a sandhi effect before a following vowel-initial word, e.g. tu es un /ti ɛ‿zɪn/ "you are a...", before being extended to all contexts.

    Diphthong shift part 2
    aj ej ij > ɛj i aj
    əj əw > aj aw

Borlish's answer to the IRL Great Vowel Shift, these changes are somewhat more modest (and take place a little later, between 1600 and 1800). In combination with the loss of front rounded vowels, however, these changes determine much of Borlish's least intuitive orthographic behaviour. For example, we have muy /maj/ "crumb", where <uy> underwent the changes /yj > ij  > aj/.

The previous shift reflects the outcomes in the Damvath Standard dialect of Borlish; these recent changes differ greatly in applicability across the island. We clos with an 1800s sound shift:

    Late consonant backing
    ʃ r > x ʀ

The latter of these appears to be part of a general areal phenomenon of backing rhotics. A single word reflecting both these changes is scuir /xajʀ/ "boy".

118.1: London

notes in translation on the subject of the city of London.

Posc un liesc com citað seconder n'Albion, Londr redenoy alcheðr y cafloy imperial ny region durant y Scon Tetrarchy ne sona d'un part dy Preu Empir Drengoçan.
After time as a secondary city in Albion, London became the imperial capital of the region once more during the Second Tetrarchy as part of the First Drengot Empire.

Y Preu Ðurnç a Londr fis loy d'an 1290; ag mendrem 400 hom ern occis deut ag catastroph d'un semman cohernt.
The First Burning of London took place in 1290; at least 400 people were killed in the ensuing week-long disaster.

L'oc no sta for un parmy conflagraçon plusour ny preu demy dy scon millenner, bempart dec y citað se cou cos saçonner concas des y norð ben y souð.
This was one of several conflagrations in the first half of the second millennium, many due to the city being perennially conquered from the north or south.

Posc l'eç Rix Democratic a plaç meg ny siecr ogtoç yemoy Londr cos final un autonomy durabr deur sy païs vecin d'an 1749 sou Quen Margaret, poðent sy caðen ancestral ligar ag linaç reyal de Marclont e Cant y dou. L'offiç de Segr Bourgmer remane possent cos politic aðief por hast pareïr coll'oç dy nou monarch, interim. 
The Democratic Wars of the mid-eighteenth century saw London finally gain lasting independence from its neighbours in 1748 under Queen Margaret, who could trace her ancestry to the royal families of both Markland and Kent. The office of Lord Mayor remained politically powerful enough to rival that of the new monarch, however.

118.2: rostr "prow"

rostr /ˈrɔ.str̩/ [ˈʀɔ.stɐ]
- prow, bow, the front part of a ship or boat;
- vanguard, the leading members of a convoy of travellers or the leading part of a vehicle (especially of a train);
- (in extended use) forefront, leader, the front part of anything and especially in metaphor to denote the earliest adopters of a technology or custom;
- nib, the point of a pen or similar tool;
- tip, any pointed extremity

Etymology: an uncomplicated descendant from Latin rōstrum "bill, beak, snout, muzzle; prow". The latter meanings are thought to derive from the anatomical senses of the Latin word. Extension from boats to other vehicles and then into metaphorical usage occured during the Middle Borlish period.

Y rostr a my creðon es coroccað.
/i ˈrɔ.str̩ a mi kreˈðɔn ɛz ˌko.rɔˈkaθ/
[i ˈʀɔ.stʀ‿a mi kʀɪˈðɔn ɪz ˌko.ʀʊˈkah]
df nib at 1s.gn pencil be crack-p.pst
The tip of my pencil has snapped. 

##

118.3: balis "beacon"

balis /baˈlɪz/ [bɐˈlɪz]
- beacon, signal fire, a warning light to communicate some message (especially in a military context);
- lighthouse, a tower supporting a light to guide sailors;
- (metaphorically) anything designed to be extremely conspicuous or mark the way;
- aerial, antenna, a device for transmitting electronic signals into the form of radio waves

Etymology: a borrowing via Middle French balise "beacon; buoy" from contemporary Portingale baliza "buoy". This appears to be from an unattested Late Latin pālītia, related to pālus "stake, post". In the sense "lighthouse" it is clipped from the phrase tour balis "beacon tower"; in the last sense it is attested from the early twentieth century.

Nos stoun balis sobottal luicessem.
/nɔz stun baˈlɪz ˌso.bɔˈtal lajˈtsɛ.sɛm/
[nɔz stun bɐˈlɪz ˌso.bʊˈtal lɐjˈtsɛ.sɐm]
1p need-3p beacon radio bright-comp
We need stronger radio transmitters.

118.4: sounç "release"

sounç /sunts/ [suns]
- release, the act of letting something or someone go or of causing something or something to become unstuck or untangled;
- launch, the movement of a vessel from land or moorage into the water;
- outbreak, outburst, the sudden appearance of something such as illness or war;
- (vulgar) orgasm, climax, the peak of sexual pleasure

Etymology: nominal derivative from verb souvr "solve, let go, release, launch", from solvō "I loosen, untie"; or, directly from a Latin noun solventia "a loosening, an untying". In the last sense attested from as early as the eighteenth century in erotic literature; the term continues to be dispreferred in formal or technical contexts.

Y sounç de var interromoy eç accommission corrogaçonal.
/i sunts daˈbat ɪnˌtɛ.roˈmɔj ɛts ˌa.kɔ.mɪˈsjɔn ˌkɔ.roˌga.tsoˈnal/
[i suns dɐˈbat ɪnˌtɛ.ʀʊˈmɔj ɛ‿ˌtsa.kʊ.mɪˈsjɔn ˌkɔ.ʀʊˌga.tsʊˈnal]
df release of=war interrupt-pst p.dt project infrastructural
War breaking out interrupted those infrastructure projects.

##

118.5: Hasiny

Hasiny is the largest and most populous of the polities of British Mendeva. This refers to the region of Mendeva which have undergone significant settlement from or otherwise been significantly influenced by the Kingdom of Britain.

Hasiny is centred on the lower parts of the watershed of the Bahassassin River, but its lands extend sufficiently far northeast so as to share a short border with New Provence along part of the Sturgovan range. It borders the polity of Taisha to the west, and its capital city is Nadacow, which lies on the Bahassassin.

The name Hasiny derives from the confederation of the same name, which extended across lands which are now part of Hasiny and Taisha.

The languages of administration in Hasiny are Jaughta (Jahtá, the Mendevan language spoken by a majority of the populace) and the local variety of Welsh (which differs in important ways from the dialects of British or Chrysian Welsh).

Hasiny was the homeland of the herdtale genre of fiction, which sought to depict a rural idyll with a focus on animal husbandry.

The resort town of Y Davarn Heul (The Sun Hotel) was constructed in the nineteenth century for Hasiny's ruling Tamaha dynasty, gaining such fame that the word "davarn" has entered many languages with the meaning "grand hotel, resort".

The first radio was built in Hasiny in 1903. The fourth Lineball Global Tourney (LGT) in 1935 took place in Hasiny, the first time it was held in Mendeva.

People
Bayac Cosωteg (fl. c19), diarist and political agitator
Kjartan Rhysvor (fl. 1889), author of spycraft work While Embers Cool (Pan Oera'r Glo)
King Maldwen Tamaha (fl. 1950), long-reigning monarch
Peðr Tamaha (fl. 1950), bon-vivant prince notorious for perennial debt troubles
Cadωgan Torriωr (fl. 1890), author of masquira work Men of Jet and Diamond (Dynnon o Vuhuð a Diamont)

119.1: Libya

collected notes in translation on the polity of Libya.

Durant y Scon Tetrarchy loy fignt ny scon millenner primal, Libya (y nom temporane Ifricia dignant) sta un admiraltað majour ny Caliphað Sengr, regnað de Tunis.
During the Second Tetrarchy of the early second millennium, Libya (under the name Ifricia) was an important admiralty of the Single Caliphate, ruled from Tunis.

Tandic prepondranç imperial n'Europ e n'Afric norðer inceveu sy dissoluçon, tan cossy y Caliphað Sengr; un admiraltað autonom ne Libya er depos d'an 1237 (a veg ceu temporane coll'admiraltað Morrou nell'ovest).
As imperial hegemony in Europe and northern Africa began to fall apart, so did the Single Caliphate; an independent admiralty in Libya was declared in 1237 (at roughly the same time as the Morrove admiralty to the west).

Noc obstroint ig y flottisc Libyan n'er ja commarçant cos direct ag Novomont ny siecr seç, moðnaut des y region stan frequent armað par y flottisc marcander de Morrac e (cos particuler) de Provenç.
Although Libya's navy was not yet trading directly with the Novomund in the sixteenth century, seamen from the region were commonly employed in the merchant fleets of Morrack and (especially) of Provence.

Ny siecr settoç primal, y gonfan de Libya abrange dou quarrel neir, un blanc eð un oransc.
In the early seventeenth century, the banner of Libya comprised two black fields, one white and one orange.

119.2: sleut "politician"

sleut /slawt/ [zlawt]
- politician, representative, someone engaged in politics as an elected or appointed official;
- smooth talker, sycophant, silver tongue, someone skilled in charming people or especially in keeping the peace

Etymology: substantive use of the past participle of verb sleir "to elect, to vote for", itself via Old Borlish isler "elect" from Vulgar Latin exligō (Classical ēligō "I pick, choose, elect"). The term was used almost immediately as a somewhat derogatory term for anyone perceived to act in the manner of a politician.

Noc imprefait es ig tell'heir denoy sleut.
/nɔk ˌɪm.preˈfet ɛz aj tɛˈlir deˈnɔj slawt/

I'm not surprised your son's a politician.

119.3: a squid "on the take"

a squid /a skwɪd/ [a skwɪd]
- on the take, corrupt, bought, bribed, accepting money from illicit sources in exchange for their influence;
- subverted, in the pocket (of), secretly under someone else's control

Etymology: 19C, analysable as a phrase meaning "at handshake", using the slang term squid "handshake; informal agreement, under-the-table deal". However, it is unclear whether the noun squid is a backformation, as the phrase may have been borrowed wholesale from contemporary Welsh á sguyd "with a (hand)shake", a derivative of verb squid "shake, toss, tremble".

J'aye spien ig l'oç madarc no fos a squid.
/ʒɛˈje spjɛn aj lɔts maˈdark no fɔz a skwɪd/
[ʝɪˈje spjɛn aj lɔs mɐˈdɐːk no fɔz a skwɪd]
1s=have-imp hope cmp df=s.dt cop ng be.sbj.imp at handshake
I hoped that that cop wasn't on the take.

119.4: rubic "sporty"

rubic /riˈbɪk/ [ʀɪˈbɪk]
- pertaining to sports;
- sporty, athletic, inclined to physical activity;
- competitive, cutthroat, eager to win against others

Etymology: a 19C backformation (based on analogy to the adjectival -ic ending) from rubicon "sports, athletic activity". This itself is an 18C folk-etymological form (evoking the idiom y Rubicon trasir "to pass the point of no return; to start a fight"), possibly via a French or English language, from Willem Dutch robicong "competition, sport, athletics". This is a compound of rob "fight, contest, brawl" and iken "to be compared, compete".

Le scey tojorn quondant con un çod rubic.
/le xi toˈʒɔrn kwɔnˈdant kɔn ɪn tsɔd riˈbɪk/
[le çi tʊˈʝɔːn kwʊnˈdaŋ kɔn ɪn tsɔd ʀɪˈbɪk]
3s.ac there.is always lurk-p.prs with indf squad sporty
She's always hanging out with sporty friends.

119.5: Seventeenth Century Studies

shortform questions lifted from a 2024 scitation paper for the course Details of the Seventeeth Century (Y Siecr Settoç a Sgart Jusser), an avenue of concurrence history offered by the Jacobin University of Axbane.

1. Which groups were expelled from Moscat in the Ibadine Imamate in 1652, and which local power would go on to seize the city some months later?

2. Which two rivers of Gaul were connected by a canal for the first time in 1679, in a bid to connect the Atlantic to the Middlesea without having to pass through Morrack-controlled seas?

3. Where was the treaty of 1621 which outlined the legal relationship of Santrafew to the local Mendevan peoples signed?

4. For how long did Emperor Carivasary of Tavancy rule until his suspected assassination in 1660?

5. Which future monarch of Barcelon spent several years of his childhood in Cordin as a ward of the Borlish royal family during the 1660s and 1670s?

6. Which power attempted to invade Borland in the seventeenth century, leading to the Hawkirch Surrender of 1632?

7. The terms "copperplate" and "tinplate" in political theory originate in David Bensaíd's treatise The Three Cities; he coins these terms in his description of the court of which seventeenth-century monarch of Libya?

8. What astronomical event of 1677 inspired theorists from across the world to undertake long journeys, including the Danish astronomers Gudmund and Rebecca Scrander's storied voyage to the Seldivan court?

9. What did the invention of the timehold in the mid-seventeenth century allow people to measure accurately for the first time?

10. The trade mesh of which Indian polity stretched from Sant Adrian to Cathay by the end of the seventeenth century?

Since it seems his invitation to eat together will not be accepted, and since he is expected back at the garrison anyway, Omar hurries to the tower.

Ac son y soldart nuvr ðorant, sur lorrell'assignment aglon de ny masquet cosogr y païsan, deut ag besogn ig il noun se situar lontan demay dy gran port condon y toxen incoïbr sorc por avartr ig y preu rostr Roman son detectað.

120.2: ne fousc "broke"

ne fousc /ne fux/ [nɪˈfux]
- broke, penniless, destitute, having no money;
- bankrupt, ruined, in a position of not having enough money to pay one's debts

Etymology: nineteenth-century idiom literally meaning "in (a) pit". The noun fousc "pit, hole in the ground; trap, snare, pitfall" descends with meaning pracatically unchanged via Old Borlish fouz /futʃ/ from fovea in Latin. The coventionalised intensifier for this idiom is arð "steep", which has been analogised to other expressions for poverty; cf. povr arð "very poor".

Jo luy dau un cromn neðan i surcous ne fousc arð.

1s 3s.obl give-pst indf purse lest 3s end.up-imp.sbj in pit steep
I gave him some cash so he wouldn't be flat broke.

120.3: inoïð "silent"

inoïð /ˌɪ.nɔjˈɪθ/ [ˌɪ.nʊˈjɪh]
- silent, soundless, noiseless, without any sound;
- unheard, unnoticed, ignored, forgotten, unrecognised, not acknowledged;
- unheard-of, unprecedented, never before having been done or otherwise experienced

Etymology: negated past participle of oïr "to hear", seen in usage extended from the literal "unheard" from the twelfth century. The verb descends directly from Latin audiō "I hear". In the specific sense "unprecedented" it is seen from the seventeenth century.

Com soð vos tout dijarnt a mesur dell'ec asc inoïð?

how be.2p 2p all cope-p.prs at course of-df=p.px time unheard
How are you faring in these unprecedented times?

120.4: frastr "ash"

frastr /ˈfra.str̩/ [ˈfra.stɐ]
- ash tree, a deciduous tree in the olive family;
- ashwood, the wood of the ash tree;
- (historical) javelin, a light spear thrown as a lang-distance weapon;
- tough, resilient, sturdy, able to withstand considerable force;
- (slang) jacked, built, shredded, strapping, burly, notably muscular

Etymology: direct descendant via Old Borlish fra(i)sre "ash tree, ash wood, spear" from synonymous frāxinus in Latin. Ash wood has been used for spear shafts since pre-Classical times. As an adjective the word is seen from the fourteenth century; in its specific slang sense it is likely at most fifty years old.

Con ðigl eu nos y dou port rent frasterrem.
/kɔn ðajl aw nɔz i du pɔrt rɛnt fraˈstɛ.rɛm/

We've reinforced both doors with planks.

120.5: Borland before Borlish

excerpt from Borland before Borlish (Istr Boral pre Borallesc), a history textbook published in 1983 though the New Vithor University.

…discussion of the Kelt peoples who lived on Borland before the Roman conquests of the Flavian period is limited by our lack of written sources. The few inscriptions we do have are mostly translations of placenames and the names of tribes in Roman sources, appearing since the onset of diplomacy and trade with Rome since Julius Caesar's expeditions to Britannia in the first century aN.

One important exception is the name the Borland Kelts appear to have used collectively to distinguish themselves from the Britons: the Bora Ale. There has been speculation for centuries that the name Borrhaloi (which the Greek explorer Pytheas gives alongside Bretannike, and which became Latin Borālēs) is of Kelt origin, and not merely a derivative of Greek Βορρᾶς "the North Wind, the North". The 1932 unearthing at the Livaucr site of a burial marker reading IANTUMOR ABONDUU ALE "Jantumarus of the Abonduvii" proved that ales (pl. alē, cognate with Welsh ail "second", Latin alius "other") was used locally to mean "people, tribe".

Hence, Bora Ale is reconstructed as meaning "people of the East", with bora(g) "East, sunrise" corresponding to Welsh bore "morning" and Irish márah "tomorrow". It may even have originated as a exonym applied by the Britons, which would explain the hypothesised sense development of a word which originally meant "others".

Of course, the Borland Kelts did not always conceive of themselves as an indivisible group, and over a dozen tribal names are attested…

121.1: Second German War

notes in translation on the subject of the Second German War.

Y Var Theudesc Dovem (1815–23) sta un rix y condensaðessem n'eiðel Theudesc ma pres toð y polity n'Europ pleitent. 
The Second German War (1815–23) was a conflict centred on German lands but involving almost all the polities of Europe.

L'interman y finisc lonc ustol dy Paç Lonc.
It marks the conventional end of the Long Peace.

L'oc var es cossirað com un part dell'occorrenç mondial dy Rix a Reacçon, ig abrangent de conflict desjognt cas traitment ma contemporane tras y mont.
This war is considered part of the global phenomenon of Reaction War, which includes politically unrelated but contemporaneous conflicts around the world.

Degnant ig Vascony acavaus cos iniçal a noc denir jannestað ny conflict, alcant ig sell'envou ne Mendeva e nell'Aust aurn se caut periglað, rey de lor Hernand IV n'aye l'ouçon sauf var souvr contr y Concert Norðer e sociant con y Convey.
Although Vascony at first managed not to become embroiled in the conflict, once its interests in Mendeva and the East were threatened, then-king Hernand IV had no choice but to declare against the Northern Concert and in favour of the Convoy.

Istr Boral se pleitoy ny var, cossy sceint soldart Borallesc present a cost batman Bavarn e Furlan ag catastroph cas mal gournment dy Battagl a Houlm d'an 1821. 
Borland participated in the war, with Borlish soldiers present alongside Bavarn and Furlain fighters at the disastrously mismanaged Battle of Hulm in 1821.

121.2: baðaspat "nonplussed"

baðaspat /ˌba.ðaˈspat/ [ˌbaðɐˈspat]
- nonplussed, bewildered, perplexed, puzzled, thrown, at a loss, in a state of confusion;
- indignant, outraged, startled, astonished, in a state of heightened emotion and reflexive disapproval

Etymology: first mentioned in the eighteenth century as a new piece of fashionable slang, probably of dialectal origin. Thought to be a compound; the first part is a form of baðar, local variant of sbayar "gawp, goggle" descending from Medieval Latin (ex)batō, exbadō "I gape, yawn". The second part spat is presumably a variant of spait, past participle of spagir "frightened, scared" and descending from Vulgar Latin expaveō "I am terrified of".

L'aye min baðaspat de my vestið vabian closnautr.
/lɛˈje mɪn ˌba.ðaˈspat de mi vɛˈstɪθ vaˈbjan klɔˈsnotr̩/
[lɪˈje mɪn ˌba.ðɐˈspat de mi vɪˈstɪh vɐˈbjaŋ klʊˈzno.tɐ]
3s=have-imp nonplussed of 1s.gn clothing disrepair beset
He looked nonplussed at my bedraggled appearance.

121.3: scaug "hung"

scaug /xoj/ [xoj]
- thicket, copse, grove, stand, a dense but small collection of trees or shrubs;
- bramble, briars, an area of thorny shrubs
- tangle, mess, snarl, a knotted twisted mass;
- maze, conflict, dispute, an intricate complication or difficult situation;
- tangled, knotty, snarled, interwoven as of strands or branches;
- thorny, complex, intricate, hard to navigate or make progress through;
- unresolved, unsolved, indeterminate, open, unsettled, not having been sorted out;
- (law) hung, undecided, of a jury not having reached a verdict;
- (politics) hung, of a legislature lacking a majority political party

Etymology: a borrowing from early Middle English shawe, scaȝe "thicket", from synonymous sceaga in Old English. Extended metaphorically to any tangle by the fifteenth century, and in adjectival use since the seventeenth. In its legal and political senses it is attested from the Global Workshop period.

Orruð ig scerra alcheðr un parolment scaug.

121.4: desbiacq "hung"

desbiacq /dɛˈsbjak/ [dɪˈzbjak]
- imbalanced, lopsided, skewed, leaning to one side or having inequal quantities in different parts;
- aslant, askew, diagonally, obliquely, turned or twisted to one side;
- (music) swung, with beats split into a pair of notes the first of which is somewhat longer than the second;
- (slang, crude) hung, well-endowed, having a notably large penis

Etymology: early modern borrowing via French desbiaque "slanted, lopsided" from synonymous di sbiaco in an Italian language. ##

121.5: Pluralisation

Final /-s/ is lost really early on in the development of Borlish; it's one of the very first sound changes that distinguishes it from the mainland Romance languages, occuring by around 500 AD. This, along with the loss of the genitive case (replaced with the ablative) makes the noun declension of typical nouns look like this:
Image

Notice that masculine nouns typically have only two forms, and feminine nouns only three. Once final vowels also get neutralised to schwa (and eventually lost entirely), the noun paradigm for regular nouns has completely collapsed.

A few nouns briefly retain an irregular paradigm of the following shape, with a separate nominative singular:
Image

However, by the late Old Borlish period these have all been levelled to (usually) the oblique form; sour "sister" is the only counterexample where instead the nominative singular survives.

Several strategies for marking noun number were innovated during the Old Borlish period, mostly involving demonstratives like ille, iste and ipse. However, the forms that survive to the present derive from the demonstrative hic "this". Specifically, we have:

    oc "singular" < hoc, neuter singular
    ec "plural" < haec, neuter plural

In the late Old Borlish period we see the redevelopment of a proximate-distal contrast, with new distal demonstratives formed using the adverb i "there" (since lost; cf. Modern Borlish la < illāc):

    oç < oc i "that" < hoc ibi
    eç < ec i "those" < haec ibi

Coda: Some Modern Borlish Names

There are a few Celtic names which survive in modern Borlish, for various reasons.

A very few names entered Borland Latin from the local Celtic during the Roman Empire. As a possible example, the male name Ivocq is thought to reflect Borland Celtic *iwok- "like a yew tree".

More Celtic names enter Borlish at various stages since the medieval period. One of the earliest is the female name Jonnovar, cognate with Guinevere and Jennifer, and which is also used as a common noun meaning "butterfly".

122.1: Breakfast Time

excerpt in translation from the beginning of the short story Breakfast Time by Derin Edala.

Mell'heir es cogntið de liesc recorrent veg ancour.
My son’s stuck in a time loop again.

I crey jo saif noc, lon digr.
He thinks I don’t know, of course.

I n'a jamay me descont ig ly cay l'oc (ben ig i poð l'oc fair, parcanç; jo no's scur de calun).
He’s never told me that this happens to him (or that he can do this, possibly; I’m not sure which it is).

Plausibr es ig jo's un mal maðr, ða jo n'ay me provað a l'ig confeyanç dignar.
Maybe I’m a bad mother, if I haven’t proven myself worthy of that trust.

Ma no scein for tan veg yon se poð y heir sgardar sy jorn passant a monnocquant ant impatienç infruniscent, reagent de tout teyon dis cos rapid demay just com picq eð alcun goppiet mostrant ag cainç y goppietandessem meðes, e soulor descenent souscen desmecchiattað ma rajounað eð ant un exuberanç novel a cost un incainç vars emboscment souvar dy cos y previsiblessem meðes, fin a tu discern y ratiocinaçon evident.
But there are only so many times that you can watch your son trudge through a day with bored impatience, anticipating everything you say just a little too quickly and showing no surprise to even the most surprising event, and then come downstairs the next day disoriented but rejuvenated and with a new zest for life and a tendency to get blindsided by even the most predictable things, before you make the obvious connection.

122.2: lastumnesc "haggard"

lastumnesc /ˌla.stɪmˈnɛx/ [ˌla.stɪmˈnɛç]
- haggard, drawn, stressed, appearing unwell or worried;
- weary, exhausted, tired, suffering from a lack of sleep;
- dilapidated, ramshackle, bedraggled, in poor condition

Etymology: fifteenth century, adjectival derivation from noun lastumn "exhaustion, weariness, stress". This is either a secondary derivation in the Old Borlish period from adjective las "tired, faint, spent" from synonymous lassus in Latin, or else a direct descendant of the Latin noun lassitūdō "faintness, weariness". In its use for things other than people the word is attested from the eighteenth century.

Il ayen heu lastumnesc, com ig il n'ayen for pog dormið.

122.4: pounçar "flirt"

pounçar /punˈtsar/ [pʊnˈtsɐː]
- abrade, exfoliate, to use pumice stone to smooth or clean;
- (archaic) snog, neck, kiss, make out, to kiss passionately;
- charm, coax, flatter, to use one's words and manner to persuade or seduce someone;
- flirt, woo, to play at courtship or seduction

Etymology: originally in the first sense, a verbal derivation from pounç "pumice stone", itself via Norman from synonymous pūmex in Latin. In its archaic sense its usage mirrors others slang terms relating rubbing motions to sexual activity. By the mid-nineteenth century the term had weakened to describe flirtatious behaviour.

Fig a pounçar e faç mey garaf poll'oc gat!
/faj a punˈtsar e fats mi gaˈraf pɔˈlɔk gat/
[faj a pʊnˈtsɐː‿ʀe fas mi gɐˈʀaf pʊˈlɔ gat]
set at flirt-inf and do.sbj 1s.dsj grip for-df=s.px gate
Stop flirting and help me with this barrier!

##

122.5: Vascon Ascendancy

    collected notes on the period of Western European history known as the Vascony Ascendancy.

The Vascon Ascendancy (Vascon: L'Ascendença Vasconna; Vask: Igualdea Vascoina) refers to the polity of Vascony from the early fifteenth century until the late sixteenth. At this time it enjoyed a territorial maximum due to several successful military conquests, as well as a general increase in prosperity.
Image

(Vascony, 1456 N)

The beginning of the Ascendancy is usually placed at the start of the reign of Ambrose II, who was crowned in 1410. His reign was marked by a succession of wars, both west into northern Portingale (taking all of Galice and even down to Braga), and east into Burgundy (taking the wealthy coastal regions of Tolose and Provence).

Ambrose III "the Ascendant" (for whom the period was retrospectively named) succeeded his grandfather in 1456. He established the New Navarre Enterprise two years later, an expanded merchant fleet with the dual aims of monopolising the trade of North Atlantic fish through the Middlesea and of creating trade ports down the western coast of Africa. This led to greatly increased fishing activity, and it was Vask ships travelling north past Valland [Greenland] that encountered Brasil [Newfoundland] in the 1471 Novomundine Landfall.

Trade with the Novomund, especially once the far more favourable southern route was discovered, enriched Vascony and especially the port towns in Portingale and Leon. Cities flourished, and there was also an outpouring of new artistic techniques from painting to poetry.

The Ascendancy is by most accounts over by the War of the Two Queens in the second half of the sixteenth century. By this time the land of both Portingale and Provence had been lost and the polity was reduced to its heartland. Furthermore, the Second Great Dying killed almost one in seven people in Vascony (although immigration was high enough to offset the loss of population by 1550).
Art

    I am Ambrose (Sou Ambroxo), a 1923 film in Portingale by director Agochino, which is a character study of King Ambrose the Ascendant through his long life.
    The Ascendant (Hwn a Guodoð), a 1934 film in Welsh by director Dormaget, which chronicles in particle the years immediately after the 1471 Novomundine Landfall.lm in Welsh by director Dormaget, which chronicles in particle the years immediately after the 1471 Novomundine Landfall.

123.2: arveiðrous "random"

arveiðrous /ˌar.viðˈruz/ [ˌɐː.vɪ(ð)ˈʀuz]
- arbitrary, discretionary, unspecific, subjective, not based on any objective criterion;
- random, unpredictable, not conforming to any perceptible pattern;
- impulsive, capricious, spontaneous, acting without reason or forewarning

Etymology: seventeenth century, adjectival derivative from arveiðr "impulse, whim, caprice". This descends directly from Latin arbitrium "judgement, decision; discretion". In the sense of unpredictability the word is attested from the late eighteenth century.

Jo fey paupieðr an spaiðoir arveiðrous con hast.

123.3: ðorof "drove"

ðorof /ðoˈrɔf/ [ðʊˈʀɔf]
- drove, a group of animals being driven as to market or between fields;

- herd, flock, a group of certain animals such as rabbits and hares

123.4: cofrsac "backpack"

cofrsac /ˌkɔfr̩ˈsak/ [ˌkɔ.fɐˈsak]
- backpack, rucksack, a case of leather or fabric for carrying things on the back;
- shoulder bag, messenger bag, a sack worn on one shoulder and around the chest

Etymology: Middle Borlish, compound of cofr "basket" (now archaic or dialect) < synonymous cophinus in Latin, and sac < Latin saccus "bag, sack". Originally in the latter senses, denoting a bag carried like a basket; in the "backpack" sense it is attested only from the late nineteenth century.

123.5: Dart Geometry

excerpted from Drawing in the Sand: the History of Calculation, a collaborative reference book originally published 1954 in Napolitan as Scheme ne Rene: a Storia d'Amiradanza by the Agenza Scholaria Fodgesa.

…tempting to draw a straight line from Euclid's Elements until the introduction of new instantiations of geometry in Ferenc's pioneering 1819 work Geometriæ Inquadrabiles, seeing any developments in the meantime as merely the proving of ever more particular theorems. However, this fails to acknowledge the truly conceptual advancements in the field, which would go on to influence diverse parts of mathematics and theory.

In this section, we chart the development of the "dart method" as an extension of Euclidean geometry. In all the theorems of The Elements, no distinction is made between a line AB and its reverse BA. It is only in the late fifteenth century that scholars like Barclythe and da Treviso begin to assign directions to lines (it is unclear whether the parallel developments at the Hicma Academy in Baghdad are due to direct communication or simply an independent invention).

It was this seemingly trivial addition that enabled geometers to do two important things. First, it brought ablate [negative] quantities into the realm of respectability in European mathematics; although the idea of "less-than-no things" was absurd (nonetheless, ablate numbers were already being used in the account-books of Venise and other trade cities to denote debts), no-one was perturbed by the concept of returning to one's starting point by trdavelling from A to B, and then from B to A. Second, it allowed for stronger ties between geometry and the newly-imported algebra; adding together two directed lines was conceptually as easy as laying two arrows point-to-vane.

In this way, one could translate a geometric statement like "the lines a, b and c form a triangle" into the algebraic equation "a + b = c". Indeed, over the proceeding decades mathematicians worked to render all the proofs of the Elements into this form. Extending the theory to mozate [two-dimensional] shapes took…

124.1: Historical Linguistics Exam

excerpt in translation from sample scitation papers for the University of Lester's Faculty of Domain History, published in 1990.

Entrou 5 (trent minut) Argument fair ou ne promoçon ben n'opposson cas dou calscon parmy l'ec thes.
Question 5 (thirty minutes) Argue either in favour of or in opposition to any two of the following theses.

(i) Y parol Anglesc 'silver' a un origin incertan—parol referent all'oç matier son accart des un lengaç vars un autr tras millenner par mejan de sar commarcer lað. L'origin y plausiblessem dell'oc parol (v. sudrabs ne Lithovan, 'asrvae ne Hausan, zirar ne Vasq) com parol trocher es 𒀫𒁍𒌝 (surpum) n'Acadian ataval.
(i) The word 'silver' is of uncertain origin—words referring to the substance have been borrowed between languages for millennia via extensive trade networks. The most likely origin of the word (cf. Lithowan sudrabs, Hausan 'asrvae, Vask zirar) as a trade-word is in ancient Acadian 𒀫𒁍𒌝 (surpum).

(ii) Y benoç de run Sinnesc lonc son, un issar por nom certan e por autr parol d'origin foran des antictað e tesmognað ne polity veçinant (v. lettranç maniocan primal) des y sieçr settem N, caf reconnoscenç ne Cathay sou y regn Kitannesc deut a gimmolt volonter por y polity sevrar deur sell'eç veçin souðer.
(ii) Usage of Sinic runes soundwise, a practice in certain names and other words of foreign origin since antiquity and seen in neighbouring polities (cf. early maniocan [man'yōgana] script) from the seventh century N, gains currency in Cathay during Kitan rule due to purposeful efforts to sunder the polity from their southern neighbours.

124.2: entr hugt e gavisc "torn"

entr hugt e gavisc /ˈɛntr̩ hajt e gaˈvɪx/ [ˈɛn.tɐ hajt e gɐˈvɪç]
- torn, unable to decide between two (good) options;
- living it up, going from strength to strength, experiencing a continual abundance of good fortune

Etymology: idiom from the fifteenth century (Kigman), literally "between happiness and joy". The noun hugt "happiness" descends from Old Borlish huȝt, a borrowing from Old English hyht "hope"; the noun gavisc is a deverbal from gavir "enjoy, feel happy", which descends directly from Latin gaudeō "I rejoice, make merry". Used primarily with negative valence (portraying the necessary choice as an imposition) until the nineteenth century, at which the latter sense begin to be attested.

L'indrec de my sour es se trovant entr hugt e gavisc.
/lɪnˈdrɛk de mi sur ɛz se troˈvant ˈɛntr̩ hajt e gaˈvɪx/
[lɪnˈdʀɛk de mi sʊː‿ʀɪz se tʀʊˈvant ɛn.tɐ hajt e gɐˈvɪç]
df=charity of 1s.gn sister be rf find-p.prs between happiness and joy
My sister's charity is going from strength to strength.

124.3: fis "done"

fis /fɪz/ [fɪz]
- set, stuck, immovable, placed somewhere on a more-or-less permanent basis;
- done, complete, finished, having nothing else of an activity or project to do;
- spent, exhausted, empty, having been entirely used up;
- despairing, hopeless, resigned to the inevitability of failure or defeat;
- screwed, finished, in a hopeless situation

Etymology: past participle of figr "set down, place down, lay" used also as the past participle of figr a "finish, finish off, complete, stop" (where perhaps fis la would be more regular). In the sense of having run out of something, the word is seen from the sixteenth century; in the last senses it is seen from the seventeenth.
