124.5: Who's Who (1700s Edition)

    collected notes on various figures active during the eighteenth century.

Raymond al Mustafa (fl. 1750) was a mathematician and philosopher. He was resident for some time in Barcelon under the Duke of Aragon's patronage. During this time he corresponded with fellow theorist Rachel Desselut, and their letters outline some of the concepts that would go on to define the field of methodics.

He spent his latter years travelling, eventually settling in Brasil [Newfoundland]. His grandson Fabian Mostàf became an eminent astronomer at the Paratzon Observatory, using mathematical techniques developed in part by Raymond (like the waveform display [Fourier transform] to compute celestial orbits).

-

Marian Siegert ~ Miller (1725–56) was the illegitimate daughter of Elias Villingen, second Duke of Far Suebia [~a region west of Swabia]. She grew up at the ducal seat in Castle Carlsfeld as a recognised bastard, and was close with the Duke's younger legitimate children. She married Albert Siegert, a merchant in leather and a magnate of the shoemaking industry, at the age of eighteen, and moved with him to Lepzi [Leipzig].

From her regular correpondence with her half-brother Thomas she is known to have learnt to speak Burgund as a child and Bohamish [Czech] as an adult. With Albert she had several children, the eldest of whom would become the pioneering author Elsebeth Sneider.

-

Lord Mathurin Carrow, Baron of Ebbasham [Epsom] (fl. 1763) was a traveller who published accounts of his journeys. He is remembered in particular for his mealbooks which compile recipes from the places he visited.

An early work of his, A Complete Assembly of the Towns and Cities of Markland for the Edification of the Good Food Amateur, was popular across the Northwestern Isles [Britain, Ireland and Borland] (the Borlish translation being infamously inaccurate) but failed to sell further afield. Later volumes like An Account of the Vittles of the Various German Peoples and On the Sundry Uses of the Shadome Fruit [tomato] were far more enduring, being republished several times even after his death.

Y Colluy dy Nou Mont nommað cos auspecer sta corporalleyað par Malic Mounir al-Hamdawi d'an 1643, e pres pront la nonçamen dell'Abanc Novomondin fos yent a cort ern vascel dy Colluy accaçað vars l'ovest.

125.3: ðorn de hanc "sideswipe"

ðorn de hanc /ðɔrn de hank/ [ðɔːn de haŋk]
- swipe, sideswipe, hook, a punch or other strike from the side;
- bolt from the blue, a completely unexpected event (especially one for which you are utterly unprepared)

Etymology: phrase meaning "punch from (the) flank", used figuratively to describe an unexpected event since the late eighteenth century. The noun ðorn "punch" is a deverbal from now-obsolete aðornar "to punch", itself directly from synonymous addurnō in Insular Latin (of ultimate Kelt origin). The noun hanc "hip, hipbone; flank, loin, side" descends from Vulgar Latin hanca "hip", from a German source related to ankle in English.

125.4: govondry "canteen"

govondry /ˌgo.vɔnˈdri/ [ˌgo.vʊnˈdʀi]
- canteen, cafeteria, a small cafe inside a larger establishment (e.g. military base, school, prison or workplace);

##

125.5: Denmark

Denmark is a peninsular polity located between the North and Graven Seas.

History
Denmark was part of the homeland of the Danes during the Dane Supremacy in the medieval period, from which viking raids and colonisation projects left. The rulers of Borland and much of Dane England during this time were dynasties originating in Denmark.

During the sixteenth century Denmark was part of the Dane Concert, a monarchic union of northern states. The royal family undertook a grand tour of their realm in the years around 1560, visiting places like Alburgh. It was this period which saw Revitalism reach Denmark, with renewed interrogation of Classical texts.

Instability in Denmark belying the Long Peace of the late eighteenth century led to an uptick in emigration, both to nearby polities like Borland and also the distant staddomains of Cappatia.

The expansion of suffrage in Denmark took place through the latter half of the nineteenth century, parallel to similar movements in Saxony and the Latin republics. During this time Denmark was drawn into the orbit of the Drengot Collusion, although it was never fully incorporated.

People
Elisa Arnoutszen (fl. 1540), nurse in the household of Duke Roger d'Avosche and later a physician in her own right
Laurz Arnoutszen (fl. 1540), famed physician whose treatise on medical handiwork revolutionised European practice
Absolon Mortenszen (fl. 1560), playwright and commentator who lived in Alburgh and is remembered for his play High Society
Gudmund & Rebecca Scrander (fl. 1677), astronomers who voyaged to Seldiva to observe a transit of Venus

126.1: Secret Notes

excerpt in translation from the 1930 work Notas a Hurt "Secret Notes", an example of the spycraft genre written in Vascony by author Micolau Zorriqueta (whose similar series of works about a Huzatre detective is more widely remembered).

Martin scoutau y baðrment durant hour monfeyað e fo mesteyað n'yembr scið posc i lançau ogl a sell'orlosc a caðen ig for veint minut n'ern laundað.
Martin listened to the ensemble for several hours and was disappointed to discover when he glanced at his watch that only twenty minutes had passed.

Cos ouveg i recuidau ig Jacq n'aye besogn aut de sy presenç la bogr; l'ec fardig a torriot dont Martin aye sy parcorrenç oïð ig crevoscr ayen son nervous e meðes foyaçant.
Sullenly he reflected that James hadn't needed him in attendance at all; the bassoon solos Martin had heard him rehearsing last night sounded confident and even virtuosic.

Manifest tan sta ig lorry caf maldigt au l'orn enter recompos.

Y cæros de Jacq caint zaressem vole avenir ag liesc outr dy crevoscr, e donc Martin poðe noc meðes sortir ortellent ag tarnot dy loy ny hiat.

It was an overture from that opera he'd been dragged to a film staging of and subsequently ranted at about for two hours.

Sceyen hombeul ant cinq pie entarn, i creye—pu veram i n'aye alcun nis prestað la.
There were monsters with five feet in it, he thought—although he really hadn't been paying attention.

126.4: soccos destr "red-handed"

soccos destr /sɔˈkɔz ˈdɛstr̩/ [sʊˈkɔz ˈdɛ.stɐ]
- made, rumbled, caught, red-handed, having been discovered doing deceitful or illicit behaviour;
- unmasked, exposed, outed, having had some formerly secret information revealed

Etymology: past participle of soccoðr des "to shake out of; to unmask". The verb soccoðr "shake, mix up" descends directly from Latin succutiō "toss up, fling into the air". The adverb destr "out of there" reflects Latin dē "from" and exter "on the outside".

We had to run as soon as we were rumbled.

126.5: Chemical Etymology

excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary of Alchemy, a reference quire compiled by Rotcham University Primers.

- moron n. /ˈmɔː.ɾɔn/ [proton] a deficient [positively charged] particle as found in atomic nuxes [nuclei]. 1888 < Kiew [Kyiv] Russian мора · mora (1882) < Ancient Greek μόρον · móron "mulberry, blackberry", in reference to Nike Sarantylack's "mulberry model" of the atom as containing a number of each of two different sorts of particle.

- lucifer adj., n. /ˈləu.sɪ.fə/ [radioactive (substance)] of a substance, spontaneously producing subatomic particles or ionising light; such a substance. 1894 < Vascon lucifer < Latin lūcifer "light-bringing", from lūx "light" and -fer "carrying". Connected only incidentally with proper noun Lucifer "Satan".

- killdark n. /ˈkɪl.daːk/ [uranium] the corporal [element] whose atoms have 92 mora, a lucifer [radioactive] grey metal. 1810 < Welsh kildárc "killdark" (1805) < the Irish shire of Killdara, where the corporal was first isolated. Plausibly respelt after "dark"; the Wessern English form darick /ˈda.ɾək/ "dark" may also have played a role.

- lix n. /lɪks/ [potassium] the corporal whose atoms have 19 mora, a soft grey metal acted on by air and water and thus never found in tesquo [in nature] as a metal. 1797 < Latin lixa "lye", which is the caustic of lix [potassium hydroxide].

- janthine n. /ˈdʒan.θəin/ [iodine] the corporal whose atoms have 53 mora, found as a grey solid, a purple-black liquid and a purple gas. 1791 < Scholastic Latin janthīnus < Ancient Greek ἰάνθῐνος "violet-coloured".

127.1: Medieval Empire

excerpt in translation on the Second Roman Empire [~the Byzantines] in the high medieval period.

Ne souc dy ruin dy Lombardesc norðer n'Italy, y linaç regnant enfugheurn vars l'Empir e sceurn autortað remarcabr allaçar la.
Following the fall of the northern Lombards in Italy, the ruling family fled to the Empire and managed to obtain appreciable clout there. 

Pieç sodal se courn lorry ascreuçon com agathin por y them ovester nell'Empir, eð y tesmogn scaut par eç autr intermann l'inquit historic y confiablessem cas occorrenç particuler durant y scompigl dy Secession German ny siecr treç.
Some members were appointed to administer the Empire's western themes, and the written accounts of others are history's strongest sources for certain events during the turmoil of the German Secession in the thirteenth century.

Stant dissoluð n'un form vabian closnautr naðusc, a mesur dy siecr catorç venoirn recostroinç effus dy cathedral Sant Sophia tan com spanjon dy quaðeglad, dirigið pall'architect Borgond Nicolà s'Avignon.
Having fallen into somewhat of a state of disrepair, the fourteenth century saw extensive reconstruction of Saint Sophia's cathedral along with expansion of the complex, headed by Burgund architect Nicolà s'Avignon.

Deut all'oc es ig s'Avignon dign parveg e cos joculant y dobanç de "l'architect dy ruin dell'Empir", la sceint y cainç tragic volent se produgr afont dy Sant Sophia aval de tre cent annað.
It is for this reason that s'Avignon is sometimes jocularly referred to as the "architect of the Empire's demise", given the tragic events that would take place within Saint Sophia's three hundred years later.

127.2: y cæros ovrir de "make possible"

y cæros ovrir de /i keˈrɔz ɔˈvrɪr de/ [i kɪˈʀɔz ʊˈvʀɪː de]
- enable, make possible, allow for, permit, to create conditions such that (something) is more feasible or more likely to occur

Etymology: idiom from the nineteenth century, literally "to open the opportune moment of". The verb ovrir descends (under the influence of covrir "cover") via Old Borlish ovrir, avrir from Latin aperiō "I reveal, open". The noun cæros "window of opportunity, opportune moment" is a modern borrowing from Ancient Greek καιρός "period of time, season; opportunity".

Sell'osceyan vil y cæros nos ovrir de lembic gostar.
/sɛˌlɔ.xiˈjan vɪl i keˈrɔz nɔz ɔˈvrɪr de lɛmˈbɪk gɔˈstar/
[sɪˌlɔˈçjan vɪl i kɪˈʀɔz nɔz ʊˈvʀɪː de lɪmˈbɪk gʊˈstɐː]
3s.gn=birthday will df opportunity 1p open-inf of alcohol taste-inf
Her birthday will give us the chance to try alcohol.

127.3: broncar "flinch"

broncar /brɔnˈkar/ [bʀʊŋˈkɐː]
- flinch, wince, recoil, to reflexively move away from something perceived as unpleasant or a threat;
- stumble, trip, slip, lurch, to make a sudden unsteady movement;
- balk, back out, chicken out, get cold feet, to refuse to act due to (espeecially sudden) fear or uncertainty

Etymology: from Old Borlish broncar "stumble, misstep", cognate with synonymous bronchier in Old French but of unknown further origin. Perhaps connected to Latin broccus "buck-toothed" or truncus "docked, cut off", but neither is particularly semantically tempting. Unhelpful also are the equally unsourceable examples of Lombard bronco "thorny branch" and Barcelon bronc "knot in wood".

Jo vole pogntar apar ma jo broncau.
/ʒo voˈle pɔjnˈtar aˈpar pi ʒo brɔnˈko/
[ʝo vʊˈle pʊjnˈtɐː‿ʀɐˈpɐː pi ʝo bʀʊŋˈko]
1s will-ipf poke-inf through but 1s balk-pst
I meant to flirt but I chickened out.

127.4: snuvr fair "sniff"

snuvr fair /ˈsnɪvr̩ fer/ [ˌznɪ.vɐ feː]
- sniff, sniffle, snivel, snort, to make an audible inhalation through the nose (especially when the nose is blocked);
- scoff, turn up one's nose, sneer, to react with contempt or scorn

Etymology: verb phrase from snuvr "sniff, snort", itself a derivation from the verb snuvlar, which had become obsolete by the seventeenth century. This descends from Old Borlish isnuvlar, a borrowing from Old English snyflan "to have a runny nose". In the latter sense the phrase is attested from the eighteenth century.

No stou bogr snuvr fair dell'oç cæros.
/no stu bɔjr̩ snɪvr̩ fer dɛˈlɔts keˈrɔz/
[no stu ˈbɔ.jɐ ˈznɪ.vɐ feː dɪˈlɔs kɪˈʀɔz]
neg be.necessary at.all sniff do.inf of-df=s.dt opportunity
The opportunity's nothing to sniff at.

##

127.5: Deadly Disasters

notes on the subject of various (alt) historical disasters.

The Great Flie Flood was a natural disaster in 1171 Willemy which submerged or swept through large parts of Frisland. Inflowing waters of the Rustig Strait created the island of Texel, and the freshwater Lake Almere (which fed into the Strait along the Flie river) became brackish and eventually fully saline as a maritime gulf.

The then-duke Lovis the Tall, who had been staying in the environs of Amstel for some months, is the most famous (and most historically influential) casualty of the Flood, but estimates have suggested a death toll approaching ten thousand.

The destruction is thought to have spurred the development of Axbane on Borland as an alternative, safer harbour for traders passing through the Rustigh Strait.

---

The First Burning of London was a conflagration in 1290 which lasted for a full week and killed approximately four hundred people. This was the earliest of several such burnings, at least two of which are more accurately described as sackings or conquerings. Unlike (say) the Fourth Burning, it is purely conjectural that this particular fire was deliberately set as part of a plot to steal the Redstone Chair (presumably orchestrated by some Markland or Kentish noble).

---

The Failed Crusade was an undertaking which aimed to recreate the March of Jerusalem. The city and its surrounds had been captured during the First Crusade and the first Marksman of Jerusalem, Savino the Just, had acceded in 1119, but it had fallen less than seventy years later.

This crusade was called in 1210 by Pope Just (a direct descendant of Lord Savino), and it was utterly unsuccessful. The campaign went so badly that the Convoy Australier having their control of Port Simon and Antioch revoked in 1208 is generally regarded as a boon for the Convoy.

The various military catastrophes stoked discontent in Rome and elsewhere, along with the outbreak of the First Great Dying (a plague thought to have been brought to Europe by returning crusaders).

128.1: St Margaret Meeting

excerpt in translation from the 1920 work A Door, Once Opened by Clarissa Bellamy.

L'aer bisan de harvest feya mornç ag gien d'Evangelin cant i quaucau par Rout San Margaret, con sy mantel raffleyant dereðr.
The crisp autumn air nipped at Evangeline's cheeks as she hurried down St Margaret's Lane, her cloak billowing behind her.

Cayen l'yeul a Londr un aucoum vivaç des y commovenç de marcant e carrot, eð y fler de castagn stant attost ðolen des y vagn d'un vençour proism.
The streets of London were alive with the bustle of merchants and carriages, and the scent of roasting chestnuts wafted from a nearby vendor's cart.

I clignau y picq pachet fassað ne papir broun contr sy peitrin, ogl lançant la por garantir ig l'oc remaneus fast.
She clutched the small parcel wrapped in brown paper to her chest, glancing at it to ensure it remained secure.

Cant l'approisma y torn vars Rout Hawthorn oc menant vars y livrer de Cavendish, un figur smargoy des vogt dy foscur.
As she approached the turn onto Hawthorn Street that led to Cavendish's bookshop, a figure emerged from the shadows.

Y domn sta cort naðusc eð i porta un curtel de bilrod plen, con sy visaç vellað par un capel nell'eutað e lað d'orlaç.
The woman was rather short and wore a dress of rich billrod, her face obscured by a fashionable wide-brimmed hat.

128.2: fardig "solo"

fardig /farˈdaj/ [fɐːˈdaj]

    solo, music played by a single performer;
    chance to shine, big moment, moment in the spotlight, an oppoortunity to be noticed to do demonstrate one's skill;
    moment of truth, critical point, a time when one's skills or resolve are finally tested (especially after a period of complacency or uncertainty)

Etymology: seventeenth century, originally in the musical sense. Borrowed from a continental language, likely Vascon fardig(a) or Portingale fardigo/a "solo, played alone". These come from a derivative of the Arabic root فَرْد · fard "alone, single, solitary". Extension to non-musical contexts is seen from the late nineteenth century.

    Jo save l'oc caum contene un fardig d'aloud.
    /ʒo saˈve lɔk kom ˌkɔn.teˈne ɪn farˈdaj daˈlud/

    I knew this piece contained a lute solo.

128.3: lau pre yonoscon "in the middle of nowhere"

lau pre yonoscon /lo pre ˌjo.nɔˈxɔn/ [lo pʀe ˌʝo.nʊˈxɔn]

    in the middle of nowhere, isolated, a long way from anywhere of interest like settlements or amenities;
    stuck, lost, making no progress on a problem

Etymology: early nineteenth century idiom literally meaning "leagues before wherever". The noun lau "league" comes via Old Borlish from Insular Latin lauga "league" (cf. leuga, legua), originally a Gaulish unit. The pronoun yonoscon "wherever, anywhere" is an extension of yon "where" < Latin ubicumque "wherever" by analogy to words like calscon "whichever" < Latin quāliscumque "of whatever quality". In metaphorical use from the early twentieth century.

    Nos feim un baugl lau pre yonoscon.
    /nɔz fim ɪn bojl lo pre ˌjo.nɔˈxɔn/
    [nɔz fim ɪm bojl lo pʀe ˌʝo.nʊˈxɔn]
    1p do.pst-1p indf camp league before wherever
    We camped in the middle of nowhere.

128.4: increiltað "disbelief"

increiltað /ˌɪn.krilˈtaθ/ [ˌɪŋ.kʀɪlˈtah]
- doubt, disbelief, incredulity, the inability to believe something;
- doubt, suspicion, mistrust, the inability to trust someone

Etymology: Middle Borlish noun derivation of increil "disbelieving, mistrustful", orphaned negative of (by then obsolete) creil "gullible, trusting". This descends from Latin crēdulus, whence also creu "an oath of frustration or (ironically) appreciation, lately particularly in sexual contexts", which is a 20C borrowing from Portingale créu via the meaning "idiot, git, jerk".

Y taflot nos souvolau un nievr d'increiltað atorn.
/i taˈflɔt nɔz ˌsu.voˈlo ɪn njɛvr̩ ˌdɪn.krilˈtaθ aˈtɔrn/
[i tɐˈflɔt nɔz ˌsu.vʊˈlo ɪn ˈnjɛ.vɐ ˌdɪŋ.kʀɪlˈta‿ðɐˈtɔːn]
df game 1p sweep-pst indf fog of=doubt around
The game sowed seeds of mistrust among us.

128.5: Mathematical Etymology

excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary o'Mathematics, a reference quire compiled by Rotcham University Primers.

zeffer /ˈzɛ.fə/ [zero] the number of things in an empty collection, the quantity one fewer than one. Before 1350 < Scholastic Latin zefer, zefrum (alt. zephirus by false connection to Zephyr) < Arabic صِفْر • ṣifr "empty, void" < in sense from Sanscrit शून्य • śūnyá "empty, void".

ablate /ˈa.blət/ [negative] fewer than zeffer, as of a debtor's money or a distance backward. 1481 < Lombard ablad < Scholastic Latin ablātus "taken away, withdrawn, removed", first used in financial accounts and taken up by mathematicians some decades later.

dart /ˈdaːt/ [~vector] a segment of a line, considered with a choice of which end is the head and which the vane. Around 1470 < Early Merch dart "throwing spear, dart" < Middle French dart, dard < Medieval Latin dardus < Frankish *darōth < Classical German *darōthus "light spear, javelin, dart". Extended to its mathematical sense by the pictorial analogy of drawing arrowheads on line segments.

augrim /ˈəu.gɾɪm/ [~arithmetic] the mathematics of calculation with numbers; computation more generally. Around 1220 < Drengot augrime, algrisme etc < Old French algorisme < Scholastic Latin algorismus "the use of Arabic numbers" < Arabic الخَوَارِزْمِيّ • al-ḵawārizmiyy, a name of the Persian polymath whose mathematical works introduced much of mathematics to Europe.

arrhumb /ˈa.ɾəm/ [cosine] the sending of an angle to the quotient of the height of a rod rotated by that angle from the vertical to the full length of the rod. Early Merch arrum, arrom (the modern spelling is influenced by unrelated rhumb "compass bearing") < Arabic الرمح • ar-rumḥ "spear, shaft". This appears to be a metaphorical extension related to the use ofوتر • watar < Sanscrit ज्या • jyā́ "bowstring" for vater.

129.2: çaveyar "cushion"

çaveyar /ˌtsa.viˈjar/ [ˌtsavˈjɐː]
- cushion, pad, to furnish with cushions or similar soft things;
- cushion, soften, to absorb or deaden the impact or weight of something;
- sugarcoat, sanitise, prettify, to make (something) more palatable or otherwise easier to accept

Etymology: seventeenth-century backformation from noun çaveyal "cushion, pillow", which descends via Old Borlish ça(r)veȝal "pillow" from synonymous cervīcal in Latin (the loss of /r/ is irregular but compare çavel "brain" < cerebellum). Dig mey; tu va noc a y los me çaveyar.

Tell me; you don't have to sugarcoat it.

129.3: supellex "paraphernalia"

supellex /ˌsi.pɛˈlɛks/ [ˌsi.pɪˈlɛks]
- paraphernia, miscellanea, stuff, assorted items and especially the things that accrue over time in the course of some pastime or occupation;
- apparatus, kit, equipment, tools of the trade, the set of items one needs to do some activity;
- habits, wont, things that one does as a matter of course (often in a negative sense);

Etymology: 17C borrowing from Latin supellēx "furniture, utensils, kit", likely related to legō "I collect, gather". Extension to behaviours is seen from the late nineteenth century.

Jo trouvau nien benoçabr entr y supellex dy collocquour.

129.4: kirt ag madou "catalyst"

kirt ag madou /kɪrt ɛj maˈdu/ [kɪːt ɛj mɐˈdu]
- catalyst, trigger, spark, inciting incident, a thing or event that sets something (especially something of outsized impact) into motion;

Etymology: idiom attested from the 18C, literally "spark to the kindling". The noun kirt "spark" descends from synonymous kirte in Old Borlish, and is probably onomatopoeic in origin. The noun madou "tinder, kindling" is a borrowing from Middle French (a)madou "lure, bait; kindling, touchwood", a deverbal of amadouer "coax, lure; kindle". This verb is thought to descend via Old Norse mata "lure, feed" from Classical German *matōnam "feed".

Cay rix un kirt ag madou por defas machinaçonal.

[ke ʀɪks ɪŋ kɪːt ɛj mɐˈdu pɔː dɪˈfaz ˌma.kɪˈna.tsʊˈnal]
fall war indf spark to.df tinder for progress technological
War is a catalyst of technological development.

##

129.5: Arcabil

The Arcabil are a collection of islands in the Atlantic, east of Mashick. They comprise hundreds of landmasses, of which Cocain is the largest.

Toponymy
The name "Arcabil" has traditionally been considered to be an uncomplicated use of Arabic أَرْخَبِيل • ('archabīl) "archipelago", borrowed into Scholastic Latin as Arcabilia (and treated as a plural on the basis of its -bilia ending). However, there is little evidence of such a word existing in Arabic in the fifteenth century.

The possibility has been raised of a metathetic and dissimilatory variant of unattested الكريب • (al-carīb) "the Carib", using a local name for a group of peoples of the Arcabil, but the phonetics are tenuous.

History
The Arcabil were first encountered by Vetomundine powers in the late fifteenth century, during the first stage of the New World Company's voyages west under the aegis of Malik Munir al-Hamdawi. By the early sixteenth century Morrack had established several semi-permanent outposts there, which were important ports for the circumnavigation of the Cynthia under Fredun al-Casmi.

The orange liqueur known as "fleuse" is a genericisation of the Fleus d'Arcabil mixer first manufactured in the early nineteenth century on a Borlish-speaking island of the Arcabil.


People
Judeta Barracin (fl. 1919), author of social comedy born in Andalus who spent her formative years in the Arcabil
Loðaç Berxon (fl. 1910), who grew up in the Arcabil and who was an important member of the Outland Arcabil Association after her emigration to Borland

130.1: The Heedless Shoal

extract in translation from 1952 work Hus Tars (literally "Sheer Haddock", published in translation under the title "The Heedless Shoal"), written by Haubrath author Marc Lambount. It has become a staple of Borlish lessons for those learning the language in the schools of Markland, despite the title's homophony with Merch his tarse "his penis".

Y port dy cahut closisceu ne çottant e Jacq plombettau sur y hamac criscant, las de sy post quiðeyant. 
The cabin door slammed shut and Jake flopped onto the creaky bunk, exhausted from his gruelling shift.

Y puð ojabr dell'effum fæx de ronç insinua toð sy cambr sarrað.
The horrible stench of diesel exhaust permeated his cramped quarters.

De truc l'accaçau sy cofrsac ragottiscent ny gaheç, dont y govon roglfeyað sonaurn de lorry vagiscment famigler.
He shoved his weathered backpack into the locker, whose rusty hinges made their familiar screech.

A starn, l'eç ont inexorabr contonen y tors dy vascel e menan jug sy cogtaçon a lorrell'istranç maritim.
Outside, the relentless waves battered the ship's hull, a constant reminder of their isolation at sea.

No sceye magn solaç deur y caldour soumargent cant tossottau l'appragl d'aeraçon antic.
There was little relief from the oppressive heat as the ancient ventilation system wheezed.

Durant ig l'allonga, sy front moglað de suour, Jacq recuida ant un benaulaçon tart cos inutr all'eç meis gelað seyon passað sur un javigour ny Mar Norðer.
As he lay there, sweat beading on his brow, Jake thought back with too-late appreciation to the icy months he'd spent on a North Sea fishing trawler.

130.2: carrot "carriage"

carrot /kaˈrɔt/ [kɐˈʀɔt]
- carriage, wagon, a (usually horse-drawn) vehicle designed for transporting people;
- car, carriage, trolley, a single detachable part of a train;
- module, component, a self-contained (often interchangeable) part of a system which interfaces predictable with other parts

Etymology: diminutive of Old Borlish car "wagon", which descends from Latin carrus "cart, wagon; load" (the suffix may have been added to distinguish the word from car "dear, darling", although the root survives as car "car, automobile" nonetheless). Use for trains is seen with their invention in the nineteenth century; metaphorical extension from that sense is seen in the twentieth.

I laundau cant i descene des y carrot.
/i lonˈdo kant i ˌdɛ.xeˈne dɛz i kaˈrɔt/
[i lʊnˈdo kant i ˌdɛ.çɪˈne dɛz i kɐˈʀɔt]

He tripped as he got out of the carriage.

130.3: bisan "crisp"

bisan /biˈzan/ [bɪˈzan]
- crisp, fresh, (of the air) dry and cold;
- bracing, refreshing, invigorating, giving someone energy or alertness;
- candid, hard-hitting, blunt, frank, truthful without consideration for finer feelings

Etymology: originally in the first sense, a Middle Borlish derivation from now-obsolete bis "cold air; specifically, a north wind". This is borrowed via French bise "north wind", of uncertain origin. Possible connections include Tuscan bigio "grey, cloudy" or Classical German *bibō "I shiver".

I had to tell my brother some hard truths.

130.4: effus "extensive"

effus /ɛˈfɪz/ [ɪˈfɪz]
- extensive, wide-ranging, covering a large area;
- far-reaching, comprehensive, big, major, significant, affecting many things

Etymology: 16th-century borrowing from Latin effūsus "poured out, discharged", past participle of effundō "pour out, discharge" (itself borrowed at roughly the same time as effondr "spread out, disperse, scatter"). As a vaguer word simply meaning "significant" it is seen from the late 18th century.

1s=get-ipf ng known cmp 3s=have-ipf indf house of book so extensive
I didn't realise her library was so extensive.

130.5: Angland

Angland (Borlish Anglont /anˈglɔnt/ [ɐŋˈglɔnt]) is a region in Borland in the west of the island. Its largest population centre is the city of Vithor.

History

The petty kingdom of Angland was founded by Angle immigrants in the fifth century, along with Southbar and several more minor settlements. It quickly established itself in opposition to Southbar and to the rump sub-Roman Borlish state in the east. At the turn of the ninth century it saw an influx of immigration from East Anglia after that kingdom was subjugated by Markland.

After a series of temporary alliances between Angland and Borland, the marriage of Roman king Stiglan's son Marc to the only daughter of Alfegh of Angland unified the kingdoms for good. This was shortly followed by the Battle of Fendal (810) which forced Southbar to swear fealty as a subordinate kingdom. Not long thereafter was Angland conquered by the Danes along with the rest of the island.

The Borland varieties of Old English survived longest in Angland, with records suggesting that an English language descending from the original settlers was spoken in rural parts of the region until as late as the seventeenth century.

Places

Çadrosc, an area of moorland in the northwest which features a labyrinth built in Kelt times
Gambrig, a village and nearby monastery noteworthy for its medieval chronicle in a variety of Old English
Hawkirch, site of the Hawkirch Surrender of 1632
Vithor, regional capital on the west coast known for the New Vithor University, a major research institution

131.2: liesc bouclant "time loop"

liesc bouclant /ljɛx buˈklant/ [ljɛç bʊˈklant]
- time loop, (in fiction) a period experienced by one or more people repeatedly;
- (by extension) routine, monotonous or repetitive activity such as errands that are done many times with little variation

Etymology: idiom from the late 19th century, literally "looping duration". The noun liesc "term, period, duration" is a Old Borlish deverbal from lejar "stop moving, crash" (the word originally meaning "endpoint"), from Insular Latin laedicō "I hit, collide". The verb bouclar "loop, curl, go in a circle" derives from Old Borlish boucle "loop, bracelet" (modern boucr), via Old French from Latin buccula "chinstrap".

The phrase was first used in the translation of 1882 work Cludor ncar Vantel "A Postman in Wrexham", which features such a time loop.

Com veleð vos farar ða vos cay un liesc bouclant?
/kɔm veˈlɛθ vɔz faˈrar ða vɔz ke ɪn ljɛx buˈklant/
[kɔm vɪˈlɛ vɔz fɐˈʀɐː ða vɔz ke ɪn ljɛç bʊˈklant]
how will.sbj-2p 2p fare-inf if 2p fall indf duration loop-ptcp.p
What would you do if you were in a time loop?

131.3: foyaçant "virtuosic"

foyaçant /ˌfɔjɐˈtsant/ [ˌfɔjˈtsant]
- virtuosic, gifted, masterful, demonstrating immense technical skill;
- flamboyant, resplendent, dazzling, theatrical, bold or audacious in the way one does something;
- showy, showing off, peacocking, ostentatious, being prideful in demonstrating one's abilities

Etymology: present participle of foyaçar "glare, shine brightly, dazzle; show off, flaunt". This is itself a derivation from foyaç "glare, intense light; gaudiness, extravagance", an Old Borlish extension of foy "fire" < focus "hearth" with the pejorative suffix -aç < -āceus "shaped like". The noun foyaç "mess, jumble" < fodiō "I dig up" is unrelated but may have had semantic influence.

The word appears in both approving and disapproving contexts from as early as it is attested.

Cay tell'yoc veram un praxitel foyaçant.
/ke tɛlˈjɔk veˈram ɪn ˌprak.siˈtɛl ˌfɔ.jɐˈtsant/
[ke tɪˈljɔk vɪˈʀam ɪm ˌpʀak.sɪˈtɛl ˌfɔjˈtsant]
fall 2s-gn=husband truly indf sculptor virtuosic
Your husband is truly a masterful sculptor.

131.4: recuidar "reflect"

recuidar /ˌre.kajˈdar/ [ˌʀe.kɐjˈdɐː]
- reflect, consider, ponder, muse, introspect, think to oneself, to actively think about something or about what one knows;
- deduce, realise, infer, construe, to reach a conclusion by reasoning

Etymology: Middle Borlish coinage derived from cuidar "think, suppose, intend". This descends directly from Latin cōgitō "I think, reflect, have in mind". The extension in Borlish to deduction is attested from the 18th century.

Jo recuida jamay noiteyar n'un davarn.
/ʒo ˌre.kajˈda ʒaˈme ˌnɔj.tiˈjar nɪn daˈvarn/
[ʝo ˌʀe.kɐjˈda ʝɐˈme ˌnɔj.tɪˈʝɐː nɪn dɐˈvɐːn]
1s reflect-ipf never spend.night-inf in=indf resort
I realised I'd never stayed in a resort.

##

131.5: Jeans

Jeans (Merch /dʒeːnz/; Borlish Jen /ʒɛn/; Jean Zena /ˈze.na/) is an Italian polity and city of the same name. It comprises the northwest Middlesea coastline of Italy bordering Provence as well as the island of Corse. It has a long history as one of the so-called 'Latin Republics'.

Toponymy

The Merch name Jeans was borrowed from Old French Jannes /ˈdʒa.nəs/, deriving originally from Genua in Latin. This is probably simply the classical local word for "knee" (cf. Classical Latin genu), in reference to the shape of the coastline it lies on.

History

Jeans is the oldest of the Latin Republics, having come into existence in the tenth century. Along with Venise, it serves as a counterpoint to the notion that the Second Tetrarchy period in the eleventh and twelfth centuries was solely comprised of great centralised empires. The leader of Jeans, known as the console, was elected from among the merchant nobility.

In 1207 N Jeans invaded the Tyrrhene Isles of Corse and Sardine, wresting them from Roman control. Only the northernmost of the two islands would remain in the Jean orbit more permanently.

Piracy plagued the Middlesea coast for the same reason that maritime trade was so profitable for Jeans. It reached a peak at the turn of the sixteenth century as newfound wealth from the Novomund flooded the region.

People

Franco Cicala (r. 1119-22/4), first console from the Cicale family

References

The Latin Republics: Jewels under Tyrian Standards, a 1902 historical reference quire by Jacob Trelaune (cf. in particular 'Part III: Old Jeans')

132.1: Cinderella Retelling

excerpt in translation from the beginning of a short story by Kitty Unpretty.

Marcus lejau cos soutan a plaç meg dy lag. Un domn oc un curtel azur portant sta ja asseyent sur y Banc de Cris.
Marcus stopped abruptly in the middle of the grass. A woman in a blue dress was already sitting on the Crisis Bench.

I reconnosce noc y curtel. Y domn lançau sy gas atras cant l'er asseyent.
He didn’t recognize the dress. She looked up from where she was sitting.

"Pardon," dis y prinç n'y man leyant. "Jo prefaye noc ig alcun hom no fos ac apart." I creye noc un acconnosc por alcun hom nell'oç curtel memorar. Caye un gendr memorabr de curtel.
“Sorry,” he said, holding up his hands. “I didn’t think anyone would be over here.” He didn’t think he remembered an introduction to anyone in that dress. It was a memorable sort of a dress.

"Jo crey vossy maðr encontrar entarn?" osau i digr, dec l'encontrau ec maðr ne ðougl.
“I believe I ran into your mother inside?” he ventured, because he ran into so many mothers.

"L'ig no's assistent," dis i, oc no stant bogr l'ig seyon desirant oïr e no stant cos absoluð nien seyon hellinabr n'oc moment.
“She’s not here,” she said, which was not what he wanted to hear and which he absolutely could not handle at the moment.

132.2: big "chariot"

big /baj/ [baj]
- (historical) chariot, a two-wheeled horse-drawn vehicle as used in Bronze and Iron Age warfare;
- bed, flatbed, a platform at the back of a vehicle on which one can sit or load cargo;
- trunk, boot, an enclosed space at the back of a vehicle for storage;
- sidecar, an attachment to a (motor)bike adding space for a passenger or cargo;
- (chess) rook, castle, the chess piece which moves orthogonally

Etymology: direct descendant via Old Borlish biȝ "wagon, haycart" from Latin bīga "chariot" (reflecting a reduced bi-iuga "two-yokes"). Revived in the sixteenth century in its historical sense, by which time it had shifted to "a platform for loading cargo", from which the other vehicular senses stem. Applied to the chess piece since the seventeenth century (formerly we see roc < Arabic رُخّ "rook").

Cargeð y boist ny big ða il voun le quottar.
/karˈgɛθ i bɔist ni baj ða ɪl vun le kwɔˈtar/

load-2p.sbj df box in-df boot if 3p will-3p 3s fit-inf
Load the boxes into the boot if they'll fit.

132.3: run "symbol"

run /rɪn/ [ʀɪn]
- character, letter, the visual representation of a letter of a writing system;
- symbol, glyph, any non-verbal representation which imparts information;
- (historical, specifically) rune, a letter in one of the German writing systems

Etymology: originally in the last sense, descending from Old Borlish run /ryn/ "rune". This was borrowed either from Old Norse rún "secret, rune" or Old English rūn "mystery, rune". In the Middle Borlish period this word retained senses like "magic spell" and "talisman", but these became obsolete in the sixteenth century (although derivatives like runam "secretly" and runastr "sorcerer" survive to the modern day).

132.4: sce "wheelhouse"

sce /xe/ [çe]
- (historical) cathedral, the principal church of an (arch)diocese containing the episcopal throne;
- (historical, specifically) papal see, Holy See, the jurisdiction of a pope;
- venue, arena, stadium, theatre, the building in which an event happens;
- place, venue, setting, the place where anything happens;
- field, domain, the study of something in particular;
- (in the expression ne sce de) wheelhouse, bailiwick, domain, a person's area of authority or expertise

Etymology: originally in the first senses, descending via Old Borlish sce, sie "see, (arch)diocese" from Latin sedes "seat; residence; (Late Latin) episcopal see". I admit differential calculus isn't in my wheelhouse.

132.5: Dime measures

The dime measures (less commonly known as the 'tithe measures' or 'tenth measures') are a modern system of units based on factors of ten. The name derives from the French dîme "one-tenth", from synonymous decimus in Latin.

The dime measures were codified during the nineteenth century for ease of communication, as theoretical development coalesced into a global endeavour. They have been updated several times since, as it has become feasible to use more convenient yardsticks.

Standard modifiers may be added to each unit to increase or decrease their size by factors of 10. In most common use are:

    great (10⁴)
    tithe (10⁻¹)
    petty (10⁻⁴)
    scant (10⁻⁸)

Length

There are three bases for dime lengths: the inch, the foot (10 inches) and the league (10⁴ feet). At first, the length of the foot was fixed somewhat arbitrarily as the midpoint of the very slightly different Roman foot and the Cathayan "surveyor's span". In 1946, the foot was redefined to make the normal speed [speed of light] (denoted œ) equal to precisely ten great leagues per second.

Several other traditional measures of length were given dime values. For instance, in dime measures the mile is equal to five thousand feet or half a league.
Heft [mass]

There are four bases for dime hefts: the scruple, the ounce (100 scruples), the tabre (100 ounces) and the ton (100 tabres). The third of these units takes its approximate value from the Persian mann and its name from the city of Tabris [Tabriz]. The ounce was originally defined to be the mass of a cube of water of side length one inch; this was later refined to specify that the water be at its triple point of pressure and temperature.
Derived units

Many units are defined in terms of these base units of length and heft, as well as the second. For example, the shove measures the might [force] required to accelerate a heft of one tabre to a speed of one foot per second.

133.1: Nocturne

excerpt from Nocturne; or, the Dividends of Vice, a 1978 work of historical fiction written by Kentish author Aleris Houghlismond (pronounced /ˈa.lə.ʀɪs ˈhoːlz.mən/).

Y peyan dessou de mell'azig stan sdruçollabr ag ploy dy crevoscr, relougen com argent deborsellað.
The cobbles beneath my boots were slick with the night’s rain, glistening like pickpocketed silver.

Y lampader vacillan cos febr e lançan ombr fruyant vars mur assombrið par suicr.
The lampposts flickered weakly and cast dancing shadows on soot-dark walls.

L'aer pene cos lort, parvasið con y fler a hum moglastr e con y fum des murðon a goðou.
The air was heavy, thick with the scent of damp earth and the smoke of a thousand chimneys.

Un carrot passau broyent tandic sy rouð clacquaurn sur y pieðr jagottað eð aug moðer souvolau den all'orlaç de my jacquot.
A carriage rattled by, its wheels clattering over the uneven stones and splashing muddy water onto the hem of my coat.

Jo fey un soçavau de maldicçon ma pausau noc a laupar—stove alcun hour despardr.
I cursed under my breath but didn’t break stride—there was no time to waste.

Jo poðe ja l'eç murmuranç lontan de voç oïr com j'aye spien, eç interront par y sounç sporadic de ricottanç heloidous.
I could already hear the distant murmur of voices I was hoping for, punctuated by the occasional burst of raucous laughter.

133.2: quiðeyar "exhaust"

quiðeyar /ˌkwi.ðiˈjar/ [ˌkwiðˈjɐː]
- exhaust, tire, frazzle, (as of work) to be physically gruelling;
- tax, challenge, to be difficult to accomplish

Etymology: the descendant of Old Borlish quiðeȝar "sicken, nauseate; unsettle, rattle, unnerve", derived from dialectal quið "belly, stomach, intestines". This is a borrowing from Old English cwiþ "womb; stomach". The shift in meaning from disgust or emotional disturbance towards hard work is complete by the eighteenth century (although related forms in rural dialects retain some earlier senses).

Caye l'oç flaðr derran uncos quiðeyant.

That last climb was gruelling.

133.3: çottar "slam"

çottar /tsɔˈtar/ [tsʊˈtɐː]
- slam, shove, bash, slug, to hit forcefully;
- fling, hurl, chuck, to throw forcefully

Etymology: from early 17th century çottar "beat, batter", which was borrowed via a Middlesea language (plausibly Napolitan zottà "flog") from Arabic noun سَوْط • (sawṭ) "whip". The word appears to have begun as naval slang, having acquired its modern meaning by the time it enters general use in the 18th century.

Çot y bal yert a haut eð atten a y laç cavir.
/tsɔt i bal jɛrt a hot e‿ðaˈtɛn a i lats kaˈvɪr/
[tsɔt i bal ʝɛːt ɐˈhot e‿ðɐˈtɛn a i las kɐˈvɪː]

133.4: monnocquar "trudge"

monnocquar /ˌmɔ.nɔˈkwar/ [ˌmɔ.nʊˈkwɐː]
- trudge, lumber, plod, traipse, to walk heavily or with some difficulty;
- struggle, persevere, to work on a task while finding it difficult

Etymology: first attested in the 18th century; further origin obscure. Attempts to connect the word "monk"—perhaps moigne or monhe from regional French and Portingale dialects respectively—stumble on phonetic grounds (and the proposed semantic connection of a monk's plodding gait is tenuous).

More tempting might be Arabic مَنْهُوك • (manhūk) "exhasuted, spent", although no account of the word's journey to Borlish has been corrobated. Claims of a Novomundine origin also lack convincing evidence. Perhaps simply an onomatopoeic or fanciful coinage.

Nos eyau monnocquar tras seg acr por ac yembr.
/nɔz iˈjo ˌmɔ.nɔˈkwar traz sij akr̩ pɔr ak jɛmbr̩/
[ˌnɔzˈjo ˌmɔ.nʊˈkwɐː tʀaz sɪj ˈa.kɐ pɔː‿ʀak ˈʝɛm.bɐ]
1p go-ipf.1p trudge-inf through six field for here arrive-inf
We had to trudge through six fields to get here.

133.5: Chemical Etymology (cont.)

excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary of Alchemy, a reference quire compiled by Rotcham University Primers [1].

athimar /ˈa.θɪˌmaː/ [antimony] the corporal [element] whose atoms have 51 mora, a reflecting grey half-metal known historically from its coholl [sulphide]. Around 1400 < Scholastic Latin athimāris "coholl of athimar" < synonymous Arabic إِثْمِد • 'ithmid, possibly from Copt. Applied to the corporal itself (as opposed to the ore) since the eighteenth century.

coholl /kʊˈhɔl/ [sulphide] any substance formed of brimstone [sulphur] and a metal—for example, fool's gold is a coholl of iron. 1610 < Vascon cohol "coholl of athimar [stibnite]" < Arabic كُحْل • kuḥl "eye-black", after the use of this substance as make-up. The term was generalised to all such metal compounds by Zaravcar in the late eighteenth century.

machovine /ˈma.kʊˈvəin/ [strontium] the corporal whose atoms have 38 mora, a yellow-grey metal. 1789 < Scholastic Latin machovīnus "machovine" < Machov, the town in Poland where the corporal was first isolated from the nearby mine's ore. The ash [carbonate] of machovine has seen use as a catalyst for the production of sugar from the braxoch beet.

maschale /məˈskɛːl/ [propionic acid] the acid oil [carboxylic acid] with a spine [carbon chain] of length three, a malodorous clear liquid. 1850 < Scholastic Latin maschāle < Ancient Greek μᾰσχᾰ́λη "armpit", after the substance's presence in human sweat as produced by skin zoia [microorganisms].

---

[1] a publishing house based in the city of Rotcham [Rochdale, Greater Manchester] and affiliated with the local university.

134.1: Lachesism

excerpt in translation from the video 'Lachesism', written by John Koenig.

For a million years, we’ve watched the sky and huddled in fear.

134.2: govon "hinge"

govon /goˈvɔn/ [gʊˈvɔn]
- hinge, a jointed device that allow the swinging of a door;
- pivot, axle, any thing on which something turns;
- centre of rotation, the point which remains fixed by a turning motion;
- pole, (in astronomy) either of the two points on the Earth's surface that intersect its axis of rotation;
- turning point, critical moment, an instant or decision with significant consequences;
- obsession, passion, fixation, the object of someone's obsessive interest

Etymology: originally in the first sense, the descendant of Old Borlish govon "hinge, tenon, pin". This reflects Vulgar Latin gōfō "nail, peg, dowel", a variant of synonymous gomphus in Classical Latin. The extension to a generic point of rotation (and from there to all other senses) had occurred by the Revitalist period.

Te stou moutessem y govon oglar.

134.3: effum "exhaust"

- exhaust, the gas released from a combustion engine;
- outgas, a gas emitted by any means (especially when considered as an unwanted waste product);
- hot air, bluster, bombast, long-winded or officious talk having no real substance

Etymology: borrowing in the 18th century from Scholastic Latin noun effūmus "emitted smoke, steam" and verb effūmō "I emit smoke, steam". These are derived from fūmus "smoke, steam" with the prefix ex- "out, away from". In metaphorical use the word is attested from the late 19th century.

134.5: A Motley Miscellany

The Bahassassin River [1] is the longest river on the continent of Mendeva [North America], with a total length of just over two thousand leagues. The river passes through multiple polities, including Sangathy and Hasiny, and its eastern tributaries descend from the Sturgovan Mountains [the Appalachians]. The largest city on the banks of the Bahassassin is Nadacow, the capital city of Hasiny. The name of the river comes from the Carovacian [Caddo] name báhassássin "mother of rivers".

[1] comprising the Missouri River and the portion of the Mississippi River downstream of St Louis.

---

Mark of Tolose (d. 1453) was the son of King Ambrose II of Vascony, and the father of King Ambrose III of Vascony. Although he was crown prince, he died three years before his father and thus never reigned. He married Margaret of Iscombe [Exeter] shortly before 1435. Along with Ambrose, they had three other children: their first child Alexandra, and two younger children Victor of Astorga and Natalia.

---

Wings Afire (Ale in Fiamme) is an opera written by Venetian Chiarina Bruno and first performed in the Verona Arena in 1824. It was the first work staged in the Verona Arena since it was shuttered at the outbreak of the Second German War.

The opera is a retelling of the legend of Icarus which takes place entirely after the events of the myth, with references to the dead Icarus in the dialogue. It follows the matron of a clothiery who meets a grieving Daedalus; she helps him to rediscover the joy of invention. The opera's music features the low-pitched mournful melodies of the graveyard fiddlers from Borlish folklore; Bruno is said to have heard of them from her brother Jacomo.

135.1: A Hotel in Nadacow

excerpt in translation from the early chapters of masquira trevold Men of Jet and Diamond, published (originally in Welsh as Dynnon o Vuhuð a Diamont) by Hasinick Welshman Cadogan Torrior in 1890, shortly after he graduated from the University of Nadacow as a scholar of diplomacy.

135.2: fæx "pollutant"

fæx /fɛks/ [fɛks]
- slag, dross, waste products from some chemical process (including mining or combustion);
- waste, detritus, any discarded or unwanted material;
- pollutant, a harmful substance which contaminates the environment;
- (figuratively) dregs, scum, the worst and lowest part of something (especially of people)

Etymology: modern borrowing from Scholastic Latin faex "unwanted product of a chemical reaction", a specialised use of Classical faex "sediment, brine, rouge, dregs". Extension from scientific usage is attested from the eighteenth century, and its use as an insult is seen soon afterwards.

L'oc detaxion es aphlox psolic effumant com fæx ou?

df-s.px reaction be.s CO2 deoxygenated outgas-p.prs as waste q
Is this reaction producing waste carbon monoxide?

135.3: runam "secretly"

runam /riˈnam/ [ʀɪˈnam]
- secretly, in secret, covertly, on the QT, not letting anyone else know about something;
- privately, in private, sub rosa, behind closed doors, in a setting conducive to secrecy

Etymology: from Middle Borlish runam "by magic, using sorcery; in secret, hidden from view" (the semantic shift mirroring that of "occult"). This is a derivative of contemporary run "symbol, spell, talisman" using the now-unproductive adverbial suffix -am, descending from Latin anima "soul" (compare kireðam "wholeheartedly", coram "in person").

135.4: brevier "memo"

brevier /breˈvjɛr/ [bʀɪˈvjɛː]
- memo, memorandum, note, reminder, a short bit of writing to prevent one forgetting something;
- summary, overview, précis, synopsis, a summarised description of something;
- brief, report, a description of events

##

135.5: Kernow

Kernow (Merch /ˈkɛː.nə/, Borlish Cornou /kɔʀˈnu/) refers to the north-western peninsula of Gaul. Known in antiquity as Armorica, Brittania or Dumnonia, it was resettled in the early medieval period by Kelt peoples from Albion.

History

The Kernovan kingdoms at the dawn of the eighth century had only recently been unified, ruled by widowed Queen Maud of Angeus. Her son Vigo ascended to the throne upon her death in 720, shortly after the Catumagin Accord which ended hostilities and established an official border with the Kingdom of the Franks. Vigo spearheaded the reconquest of Devon from the kingdom of Wessex, uniting the two peninsulas as the Kingdom of Greater Devon.

The polity suffered somewhat during the ninth and tenth centuries, with the encroachment of the Franks in the east and with extensive Viking raids along the coasts (the monastery at Landvennick was even burned to the ground in 888 N).

The region derives its modern name from the House of Kernow, which in the eleventh century took power by means of an alliance with Normandy. This Kernovan Conjuring led to the establishment of the First Drengot Empire, of which Kernow was a minor vassal.

The Brethin of Kernow enjoyed significant religious influence during the late medieval period.

Kernow became part of the Kingdom of Britain in the fifteenth century as it incorporated territories further afield from its heartland in Wales.

People

Catrin of Kernow, sister of the Devoner king and influential figure in thirteenth-century Borland

Pope Damian VI (the Wise), reigned 1199-1208 N

Saint Victor of Dunkirk, d. 1245 N

136.1: Historiography Questions

-1. Cal historicour dy siecr catorç fornisceu primer y Preu Empir Drengoçan sceint tre siecr paravant con nom de 'Empir Constant', oc moliscent a le ligar con y Pag de Constanç (y part frender dy Tetrarchy Diocletian dy siecr catr, Bretagn Roman e Gal administrant)?

-2. Nommeð tre conflict entr polity (y Var Theudesc Primer abseïð) ec loy fignt a mesur dell'epoc dy 'Paç Lonc", ac definið com y liesc d'an 1770 fin a 1815.
-2. Name three international conflicts (not including the First German War) which took place during the 'Long Peace' period, here defined as lasting from 1770 until 1815.

-3. Cu scaveu l'ouvr d'an 1872 'Un Onomatoir Parçal dy Novel Londr'? Com y bustr y reconnuðessem des l'epoc Futurist de romanç parachthon, i contien y preu inquit de 'ardois' por un icon moustr despleyant indicar, tan com cal autr fanglanç lengacer surveunt?

136.5: The Novomund (briefly)

This term Novomund for the great landmasses of the western hemisphere is attested from the early sixteenth century, reflecting a univerbation of latin novus mundus "new world". 
Mendeva [North America]

The name Mendeva was formed backwards from Latin Mendevalēnsis "from Mendeva", attested already on the maps made during the 1471 Landfall (the demonym was later rederived as Mendevānus "Mendevan" from the placename). This comes from Vask [Basque] mendeval "west", itself likely a borrowing from Vascon vent de val "valley wind".

    Ambrosia [~Quebec, the Maritimes, New England] is a Vascony-settled polity named for King Ambrose III of Vascony (r. 1456–1518).
    Zangathy [~the Dakotas, Minnesota, Iowa, Wisconsin, Winnipeg, Ontario] is a landlocked polity occupying the upriver Bahassassin [Mississippi] directly west of the Five Seas [Great Lakes]. Its name reflects Daccotan [Dakota] zaŋathi "flint region".
    New Provence [~New England, New York, and south as far as South Carolina] is a coastal polity extending westward to the Sturgovan Mountains [Appalachians] which grew from a series of trading post established by Provence merchants.
    Hasiny [~Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, Arkansas, Oklahoma] is the largest polity in so-called British Mendeva, a few states along the Gulf settled by the Kingdom of Britain [~Wales, etc]. It takes its name from the Ractish [Caddo] name Hasíne "our people" for one of the previous nations the modern polity is descended from.
    Taisha [~Texas, Coahuila] is a minor polity of Gulf Mendeva at the crossroads of British and Morrack [Moroccan] influences. Its name comes via Arabic Tayisha' from Ractish taísha' "welcome".
    Mivock [~northern California] is a minor coastal polity on the Lovaqua [Pacific] known for its congenial climate. Of exceedingly sundry influence, its name reflects the name miwoc of the local Mendeva peoples and languages.
    Mashick [~Mexico, southern California, New Mexico, Arizona] is the largest polity in Lower Mendeva, the descendant of the Mashick [Aztec] Empire with heavy Morrack influence. Its name derives via Arabic from the Nawat [Nahuatl] meshi'ca' "Mashick people".

The Arcabil [~the Caribbean] are a collection of islands in the Atlantic, east of Mashick. They have a complicated history of influences from various Vetomundine powers. The name probably comes via the Arabic cognate of "archipelago".

    Cocain [~Cuba] is the largest of the islands of the Arcabil. Its name comes from the European folk tradition of a "land of plenty" (compare pays de Cocaigne, país de Cucanna, paese della Cuccagna).

Cappatia [South America]

European languages take the name Cappatia of this continent from Latin Cappātia, which comes via Arabic from Run'allo [Quechua] cappacha "this world".

    Tavancy [~Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Boliva, northern Chile] is major polity on the western coast, descended from the Tavancine [Inca] Empire. Its name comes from the Latin imperium tavantīnum, which was borrowed via Arabic as a partial calque from the Run'allo tawantin-suyu "the quartet of provinces".
    Staddomains, rather small polities, dot the eastern coast. These grew out of individual trading posts and have many different influences. Examples abound from Dutch influence in Neuwillem, Parnaven and Waronøu to Borlish influence in Monçating.
    Dowahine [~southern Patagonia, Tierra del Fuego] is a minor polity at the southern tip of Cappatia. Its name comes from the Arabic word for "smoke", after the smoke-towers sighted there by Captain al-Casmi in 1513.

137.2: reunç dy blad "roll of the dice"

reunç dy blad /raunts di blad/ [ʀauns di blad]
- roll of the dice, coin flip, shot in the dark, gamble, a risky or uncertain attempt at doing something;

137.5: The Dangers of DHMO

An illustration of the language Merch (the most widely-spoken language in the polity of Markland) through close analysis of the following example sentence.

Al as drink the leigh of aquifex ar sicker to dy.
/al əz dɾɪŋk ðə leːʃ ə‿ˌva.kwɪˈfɛks aː ˈsɪkə tə dəi/

Translated to IRL English with Boralverse jargon:

Everyone who drinks aquifex's lye will surely die.

Something which seems minor but which actually affects the aesthetic of Merch greatly is the lack of the "three-letter rule". In IRL English, almost all function words (nouns, adjectives, verbs) are at least three letters long. This rule is why we have such pairs as "inn - in" and "bee - be", as well as the redundant double letters in words like "ebb" and "egg". By contrast, Merch never did anything analogous, as can be seen here in the words al, ar and dy (cf "all", "are" and "die").

Merch also has somewhat less French influence than IRL English (while Kentish has somewhat *more*), due to the incomplete replacement of the English nobility there during the period of the Norman-ruled First Drengot Empire. Evidence of this in the above sentence is in the word sicker "certain" < Old English sicor, which lost out to French-derived "sure" in IRL English.

Grammatical differences on display here are: (1) the use of "as" in relative clauses, e.g. "the man as I love", "the man as loves me"; (2) more colloquial use of "be to VERB" with (non-volitional) future meaning, e.g. "the boats ar to sink!".

Finally, the scientific jargon in this alternate history is of course entirely different. The word leigh < OE lēag is cognate with IRL "lye; potassium/sodium hydroxide", and has been generalised to refer to any hydroxide substance. The word aquifex is a Scholastic Latin coinage (meaning "water-maker") for "hydrogen".

Thus we could informally convey the Merch sentence in IRL English as:
> Drinking hydrogen hydroxide has a 100% mortality rate.

Which of course it does—eventually.

138.1: Avosche

notes in translation on the region of Avosche (Paris French /aˈvɔːʃ/, Willem Dutch /ˈa.vusx/) in Willemy [Lotharingia].

The region Avosche is named for its first ruling house, which in turn takes its title from its founder Cuonrat Aihuosc (seen in Latin as Corradus Aevoscus).

Y nom a un origin obscur; se poð appondr ig y sodal primer se dey ag German Classic *ehu-* "coval", cant y dovem se dey parcanç ag fin *-iscas* "-esc" (pu sy voyal apport vandy).

138.4: suicr "soot"

138.5: Steeplepost Tapestry

The Steeplepost Tapestry (Vascon: Lo Tapìs Campanaral) was a screen of several myriad black or white tiles built in Ambrosia's capital city of Aiga d'Angoixa [~Quebec City]. Completed in 1820 and erected to overlook one of the city's central squares, it was inspired by the (fairly new) 'latticework' art movement.

One ambitious goal for the Tapestry was to be able to portray journalist's sketches of events from across the country with great speed, using the flag-lamp steeplemesh infrastructure that had been built up over the last few decades. Although this was achieved several times, the practical limitations of transmitting so much information by steeplepost prevented it from becoming routine. Instead, the majority of the tapestry's time was spent displaying short pieces of news or government messages in text and simple symbols.

The use of the word 'diced' to mean 'blocky, pixellated' dates back to a calque of Provincial icon dau 'die image'. This phrasing was coined in 1821 in disparaging reference to the Tapestry.

Just a few years into its operation, a series of hoax messages which spread rapidly via the Ambrosian steeplemesh made their way onto the Tapestry. These so-called 'Lies of 1824' included a report of the governor's death and culminated after several days with an alleged declaration of war from New Provence.

In 2020, a replica of the Tapestry was unveiled in Markland to mark the bicentenary of the original's completion.

139.2: truc "shove"

truc /trɪk/ [tʀɪk]
- shove, thump, jab, jostle, tackle, thrust, a forceful push without gentleness;
- try, go, stab, an (especially unpractised or clumsy) attempt at doing something

Etymology: Old Borlish deverbal from truccar "shove, jostle" (now archaic, superseded by truc fair), which reflects a Vulgar Latin extension trūdicō of Classical trūdō "I shove, thrust". In the latter senses it is attested from the nineteenth century.

139.3: zovay cavir "take a taxi"

zovay cavir /zoˈve kaˈvɪr/ [zʊˈve kɐˈvɪː]
- take a taxi, go via cab, to travel somewhere as a passenger in a taxicab;
- take the easy way out, follow the path of least resistance, to take a course of action which requires minimal personal effort

Etymology: late ninetenth century, literally "to get (a) taxi". The noun zovay "taxi" is a clipping of earlier carrot zovay "taxi carriage", often mistakenly capitalised to carrot Zovay by analogy with other types of carriage named after places.

The word was borrowed via French from Furlain slang term zovaie "coach for hire with a taximeter", literally "convenience" (one did not have to pay up front, unlike earlier hired coaches). This is a derivative of verb zovà "be useful, be convenient", from Latin iuvō "I help; I please".

In the metaphorical sense the phrase is seen only from the 1970s.

Nos coum zovay eð alandaum tost.
/nɔz kum zoˈve ɛθ ˌa.lanˈdom tɔst/
[nɔz kum zʊˈve ɛ‿ˌða.lɐnˈdom tɔst]
1p get.pst-1p taxi and turn.up-pst-1p early
We took a taxi and arrived early.

139.4: n'eç cahut "separately"

n'eç cahut /nɛts kaˈhɪt/ [ˌnɛs.kɐˈhɪt]
- apart, siloed, segregated, separated from each other into disjoint areas;
- separately, independently, without any communication or collaboration;
- estranged, alienated, no longer speaking to one another (especially after a falling out)

Etymology: idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally meaning "in cabins". The noun cahut "cabin, dorm, sleeping quarters" is a Middle Borlish borrowing, originally in a naval context, from synonyous caihute in Middle Dutch. This is possibly a portmanteau of Old French cabane and hutte, both meaning "hut, shack".

The Borlish idiom appears roughly contemporaneously with cognate idioms in other languages, such as Merch's in cahutes "independently".

Jug sein y domn egrtumnesc n'eç cahut.
/ʒai sin i ˈdɔmn̩ ˌijr̩.tɪmˈnɛx nɛts kaˈhɪt/
[ʝai sin i ˈdɔ.mɐn ˌɪjɐ.tɪmˈnɛç ˌnɛs.kɐˈhɪt]
ever be.sbj-3p df woman sick in=p.dt cabin
Keep the sick women quarantined.

##

139.5: Monarchs of Borland

collected notes on various monarchs of Borland.

Victor Rossetus 'the Red-haired' (fl. c6) was the first Prase of the Boral Diocese. He rose to prominence after the fall of the First Roman Empire and unified the urbanised east of the land while the west and south were settled by Anglians to form Angland and Southbar, respectively. It was under him that so-called 'Roman Borland' first began to succesfully repel the new settlers. By the late sixth century the Diocese of Boral had become a monarchy (described in retrospect as the First Kingdom of Borland), whose ruling dynasty claimed descent from Rossetus.

Jothey, King of Borland (fl. 898), known in Borlish as Joðeg /ʒoˈðij/, was the last ruler of the First Kingdom of Borland before it fell to the Danes in 898. Married to Brenna of Barrow, cousin of King Roderick of Dunclothe, they fled to neighbouring Southbar (and once Southbar also fell to Dane rule, to Kent).

In the first decade of the fifteenth century, Queen Natalia I and her husband King Joseph I ruled jointly. Their family had been and would continue to be beset by misfortune; all three of their sons predeceased them, as did their few male grandchildren (either in infancy or by misadventure). The succession crisis prompted by their deaths in 1411 and 1416 spelt the end of their dynasty.

From the ashes rose the Saulestran lineage of kings, whose banner comprised a white bar cutting a twilight-blue field. This dynasty would go on to last for over four hundred years until the dissolution of the Borlish monarchy itself.

Joseph III (d. 1534) was king of Borland, remembered for ruling the kingdom through the ravages of the Second Great Dying. Joseph never succeeded in producing a natural-born heir, despite several recognised yet illegitimate children by his various mistresses. Thus, after his death in 1534, he was succeeded to the throne by Brandon II, his nephew.

Natalia II (Borlish Natagl, abd. 1894) was the last queen of Borland before the dissolution of the monarchy. She abdicated on Revillon of 1894 during the political upheaval leading to the country joining the Drengot Collusion (several Borlish cities, although not the capital, had already joined as part of the New Urban Mesh).

140.1: Redstone Chair

notes in translation on the subject of the Redstone Chair.

Y Caðer ne Pieðr Roug sta costroit ny siecr deg jagerrem atorn d'un los ne greut; y nom dy carpenter es repars ne vogt dell'hour.
The Redstone Chair was fashioned in the late tenth century around a block of sandstone; the name of the carpenter is forgotten.

L'oc los intermane (cos noncupað) y los yon dessur y Nuçal a Elved entr un princes Markesc eð y sovran de Norðhumbr Dannesc er solemneyað, rix entr y dou polity coyent tras un siecr pres enter.
This block was (allegedly) the block upon which the Elved Marriage between a princess of Markland and the ruler of Dane Northumber was solemnised, ending hostilities between the two polities for almost a century.

Bempart monarch n'Albion sousevent, e cos particuler de Marclont e de Norðhumbr, ern coronnað sur y Caðer ne Pieðr Roug.
Many subsequent monarchs of Albion, and especially of Markland and Northumber, were crowned on the Redstone Chair.

Durant y Scon Tetrarchy ny siecr onç e doç, gran part all'Emperour Drengoçan asseyen sur y Caðer, e cossy sceint l'er emportað a Londr.
During the Second Tetrarchy of the eleventh and twelfth centuries, most of the Drengot Emperors sat upon the Chair, and as such it was relocated to London.

140.2: nothe "forged"

nothe /noˈθe/ [nʊˈθe]
- bastard, illegitimate, born to unmarried parents (when this means one is not able to inherit something);
- counterfeit, forged, claiming falsely to be something genuine;
- spurious, specious, fallacious, superficially plausible but not in fact logically deducible;
- (botany, zoology) false, denoting various plants and animals which resemble but which are not other species

Etymology: Middle Borlish borrowing from Scholastic Latin notheus "illegitimate, bastard", a pleonastic extension of synonymous nothus in Classical Latin. Originally restricted to legal contexts (where it replaced terms like bort and cif which were considered vulgar), it is now in general use. The term coexists as a higher-register term with French-derived bastart, which is somewhat crass.

Nos yemoim toð pront scið y Jorala sta nothe.

1p get-pst-1p all immediate known df Jorala be.ipf forged
We immediately realised the Jorala was forged.

140.3: ðocaç "haunting"

ðocaç /ðoˈkats/ [ðʊˈkas]
- bedevilment, torment, vexation, the affliction of (especially mental) distress;
- trauma, haunting, hell, the aftereffects of terrible experiences

Etymology: noun derivation from the verb ðocar "harrow, till; afflict, bedevil, torment, haunt" with the pejorative suffix -aç (from Latin -āceus "shaped like"). 140.4: hamac "bunk"

hamac /haˈmak/ [hɐˈmak]
- bunk, berth, cot, one of a series of beds installed in rows or tiers (especially in a nautical context);
- hammock, a hanging bed made of cloth or netting;
- swing, a seat hanging from two cords or cables and free to move back and forth;
- (mechanics) oscillation, harmonic motion, the behaviour of an object undergoing a returning force proportional to its distance from equilibrium

Etymology: originally in the second sense, borrowed via Morrove Arabic همك · hamaca and French hamac from Tainow [Taino] hamaca "hammock". 140.5: Chemical Etymology (cont. 2)

excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary of Alchemy, a reference quire compiled by Rotcham University Primers [1].

corporal /ˈkoː.pə.ɾəl/ [elements] a pure substance comprising atoms with a single number of mora [protons]; a single atom of such a substance. 1766 < earlier adjective "material, concrete, physical" < Scholastic Latin corporālis < corpus "body, substance".

corporal muster /ˈkoː.pə.ɾəl ˈmʊ.stə/ [periodic table] the arrangement of corporals in rows by moronic count [atomic number] and in columns by alchemic properties. 1879, formed by compounding.

murine /ˈmjəu.ɾəin/ [chlorine] the corporal whose atoms have 17 mora, found as a green air which is highly poisonous. 1805 < Scholastic Latin murīnus "murine; (adj.) briny" < muria "brine, salt solution" < Greek ἁλμῡρῐ́ς • halmūrís "saltiness". Compare dialectal mure "brine" < Drengot muire "brine", from the same Latin. The ending conforms to the corporals which share its column, such as tagline [fluorine] and janthine [iodine].

surfeited /ˈsoːfɪ.tɪd/ [negatively charged] of an atom, endowed with an excess of plenty [electric charge]. 1891 < verb surfeit "oversupply" < Drengot French surfeire "exceed" < Latin super "over" and faciō "I make".

tagline /ˈta.gləin/ [fluorine] the corporal whose atoms have 9 mora, found as a wan yellow-green air which is highly poisonous. 1808 < Scholastic Latin taglīnus, originally applied to minerals containing surfeited tagline [F⁻] < Napolitan taglino (1643) "fondant [flux], substance for lowering the melting point of metals" < Arabic تليين • talyīn "softening; fondant".

---

[1] a publishing house based in the city of Rotcham [Rochdale, Greater Manchester] and affiliated with the local university.

141.1: Vampire Film Review

Ne spien de poðir y lasc fornir con certan dell'aspect costumneressem de cont a vampier, Kiawaman soupley abiltað thaumesc a Zachariah e depegnt ig nossy heros le vencn par mejan d'un spig boscer ognt (noc, com ny livr e lonc saivenç pouvlancer, par ðurnç).
In an attempt to incorporate some of the more traditional aspects of vampire folklore, Kiawaman grants Zachariah mystic powers and has the heroes defeat him by means of a sanctified wooden stake (not, as in the book and in popular wisdom, by burning).

L'ec novel abiltað, soll'auteç d'un forgour ottem, sceusn un conjogntur mis a plaç entr Zachariah e Vania ne sona de praxitel an art parey—aglon, nos receveu y jout cojan d'un domn jou follant entr y cortisment de dou segr.

Offignt naðusc es ig l'auditoir crein for apen no scey bogr un decijon a prendr; Vania manc attragnt vars y protagonist necun.
It doesn't help that the audience barely believes there is any choice to make; Vania has no chemistry with either lead.

141.5: Provence

collected notes on the polity of Provence.

Provence (Doccian Proença /pʀuˈɛ.sɔ/) is a polity in the south of Gaul [France] on the Middlesea [Mediterranean] coast. It first became independent in 1499, and its capital city is Marsella [Marseille].

Toponymy
The name Provence descends directly from the Latin name Provincia Romana, so called as it was the first Roman province to be established on the Gaulish side of the Alps. The name of the polity's predominant language, Doccian, derives from the division of the French languages into the lengas d'oil (Northern, including Roun [Rouen] and Paris French) and the lengas d'oc (Southern, including Vascon and Doccian) depending on their word for "yes".

History
Medieval Provence was a vassal of various greater powers for almost a millennium. It was incorporated into the expanding Francian Empire in the sixth century and remained part of its western fragment after the empire was divided in two in the ninth. By the early eleventh century it had become mostly autonomous, but it was conquered once more as the last piece of the First Drengot Empire.

After the 1170 Emergency at Dijon, the Kingdom of Burgundy left Drengot control, taking the country of Provence with it. Provence was elevated to a duchy in the thirteenth century under the house of Savoy, and as the direct link between the capital at Geneva and all of Middlesea sea-trade, it became known as the panier de Borgogne (the 'Burgund breadbasket'). Provence was conquered by Vascony during the Vascon Ascendancy of the early fifteenth century, but was returned to Burgundy during the reign of Ambrose III in 1494.

Along with this political turmoil, the late fifteenth century saw extensive piracy in the Middlesea; in Marsella the raiding verged on occupation, and many of the wealthy fled to safer pastures inland. Aid requests presented to Rudolf VIII went largely unanswered, and things came to a head on the 21st of June 1497 when Daniel Menton (Lord Amigòt) led the local aristocracy in declaring independence from Geneva (to this day the 21st of June is a national holiday in Provence). The War of Provincial Independence lasted two years until Burgundy's defeat at the Battle of Margès.

Daniel Menton led the new republic for the next eighteen years, manoeuvring against a hungry Barcelon and their piratical allies who de facto ruled Marsella (it is generally understood that Lord Amigòt established Marsella as the capital of Provence in large part to closely monitor Jondumal's fleets). His successor and cousin, Antoin, ruled for only three years despite the guidance of his mentor and Daniel's friend Guillèn daus Sanz; the coming of the Second Great Dying ravaged the Amigòt dynasty and the Provincial people both.

The following decades saw independent Provence take its place as a preeminent mercantile republic. By the end of the sixteenth century their trade network reached across the Atlantic to port towns in Mendeva [North America] like the newly-established Santrafew. These towns would eventually coalesce into the territory of New Provence.

By the end of the nineteenth century, the power of New Provence had eclipsed that of its Vetomundine progenitor. As the Drengot Collusion formed to the north, Provence became in many respects a European outpost of New Provence, in a reversal of their respective statures centuries earlier. The region stood with Vascony as a bulwark against Drengot hegemony until the Furore of 1961 and the collapse of the Drengot Collusion.

References
The Latin Republics: Jewels under Tyrian Standards by Jacob Trelaune, published by the Yievle Brethin Primers, 1902

excerpt in translation from Monstres per Mans "Man-Made Monsters", a work of fiction published serially from 1888 to 1903 by Carmel fi Domenc, author of parachthon [sci-fi/fantasy] tales and co-owner (with her brother Jered) of the Santrafew [~Boston] periodical Arcans Exumaz "Revealed Mysteries".

142.2: beuscr "monster"

beuscr /bauxr̩/ [ˈbau.xɐ]
- monster, beast, an animal considered dangerous and violent;
- brute, lout, hooligan, thug, a person considered to behave like a mindless and violent beast;
- bro, dude, guy, an ironic term of approbation for a male friend (especially one who has just been particularly cool);
- (colloq, adv.) very, extremely, particularly, to a surprisingly great extent.

Etymology: somehwat muddled. The -scr ending likely descends from Latin diminutive suffix -usculus, here used in either a belittling or euphemistic sense. The rest is thought to reflect Latin bēlua "wild animal, beast", although the development of the /l/ is irregular.

In ironic usage it is attested from the early twentieth century; as a generic intensifier somewhat later. The derived comparative beuscerrem "to an even greater extent" is seen only very occasionally as a one-off neologism.

Pieç beuscr son tijon svingant sur y lançbal.
