142.3: ec ogl quïr "close one's eyes"

ec ogl quïr /ɛk ɔil kwaiˈɪr/ [ɪˈgɔil kwɐˈʝɪː]
- close one's eyes, to cover one's eyes with one's eyelids so that one cannot see;
- ignore, turn a blind eye, to intentionally fail to recognise that something (usually bad) is happening

Etymology: fixed idiom literally meaning "to extinguish eyes". Both this and its opposite ec ogl accendr "open one's eyes, lit. light eyes" first appear in the early Middle Borlish period, presumably via the notion of making things light and dark. In metaphorical use the phrase is seen from the fifteenth century.

The noun ogl "eye" descends unproblematically from Latin oculus "eye"; the verb quïr "extinguish, darken; turn off, switch off" comes from Latin quiēscō "quieten, stop" after analogy to other inchoative verbs like finir < fīniō~fīniēscō "to finish".

Jo quïsceu ec ogl eð ençau a conteyar.
/ʒo ˌkwai.iˈxau ɛk ɔil ɛθ ɛnˈtso a ˌkɔn.tiˈjar/
[ʝo ˌkwajˈxau ɪˈgɔil e‿ðɪnˈtso a ˌkɔntˈjɐː]
1s extinguish-pst p.px eye and start-pst at count-inf
I closed my eyes and started counting.

##

142.4: oundrar "wound"

oundrar /unˈdrar/ [ʊnˈdʀɐː]
- wound, injure, hurt, harm, to cause an injury or similar harm to;
- damage, break, impair, to cause not to function correctly;
- offend, spite, insult, to hurt the feelings or honour of

Etymology: from Old Borlish (v)ounrar, oundar "wound, injure", a conflation of the descendant of Latin vulnerō "I wound" and the borrowing of Old Norse unda "to wound" (which are unrelated). The loss of the initial consonant would be unexpected if the Latin etymon was the only one; however, this was a regular feature of Old Norse.

M'orruð un hom ay my bos oundrað.
/mɔˈrɪθ ɪn ɔm e mi bɔz unˈdraθ/
[mʊˈʀɪ‿ðɪˈnɔm e mi bɔz ʊnˈdʀah]
1s.obj=seem indf perosn have.sbj 1s.gn gun wound-p.pst
I think someone's broken my gun.

##

142.5: Tremonnow

Tremonnow (Merch /tɾəˈmɔ.nə/, Welsh Trevonwy /ˌtɾe.vəˈnui/) [Monmouth] is a town in the southeast of Wales, the administrative centre of the district of Ux [1].

Toponymy

The name Tremonnow derives from the Welsh trew "town" and the name of the river it lies on, the Monnow (compare Welsh Mynwy "the Monnow", which is of unclear origin).

History

The lands around Tremonnow were conquered from the medieval Welsh kingdom of Guent [Gwent] by Vigo the Magnificent during the formation of the kingdom of Greater Devon in the first half of the eighth century.

The Christian order called the Brethin was founded in Tremonnow at some point before 800 N under the patronage of Vigo's daughter Iseld. The order would become renowned for their efforts at historical documentation, and their archives in what eventually became the modern Tremonnow Gravatory preserve invaluable sources on early medieval Albion [Great Britain] (including a copy of the Chronicle of Carlile [Carlisle]).

From the mid-twentieth century, the Tremonow Open School, formerly known as the Brethin Mesh Institute, provided distance learning in Welsh and Wessern [2] across Albion and, latterly, also across British Mendeva.

People
Dewock Barclythe (1452-1539 N), Friar of Tremonnow and for several decades the prime Factor of Records at the Brethin House there.

---

[1] roughly corresponding to Monmouthshire, named for area's main river [the Usk], from an old Welsh word for "water".

[2] the English language variety spoken as a recognised minority language in Britain [Wales, Devon and Cornwall, Brittany, Cumbria, Strathclyde, Man and the Isles, parts of Ireland], mostly in its eastern regions bordering Markland and Kent.

##

143.1: Prehistory Curriculum

excerpt from the 1981 Report towards a Normal Teaching for Children at Mantleschool, a public report from the Ministry for Schools within Borland's contemporary anthracite administratration, which was intended to standardise the education of children up to the age of twelve.

Posc il ain schol lajarn complið, val ig stuðant broucn un recordaçon mozað ag mendrem cas y defas des prell'aubon de scrittur jusc l'epoc dy Scon Tetrachy, con tan casc schol son hortaminað a them recendessem admettr lonc y bustr d'envou vecin.
Upon completing mantleschool, pupils should have at least a surface-level understanding of the development from prehistory until the time of the Second Tetrarchy, although individual schools are encouraged to include more recent material as it relates to vicine matters.

Masctighað es ig l'ec them sein abrangent dy costumn ag toun ben muncef local, aglon cainç diçr (battagl, descovart eð aval) ayent avenuð cos veçin.
This may include the traditions of the local village or quarter, or else notable events (battles, discoveries, etc) which occurred nearby.

Enombrað secuð, val ig stuðant recievn y cæros por ec splorar:
Taken in order, pupils should have the opportunity to learn about:

scamn de migraçon vars Istr Boral jusc e par y Kelt Albic
waves of migration into Borland up to and including the Albic Kelts

ðar primal eð y hopr ne pieðr effojað ny tombr a Revel (comparað con y plaçment Orcadesc a Scarreð ottem mantenuð)
early farming and the stoneware found in the Revel mounds (compared to the better-preserved Orkney site at Scarreth)

sojornaçon, conveyaçon e machinaçon, abrangent ag commarç obligað por eramn, l'avent aval de far, eð y costroinç dy labyrinth a Çadrosc
travel, transport and technology, including the trade necessary for bronze, the later introduction of iron, and the construction of the Çadrosc labyrinth

y doujug entr tribu ne castr colliner nell'epoc pre Rom e lorry cultur cas autortað, soumoin jaint vars art, ensignment e jovagl ja sceint
the intertribal system of hill forts in the pre-Classical period and the culture around authority, with reference to extant art, sculpture and jewellery

143.2: æternar "immortalise"

æternar /ˌe.tɛrˈnar/ [e.tɪːˈnɐː]
- perpetuate, continue, maintain, prolong, eternise, to make last indefinitely;
- immortalise, to cause to be renowned;
- memorialise, commemorate, mark, to ensure that someone or something is remembered

143.3: rasamar "tsunami"

rasamar /ˌra.zaˈmar/ [ˌʀa.zɐˈmɐː]

143.4: assuvar "meteor"

assuvar /ˌa.siˈvar/ [ˌa.sɪˈvɐː]
- meteor, shooting star, a piece of extraterrestrial rock falling through the Earth's atmosphere;
- meteoroid, meteorite, such a piece of rock before it enters the Earth's atmosphere or after it has landed on the ground;
- harbinger, omen, herald, something that foretells the coming of some person or event (especially something bad)

Etymology: from Scholastic Latin assūvāris "meteor; meteoric", and specifically from the thirteenth-century work Dē Assūvāribus "On Meteoric (Phenomena)". This is a borrowing from Arabic شُهُب • shuhub "shooting stars", plural of شِهَاب • shihāb "blaze, brand; shooting star". In the last senses it reflects a long history of comets and similar celestial appearances being used to foretell the future.

Nos s'asseyau tras port e conteyau assuvar.

1p rfl=sit-ipf.1p across door and count-ipf.1p meteor
We sat outside and counted shooting stars.

143.5: In the Solar System

    excerpt taken from 1936 work Tell Me Everything About the Solar System [1], part of the Tell Me, Telmy! series of children’s educational books. These were originally written by Adamara Godwilham [2] and featured a fictionalised version of her father Bartelmy, “Telmy”, acting as guide and entertainer. After her death she bequeathed the series to her publishers, Zizania Nexus, who have continued the series to the present day.

…found the four biggest jovial moons right in the middle of the Revitalist period. This time during the sixteenth century was when scholars and artists across the Middlesea [Mediterranean] and the Persias looked back to the works and beliefs of Classical Greece and Rome.

As word spread of the first really new celestial bodies to be discovered for thousands of years, people came up with lots of names for these pharī Iovis “lighthouses of Jove”. Some people wanted to bring glory to their patrons, lords or lands. Others reached to retellings of Classical legends which were in fashion.

The convention that has lasted in European languages, and which has been maintained since we have found many more small jovial moons in the last century, has been to name Jupiter’s gyrers [satellites] for his mortal descendants. We have done the same with the two moons of Mars, Dimus [Phobos] and Phobus [Deimos], which are named for his twin sons and attendants.

In myth, Æacos was the grandfather…

—

[1] originally published in Kentish as Tell Me Wrich by th'Ambit ot Son, pronounced /tɛl mə vʀɪtʃ bi θamˈbɪt ɔt sɔn/.

[2] Adamara is a feminine form of Adamar, from Classical German roots audas “wealth” and mēras “fame”. The surname, pronounced /ˈgwɪ.ləm/, is from placenames deriving from early Kentish godwille “fortune, blessing” and hamme “enclosure”.

144.1: The Kernovan Conjuring

notes in translation on the subject of the Kernovan Conjuring.

Y Conjuraçon Cornovan sta un collaboraçon entr y Reyaum a Dorogn Massem e Roger Drengot, Duc a Normandy por y pretenjon dy Duc sur y thron de Cantuer appoyar. 
The Kernovan Conjuring was a collaboration between the Kingdom of Greater Devon and Roger Drengot, Duke of Normandy to press the Duke's claim to the throne of Kent.

Cossirað es l'oc vellisqment com y caus y proismessem por ig y Preu Empir Drengoçan inceveus tras Gal eð Albion souðer.
This plot is considered the proximate cause for the creation of the First Drengot Empire across Gaul [France] and southern Albion [Great Britain].

Y Conjuraçon sta accommis d'an 1029, ne souc dy mort de Rey Rodolf de Cantuer.
The Conjuring was carried out in 1029, following the death of King Rodulf of Kent.

Cantuer sou Rodolf regnant jaçol aye se monfeyað, ant dominanç reconnuð sur y Vessax diminoit (con tan noc inkerellað par Dorogn) e sur Essax ny norð.
Kent under the long-reigning Rodulf had prospered, with recognised supremacy over the rump Wessex (albeit not uncontested by Devon) and over Essex to the north.

Posc ogt dezein de manovranç politic, Rodolf parmane ag sougl de mort eð y succession no sta bogr certan.
After eight decades of political manoeuvring, Rodulf lingered on his deathbed and the succession was deeply uncertain.

144.2: cavir yert "boot up"

cavir yert /kaˈvɪr jɛrt/ [kɐˈvɪː ʝɛːt]
- wake up, come to, stir, to regain consciousness;
- turn on, switch on, activate, start, boot up, to begin operating;
- (of a business) open, to start serving customers

Etymology: early Modern Borlish idiom literally meaning "to get awake". The verb cavir "get" is a direct descendant of capiō "take, pick, recieve", used in the sense "become" since the Middle Borlish period. The adjective yert "awake, alert; (of a business) open" descends via Old Borlish yerte "standing, upright, vertical" and synonymous ērctus in Vulgar Latin from Classical ērēctus "raised, built, erected". Extended from people to machinery and thence to businesses by the nineteenth century.

J'attenoy cos infruniscent tandic y grimmour cave yert.
/ˌʒa.teˈnɔi kɔz ɪnˌfri.niˈxɛnt tanˈdɪk i grɪˈmur kaˈve jɛrt/
[ˌʝa.tɪˈnɔi kɔz ɪɱˌfʀi.nɪˈçɛnt tɐnˈdɪk i gʀɪˈmʊː kɐˈve ʝɛːt]
1s=wait-pst adv bored while df computer get-ipf awake
I waited impatiently while the computer booted up.

144.3: parsemnar "dot"

parsemnar /ˌpar.sɛmˈnar/ [ˌpɐː.sɪmˈnɐː]
- plant, sow, to throw (the seeds of a crop) onto fertile ground;

144.4: congenir "conceive"

congenir /ˌkɔn.ʒeˈnɪr/ [ˌkɔɲ.ʝɪˈnɪː]
- conceive, beget, to have as a child;
- to be the ancestor of, more generally;
- create, generate, to bring into being;
- originate, invent, to be responsible for the existence of

Etymology: from Scholastic Latin congenēscō "I bring into being", a regularised derivative of gignō "I beget" (past participle genitus "begotten"). Originally restricted to familial legal contexts, the word had entered the wider lexicon via patent law by the early modern period. In modern usage the verb is preferentially used as an infinitive or participle, although conjugated forms are still well attested.

df word ewe and ram be.3p beget-p.pst of old Norse
The words 'ewe' and 'ram' descend from Old Norse.

144.5: Mashick

Mashick (Borlish Mascic /maˈxɪk/, Nawat Maishī'co /maiˈʃiːʔ.ko/, Mashick Arabic المشيق · al-Mashīq) is a polity in Lower Mendeva and in fact by land area the largest polity in all of Mendeva. At its greatest extent the then-Empire stretched as far northwest as Mivock.

Morrack vessels of the New World Company established trading relations in the late fifteenth century with the relatively-new Mashick Empire, which at that time was much more geographically restricted. The next decades saw many Novomundine crops make their way across the Atlantic from Mashick, including tashban and shockle.

Mashick (and, to the south, Tavancy) served as bases for exploration of Mendevan lands. Fleets charted as far afield as the Ax, and Mashick was used to exercise control over parts of the Arcabil and their growing riches.

Nineteenth-century Mashick was one of the hotbeds of the nascent political philosophy of Ubiquity. It lagged behind British Mendeva in the adoption of the new morals of the Household Renovation, although by the early twentieth century it had caught up (unlike the more regressive New Provence).

The Lovac Wars of the 1920s and 30s saw the first major bombing campaigns on civilian targets, including many cities in Mashick like Moshtar. The unrest and economic downturn following these wars, more than actual military losses, led to Mashick losing significant parts of its northern territory.

In the modern day Mashick is a major food exporter. Droughts in the late 1960s led to reduced amback and mause supplies and sharply rising prices for these fruits in the Vetomund.

People

Mollam Bushta (fl. c19), composer remember for his pieces featuring the torriot and an ally of the early Deviance movement.

Yollamaniza Elcabir (fl. 1943), spy and later author of La te Hozuho Sineton (No Slumber Will Seize Him). The work's depiction of Mashick's Ministry for Knowledge was revealing enough that he was forced to flee the country to avoid arrest.

Tazim Gennun (fl. 1823), author of short story 'The Witch of Tebjacka'.

Sólin Izcoál (fl. c18, Latinised as Solinus Iscovalis and known in Merch as Iscoval), the life scientist who first expounded a scientific account of evolution. He is responsible for the terms 'Iscovalian variation' and 'living web'.

Poshack Nerwaman (fl. 1848), famed lady explorer whose written accounts remained popular works of writing into the twentieth century.

Y nom Hasiny es congenið des y federaç parey nommað, oç autr annað abrangent d'eiðel sceint oy sou y gournanç de Hasiny e Taisca.
The name Hasiny derives from the federacy of the same name, which once extended across lands which are now part of Hasiny and Taisha.

Y lengaç administraçonal ne Hasiny son Jaugta (Jahtá, y lengaç Mendevan parolabr par y majortað dy pouvlanç) eð y gendr vecin de Cambresc (discrepant a façon signfeyant deur y vernacr de Cambresc Brittan ben Chrysian).

145.5: Furlain

Furlain (Merch pronunciation /fʊːˈləin/, endonym Furlagne /furˈlaɲə/) is a polity in the northeast of the Italian peninsula, whose principal cities are Verona and Odin. It borders Lombardy to the west, Bavarn to the north, Crain to the east, and Venise to the south.

History

During the Second Tetrarchy of the eleventh and twelfth centuries, the March of Furlain was the southernmost part of the German Empire, at first a direct imperial vassal and later specifically consolidated under the suzerainty of the Kingdom of Bavarn. After the collapse of the German Empire in the thirteenth century, Furlain's most frequent rival became the Republic of Venise.

Furlain suffered a severe earthquake in 1348 which destroyed both the castle and cathedral in Odin [Udine]. Reference to this event is the first attestation of the word quagment "earthquake" in the Borlish language.

The armourcloth trend in women's fashion (which emulated men's military dress) began in Furlain during the Long Peace in the late eighteenth century. The local term voinacciale (from voina, a slang term for a soldier) was borrowed into several other languages to describe the style.

Troops from Furlain fought in the Second German War (1815–23), principally against Bavarn. Furlain was allied with such countries as Borland, with whom they undertook the disastrous Battle of Hulm in 1821.

People

Chiarina Bruno (fl. 1824), librettist and composer who wrote the opera Wings Afire.
Jacomo Bruno (fl. 1821), twin of the better-known Chiarina and soldier of the Second German War.

##

145.7: 1st Lexember - des caucet "utterly"

des caucet /dɛz koˈtsɛt/ [dɛz kʊˈtsɛt]
- utterly, absolutely, downright, to the fullest extent possible;
- completely, totally, all the way, all-out, every inch, done to completion;
- irreversibly, irretrievably, irrevocably, in a way that cannot be taken back

Etymology: idiom attested from the late nineteenth century, literally "out of (one's) socks". Thought to have arisen in Damvath slang as a sexual metaphor (taking one's socks off prior to sleeping with someone), although in modern usage it is not considered at all obscene. The noun caucet "sock" is a diminutive of obsolete cauç "hose, stockings, tights", via Medieval Latin calcea from Classical calceus "boot".

Nos stou la javigar des caucet.
/nɔz stu la ˌʒa.viˈgar dɛz koˈtsɛt/
[nɔz stu la ˌʝa.vɪˈgɐː dɛz kʊˈtsɛt]
1s needed there trawl-inf out.of sock
We must leave no stone unturned.

146.1: 2nd Lexember - deunx "close shave"

deunx /daunks/ [daunks]
- near thing, close call, close shave, a situation where an injury or other undesirable outcome is narrowly avoided;
- (interj.) an expression of shock or relief at such a situation;

deunx fair
- get lucky, dodge a bullet, to narrowly escape an undesirable outcome

Etymology: university slang among the Vithor New School's students, attested there from the eighteenth century and entering the wider lexicon some decades afterwards. The noun is a borrowing from Latin deunx "eleven twelfths", related to uncia "one twelfth". The story linking its modern usage to a twelve-man jury is almost certainly false; more likely is simply the sense of being almost but not quite the whole thing.

Nos farreu noc deunx cossy alcheðr.
/nɔz faˈrau nɔk daunks kɔˈsi alˈkɛðr̩/
[nɔz fɐˈʀau nɔg daunks kʊˈsi ɐˈgɛ.ðɐ]
1p do-fut.1p ng close.shave thus again
We won't get so lucky again.

The Deviance movement

notes in translation on the subject of the Deviance movement (also called Anti-Paradise Theology).

Un ouvr primal signfeyant por y commouð a Desveyanç sta l'ediçon lon nom 'E Nos Amareu y Foy', ençant a s'evolgar d'an 1799 eð offiruð par sdegn cas rigteç incommorant.
An important early work to the Deviance movementhm was the anonymously-published 'And We Will Love the Fire', which began circulating in 1799 to immediate moral outrage.

Con tan scein pres un doçan de possibiltað creibr soumis cos serious por cuscon sta sy scrittour, jamay no scey alcun accort acavað sull'oc them.
Though almost a dozen plausible candidates for its authorship have been seriously proposed, no consensus has ever been reached on the issue.

Y commouð a Desveyanç joun coincideu coll'ersteigon dy nuton a trevogt deshormejað par y livr d'an 1795 par Elsebeth Sneider 'Par un Argent Neir'.
The early Deviance movement coincided with the height of the voidtale craze launched by Elsebeth Sneider's 1795 trevold 'Through a Black Mirror'.

Plusour dell'eç idea introdoit n'ouvr a trevogt se courn sousunt afont de theology Contr-Paradis, eð y commouð au taur a l'eç ouvr de Sneider adoptar cos particuler.
Many of the ideas conjured in voidtale works were incorporated into Anti-Paradise theology, and Sneider's works in particular were embraced by the movement.

Interim, Sneider meðes abhorre y doctrin Contr-Paradis; lonc sy parol meðes:
However, Sneider herself despised Anti-Paradism; in her own words:

"Cay doutr lorrell'idea stragn e lorrell'univers solumnesc e nienter, car Thifäne, pu tan ig bempart alcot de lou aun me traitað com ða jo sey lorry confraðr l'evidendessem!"
“It is not only their strange ideas and lonely, nihilist universe, dear Thifäne, but that so many of their number have approached me as if I were their most natural ally!”

##

146.2: 3rd Lexember - collindar "abut"

collindar /ˌkɔ.lɪnˈdar/ [ˌkɔ.lɪnˈdɐː]
- abut, neighbour, border, to lie adjacent to (as of a piece of territory);
- run up against, bump into, to start encountering problems with;
- resemble, recall, to remind one of due to similarity

Etymology: regular descendant of Latin collimitō "I border on", from limitō "I delimit, bound". Alternatively, a derivation in the Old Borlish period from an unattested lindar or now-dialectal lint "fence". Extension to conceptual closeness is attested from the seventeenth century.

I reconnoy y segr luy collindant.
/i ˌre.kɔˈnɔi i sijr̩ lai ˌkɔ.lɪnˈdant/
[i ˌʀe.kʊˈnɔi i ˈsɪ.jɐ lai ˌkɔ.lɪnˈdant]
3s recognise.pst df man 3s.obl abut-prs
She recognised the man next to her.

146.3: 4th Lexember - verdeyant "lush"

verdeyant /ˌvɛr.diˈjant/ [ˌvɛː.dɪˈʝant]
- verdant, green, lush, abundant with (especially new-grown) vegetation;
- rife, plentiful, abounding, present in large numbers;
- thriving, flourishing, prosperous, successful, characterised by happiness and achievements

Etymology: present participle of verdeyar "become green; flourish; abound", a verbal derivative of vert "green" (or directly from Vulgar Latin virdidiō "I turn green"). Metaphorical extensions parallel those in neighbouring Romance and Germanic languages.

Cou je meis Juglot an smout de forest verdeyant.
/ku ʒe miz ʒaiˈlɔt an smut de foˈrɛst ˌvɛr.diˈjant/
[ku ʝe miz ʝɐiˈlɔt an zmut de fʊˈʀɛst ˌvɛːdɪˈʝant]
fall.pst time.of month July at-indf riot of forest lush
July came with a profusion of lush forest.

##

146.4: 5th Lexember - roç "cabbie"

roç /rɔts/ [ʀɔts]
- cabbie, taxi driver, driver hired by a passenger and paid according to the distance and time of the trip;
- cab, taxi, the vehicle driven by such a person

Etymology: early 20C from Napolitan rozzo "cabbie", further origin disputed. Formally identical with earlier rozzo "boor, lout", from Latin adjective rudis "rough, unskilled, rude", but this term seems to have been obsolete by the mid-19th century. Occasionally identified with dialect ruzza "wheel", from Latin rotula "small wheel, scroll".

I save cojan alcot volen y cançon accis par y roç.
/i saˈve koˈʒan alˈkɔt voˈlɛn i kanˈtsɔn akˈsɪz par i rɔts/
[i sɐˈve kʊˈʝan ɐˈgɔt vʊˈlɛn i kɐnˈtsɔn ɐkˈsɪz pɐː‿ʀi ʀɔs]
3s know-ipf mundane how.much will-ipf.3p df song turn.on by df cabbie
He knew how boring the cabbie's music would be.

##

146.5: 6th Lexember - lançbal "lineball"

lançbal /ˌlantsˈbal/ [ˌlansˈbal]
- lineball, a particular team sport similar to handball or rugby;
- the ball used in this sport;
- (loosely, informal) other team sports involving throwing a ball;
- hot potato, something which gets passed on rapidly due to nobody wanting to deal with it

Etymology: eighteenth-century compound from lançar "to throw" and bal "ball". The verb descends from Late Latin lanceō "I launch, shoot, pierce", a derivative of Classical lancea "javelin, spear". Compare caugtrbal "kickball, football", which dates from roughly the same time as a word but whose rules were standardised several decaded later than lineball. In the last sense the word is attested from the 1950s.

Candon y nuverrem es ig Istr Boral vencoy ny torne a lançbal?
/kanˈdɔn i niˈvɛ.rɛm ɛz ai ɪstr̩ boˈral vɛnˈkɔi ni torˈne a ˌlantsˈbal/
[kɐnˈdɔn i nɪˈvɛ.ʀɐm ɪz ai ˈɪ.stɐ bʊˈʀal vɪŋˈkɔi ni tʊːˈne a ˌlansˈbal]
when df recent-cmp be cmp island Borland win-pst in-df contest at lineball
When did Borland last win the lineball tournament?

Twentieth Century History

excerpt from a 2021 book called Excourse Puzzlers, published by the Royal Tommarth Castinghouse. This was a collection of casual party games using the branding and popularity of a long-running series begun by Merch couple Anna and Ralph Highwater in the 1930s.

Twentieth Century History II (answers on sheet 143)

1. In which Mendevan [North American] polity were the first sobot [radio] transmitters and receivers invented in 1903?

2. Which of the adolescences [coming-of-age novels] of Dorotha Quistack, published in 1917, won the Hatfell Honour and was adapted into a film starring Joke Pentawer just two years later?

3. Who led the government whose collapse in 1925 was the beginning of the so-called Portingale Anarchy?

4. What is the full name of the painkiller present in "Tommy pills", first synthesised in 1932 as the result of collaboration between the Branwen Sanatory and the University of Rimack?

5. How was the length of the (dime) foot redefined in 1946, giving it the value it has to this day?

6. Who was the monarch of Hasiny whose death due to a convoy accident in 1950 is alleged to have been purposefully orchestrated with the knowledge of his grandson Pether?

7. Which national team achieved its only victory in the Lineball Global Tourney to date in 1965?

8. As part of the 120-year celebrations of the Laic Declarions of Belgrade, what was legalised by laws passed simultaneously in 1970 across over a dozen polities?

9. What was the name given to the natural disaster which struck Mashick [Mexico] on the 19th of September 1985?

10. The restored steamship displayed from 1991 to 1995 in Deganny [Deganwy, Wales] was originally part of what polity's "Culombálu" fleet?

##

146.6: 7th Lexember - clacqment "clatter"

clacqment /klakˈmɛnt/ [klɐkˈmɛnt]
- clatter, rattle, a succession of loud and abrupt noises;
- gunfire, the sound of firearms being repeatedly shot;
- racket, din, commotion, ruckus, an environment of loud noise and disturbance;
- controversy, discord, strife, bitter conflict arousing much debate or even violence

Etymology: noun formation from clacquar "rattle, clatter, cause a disturbance". This was borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from contemporary French clacquer "clap, slap, slam", or directly from that word's Germanic origin (compare Willem or Kentish clacken "whack, shake"). Used for gunfire since the eighteenth century, and for general disruption from the nineteenth.

Jo sveilau des y clacqment a jarry jusser.
/ʒo sviˈlo dɛz i klakˈmɛnt a ʒaˈri ʒiˈsɛr/
[ʝo zvɪˈlo dɛz i klɐkˈmɛnt a ʝɐˈʀi ʝɪˈsɛː]
1s wake-pst from df clatter at crockery downstairs
I woke to the clatter of plates downstairs.

##

146.7: 8th Lexember - inquillin "roommate"

inquillin /ˌɪn.kwɪˈlɪn/ [ˌɪŋ.kwɪˈlɪn]
- tenant, lodger, renter, one dwelling in a residence they do not own;
- roommate, dormmate, a person with whom one shares living quarters;
- (crude, euphemistic) bedfellow, bedmate, mistress, a sexual partner one lives with

Etymology: from Latin inquilīnus "sojourner, lodger; inmate", related to incolō "I inhabit". Influenced in sense by the unrelated noun quil "bed" and verb inquillir "embed"; these descend from Latin cubīle "bed, lair, kennel", which is related to cubō "I lie down". The euphemistic sexual sense has a possible citation in the seventeenth century, but is only securely attested in the nineteenth.

Deu mien, il s'ayen por inquillin!
/dau mjɛn | ɪl sɛˈjɛn pɔr ˌɪn.kwɪˈlɪn/
[dau mjɛn | ɪl sɪˈʝɛn pɔː‿ˌʀɪŋ.kwɪˈlɪn]
God mine | 3p rfl=have-ipf-3p for roommate
Oh my God, they were roommates!

##

147.1: 9th Lexember - bount "en route"

bount /bunt/ [bunt]
- en route, heading, on the way, along the way, in the course of travelling from one place to another;
- directed, pointing, facing, oriented in a particular direction;
- determined, willing, intent, bent, wanting to do something;
- set, set up, ready, prepared, arranged as necessary ahead of time

Etymology: from Old Borlish boun "ready, willing", altered to bount by analogy with the present participle ending -nt by the early modern period. This is a borrowing from Old Norse búinn "adapted, fit", the past participle of búa "reside, prepare, decorate". In archaic or poetic use the word may be used as a preposition meaning "about to; approaching".

I me quistau por m'addocir ig bount son il ag quarf.
/i me kwɪˈsto pɔr ˌma.doˈtsɪr ai bunt sɔn ɪl ɛi kwarf/
[i me kwɪˈsto pɔː ˌma.dʊˈtsɪː‿ʀai bunt sɔn ɪl ɛi kwɐːf]
3s 1s.obl phone-pst for 1s.obl=inform cmp en.route be.3p 3p to-df station
She phoned me to say they're en route to the station.

Alburgh Anecdotes

excerpt in translation from a letter from the Danish playwright Absolon Mortenszen to his Borlish friend Anscon d'Aupont.

Scey un novel freir ag hostel, lovastr a men e (ða tu vil my femn confeyar) formous a men sou Daniel.
There is a new friar at the hostel, less talkative and (if you will believe my wife) less handsome than Daniel.

Lonc mey soumonendessem es i cas min all'astuçour demant encontrað n'eç dram a rigteç inerrevibr ancour scenað ny citað aval; l'a heu d'un segr sognant de parrinment fair a Rom e posc alandar de le stimar noc Chrestan aðief!
More than anything he reminds me of the moralising mentor one sees in the dreadful morality plays they still show down in the city; he seems the sort to dream of visiting Rome and upon arriving declare it insufficiently Christian! 

Se poð appondr ig y novel ensignment y Machinaçon de Helios de Lorenzo yon tu m'expateyau tras un asc volois y bossir appoussar colombant vars un raivottaç, oc m'ajoutaçant toð cas.
One supposes Lorenzo's new Machines of Helios sculpture about which you droned on at me for hours might send the good man directly into an apoplexy, which would at least be entertaining.

Y novel dram es un picq issaur, noc obstroint y temp moglastr y vertað desconent naðusc ig Albourg no's, a my sorc, Barcelon.
The new play is a mild success, despite the inclement weather rather betraying the fact that Alburgh is not, to my regret, Barcelon.

##

147.2: 10th Lexember - tourm "troop"

tourm /turm/ [tʊːm]
- troop, squadron, company, platoon, a body of soldiers;
- barracks, base, fort, fortification, encampment, a structure built for the (temporary or permanent) housing and mustering of soldiers;
- crew, squad, gang, a group of people brought together to do a particular task;
- team, group of people playing on the same side of a sport or game;
- swarm, colony, hive, collective noun for various insects

Etymology: Middle Borlish, via the conflation of contemporary French tourme "troop" and Dutch torem "tower, fort". The former is a borrowing from an Italian descendant of Latin turma "troop, team", while the latter is probably a borrowing from a Romance decendant of Latin turris "tower". As a collective noun it is attested from the sixteenth century for ants and somewhat later for some other animals.

Stoura un tourm ottem all'oc kevlar.
/stuˈra ɪn turm ˈɔ.tɛm aˈlɔk kɛˈvlar/
[stʊˈʀa ɪn tʊːm ˈɔ.tɐm ɐˈlɔk kɪˈvlɐː]
need-fut indf crew better to-df=s.px heist
This heist will need a better crew.

##

147.3: 11th Lexember - alcant aposc "eventually"

alcant aposc /alˈkant aˈpɔx/ [ɐˈgan.tɐˈpɔx]
- some day, in the future, eventually, at some point, after an unspecified amount of time;
- (interjection) about time, finally, jibe at someone or something taking a notionally excessive amount of time

Etymology: idiom found in this form since the eighteenth century, literally "once later". The adverb alcant "once" is an analogical form derived from cant "when" with the word element alc- < Latin aliquī "some". The adverb aposc "later" is from the preposition posc "after", from Latin post quid "after what". As an interjection it is only securely attested in the twentieth century.

Quippe l'oc havara un hom alcant aposc.
/kwɪˈpe lɔk ˌha.vaˈra ɪn ɔm alˈkant aˈpɔx/
[kwɪˈpe lɔk ˌha.vɐˈʀa ɪˈnɔm ɐˈgant ɐˈpɔx]
surely df=s.px hail-fut indf person once later
Surely someone will notice eventually.

##

147.4: 12th Lexember - tegmn "shelter"

tegmn /ˈtijmn̩/ [ˈtij.mɐn]
- shelter, cover, protection, refuge, a physical structure that keeps one safe;
- (specifically) shade, an area shielded from direct sunlight;
- buffer, cushion, anything used to isolate or minimise the effect of one thing on another;
- leeway, grace, wiggle room, freedom, flexibility, latitude, a range in which one can operate safely

Etymology: originally in the first senses, a direct descendant from Latin tegimen "cover, protection". This noun comes from verb tegō "I cover, conceal", which became Old Borlish ter "span, cover (an amount of land)" and thence modern teir "amount to, number". Extended to safety in more abstract contexts by the early modern period.

Jo duvau y bosaç con y tegmn d'un hey.
/ʒo diˈvo i boˈzats kɔn i ˈtij.mn̩ dɪn hi/
[ʝo dɪˈvo i bʊˈzas kɔn i ˈtij.mɐn dɪn hi]
1s duck-pst df gunfire with df cover of=indf fence
I used a fence as cover from the gunfire.

##

147.5: 13th Lexember - zizania "discord"

zizania /ˌzi.zaˈnja/ [ˌzi.zɐˈnja]
- discord, disharmony, dissonance, cacophony, a harsh combination of sounds;
- discord, tension, strife, dissension, arguing, lack of agreement of harmony between people;
- anguish, distress, angst, inner conflict;
- temptation, spite, vice, sin, feeling drawn to doing wicked things

Etymology: seventeenth-century borrowing from Lombard zizania "ryegrass, weed; discord, vice", which displays a metaphorical extension dating back to its ancestor in Late Latin zizanium "cockle, ryegrass, darnel; vice", a borrowing from Greek. Its modern association with cacophonous noise is probably due to sound symbolism.

Nos oyau zizania dereðr dy mur dy rajognoir.
/nɔz oˈjo ˌzi.zaˈnja deˈrɛðr̩ di mɪr di ˌra.ʒɔiˈnɔir/
[nɔz ʊˈʝo ˌzi.zɐˈnja dɪˈʀɛ.ðɐ di mɪː di ˌʀa.ʝʊiˈnɔ.jɐ]
1p hear-ipf.1p discord behind of-df wall of-df boardroom
We heard arguing through the boardroom's wall.

All Change

collected notes on a variety of topics.

Vigo VII (fl. 1121) was king of Greater Devon [Devon, Conrwall, Brittany] in the twelfth century, which was a major vassal of the First Drengot Empire under Emperor Roger II (and later briefly under Roger's son). In 1121 N he invaded the south coast of Wales, attempting a reconquest of the southeastern Welsh principalities, without the support of the Emperor.

Zahid Russian is a Slavone language spoken in Crovatia, Servia and surrounding regions, although having little official recognition anywhere. Despite its current location it is mostly closely related to eastern Slavone languages like Kievan [~Ukrainian]; it descends from communities in the late medieval and early modern period who migrated westward due to the disruption of Islamic conquests from the south. The language is named за́хід • záhid, meaning "west". It is the source of some words in modern Merch (and other Englishes), such as rasgatto "dénouement", which comes via Venisian from Разгадто, a nineteenth-century mystery trevold by Olexi Harchenko.

New Skies, Old Stories (originally published in Provincial French as Novè Cial, Anzan Conte) is a work of popular history detailing the origins of the various threads of parachthon [scifi/fantasy] fiction. It was written by Simon d'Estiala and published by Prindor Marsillès in 1980. Its thesis is that many of the tropes often considered to have been invented by particular parachthon authors are in fact simply examples of existing tropes used in new settings.

Margaret of Iscombe [Exeter] (fl. 1435) was the wife of Mark of Tolose and the mother of King Ambrose III of Vascony. She married at some point shortly before 1435 N. She bore four children who survived infancy, including the future King Ambrose: her first child Alexandra and two younger children Victor (later Duke of Astorga) and Natalia.


##

147.6: 14th Lexember - a plaç entarn "some way in"

a plaç entarn /a plats ɛnˈtarn/ [ɐ ˈplats ɪnˈtɐːn]
- some way in, lodged, embedded, inside, located (usually not far) underneath the surface of something;
- along, at some point in the length of some object or space;
- during, at some point in the course of some time period;
- after a while, not at first, eventually, only at some time later than the beginning of something

Etymology: phrase meaning "at (a) position inside", used idiomatically from as early as the fourteenth century. The noun plaç "position" is an Old Borlish borrowing via Old French place "location" from Latin platea "courtyard". The adverb entarn "inside", which corresponds to the preposition ne "in", descends directly from Latin adjective internus "internal, interior".

Y melody dy sanfoin me hamtau a plaç entarn.
/i ˌme.loˈdi di sanˈfɔin me hamˈto a plats ɛnˈtarn/
[i ˌme.lʊˈdi di sɐɱˈfɔin me hɐmˈto ɐ ˈplats ɪnˈtɐːn]
df tune of-df bagpipe 1s.obl win.over-pst at place inside
The bagpipe tune grew on me eventually.

##

147.7: 15th Lexember - kiveury "herdtale"

kiveury /ˌki.vauˈri/ [ˌki.vɐuˈʀi]
- herdtale, a genre of fiction originating in nineteenth-century Hasiny and depicting rural (prototypically, cattle-herding) life as a virtuous idyll;
- pastoralism, bucolicism, Arcadianism, the idealisation of rural life perceived as morally superior to urban modernity

Etymology: 19th-century derivative of kiveu "cattle, herd" with the suffix -ry "a collection of things, a shop, a gestalt quality", coined as a calque of Hasinic Welsh jadełath "herd-dom". The noun kiveu descends from Old Borlish kifew "cattle", a borrowing a Borland Old English cyfeoh "cattle-herd". To describe an ideology the term is seen from the early twentieth century, usually in critical contexts.

Jo cof un grivougl de kiveury ag quarvol.
/ʒo kɔf ɪn griˈvuil de ˌki.vauˈri ɛj kwarˈvɔl/
[ʒo kɔf ɪŋ gʀɪˈvuil de ˌki,vɐuˈʀi ɛj kwɐː]
1s get.pst indf scribble of herdtale at.df airport
I got a herdtale potboiler at the airport.

##

148.1: 16th Lexember - prophthan "faster than light"

prophthan /prɔfˈθan/ [pʁʊfˈθan]
- faster than light, FTL, superluminal, travelling more quickly than the so-called "normal speed" of ten great leagues per second;
- (informal) at warp speed, double-time, lightning fast, with any extremely rapid pace

Etymology: coined in 1949 by Napolitan author Ludgia Pitceri as awareness of the normal speed entered popular culture and parachthon (fantasy/sci-fi) writers reached for various justifications for speedy interstellar travel. The word is a borrowing from Scholastic Greek προφθάνων • prophthánōn "preceding, overtaking", from φθάνω • phthánō "I precede, overtake". In its imprecise use the word is attested from the 1970s.

Capitan, cay uncos inovrant cas y motour prophthan.
/ˌka.piˈtan | ke ɪnˈkɔz ˌi.nɔˈvrant kaz i moˈtur prɔfˈθan/
[ˌka.piˈtan | ke ɪŋˈkɔz ˌi.nʊˈvʀant kaz i mʊˈtʊː pʀʊfˈθan]
captain | fall sth out.of.order wrt df engine FTL
Captain, something's gone wrong with the warp drive.

Maths and Gossip

excerpt in translation from the correspondence of Darren Brodus to Niklás der Fecht; this letter was sent in 1828.

Y majon livr a me fornið tandem con y homily de Dümmeyer a them de tas e mission; jo nil attendr a te molfeyar ne fegndr a aïr le leut, ma se poð t'aiçar ig jo vil l'hour stovent benoçar l'oc semman meðes!
The library has finally provided me with Dümmeyer's treatise on class and delivery; I will not appease you by pretending to have read it, but be assured I will find the hours for it this very week!

Car Johan flagit ig l'es tout theology inutr des l'atmospher, ma contrig Johan da fieltað a alcun mathematic posc y livr de Craddock sur roum a lonctumn.
Dear Johan insists it is all atmospherical and futile nonsense, but then Johan trusts no mathematics since Craddock's book on distance rooms.

Vertað volent so jo soupris ig l'acquïsc por y method machinal meðes benoçar, me j'appon ig i n'a veram un test ossos aðief por se rendr sy modellaçon n'atelier defaglessem.
Honestly I'm surprised he consents to use even the mechanical methods, but I suppose he isn't quite bone-headed enough to make his workshop designing more difficult for himself.

Es tu pretenent vars eir ne souð l'oc stað?
Have you any plans to go south this summer?

J'oy il voun l'area ne Veron rallumar alcheðr por parform—rumorað es ig Al Igne par Bruno sera y primer la scenað posc y var!
I hear they shall reopen the arena in Verona to performances—they say Bruno's Wings Afire will be the first shown there since the war!

##

148.2: 17th Lexember - ja sceint "extant"

ja sceint /ʒa xint/ [ʝa çint]
- extant, in existence, surviving, not yet having disappeared or died;
- attested, recorded, present, in evidence, proven to exist or have once existed;
- (orig. law) preexisting, being present before some other event (and thus having certain legal privileges or protections)

Etymology: phrase meaning "still being there", used as legal jargon from the early Middle Borlish period. The adverb ja "already, still, yet" descends directly from Latin iam "already, now" (the homonym ja "yes" is a Germanic borrowing and thus likely unrelated). The participle sceint "being there, existing" comes from the verb sceir "for there to be" used in existential sentences (scey uncos "there is something"). This descends via Old Borlish seer, sier, scer "exist, be located" from Latin sedeō "I sit".

Cay gravatoir y massem de descovan ja sceint dy siecr catorç.
/ke ˌgra.vaˈtɔir i ˈma.sɛm de ˌde.xoˈvan ʒa xint di ˈsjɛ.kr̩ kaˈtɔrts/
[ke ˌgʀa.vɐˈtɔjɐ i ˈma.sɐm de ˌde.xʊˈvan ʝa çint di ˈsjɛ.kɐ kɐˈtɔːts]
fall archive df big.cmp of folio yet there.be-p.prs of-df century 14
It's the largest collection of extant fourteenth-century folios.

148.3: 18th Lexember - ersteigon "climax"

ersteigon /ˌɛr.stiˈgɔn/ [ˌɛː.stɪˈgɔn]
- climax, the high point of a narrative or a piece of music;
- peak, apogee, zenith, acme, pinnacle, culmination, the highest point or best state of something;

l'ersteigon yembr "come to a head; reach a critical point"

Etymology: originally a term of art, borrowed from Saxon ersteigon "rise, climb, ascension", a noun from steige "climb". This properly referred to the events before the climax, but by the time of borrowing the shift in meaning had become entrenched. The term was used in more general contexts in Borlish by the mid-nineteenth century.

Y trevold de Docquerl es l'ersteigon dy commouð Futurist.
/i treˈvɔld de dɔˈkwɛrl ɛz ˌlɛr.stiˈgɔn di kɔˈmuθ ˌfi.tiˈrɪst/
[i tʀɪˈvɔld de dʊˈkwɛːl ɪz ˌlɛː.stɪˈgɔn di kʊˈmuh ˌfi.tɪˈʀɪst]
df novel of Docquerl be df=peak of-df movement Futurist
Docquerl's novel is the pinnacle of the Futurist movement. 

##

148.4: 19th Lexember - euxon "quartz"

euxon /aukˈsɔn/ [ɐukˈsɔn]
- quartz, an abundant mineral made of crystalline or amorphous silicon dioxide;
- jargon, technobabble, scientific words or concepts that do not (or appear to not) make any sense

Etymology: compare Scholastic Latin euxō "quartz" and Malchassian Greek εὔξώνας • euxṓnas "quartz", both first attested in the tweflth century. Traditionally connected to early Ancient Greek ἐΰξοος • eúxoos "well-polished" and the verb ξύω • xúō "scrape, polish", though this theory has some diachronic and semantic issues. The adjective is attested in Epic literature but no later, and moreover the root pertains very specifically to wood (being related to ξόανον xóanon "wooden image" and ξύλα • xúla "timber").

More recently it has been suggested that the word was borrowed into Latin (and then Greek) from a vernacular. Multiple early attestations have led scholars to propose that the word might have come from Borlish itself. If so, the most accepted theory is that the word is originally from attested Old English eolh-sond "amber", literally "elk-sand".

The latter sense is seen mostly in the idiom l'oc m'es euxon (literally "this is quartz to me"), used to express unfamiliarity with a technical field.

Y clocq parey l'hour con un scard d'euxon.
/i klɔk paˈri lur kɔn ɪn xard daukˈsɔn/
[i klɔk pɐˈʀi lʊː kɔn ɪŋ xɐːd dɐukˈsɔn]
df clock match df=time with indf shard of=quartz
The clock keeps time with a piece of quartz.

148.5: 20th Lexember - incommorant "immediate"

incommorant /ɪnˌkɔ.moˈrant/ [ɪŋˌkɔ.mʊˈʀant]
- immediate, instant, happening straight away;
- expeditious, speedy, acting with efficiency and rapidity;
- proactive, driven, showing initiative and acting without delay;
- punctual, prompt, timely, acting or happening on time

Etymology: Middle Borlish borrowing from Scholastic Latin incommorāns "not lingering; not delaying", a derivative of the root moror "I linger, loiter" (compare also commorar "tarry", borrowed or backformed somewhat later).

Sell'ec gest volen rebondir cos incommorant.
/ˈsɛ.lɛk ʒɛst voˈlɛn ˌre.bɔnˈdɪr kɔz ɪnˌkɔ.moˈrant/
[ˌsɛ.lɪgˈʝɛst vʊˈlɛn ˌʀe.bʊnˈdɪː kɔz ɪŋˌkɔ.mʊˈʀant]
3s.gn=p.px act will.ipf rebound-inf adv immediate
His acts would have immediate consequences.

The Fourteenth Century

collected notes on various features of the fourteenth century.

Nicolas of Avignon (Provincial Nicolà s Avignon /ni.koˈlɔ sa.viˈɲũ/, fl. 1347) was a renowned Burgund architect. He is principally remembered for leading the renovation and expansion of Saint Sophia's Cathedral in Stamboul, the capital city of the Second Roman Empire. His use of experimental techniques in supporting the central dome are alleged to have rendered the entire main body of the cathedral slightly unstable. For this reason he is sometimes jocularly referred to as the "architect of the Empire's demise", given the tragic collapse of the building during a coronation ceremony three hundred years later that killed most of the imperial family (and hundreds more) and sparked the unrest that would end the Empire for good.

The Noccair Lyceum (Borlish Lyce a Noccair /liˈtse a nɔˈker/) was established in the early 1300s in the minor town of Noccair; it was the first institute of higher learning on Borland. Like many similar European universities, it initially taught students the so-called Five Romantic Arts of literature, argument, reckoning, geometry and songcraft. By the end of the century alchemy had been introduced to the curriculum.

The Tales of Enfield Wood was a compendium of folk tales compiled in Kent in the late fourteenth century. It is usually credited to the author John of Yare, although this has been questioned. It contains many interpretations of episodes in the life of the Farmer Duke, a folk hero common to English-speaking peoples, as well as demonstrating the growing divergence between the Kentish and Merch tongues.

##

148.6: 21th Lexember - grivougl "scrawl"

grivougl /griˈvuil/ [gʀɪˈvuil]
- scrawl, scribble, chickenscratch, illegible handwriting;
- potboiler, shlock, hackwork, a written work of no artistic merit

Etymology: deverbal noun from grivoglar "scrawl, scribble, write illegibly", a borrowing via synonymous French grivouiller from Willem criblen "scratch". The second sense is attested from the early twentieth century.

Quippe porra tu noc my grivougl leir.
/kwɪˈpe pɔˈra ti nɔk mi griˈvuil lir/
[kwɪˈpe pʊˈʀa ti nɔg mi gʀɪˈvuil lɪː]
surely can-fut 2s ng 1s.gn scrawl read-inf
Of course you can't read my scrawl.

148.7: 22th Lexember - piver "livestock"

piver /piˈvɛr/ [pɪˈvɛː]
- livestock, cattle, farm animals, creatures domesticated for any type of cultivation;
- breeding, husbandry, ranching, the cultivation of domesticated animals;
- (work that is) practical, hands-on, experiential, first-hand experience as opposed to theoretical knowledge

Etymology: via Old Borlish peȝvair "livestock" from Latin pecuārius "pertaining to sheep or cattle", from pecū "domestic animals". In the last sense attested from the early modern period, especially in constructions like y piver de X "the practical skills required to do X".

L'Agathin a Ðar derra nis prestar ag stoccad cas piver.
/ˌla.gaˈθɪn a ˈðar dɛˈra nɪz prɛˈstar ɛi stɔˈkad kaz piˈvɛr/
[ˌla.gɐˈθɪn a ˈðɐː dɪˈʀa nɪz pʀɪˈstɐː‿ɛi stʊˈkad kaz pɪˈvɛː]
df=minsiter at farming must-fut effort lend-inf to.df lobby wrt livestock

149.1: 23rd Lexember - nuton "fad"

nuton /niˈtɔn/ [nɪˈtɔn]
- will-o'-the-wisp, marshlight, ignis fatuus, a pale flickering light appearing at night over swampland;
- caprice, whim, fancy, vagary, an idle impulse or idea;
- fad, fashion, craze, rage, a short-lived general public interest in something

Etymology: Middle Borlish borrowing from various French forms such as luiton, nuitin, lutin, neton, all meaning "sea monster; mischievous spirit; will-o'-the-wisp". These appear to have been influenced by luire "shine" and nuit "night"; the oldest form is netun "sea monster", which descends from Latin Neptunus "the sea god Neptune".

The second sense is seen from as early as the sixteenth century; the last only in the twentieth.

Lor sceye un nuton a tapeçment e pieðr nuaç.
/lɔr xiˈje ɪn niˈtɔn a ˌta.pɛtsˈmɛnt e ˈpjɛðr̩ njats/
[lɔː ˈçje ɪn nɪˈtɔn a ˌta.pɪsˈmɛnt e ˈpjɛ.ðɐ njats]
then there.be-ipf indf fad to tapestry and stone naked
Then there was a fad for hangings and stonework.

Marking Rubric

excerpt in translation from the censor's guide for the Dijon New School 2019 Concurrence History scitation paper Family, Tradition and Language: the Changing Culture of the Good Game Decades.

Entrou 1: Comoscon poðe Brittan sy stat de prestanç cultural sur Mendeva Brittanesc vardir durant l'eç annað final ny siecr novoç cant meðes l'oç un sovra Brittan cas pouvlanç e laboriostur, e diçr alcot sta l'oc famostað por ig y moraltað dy Renovellaçon Famigler fosn enajað vars y Novomont?
Question 1: How did Britain retain its position of cultural prestige over British Mendeva during the final years of the nineteenth century even as the latter overtook Britain in population and industry, and to what extent were the ethics of the Household Renovation exported to the Novomund via this cachet?

- cas y primer, carað svoccanç de tramigraçon monfeyað dy vige novel tras l'Atlantic e de frequenç de mariðaç combinant entrig.
- for the first, look for talk of increased transmigration of the new rich across the Atlantic and rates of intermarriage thereamongst.

- ancour, præmieð soumoin vars y scanjon dy spaiðoir Vetomondin a masquira e vars y façon yon i destarrisceu y costumn autochthon de kiveury (cos particuler carað referiscenç ag chronic de Hasiny par Coswteg).
- further, reward mention of the boom of the Vetomundine masquira genre and how it displaced the autochthonous herdtale tradition (specifically look for reference to Coswteg's Hasiny diaries).

- cas y dovem, jayað soumoin for vars respos caglou irrayant sur y disputaçon irresoluð cas y defas d'adopçon Laic ne Mendeva Bugter; stou discorrir cas dou scrittour ag mendrem.
- for the second, only give credit to responses highlighting the ongoing debate as to the timeline of Laic adoption in Gulf Mendeva; at least two disagreeing authors must be mentioned.

149.2: 24th Lexember - revottaç "tantrum"

revottaç /ˌre.vɔˈtats/ [ˌʀe.vʊˈtats]
- tantrum, fit, outburst, pique, apoplexy, a contemptible display of bad temper;
- scene, disruption, embarrassment, the result of somebody having a tantrum

Etymology: pejorative derivation from revot "annoyance, irritation". This is an alteration of earlier raivot, diminutive of now-obsolete raif "rage", which descends from Late Latin rabia "rage" (the usual modern word is voudy, a borrowing). The word is considered impolite as a description of an adult's behaviour.

J'oye un revottaç allors nell'oc varosset.

1s=hear-ipf indf tantrum elsewhere in-df=s.px shop
I heard a tantrum elsewhere in the shop.

149.3: 25th Lexember - errevour "saviour"

errevour /ˌɛ.reˈvur/ [ˌɛ.ʀɪˈvʊː]
- saviour, rescuer, deliverer, person who prevents danger or harm befalling another;
- the Redeemer, the figure of Jesus Christ in his role as deliverer from sin;
- (attributive, of meat) stuffed with a particular combination of breadcrumbs, wine, herbs and chestnuts

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish erevor "saviour", agentive derivation of erevre, erever "save" (which gives modern errevir "rescue"). This comes from Latin ēripiō "I set free; I remove", related to rapiō "I grab, seize". The term has been applied to Christ along with similar sauvour, reðentor "saviour" since the tenth century. In the last sense referring to a preparation of meat now often served around Christmas on Borland (although historically it, minus the chestnuts, was usually eaten on Easter Sunday).

Gehennant ig nos ayau porc errevour tost y dou por y fest.
/ˌʒe.hɛˈnant ai nɔz eˈjo pɔrk ˌɛ.reˈvur tɔst i du pɔr i fɛst/
[ˌʒe.hɪˈnant ai nʊˈzjo pɔːk ˌɛ.ʀɪˈvʊː tɔst i du pɔː‿ʀi fɛst]
embarrass-p.prs cmp 1p have-ipf.1p pork redeemer roast.p.pst df two for df feast
Embrassingly we'd both made pork redeemer for the feast.

149.4: 26th Lexember - scop "idea"

scop /xɔp/ [xɔp]
- aim, end, purpose, point, goal, what something is intended to achieve;
- crux, heart, gist, essence, thrust, pith, the central idea of a longer or more complicated matter;
- idea, conceit, a summary of the novel part of a piece of fiction

Etymology: Middle Borlish borrowing from Tuscan scopo "purpose, point", which descends from Latin scopus "target". This was borrowed from σκοπός • skopós "watcher; target" in Ancient Greek. The second sense is attested from the seventeenth century; the last only in literary criticism of the twentieth.

Jo poðe noc me quottar ag scop dy trevold parachthon.
/ʒo poˈðe nɔk me kwɔˈtar ɛi xɔp di treˈvɔld ˌpa.rakˈθɔn/

1s can-ipf ng 1s.obl fit-inf to.df aim of-df novel sci-fi
I couldn't get on board with the sci-fi novel's conceit.

149.5: 27th Lexember - demastr "judgemental"

demastr /deˈmastr̩/ [dɪˈma.stɐ]
- judgemental, moralising, opinionated, critical, quick to form (especially negative) opinions of things or people;
- overstepping, butting in, inserting one's opinions when they aren't welcome;
- hypocritical, holier-than-thou, snobby, sanctimonious, having an inflated sense of one's own moral high ground

Etymology: derivation from demar "to opine, to express an opinion" with -astr, a pejorative suffix. The verb was borrowed in the tenth century from Old English dēman "judge, decide". First attested in the eighteenth century as the name of a character in one of Tamottan's satirical dramas.

I reconnosc ou sy fraðr sey tan demastr?
/i ˌre.kɔˈnɔx u si fraðr̩ si tan deˈmastr̩/
[i ˌʀe.kʊˈnɔx u si ˈfʀa.ðɐ si tan dɪˈma.stɐ]
3s recognise q 3s.gn brother be.sbj so judgemental
Does he know his brother is so judgemental?

Revisionist History

excerpted from The Realignment of Borlish Inflection and Derivation, an article in the Winter 1909 issue of Theoretical Uncoverings in the History of Languages. This is a venerable scientific journal published at that time through the University of Lester [Leicester].

…undeniable that the modern form -aurn of the first conjugation's third-person plural preterite, as well as its ancestor in Old Borlish -avren /-ˈau.rən/, would descend regularly from the Latin *pluperfect* -āvĕrant and is less straightforward a reflex of the Latin perfect -āvērunt (from which we would naïvely expect modern Borlish -eirn). Nevertheless, the attestation, though rare, of syncopated perfect -ārunt (from which Vascon -aron, among many others) offers a plausible direct ancestor. This is especially tempting if we are permitted to assume influence from the other persons of the Borlish preterite, all of which employ an -au- theme.

We turn to perhaps the most contentious claim of this article. The fate of the Latin occupational suffix -ātor in Borlish has been a perennial puzzle since Bughter noted that modern Borlish -our cannot be its simple reflex. It was possible to suspect that an early -aðour or -dour was reduced, but absolutely no evidence of such forms has emerged from any medieval manuscript (the word saðour "farmer" is not a counterexample, as the connection of Latin sator to the verb serō "I sow" was opaque). This further precludes the possibility of mere analogy from third-conjugation verbs (Old Borlish corsor "runner" < Latin cursor), which would have taken time to spread to the much more numerous first-conjugation verbs.

One might also attempt to claim the Borlish suffix is a borrowing from one of the French languages, most of which lost -t- entirely between vowels (e.g. Old French chant(e)or "singer" < cantatorem). We do not deny that such forms reinforced -or in Old Borlish, but the suffix is manifestly native, appearing productively as early as the eighth-century Halvuy chronicle. Our new proposal begins from a few aberrant words in modern dialects and extends back to the first decades of Roman Borland.

Now restricted to northern dialects, the term orrel "penis" is…

149.6: 28th Lexember - sontiçtað "linchpin"

sontiçtað /ˌsɔn.tɪtsˈtaθ/ [ˌsɔn.tɪˈstah]
- criticality, necessity, exigency, requirement, the state of needing something (especially when there are significant negative consequences for lacking it);
- linchpin, mainstay, backbone, keystone, sine qua non, a person or thing that is critical to a system working or even existing`

Etymology: borrowed from Scholastic Latin sonticitās "urgency, exigency" or a derivation within Middle Borlish from sontic "urgent, critical" < Latin sonticus "dangerous, serious". The word has been used to refer to a necessary thing or person since the eighteenth century.

Desmettað noc y sontiçtað de nossell'entrpris!
/ˌdɛ.zmɛˈtaθ nɔk i ˌsɔn.tɪtsˈtaθ de ˌnɔ.sɛˌlɛntr̩ˈprɪz/

fire-imp.2p ng df necessity of 1p.gn-df=business
Don't fire the backbone of our company!

149.7: 29th Lexember - taur aïr "look forward"

taur aïr /tor ɛˈjir/ [toː‿ʀɪˈʝɪː]
- look forward, anticipate, to await with eagerness;
- be eager, be excited, to feel enthusiasm;
- be raring, be antsy, to feel impatience;
- (colloquial, dated) be horny, to feel arousal

Etymology: literally "to have bull", idiom attested (in the slightly different sense of impulsiveness) from the sixteenth century. The noun taur was altered from early Middle Borlish tor to be closer to Latin taurus "bull, steer". The last sense is attested sporadically from the late nineteenth century and reached its peak popularity in the mid-twentieth.

Nos orruðe casc y gent ausn taur a ençar destr.
/nɔz ˌɔ.riˈðe kax i ʒɛnt ozn̩ tor a ɛnˈtsar dɛstr̩/

1p seem-ipf each df person have.sbj.ipf-3p bull to start-inf out
It looked like everyone was eager to get going.

150.1: 30th Lexember - sdegn "scorn"

sdegn /zdijn/ [zdɪjn]
- scorn, contempt, disdain, displaying one's feelings that something is inferior or vulgar;
- flak, criticism, bad press, censure, disparaging remarks made towards someone or something

Etymology: deverbal noun from sdegnar "scorn, malign", a derivative of archaic degnar "deign, condescend, begrudge", which comes from Latin dignō "I deem worthy". The word nowadays often connotes that the criticism is undeserved (compare the phrase sdegn accarr "to be wrongly criticised").

A sy lasc novel scey un tombr a sdegn.
/a si lax noˈvɛl xi ɪn tɔmbr̩ a zdijn/

at 3s.gn film new there.be indf heap at scorn
Her new film's garnered lots of criticism.

Death in the Spires

excerpt in translation from the beginning of (IRL) historical mystery Death in the Spires, by KJ Charles.

Jem gasau all'eç parol.
Jem stared at the words.

Lou remane tars eð accusant, hetrous demay sur y lettr tachygraphað lou intermanent, ben y papiraç frail lou portant.
They sat stark and accusatory, too brutal for the typewritten letters that made them, or the thin cheap paper that bore them.

L'encost sta lessy naðusc, com ða y rimband dy tachygraph aye pres s'usað.
The ink was a little faded, as though the typewriter’s ribbon was almost worn out.

No sceye alcun dat, alcun asmuth, alcun souscreut, nien for tre lign de scrit.
There was no date, no address, no signature, nothing but three lines of text.

Jeremy Kite es un mordrer. L'occeu Toby Feynsham. Roveð lour y raçon.
Jeremy Kite is a murderer. He killed Toby Feynsham. Ask him why.

Jem fey y papir reuvr, com ou se poð ec may trovar dereðr.
Jem turned the paper over, as if there might be more on the back.

L'oç broyeu pog, y tremanç de sy man desconent.
It rattled slightly, betraying the tremor of his hands.

I le refey reuvr alcheðr por y parol enverimmað mostrar, e leyau gas vars Sr Leighton, oç asseyent oppos all'acraç gaubanneresc de tablaur, le spiant a min malvolent.
He turned it back again to the poisonous words, and looked up at Mr Leighton, who sat across the mahogany acreage of desk, regarding him with disfavour.

150.2: 31st Lexember - scaur ag mur ne Pompeï "write one's name in the history books"

scaur ag mur ne Pompeï /xor ɛi mɪr ne ˌpɔm.piˈji/ [xoː‿ʀɛi mɪː ne ˌpɔm.pɪˈʝi]
- write one's name in the history books, make a name for oneself, to do things which will cause one to be renowned for a long time;
- act with posterity in mind, to be conscious of one's legacy when deciding one's actions;
- (jocular) make last-minute revisions, to make rushed changes due to having little time left before a deadline

Etymology: literally "to write on the walls of Pompeii", first attested as an idiom in Napolitan some years after the unearthing of the ruins of Pompeii and the uncovering of its trove of graffiti. The verb scaur "write", which displaced now-obsolete or poetic scrir "write", descends from Latin scalpō "I scratch; I engrave". The last sense, attested in Borlish since the 1920s, refers directly to the volcanic eruption of 79N which buried the city.

L'oç segr es dignt tojorn i vil scaur ag mur ne Pompeï.
/lɔts ˈsijr̩ ɛz daint toˈʒɔrn i vɪl xor ɛi mɪr ne ˌpɔm.piˈji/
[lɔs ˈsɪ.jɐ‿ʀɪz daint tʊˈʝɔːn i vɪl xoː‿ʀeɪ mɪː ne ˌpɔm.pɪˈʝi]
df=s.dt man be say-p.prs always 3s will write-inf at.df wall in Pompeii
That guy's always saying he'll make a name for himself.

150.3: bucol "idyll"

bucol /biˈkɔl/ [bɪˈkɔl]
- idyll, haven, paradise, solace, oasis, a peaceful location or circumstance especially in the countryside;
- respite, break, relief, lull, a (usually temporary) decrease in stress or difficulty;
- reverie, daydream, idle and pleasant thoughts

Etymology: Middle Borlish, a backformation from earlier adjective bucolic "idyllic, peaceful", a borrowing from Latin bucolicus "pastoral, rustic". The word had broadened from the first senses by the late eighteenth century, and has been used for purely mental peace since the early twentieth.

Jo kiglau l'oç seyon rovað dec j'er bucol hamtant.
/ʒo kaiˈlo lɔts siˈjɔn roˈvaθ dɛk ʒɛr biˈkɔl hamˈtant/
[ʝo kɐiˈlo lɔts ˈsjɔn ʀʊˈvah dɛk ʝɛː bɪˈkɔl hɐmˈtant]
1s miss-pst df=s.dt 3s.agt ask-p.pst because 1s=cop.ipf idyll dwell-p.prs
I missed what he asked because I was daydreaming.

150.4: coyol "cone"

coyol /kɔˈjɔl/ [kʊˈʝɔl]
- (geometry) cone, the surface formed by rotating a deflected line segment around its end (or the solid thus circumscribed);
- anything conical;
- spire, point, a tapering structure built to cap a roof or tower;
- acme, zenith, peak, cap, summit, the best or highest-quality type of something;
- cap, coif, bonnet, a piece of headgear covering the top and sides of the head

Etymology: via Old Borlish coȝol "hood; cone" from Latin cucūlla "hood, cowl; conical wrapper or case". Used consistently to translate Scholastic Latin cōnus "cone" in geometrical texts since the fourteenth century (possibly the unrelated con "with" discouraged directly borrowing that Latin). In the modern language restricted to detached headgear that is at least vaguely conical.

Y coyol dy cligs es coup de fourraç mout cavent.
/i koˈjɔl di klaiz ɛz kup de fuˈrats mut kaˈvɛnt/
[i kʊˈʝɔl di klaiz ɪz kup de fʊˈʀas mut kɐˈvɛnt]
df cone of-df church be hit of lightning often get-p.prs
The church's spire often gets struck by lightning.

150.5: H is for History

collected notes on three features of the Boralverse alternate history that begin with the letter H.

Hasinic Welsh (Cambroec Hasinia /kəmˈbreːk həˈziː.njə/) is one of the primary languages of Hasiny [~S Mississippi River], along with the Mendevan language of Jaughta [~Choctaw]. It is mutually intelligible with other varieties of Welsh, although its orthography uses a different standard to British or Chrysian [Australian] Welsh. A few English words come via this language, like herdtale (a calque of jadełath "herd-dom") and sobot "radio" (originating in Jaughta çobota "message").

Hatfell Honours (Merch /ˈhat.fəl ˈɔ.nəz/) refer to several prizes awarded since the early twentieth century to artists in various fields across the Drengot Collusion (and, after that alliance-federacy collapsed in 1961, across all of Gaul and the Northwestern Isles [Ireland, GB, Borland]). The Honours in literature and drama are among the original set of prizes, while new arts have been admitted as recently as the 2010s. The Honours are named for Hatfell [Hatfield, Hertfordshire], a northern town in London near the border with Markland which was home to a collective of renowned authors in the nineteenth century. In 1918, the writer Dorotha Quistack won a Hatfell Honour for one of her adolescences [coming-of-age novels].

Hostilian (in Borlish often Stiglan /staiˈlan/, latinised as Hostīliānus) was a Borlish monk in the ninth century, often considered the father of Borlish history. His most famous work Historiæ Terrarum Boralensium "Histories of the Borlish Lands" is a semi-mythic account of Borland for the past five centuries since the arrival of Germanic peoples on the island. It includes a continuous list of rulers from Prase Victor Rossetus, several of which are not attested in any other source. This has led some historiographers to conclude that Hostilian was commissioned by the contemporary monarchy to legitimise their rule.

##

151.1: The Odyssey

excerpt in translation from the beginning of the Odyssey, as translated into prose Borlish from the original Epic Greek by Rosctey Villautin in 1910. The translation has been criticised for hewing too closely to the Greek syntax at the expense of sounding natural in Borlish.

D'un segr racont mey, Mus, mout tornant, oc magn lað
Of a man tell me, Muse, often turning, who very widely

sgarant, posc y citað sagntað a Troy i devastau;
wandered, after the holy city of Troy he sacked;

dy larc hom seyon vis, dy ment den seyon connuð
of the many people he saw, whose minds he knew

e dy larc cos sur mar seyon souvað e caut ny cour,
and of the many things at sea he endured and took to heart,

gimmolent kireðam a sy við eð ag repaðr de sy commilton.
striving wholeheartedly for his life and his comrades' homecoming.

Ma noc cossy sceus i sy commilton errevir, meðes auvorn oblimant;
But not like this could he save his comrades, even longing to so much;

lou desig lorry fol temertað il perisceurn;
they, for their foolish recklessness, perished;

borel, eç des y kiveu dy sol Hyperion
fools, who from the herd of the sun Hyperion

ayent repasc fait e lor i lou effurau deur y jorn de repaðr.
dined, and so he deprived them of the day of homecoming.

151.2: nienter "void"

nienter /njɛnˈtɛr/ [njɪnˈtɛː]
- (rare) void, empty, vacant, not filled or occupied;
- useless, ineffective, futile, vain, not producing any effect;
- invalid, worthless, without legal force or other analogous use;
- nihilist, pessimistic, holding that things do not have any point or purpose

Etymology: adjective derivation from nien "nothing" (earlier nient), which reflects either nē gentem "no person" or nē entem "no being" in Late Latin. Even in early texts the word has seldom been used literally (competing with vogt "empty"); senses to the effect of "amounting to nothing" predominate.

L'arra oç saut ig caye sy mariðaç dovem nienter.
/laˈra ɔts sot ai kɛˈje si ˌma.riˈðats ˈdo.vɛm njɛnˈtɛr/

He must have known his second marriage was void.

151.3: scanjon "climb"

scanjon /xanˈʒɔn/ [xɐnˈʝɔn]
- rise, ascent, climb, an increase in elevation;
- upgrade, uplift, overhaul, improvement, the replacement or betterment of something to have new or renewed features;
- boom, bonanza, a period of wealth or prestige

Etymology: noun from scandr "rise, climb" or directly from Latin scansiō "a climbing", from Latin scandō "I climb". The word is attested in metaphorical uses from the sixteenth century, and in its specifically economic sense it is seen from the nineteenth century.

151.4: borel "idiot"

borel /boˈrɛl/ [bʊˈʀɛl]
- idiot, fool, numpty, nincompoop, numbskull, dunderhead, a person lacking intelligence or common sense;
- sap, patsy, rube, chump, schmuck, a person who is notably naïve and easy to dupe;
- yokel, bumpkin, rustic, an unsophisticated person from a rural area

Etymology: disputed. The word is seen from the early Middle Borlish period with indeterminate meaning. Possibly a diminutive from an unattested *bour "peasant", which would have been borrowed from Old English (ġe)būr "farmer". Otherwise, perhaps a direct descendant from Latin puerīlis "youthful; childish". However, both explanations require somewhat irregular sound changes.

L'agathin le nommau de borel a phasm prose.
/ˌla.gaˈθɪn le nɔˈmo de boˈrɛl a ˈfazm̩ proˈze/

df=minister 3s.acc name-pst of idiot at TV live
The minister called her an idiot on live TV.

##

151.5: War and Peace

Mystra (in full the Principality of Mystra; Greek: Δεσποτᾶτον τοῦ Μυστρᾶ) was a mordether [crusader] state founded in the eleventh century in the Peloponnese. The holy order of soldiers known as the Convoy Australier was instrumental in conquering the peninsula as a staging post for further attempts at conquest in the Masreck [Levant]. It was named for its then-capital, the city of Mystras. Originally independent, the polity was after some decades reincorporated into the resurgent Roman Empire, and the capital eventually moved to Mysarnos [Pylos]. Mystra was formally dissolved in the mid-seventeenth century as a result of the Romantic Wars.

New Leudong (Welsh: Leudong Newð /ˌlyːˈdɔŋ ˈnawð/) is a polity covering the southeast portion of Chrysia [Australia]. Named for the Cathayan state of Leudong, it has experienced significant Cathayan nation-building alongside British settlement since the late seventeenth century. In the early eighteenth century the trade network of Gurjat [Gujarat] extended as far as New Leudong. Born in New Leudong, mixed-heritage writer Pether Hetsong penned semi-autobiographical work The Land of Golden Lies and Sugared Fire in 1864, often considered the first Chrysian work of literature to enjoy Vetomundine [Eurasian] success. New Leudong was an early adopter of the new social mores of the Household Renovation in the late nineteenth century. A collaboration involving the Branwen Sanatory in New Leudong's capital invented the chemical painkiller cozebdo-diamaschal benjamine [ibuprofen]. In the late twentieth century the New Leudong city of Mehannin [Brisbane] became a technological hub, spurring developments in grimmer [computer] design and methodics [programming].

152.1: Apprenticeship

excerpt in translation from Guillotine Hadjatoux's 2001 trevold Tyrocinie "Apprenticeship", her first in a series of deconstructionist tales alluding to tropes in parachthon [specfic] fiction from unexpected points of view.

Y figl de casc gent reuloirn des y campagn autrað. Il stan veilessem, cos primer.
Everyone's children came back from the country changed. They were older, for a start.

Certan entr lou stan çoucherrem, e certan mancan ustolment—certan stan metamorphosað vars joun dy campagn lon alcun residu de Paris entarn, parfait con y vernacr.
Some of them were wilder, and some had no manners—some had transmogrified into country children with not a trace of Paris in them, complete with accent.

Toð y mont souprenent y jammel Tovat stan reuluð fort ustolent ant un zeltað a gimmoldr, ig degnant il stan paravant eç picq beuscr.
To everyone's surprise the Tovat twins had come back well-behaved with a strong work ethic, despite the little louts they had been.

Y joun Pinze, interim, reuluð stragn. Caye noc un autranç vecinabr cos fagl.
The Pinzé children, though, came back odd. It wasn't something readily identifiable.

Il ayen cortiseç eð ovranç aðief por surcrescr de coðelostað, ma tojorn il pariscen gasar vars nuton mental par ogl ayent ancour may vis meðes all'eç dy soldart excavað. 
They were polite and tactful to the point of overcaution, but they always seemed to look into the middle distance with eyes that had seen even more than the hollowed-out soldiers.

152.2: præmiar "reward"

Etymology: borrowed from Scholastic Latin præmiō "I reward, honour", a verbal derivative from præmium "profit, prize, bribe". Though the verb was once poetically used with the person rewarded as the direct object, now only the honourable act itself may take that position.

152.5: False Friends

a complete arbitrary selection of dictionary entries from the Concise Onomatory o'Merch (fifth edition), a reference work published in 1961 and compiled by the Utcheter Lexical Association.

carjack [/ˈkaː.dʒak/ "breakup"] n. the ending of a romance, especially if unexpected or one-sided; v. intr. of a romance, to end; v. tr. to end a romance with (someone). The term once referred specifically to a letter informing one's partner of the end of your romance. Early 20C < Borlish soldiers' slang carjacq, car-Jacq meaning "dear John". During the Millstone Wars, this referred to a dreaded letter from one's beloved back home cancelling promises of marriage after the war.

danny [/ˈda.ni/ "nuisance"] n. an annoying person or thing, especially when obstructing what one wants to achieve; adj. annoying or obstructive. 10C Old English danneġ "stinging nettle" < Old Borlish danney, nanney (æq.), thought to reflect a Borland Kelt ?naindia "nettles" (cf Irish ńandóc).

eager [/ˈeː.gə/ "acid"] n. a sour or corrosive substance, (in alchemy) a substance which gives up mora [protons] in aqua or directly to another substance; adj. sour or corrosive, (in alchemy) giving up mora in aqua or directly to another substance, (by extension) unlikable or spiteful. Early Merch eagre "sour" < Middle French aigre (æq.) This descends from colloquial Latin ācrus "sour, bitter", variant of ācer in Classical Latin.

marksman [/ˈmaːks.mən/ "marquess"] n. the noble ruler of (originally) a borderland region known as a mark [march], traditionally ranking above earls due to the prestige of defending the realm's borders. 13C Early Merch < compound of Old English mearc "boundary" and mann "person" used to translate Old French marchis "marquess" in reference to the Marksman of Jerusalem. The term is primarily used for titleholders overseas; within Albion (possibly due to collision with "Markland") predominates the synonymous term edgelord.

153.4: saget "arrowhead"

saget /saˈʒɛt/ [sɐˈʝɛt]
- arrowhead, the pointed part of an arrow or similar projectile;
- arrow, the pictorial representation of an arrow used to indicate direction;
- chevron, vee, a V shape;

153.5: Maritime Cards

excerpt from Crossing the Rubicon: a Hidden History of Games, a 1982 work of popular history written (originally in Borlish as Y Rubicon Trasir: un Stoir Scos de Joy) by writer and stage performer Jonnovar Meyaunot. She became famous later in life as a humourist and sobot [radio] host of documentaries and quiz games.

…more common across the Northwestern Isles [Ireland, Britain, Borland], as well as Denmark and Willemy [~Lotharingia]; however, this particular style of deck actually originates in fifteenth-century Poland. The Maritime deck comprises fifty cards organised into five ensigns [suits] and three colours: these are gold, bucklers, staves, jewels and arrows (depicted below).

Many of the cards furthermore have conventional titles separate to their rank and ensign—for example, the deuce of staves is called the Duel, while the sept of jewels is known as the Stars. Over time the artwork on these cards has come to incorporate these thematic elements. In games where some cards trump the rest, the gold ensign typically takes this role, although some more modern games will use the aforementioned "named" cards in this way.

The use of a Maritime deck for divination mirrors many other sources of randomness, although the modern occult practices only date back to the early nineteenth century. They appear to have been popularised by Promethean clubs associated with the Deviance movement, and specifically the storied Winchester group.

Early records of the specific rules of card games using the Maritime deck are unfortunately thin on the ground. The first real description of a particular game appears in 1555 court records regarding the gambling debts of one Marc Levosclin…

##

154.5: Northumber

Northumber (Borlish Norðumbr /nɔːˈðɪm.br̩/) is a polity on the east coast of Albion which borders Markland, Dunclothe and Scotland. Its largest cities are Yorwick (the capital) and Edinbrough.

History

Originally a pair of English kingdoms settled through the fifth and sixth centuries, Northumber was invaded and conquered from the late ninth century onwards by forces from Denmark and Horther. The city of Yorwick is even alleged to have practically given itself over to Dane rule, deposing the alderman and hoping to offer enough loot freely to the invaders so as to avoid the total destruction of the city.

Relations with neighbouring Markland were fraught until the tenth-century Elved Marriage between a Merch princess and the king of Northumber, which ended direct hostilities for nearly a century. Wars continued however with its other neighbours; for example, Northumber captured the city of Edinbrough (then called Eidin) from Dunclothe in 928, taking the last vestiges of Dunclothe's eastern coast.

By the end of the tenth century the territory of Northumber was united under Dane rule from Yorwick. With the waning of the Dane Supremacy the ability of Horther to project its rule overseas collapse; in Albion, Northumber became first among equals in a confederation of the local Dane kingdoms, including Dunclothe, Sodrick and Dublin. At this point Yorwick was by some way the richest city in Albion.

In the eleventh and twelfth centuries, Northumber became the northernmost vassal of the First Drengot Empire, which ruled over much of Albion and most of Gaul.

People

Wolfstan II (fl. c9), last English monarch of Northumber before it fell to Dane forces.

155.1: Wings Afire

notes in translation on the opera Wings Afire (Ale in Fiamme).

Al Igne es un melodram compos par y Venijan Chiarina Bruno e preu parformað nell'Arena de Verona d'an 1824.
Wings Afire is an opera written by Venisian Chiarina Bruno and first performed in the Verona Arena in 1824.

Caye l'ouvr primer scenað nell'Arena de Verona posc i dene closið con y sounç dy Var Theudesc Dovem.
It was the first work staged in the Verona Arena since it was shuttered at the outbreak of the Second German War.

Y melodram es un renarranç dy legend d'Icar oc loy fignt cos enter apres dy cainç ny mythos, ant soumoin jait vars Icar mort ny collocq.
The opera is a retelling of the legend of Icarus which takes place entirely after the events of the myth, with references to the dead Icarus in the dialogue.

Entarn scey y matron d'un vessonman acconnosc ayent a Dædal gemiscent; i l'aïð a y gavisc d'orðenjar redescovrir.
It follows the matron of a clothiery who meets a grieving Daedalus; she helps him to rediscover the joy of invention.

Y music dy melodram es abrangent dy melody mogn e dolorous dy viol cemtir des cont a pouvr Borallesc; rumorað es ig Bruno au parol oïð den de sy fraðr Jacomo.
The opera's music features the low-pitched mournful melodies of the graveyard fiddlers from Borlish folklore; Bruno is said to have heard of them from her brother Jacomo.

maugr /ˈmojr̩/ [ˈmo.ʝɐ]

- edge, border, flank, brink, the area near the edge of anything;

155.3: hivocin "armadillo"

hivocin /ˌhi.voˈtsɪn/ [ˌhi.vʊˈtsɪn]
- armadillo, any of several burrowing mammals covered with bony protective plates;
- (colloquial) recluse, loner, hermit, wallflower, shrinking violet, a shy or retiring person whom it is hard to get to know

Etymology: from Vascon hivocin or Scholastic Latin hivocīnus, each having come via Morrove Arabic from a Mayattan language, plausibly Gish 'ibach "armadillo".
