155.4: marrenquon "nightmare"

marrenquon /ˌma.rɛnˈkwɔn/ [ˌma.ʀɪŋˈkwɔn]
- nightmare, bad dream, an unpleasant or frightening experience during sleep;
- incubus, a malevolent supernatural entity thought to cause nightmares;

Etymology: pleonastic compound of Old Borlish marr and enquon, both meaning "nightmare". The extension of this word to other malevolent demonic figures is seen from the sixteenth century.

I didn't have any nightmares for a while.

155.5: Everywhere and Everything

excerpt from popular work of nonfiction Everywhere and Everything: the Third Millenium, published in April 2000 (originally in Leon as Jallondes y Jallisca: la Terça Milada) by Justino Silvera at the request of his publishers. The book purports to contain two thousand pieces of unusual or obscure trivia about the world; while most are accurate, the rushed research process led to several inaccuracies and a few flat-out lies finding their way into the book.

…threshold force mill [nuclear power plant] in the Groin [A Coruña].

Due to the region's janual religious history, the archbishop of Waduz [Vaduz, Liechtenstein] (which in laic terms is a minor city in Bavarn) is the only Christian official who can vote as a cardinal in the conclaves for electing both the Augsburgher and the Roman Popes. Fortunately, conclaves have never been called simultaneously for both Popes—nobody knows how the archbishop of Waduz would attend both conclaves in such a situation.

The tabre unit of heft, equal to one hundred (dime) ounces [~2.7kg, ~6lb] and first introduced in its modern form with the rest of the dime system in the 1820s, is named after Tabres' batman (Persian man tabréz), the principal commercial weight used in the Persian city of Tabres [Tabriz] and its surrounds. It is related to traditional units used across the Vetomund from Kiew [Kyiv] to Madray [Madurai], which vary widely from one-half a tabre to over thirty tabres.

The Draconic Age is now generally agreed to have ended abruptly sixty-six hundred myriad years ago, when a cisjovial sax [asteroid within the orbit of Jupiter] over three leagues across…

156.1: A Parody of Literature

    excerpt in translation from the 1990 short story The Littlest Things We Know to be Small (originally in Vascon as Los Mens que Sems come Pochins) by Anna Rocamora. It parodied the overelaborate, overspecific style that had become popular in the regional highbrow literary scene in recent years and almost singlehandedly changed publishing trends overnight.

Mell'inquillin e mey entrquïsceurn a plaç meg dy torn ag droccon por aug libar e gostaçon pascr des y plat a lox.
My roommate and I paused mid-lap on the driveway to sip water and nibble from the tray of pizza slices.

Caye l'yeul un marrenquon harif eð affrous de ciscr, hurlanç e slenget occajonal entr groun abrevað.
The street was a weird, scary nightmare of squeals, shrieks and occasional snogs between tipsy teens.

Un camil vabian closnautr passau clacquant. Un connart magrastr quidam craccau un mot all'orlaç groinant, senglottaç e glouç indugnt de sbayour.
A battered jeep rattled by. Some scrawny bastard spat a wad onto the kerb with a grunt, prompting whines and giggles from bystanders.

Pieç pas ados, un frot flasq a cedar sonau cant lamp a xanthal cardaurn y teneur.
A few footsteps behind, a pathetic guitar strum sounded as neon lights teased the darkness.

Jo senteu un stig leger ag ventr. "Or bon, tenau a traiscnar," murmurau mell'amig cos ouveg, cur tornant deur y stril gapiscent de fren.
I felt a slight pang in my gut. "Alright, let’s shuffle on," my friend mumbled with a pout, ignoring the intermittent squeals of brakes.

N'oc hour surrun, jo vole eir por y salonnour nell'avoccoir destarrir e por l'entrou pondr dell'oç diabr de rumour cas cahut.
Sometime soon, I’d go to relieve the receptionist at the rec centre and inquire about that damned dorm rumour.

156.2: pengovin "pangolin"

pengovin /ˌpɛn.goˈvɪn/ [ˌpɛŋ.gʊˈvɪn]
- pangolin, any of several species of long-tailed and scaly mammals found in tropical Africa and Asia;
- a particular gambling card game, not dissimilar to bezique or pinochle, which originated in Bengal and became popular internationally during the nineteenth century

Etymology: borrowed into European languages (compare Merch penguin /pɪŋˈgjəwɪn/) in the seventeenth century from Bāsan [Malay] penguwing "pangolin", literally meaning "one who rolls". In the second sense, the word is a calque from Bengal bonoro "pangolin; bezique", apparently named for a deck which featured art of a pangolin on some of the cards.

I've never lost like that at pinochle.

156.3: vajot "perk"

vajot /vaˈʒɔt/ [vɐˈʝɔt]
- benefit, advantage, something in one's circumstances that is helpful;
- perk, bonus, any incidental benefit that one receives;
- (archaic) wage, profit, salary, money or other compensation received for work

Etymology: originally in the last senses, from a diminutive of Old Borlish uai "legal contract; salary, wage", from synonymous wadium in Medieval Latin (compare gage in Old French). This comes from Frankish wadi "stake, pledge", which is related to English "wedding". The word was displaced in its original sense by parsou "wage, rate; worth, value".

Y masctig trovar sta un vajot imprefait.
/i maxˈtai troˈvar sta ɪn vaˈʒɔt ˌɪm.preˈfet/
[i mɐxˈtai tʀʊˈvɐː sta ɪn vɐˈʝɔt ˌɪm.pʀɪˈfet]

156.4: droccon "driveway"

droccon /drɔˈkɔn/ [dʀʊˈkɔn]
- lay-by, an indentation in the side of a road for vehicles to stop in;
- parking space, berth, an area where a vehicle is intended to be left;
- driveway, a private area at the front of a dwelling where one might keep one's vehicles

Etymology: twentieth century, a noun formation from verb droccar "notch, indent" calqued from dentelon "lay-by" in Parisian French. The verb comes from droc "notch, indentation", which is of obscure origin. Putative connections with English trough or Welsh rhych "furrow" have too many issues to be workable, and nobody credits a link with draucus "strongman" in Latin; perhaps the word (which is first attested in the Old Borlish period) is simply onomatopoeia.

Cayen deg minut pre un vec alandau ny droccon.
/keˈjɛn dij miˈnɪt pre ɪn vɛk ˌa.lanˈdo ni drɔˈkɔn/
[kɪˈʝɛn di mɪˈnɪt pre ɪɱ vɛk ˌa.lɐnˈdo ni dʀʊˈkɔn]
fall-ipf-3p ten minute before indf bus arrive-pst in-df lay.by
It was ten minutes before a bus pulled into the lay-by.

##

156.5: Through the Ages

collected notes on a variety of background figures in Boralverse history, listed in chronological order.

Franco Cicala was the console of the maritime republic Jeans [Genoa] from 1119 until either 1122 or 1124 (records differ). The console being an elected position voted on by the local nobility, Franco would be followed intermittently by over a dozen consoli from among his descendants.

Andrew II was a martial-minded king of Markland in the early fourteenth century. He succeeded his uncle, who is remembered as being far more diplomatic. Andrew II oversaw the Sack of Rexam in 1301, an act which reignited the on-again off-again conflict between Markland and Wales known as the Mallor Wars. The original medieval building at St Brigid's Abbey was razed during this offensive.

Dewock Barclythe (1452-1539 N) was the Friar of Tremonnow and for several decades the prime Factor of Records at the Brethin House there. Records of his correspondence with clergy and academics across western Europe have survived to the present day. These include some of the earliest attestations of dart [vector] geometry, and thus the beginnings of the unification of geometry and computation.

Lord Simon, the sixth Baron Monçating (b. 1770) was an intellectual, a notorious libertine of the Damvath melee, and an early proponent of Deviance Theology in Borland. He was of Warnine [Guaraní] descent through his mother. His family had been notorious for decades due to a protracted legal battle between his father and second cousin over the Barony of Haubrath. By the age of eighteen Simon could speak Latin, Dutch (and according to his defamers, Warnine), and he could play the clavier and the torriot [a bassoon-like wind instrument].

Marcio Dourao was an author and rabblerouser best remembered for his work Galatheus, or the Knowledge of Good and Evil. This collection of short stories pastiching Greek mythology was written in 1930 during the decade-long Portingale Anarchy. The title references the story of Galatea and Pygmalion. Galatheus was banned in neighbouring Vascony and Morrack for its background politics and, unofficially, for its throughline of gender exploration; neither polity had quite forgotten their roles in the traditionally-minded Modest Arrangement of the previous century.

157.1: Typewriters

notes in translation on the early development of tachygraph [typewriter] technology.

Tachygraph primal de dezein 1830 e 40 stan fatuous cos imman, dec y majortað a appragl no poðen for lettr inscaur con un mendranç ag hast de lettranç a man doit.
Early tachygraphs in the 1830s and 40s were extremely cumbersome, with most models only capable of setting type at a fraction of the speed of practised handwriting.

Y Tachygraph d'Armanbourg, oc stant accatabr ne Pologn des an 1842, surcayen impernix ne benoç aðief por se cavir narreyað ny fougl pavarrot sou nom dy Bradygraph (a verb y "scrittour lent")
The Armanburg Tachygraph, which was commercially available in Poland from 1842, was so awkward to use that it was lampooned in the bit-sheets as the Bradygraph (literally the "slow writer").

Ceu incommorant destr, sceyen gimmolt vars poðir tachygraph ligar ag sar campaner, a fin oc se sceus un pistol coutoccar sur papir e lor cos simoltane un facsimile dy pistol boðar vars un autr hom.
Since very early on, attempts have been made to connect tachygraphs to the steeplemesh, so that one could type a message onto paper and simultaneously transmit a copy of the message to someone else.

Y preu tachygraph poðent cos particuler pistol boðar par y sar campaner sta y Teleclavia de Vilmanas, oc orðenjað ne Lithou par Toman Vilmanas d'an 1859. 
The first tachygraph specifically able to send messages on the steeplemesh was the Vilmanas Teleclavia, designed in Lithow by Tomas Vilmanas in 1859.

Sy boðanç primer er conveyað sull'oç Sant Michæl vars sell'amig Margreta Legaite ne Tvaniste.
Its first message was sent on Michaelmas of that year to his friend Margreta Legaite in Tvaniste.

157.4: harif "weird"

harif /haˈrɪf/ [hɐˈʀɪf]
- weird, eldritch, uncanny, off, unsettling in a mysterious way;

157.5: Painkiller Philology

notes on the chemistry and linguistics of the painkiller cozebdo-diamaschal benjamine [ibuprofen].

Cozebdo-diamaschal benjamine (as a medicine sold under several names, including "CD" or "Tommy pills") is a hebetant [painkilling] substance developed in the early twentieth century. It was the result of collaboration between the Branwen Sanatory in New Leudong [south-eastern Australia] and the University of Rimack [Lima] in Tavancy [descendant state of the Incan Empire], which sought to develop hebetants with faster action and milder adversions [side effects]. It was first synthesised in 1932, and a decade later it had surpassed salix derivatives [e.g. aspirin] in sales worldwide, due to providing better pain relief (as opposed to merely reducing the symptoms of fever).

Name

The name of this substance comprises three parts.

The core of the substance is a benjamine [benzene] ring; the name "benjamine" is borrowed via Scholastic Latin and Vascon from Arabic لُبَان جَاوِيّ‎ • lubān jāwiyy, literally "Jawan [Javanese] frankincense", corrupted at some point by the name Benjamin.

The first of the extensions in this substance is a cozebdone branch [isobutyl]. Cozebdone spirit [isobutane] is a rearrangement of the linear zebdone spirit [butane], a colourless and flammable air with a spine of four coke [carbon] atoms. The root zebdo- "four colk atoms" derives from Cairene Arabic زبدة • zébda "butter", first used when zebdone acid [butyric acid] was isolated from milk fat.

The second of the extensions is located directly opposite the first, as indicated by the prefix dia- "across, over", from Greek. It consists of a maschale [propionic acid] branch, which is the acid oil with a spine of length three, a malodorous clear liquid. The substance was named in 1850 after the Ancient Greek μᾰσχᾰ́λη • maschálē "armpit", since it was isolated from human sweat excreted by skin zoia [microorganisms].

##

158.1: Medieval Provence

notes in translation on the territory of Provence in the medieval period.

Provenç Mitað-Asc sta un vassal sou massem possenç divers tras un millenner pres.
Medieval Provence was a vassal of various greater powers for almost a millennium.

I denoy incorporað nell'Empir Françan durant sy spanjon ny siecr seg eð i parmaneu com un sodal de sy ronç ovester posc ig l'empir dehisceu a dou part ny siecr nouf.
It was incorporated into the expanding Francian Empire in the sixth century and remained part of its western fragment after the empire was divided in two in the ninth.

Pre y siecr onç primal y region er denuð autonom majortaðer, ma l'er concas alcheðr oc surcaint y kynous final por y Preu Empir Drengoçan intermanir.
By the early eleventh century it had become mostly autonomous, but it was conquered once more as the last piece of the First Drengot Empire.

Posc l'Urgenç a Dijon d'an 1170, y Reyaum a Borgogn fey exeunt des auteç Drengoçan, y comtað a Provenç apportant galað.
After the 1170 Emergency at Dijon, the Kingdom of Burgundy left Drengot control, taking the country of Provence with it.

Provenç er extollið an ducað ny siecr treç oc gournað par y linaç de Savoy, e ne sona dy conjogntur direct entr y citað caver a Genef e l'entertað dy commarç maritim ny Miterran, i receveu y dob 'y paner Borgond'. 
Provence was elevated to a duchy in the thirteenth century under the house of Savoy, and as the direct link between the capital at Geneva and all of Middlesea sea-trade, it became known as the 'Burgund breadbasket'.

158.3: ciscr "squeal"

ciscr /tsɪxr̩/ [ˈtsɪ.xɐ]
- squeal, screech, shriek, a strident high-pitched sound as may be caused by friction;
- a loud, high-pitched animal cry;
- scream, yelp, a high-pitched vocalisaton due to fright or surprise

Etymology: attested in Old Borlish ciscle "shriek", a deverbal from cisclar "to shriek, scream" (now obsoleted by ciscr fair "to do a shriek"). This descends from a synonymous cistulō in Vulgar Latin reflected also in Vascon chillar "creak" and Parisian gicler "spurt". In turn this is presumed to be an alteration of Classical Latin fistulō "I whistle, play the flute" via assimilation or sound symbolism.

Y belem ny forest se mis afaç con ec ciscr d'aucel.

df scene in-df forest rfl put.pst forward with p.px squeal of=bird
The forest scene opened with shrieks from birds.

158.4: slengettar "snog"

slengettar /ˌslɛn.gɛˈtar/ [ˌzlɛŋ.gɪˈtɐː]
- snog, pash, make out, French kiss, to kiss passionately (especially with tongue);
- mangle, botch, fumble, to do something sloppily;
- overegg, splurge, slather, to do something overenthusiastically;
- meddle, pry, butt in, overstep, badger, to be overly familiar or intrusive into personal or private matters

Etymology: originally in the first senses, attested along with the related noun slenget "snog, make-out session" in the late eighteenth century. It applies the somewhat pejorative verbal derivation s- -ar and the diminutive suffix -et to the root lenc "tongue" < Latin lingua "tongue". The first metaphorical extensions are each attested from the early twentieth century; in the sense of "meddle" it is an innovation of the last couple of decades.

158.5: Roun

Roun (Norman, Kentish /ʀãw̃/) is a port on the Seine river and the capital city of Kent.
History

Founded by the Gauls, the city was known to the Romans as Rotomagus and it became the seat of the local bishopric in the early medieval period. The ninth century saw the incursion of the Normans into the region as part of the wider Dane Supremacy; by 850 Roun was under their control. By the eleventh century Roun had become the seat of the Drengot family, ruling the Duchy of Normandy as a semi-autonomous vassal of the Kingdom of the Franks (the western fragment of the erstwhile Francian Empire).

After the Kernovan Conjuring and the formation of the First Drengot Empire covering much of Albion [Great Britain] and most of Gaul [France], Roun was sidelined. The Drengot Emperors moved their court to Paris, although they continued to personally own the duchies of Normandy and Kent. This period marks the beginning of the persistent political union of these two regions on either side of the English Channel.

One of the successor states to the First Drengot Empire was this united Norman Kent, ruled from Roun. King Vincent II of Kent, who ruled in the mid-fifteenth century, is remembered for the expansion of the city keep and for his twin sons (the "Two Henries") who ruled jointly after his death. During this period Roun French developed fully as one standard written form of the language (as opposed to Parisian or Burgund French).

Roun was the administrative centre of the Drengot Collusion from the nineteenth century until its collapse in 1961. The city housed the "Red House", the headquarters of Collusion's Ministry for Information.

Authors
    Mark Deuthex (fl. 1973), whose spycraft tale We Wake to Broken Windows draws on his own experiences in the Red House.
    Josephene Foilliers (fl. 1913), writer of the first work of fiction to sell over a million copies in a single year.
    Ashford Pasquier (fl. 1968), inventor of the term "pistol mesh" in his parachthon work Starsail.

159.1: Furlain

notes in translation on the polity of Furlain [Friuli].

Durant y Scon Tetrarchy ny siecr onç e doç, y Marc a Furlagn intermane y porçon y souðeressem nell'Empir Theudesc, cos primer un vassal imperial prose eð aval sousunt cos particuler ny paramontað dy Reyaum a Bavarn.
During the Second Tetrarchy of the eleventh and twelfth centuries, the March of Furlain was the southernmost part of the German Empire, at first a direct imperial vassal and later specifically consolidated under the suzerainty of the Kingdom of Bavarn.

Posc y dissoluçon dell'Empire Theudesc ny siecr treç, y compeðour y frequendessem de Furlagn denoy y Republic a Venis.
After the collapse of the German Empire in the thirteenth century, Furlain's most frequent rival became the Republic of Venise.

Furlagn soffreu un quagment gra d'an 1348 oc ayent y castel e cathedral y dou devastað n'Odin. 
Furlain suffered a severe earthquake in 1348 which destroyed both the castle and cathedral in Odin.

The armourcloth trend in women's fashion (which emulated men's military dress) began in Furlain during the Long Peace in the late eighteenth century.

The local term (from voina, a colloquialism for a soldier) was borrowed into several other languages to describe the style.

159.3: groun "teen"

groun /grun/ [gʀun]
- a member of a countercultural and rowdy youth movement in the latter days of the Drengot Collusion;
- (colloquial) teen, teenager, adolescent, youth, a young person in the years around the age of majority;

159.4: abrevar "water"

abrevar /ˌa.breˈvar/ [ˌa.bʀɪˈvɐː]
- water, irrigate, to pour water over in order to help grow;
- wet, soak, drench, moisten, to cause to be wet;
- slake, quench, to satisfy the thirst of;
- to supply with (usually alcoholic) drinks;
- schmooze, butter up, chat up, to curry favour with

Etymology: from Old Borlish abrevar "to water", likely borrowed from Old French synonymous abrever in Old French. This is a metathetic variant of abevrer, which descends from Vulgar Latin abbiberō "I water" (which the Old Borlish may alternatively reflect directly), a derivative of Classical bibō "I drink". The word's association with alcohol and social gatherings shows influence from slang term abrevað "tipsy, squiffy, somewhat drunk", literally "watered".

I thought the host gave us lots to drink.

##

159.5: Cambrick Codices

summaries of two twentieth-century works of writing which were originally written in one or another standard of the Welsh language.

Children of the Battle of Rexam [Wrexham, 1] is a sensation trevold [hit novel] written by Jon Paldreth and published in 1931. It is a fictionalised account of the orphaned children of the Duke of Chester in the decades following his death at the 1483 Battle of Rexam. By Paldreth's account, the children met practically every famous personage in contemporary western Europe, from General daus Sanz to King Andrew of Markland (in fairness, the eldest child was indeed briefly a hostage of the then-prince Andrew). Moreover, Paldreth contrives to have the children present at almost every significant historical event of the time; unlikely as this all is, the book has enjoyed much use in school history lessons as an approachable introduction to the politics of the time.

---

The Grimmer Hall [2] is a scholastic reference quire about developments in early methodics [programming]. It was published in 1999 and written by New Leudong methodist Cai Sonquo during his tenure at the University of Mehannin [Brisbane]. The work covers the use of algorithms from antiquity (for example Euclid's method for finding coarsest division), through the early modern period (e.g. the waveform display [Fourier transform] and its application to astronomy), and into the titular "grimmer halls" (rooms of many people—usually women—performing calculations longhand) of the early twentieth century. The work ends its account just before the invention of the entirely mechanical general-purpose grimmer [computer].

[1] released in Merch as Chulder oth Feight at Rexam /ˈtʃʊl.də‿ɾʊð fɛʃt ət ˈɾɛk.səm/, and originally published in Welsh as Pa Ðywdan y Plant Car Vantel /pa ðəuˈdɔn ə plant kaː vənˈtɛɬ/ "What the Children of Rexam Said"

[2] originally in Welsh as Łis y Grimrageð /ɬiːs ə ˌgɾɪm.ɾəˈgɛð/ "The Computing-Women's Hall".

160.5: Diversions and Dilettantes

notes on various features and historical figures beginning with a common pair of letters.

Diana Theodora Queiroz (fl. 1810) was a writer and polemicist from Vascony who was primarily active during the Long Peace period. She was a major figure in opposition to Deviance theology and an ally of the Modest Arrangement, hewing especially closely to the latter's emphasis on morality and familial obligation. Her views have seen her cast as a precursor to the Blue Marian movement, which sought to advance the status of women within a highly religious and stratified framework.

A dice is a value or score of ten in a game or sport. For example, the Maritime deck contains cards like "the dice of staves" or "the dice of gold", and the chances of getting a dice when rolling a pair of dice are one in twelve. This term, along with its cohort [1], were borrowed into the English languages from the Norman names for numerals during the First Drengot Empire in the early second millennium. In certain sports, including lineball, the most points one can score at once is ten; because of this, the word "dice" appears in some idioms meaning "sudden good fortune" or "an impressive feat".

Dimus [Phobos] is the larger of the two moons of Mars. It was discovered, along with the smaller moon Phobus [Deimos], in 1869 by Mashick astronomer Coscatl bint Inám; she also discovered the eighth planet of Janus [Neptune]. Following the custom set by the four great jovial moons, she named the pair after the twin sons of Mars, who personify dread and panic respectively.

Dion Becolla (fl. 1968) was a Borlish author who grew up in the industrial city of Neuvort. She wrote several trevolds [novels] during the 1960s which capitalised on the so-called General Italian Fervour of the period. Her most famous work is the period piece Waging World Peace [2], set during the 1880s in the midst of the Good Game period and owing much to the masquira genre and its hidden identities, high society and complicated schemes.

[1] in full: ace, duce, trey, cater, cink, sice, sept, hute, nuve and dice [Merch /əis, djəus, tɾəi, kɛːtə, sɪŋk, səis, sɛt, hjəut, njəuv, dəis/].

[2] Borlish Paç Mondial Accommettent /pats mɔnˈdjal ˌa.kɔˈmɛ.tɛnt/.

"Ou ave, Ben! Jo n'ay te vis posc larc semman—Torn all'An Allagr! Increibr no's y temp ou nos caint cos nuvr?"
“Oh wow, Ben! I haven’t seen you in weeks—happy New Year! Can you believe the weather we’ve been having?”

"Carrow! Ajoutað de te quinar—or vis ay jo stað aval a Runkhorn a mesur de toð y gaviscenç, oc me soumonent ne vertað, me valois ne bon mont lign fait ag çod enter jusc oy—Martha e tey ou son cavibr je Mart?
“Carrow! Lovely to run into you—I’ve actually been downstream in Runkhorn for the festivities, which reminds me, actually, I should have quisted the whole crew by now really—are you and Martha free on Tuesday?

"Zo jo seray raut de la assistr—ja, Matt a famigl ac convoccar des toð loy por y spectacr de lumner, ma prefaibr es ig i nil se cavir meyon gehennað avant sell'aldr scey calscon, haha!
“Oh I’d love to come down—yeah, Matt’s got family in from all over for the light shows, but she probably won’t want me embarrassing her in front of the parents in any case, haha!

Donc Jacq sera ben, ja vegnt dou eld, bon Deu—ma paus, comoscon sceus jo Jacq connoscr un dezein lon descovrir ig cay sell'osceyon je Sant Patriç? My bel paðr dign Patriç, m'orruð ig stou all'oc smargr ne collocq."
So Jack’ll be what, twenty-two already, goodness—wait, how have I known Jack for a tenyear and not found out his birthday’s on Patrick’s Day? My father-in-law’s called Patrick, I feel as though this should have come up.”

- bystander, onlooker, witness, spectator, rubbernecker, a person present at but not involved in some event;
- voyeur, peeping Tom, someone viewing a scene from hiding for their own  (often erotic) pleasure;
- gossip, busybody, quidnunc, nosy parker, somebody considered to have an inappropriate interest in others' affairs

Etymology: first seen with the later senses in the nineteenth century, agentive derivation from sbayar "gawp, goggle". Originally the term was exclusive negative or insulting; by the early twentieth century more neutral usage begins to be attested.

- whine, whinge, moan, a noise of complaint or pain;

Etymology: nineteenth century derivative from senglot or the related verb senglottar "sob, sigh, lament". These descend from Vulgar Latin singluttus "sob, hiccup", a alteration of synoynmous singultus in Classical Latin under the influence of gluttiō "I swallow, gulp". Metaphorical use is attested from the early twentieth century.

161.5: Dunclothe

Dunclothe (Merch /ˈdʊŋ.kluːð/, Welsh Dincluth /dɪŋˈklyːθ/) is a political and cultural region of western Albion, located south of Scotland and north of Markland. From the Clothe river valley it extends down along the coast to the Bay of Morcambe.

Toponomy

Dunclothe takes its name from the early medieval petty kingdom known alternately as Alt Clud, Strad Clud, or Din Clud; these are ancient British or Guile phrases meaning "cliff, valley or fort of the river Clothe". It is uncertain whether the Dun- element seen in English names for the region reflects Old Irish dún "fort" or Old English dún "hill".

History

The British territory of Dunclothe was partially conquered settled by Dane invaders during the ninth century. However, the region was not subsumed into the Dane Supremacy as fully as neighbouring Sodrick and Northumber to the west and east respectively.

Dunclothe appears to have controlled the fort at Eidin (modern Edinbrough) until it was sacked by Northumber in 928. Meanwhile Sodrick's power was waning; under King Roderick, Dunclothe conquered the isles of Arran and Mann by 942. The bride of King Radulf of Northumber (r. 951–), one Atre of Cheswic, may perhaps be one of King Roderick's daughters.

In the early eleventh century, Dunclothe is part of a confederation of Dane Kingdoms. However, this would shortly collapse with the rapid expansion of the First Drengot Empire to the south, which incorporated Northumber along with most of southern Albion. This period sees Dunclothe grow closer to newly-united Wales, allies in opposition to Drengot power.

In the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, Dunclothe-led fisheries in the North Atlantic were a major exporter of dried and/or cured cod, selling it via the meshes of Borland and Vascony as far afield as the Eastern Middlesea. This trade was a notable source of specie for the vicinity.

The Kingdom of Britain was founded in the fifteenth century, formalising the suzerainty of Wales over the tallaths of Devon and Dunclothe.

162.1: Raymond al Mustafa

collected notes in translation on Raymond al Mustafa.

Raymond al Moustafa sta un mathematorg e philosoph veunt a plaç meg ny siecr ogtoç.
Raymond al Mustafa was a mathematician and philosopher in the mid-eighteenth century. 

I reseyeu lonc un mesur ne Barcelon sou y patronnement dy Duc a Aragon.
He was resident for some time in Barcelon under the Duke of Aragon's patronage.

Durant l'oc epoc i corresponoy retrasiscent dy theorist soicer Rachel Desselut, e lorry pistol sovemblaurn certan entrell'idea volent tandem y sce de methodic signfeyar.
During this time he corresponded with fellow theorist Rachel Desselut, and their letters outlined some of the concepts that would go on to define the field of methodics [programming].

I passau sell'annað aval ne sojornaçon, souseyent cos final ne Brasil, no stant ancour un part dy polity d'Ambrosia.
He spent his latter years travelling, eventually settling in Brasil [Newfoundland], which was not yet part of the polity of Ambrosia.

Sy granfigl Fabian Mostàf denoy un astronom parnommað all'Observatoir a Paratzon, se sarvent de lodrignað mathematic ec defassað cos parçal par Raymond (com y despley ondatim por gyr celest augrimar).
His grandson Fabian Mostàf became an eminent astronomer at the Paratzon Observatory, using mathematical techniques developed in part by Raymond (like the waveform display to compute celestial orbits).

162.2: glouç "giggle"

glouç /gluts/ [gluts]
- cluck, gobble, the sound made by poultry;
- giggle, snicker, titter, a high-pitched and silly sort of laugh;
- (interj.) pah, pshaw, faugh, a noise of derision or incredulity

Etymology: Middle Borlish deverbal from now-obsolete gloçar "cluck; chuckle" (now usually glouç fair "to do giggles"). This reflects Vulgar Latin glōciāre "to cluck", a regularised conjugation class variant of synonymous glōcīre in Classical Latin. As an interjection the word is attested from the eighteenth century and is now somewhat old-fashioned or facetious.

162.3: ðesmbal "bombshell"

ðesmbal /ðɛzm̩ˈbal/ [ˌðɛ.zɐmˈbal]
- a sport with similarities to dodgeball in which players aim to throw a ball so it hits their opponents;
- dodgeball, the ball used in this sport;
- surprise, bombshell, bolt from the blue, an unexpected event or arrival that is felt to come out of nowhere;
- inspiration, flash of insight, a sudden realisation or deduction

Etymology: verb-noun compound formed in the twentieth century by analogy to earlier analogous words like caugtrbal "football", lit. "kick-ball". The noun bal "ball" comes from a variety of Germanic sources and potentially via Medieval Latin—cf. Old English beall, Old Norse bòllr, Frankish bal "ball". The verb ðesmar "aim, target, direct" reflects Old Borlish ðestmar "work out, consider, turn one's attention to", which descends from an extension of Classical Latin æstimō "I determine the worth of, I value"; thus, ðesmar is a doublet of semi-learned stimar "consider, deem". The word has been used metaphorically for unexpected things since the 1990s.

All'oc ostendour fey jougl y ðesmbal d'Apollon.
/a.lɔk ˌɔ.stɛnˈdur fi ʒuil i ðɛzm̩ˈbal ˌda.pɔˈlɔn/
[ˌa.lʊ‿ˌgɔ.stɪnˈdʊː fi ʝwɪl i ˌðɛ.zɐmˈbal ˌda.pʊˈlɔn]
to-df=s.px blogger do.pst KO df dodgeball of=Apollo
This blogger unexpectedly predicted the future.

162.4: frottar "strum"

frottar /frɔˈtar/ [fʀʊˈtɐː]
- rub, chafe, scour, scrub, scrap, to move one object over another with pressure and friction;
- tickle, to touch (a person) in a manner so as to cause laughter;
- strum, to draw the fingers or a plectrum over the strings of a musical instrument;
- pluck, pick, press, to sound the individual strings or keys of an instrument;
- play, to make sounds with a guitar/harp/keyboard instrument

Etymology: from Old Borlish, borrowed from (or possibly the source of) Old French frotter "rub, polish". This is in either case of uncertain origin, but is generally thought to reflect Latin participle frictus of fricō "I rub, chafe". Musical senses are attested from the Middle Borlish period.

Jo's y jarry frottant tras un demy d'hour.
/ʒɔz i ʒaˈri frɔˈtant traz ɪn deˈmi dur/
[ʝɔz i ʝɐˈʀi fʀʊˈtant tʀaz ɪn dɪˈmi dʊː]
1s=be df crockery rub-p.prs across indf half of=hour
I've been scrubbing dishes for half an hour.

162.5: Mathematical Etymology (cont.)

more excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary o'Mathematics, a reference quire in the Merch language compiled by Rotcham [Rochdale] University Primers.

æther /ˈiː.θə/ [field] the assignment of a quantity (e.g. a dart [vector]) to each point in space. In the modern sense from the late 19C, formerly used to refer to the supposed medium within which phenomena like light, heat or astraphor [electricity] propagate. Early Merch ether (later re-classicised) < Old French < Latin æthēr "the heavens" < Greek αἰθήρ • aithḗr "heavens, open sky".

hedre /ˈhɛ.də/ [face; bivector] one of the mozate [2D] components of the surface of a solid figure; a physical quantity of mozate kind, such as rotation. 16C, extracted from compounds like octahedre < Scholastic Latin -hedrum "-faced" < Greek ἕδρᾱ • hédrā "seat, chair; face".

matching /ˈma.tʃɪŋg/ [bijection] a reversible correspondence between the elements of two collections W and X, both severing [injective] and covering [surjective], so that each element of X is associated to a unique element of W and vice versa. 1831 < translation of Saxon jochung "yoking" in Dümmeyer, 1827. The verb match comes from the identical noun < Old English mæċċa "consort" < Classical German macciō "partner".

oversamn /ˈoː.sa.mn̩/ [superset] a collection X which contains all of the elements of another collection W, and usually more besides. 1831 < calque of Saxon övrsammel "superset" in Dümmeyer, 1827. The noun samn "set" is from the identical verb < Old English samnian "collect, gather" < Classical German samnō "I gather".

stepth /ˈstɛpθ/ [gradient] the ratio of a change in vertical displacement to the corresponding change in horizontal displacement, a measure of how sloped an incline is. 1690 in mathematics < early Merch steapth < adjective steap "steep, sheer" < Old English stēap "high, lofty" < Classical German staupas "high, lofty".

vater /ˈvɛː.tə/ [sine] the ratio of the lengths of the side of a triangle opposite a given angle to the length of the hypotenuse. 17C < Scholastic Latin vatrus (cf. earlier alvatrō etc) < Arabic وَتَر • watar “bowstring, chord” < calque of Sanscrit ज्या jiā "bowstring; vater". The polysemy arises by picturing an arc of a circle with the chord drawn as a bow with bowstring.

163.1: This Side of Aldebaran

excerpt in translation from 1987 book This Side of Aldebaran [1], the official print adaptation of the 1986 film of the same name. The story is a touchstone of the contemporary voidtale genre, despite lacking the xenic [alien] peoples so common to the genre.

Jo m'appen contr y pereð ny roum d'occajon sarrað oç se sarvent an entrquïscoir insolemn por machinour vassaler, sgardant tandic Darios faye loit coll'entragl d'un indagour defonct.

163.2: flasq "pathetic"

flasq /flask/ [flask]
- limp, sagging, flaccid, flabby, flimsy, loose, not taut or otherwise lacking stiffness;
- unenthusiastic, half-hearted, dispassionate, tepid, lacking interest or passion;
- pathetic, pitiful, hapless, inspiring scorn or compassion due to inadequacy or ineptitude

Etymology: borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from early Norman flasque "soft, malleable". This appears to be a hypercorrected variant of earlier flaque, descending from Latin flaccus "flabby, sagging". The unetymological /s/ would reflect analogy from other words whose coda /s/ had been lost in Parisian French. The term has been applied to emotion since the seventeenth century, and to people since the nineteenth.

Jo scavau un grinment flasq dy melodram.
/ʒo xaˈvo ɪn grɪnˈmɛnt flask di ˌme.loˈdram/
[ʝo xɐˈvo ɪŋ gʀɪmˈmɛnt flask di ˌme.lʊˈdʀam]

I wrote an unenthusiastic review of the show.

163.3: cedar "guitar"

cedar /tseˈdar/ [tsɪˈdɐː]
- guitar, a fretted string instrument strummed or plucked with the fingers or a plectrum;
- zither, gittern, any of several similar such instruments in the lute family;
- (informal) skate, ray, any flat-bodied fish with wing-like fins and a whip-like tail

Etymology: Middle Borlish, borrowed from early Jean cedara "guitar", a descendant of Latin cithara "lyre, lute" which was repurposed to refer to a related instrument of Morrove descent imported via Spain. The term has been used in the last sense since the nineteenth century (cf earlier ray a cedar "guitar ray") in reference to the shape of these fish.

Sy femn es y frottour de cedar y faverrem ny muncef.

3s.gn wife be df player of guitar df clever-cmp in-df borough

163.4: gapir "pop up"

gapir /gaˈpɪr/ [gɐˈpɪː]
- happen intermittently, to occur at unpredictable intervals;
- pop up, crop up, to appear (multiple times) without warning;
- be flaky, shilly-shally, to behave unpredictably or unreliably

163.5: Like Oil and Water

collected notes on two unrelated topics.

Psolic aphlox (Merch /ˈsɔ.lɪk ˈa.flɔks/) [carbon monoxide] is a colourless, odourless and toxic air formed by burning organic material without enough ignifex [oxygen].

Though the noxious effects of breathing the air in closed spaces where a coal fire is burning have been known since antiquity (and likely since prehistory), truly theoretical investigation did not begin until the seventeenth century, and the air was not isolated from the acid oil palacy [oxalic acid] until the Long Peace period at the turn of the nineteenth century. Its modern name, first used in 1854, comprises the adjective psolic [deoxygenated, with a lower oxidation number] from Greek ψόλος • psólos "soot, smoke" and the noun aphlox [carbon dioxide] from Greek ᾰ̓φλόξ  • ăphlóx "without flame".

---

The Graven Sea (Merch /ˈgɾɛː.vən ˈseː/) [Baltic Sea], formerly or poetically also the Eastmere, is an arm of the Atlantic Ocean in northern Europe east of Denmark and enclosed by several polities.

The name derives from Scholastic Latin Gravinia, a term for the region around this sea. This is a backformation from gravinicus, graunicus "from or pertaining to the Graven Sea". In turn, this appears to have been a minim error by a late medieval scribe from former granvicus, a borrowing from Old Norse Gandvik. This placename, identified with the Graven Sea since the fourteenth century, may have originally referred to any of several bodies of water, including the Arctic Ocean.

The archaic synonym Eastmere is a calque from the name in various German languages; for instance, in Frise [Frisian] the sea is called the Astmar "east sea".

The work A Baptism of Fire: Christianity and the Graven was written by Agata Naziunas and published in 1988 by Leidéiai Givatés. This work chronicles the history of the Christianisation of the states and peoples on the Graven Sea's coasts, with a particular focus on Naziunas's homeland of Lithow [Lithuania].

164.2: cardonar "unknot"

- card, tease, to separate and align the fibres of wool, etc;
- comb, curry, to run a carding tool through fur or hair;
- disentangle, unknot, to unfasten a knotted string or to separate several entwined strings;
- sort through, organise, to go over a collection of things and separate them into groups;

164.3: stig "pang"

stig /stai/ [stai]
- stitch, a stabbing pain in the side caused by exercise or laughter;

- pang, throe, a sudden outburst of a negative emotion

164.4: ahoy "imminent"

- in view, visible, within sight as from a lookout;
- nearby, close, within reach, accessible, not particularly far away;
- approaching, oncoming, imminent, heading towards one or about to occur (especially of something negative)

164.5: Kelt Borland

notes on the people and culture of Borland before the Roman invasion.

The Iron Age began on Borland at approximately the same time as on the other Northwestern Isles [Ireland, GB] in the ninth century aN. The identity of the first Borland ironworkers is debated and is made complicated by overlapping waves of migrations, but eventually they became identifiably Kelt. The last significant such wave was of early Brythonic speakers on Albion settling Borland from the west in the fourth century aN, the ancestors of the small hill-fort kingdoms which covered the island at the time of the Roman invasion in the first century N.

There are several archaelogical structures on Borland which predate the Kelt migrations but which the Kelts repurposed for ritual use. The most famous of these sites is a so-called "labyrinth" located on Çadrosc Heath in the northwest of the island. There are also many cairns dating to this period, now called sarzin stones (from a late medieval use of sarzin "pagan" deriving from Latin Saracēnus "Muslim").

The name Borland (Istr Boral) is thought to descend from the Kelt enis borag "island of the dawn [viz. East]" and bora ale "the other Easterners", which would imply the name was originally as exonym used by Brythonic speakers on Albion. The adoption of this name for the island by the Romans was undoubtedly influenced by its similarity to unrelated Latin boreālis "northern"; this connection is referenced by contemporary writers.

The Borland tradition of Revillon can trace its origins to a winter feast celebrated by the Kelts, recorded as the Flidōlus (further etymology unknown) by third-century Roman historian Ammian.

##

165.1: Length and Mass

notes in translation on lengths and masses in the dime system of measures.

Scein tre font cas y lonctumn degm: y polç, y pie (10 polç) eð y lau (10⁴ pie).
There are three bases for dime lengths: the inch, the foot (10 inches) and the league (10⁴ feet).

Nell'enç, y lonctumn dy pie denoy fis cos quidam naðusc com y mojol entr y "pie romannesc" eð y "paum accenser" Cathayan, stant un picq pog inequal.
At first, the length of the foot was fixed somewhat arbitrarily as the midpoint of the very slightly different Roman foot and the Cathayan "surveyor's span".

D'an 1946, y pie sta redefinið por ig y veloçtað normal din equal cos exact a deg gran lau par second.
In 1946, the foot was redefined to make the speed of light equal to precisely ten great leagues per second.

Bempart autr mesur a lonctumn pouvler receveurn valour degm.
Several other traditional measures of length were given dime values.

Com bustr, cas y mesur degm y mil val cinq mil pie ben demy d'un lau.
For instance, in dime measures the mile is equal to five thousand feet or half a league.

Scein catr font cas y moul degm: y scrupol, l'onç (100 scrupol), y taber (100 onç) eð y ton (100 taber).
There are four bases for dime hefts: the scruple, the ounce (100 scruples), the tabre (100 ounces) and the ton (100 tabres).

165.2: groinar "grunt"

groinar /grɔiˈnar/ [gʀʊiˈnɐː]
- oink, grunt, snort, to make the sound of e.g. a pig;
- growl, snarl, (of an animal) to make a deep rumbling sound;
- grumble, scoff, (of a person) to make a similar such sound to indicate disapproval or scorn

Etymology: from Old Borlish groȝnar, groȝndir "grunt", reflecting Vulgar variants of Classical Latin grunniō "I grunt". To describe sounds made by people the word is attested as early as the Old Borlish period. The expected modern spelling grognar was once sporadically used but may have been avoided on aesthetic grounds (compare genoil "knee" < genoȝl in Old Borlish).

Y bourgmer ag Groin groin posc y decret.
/i burgˈmɛr ɛi grɔin grɔin pɔx i deˈkrɛt/

165.3: sax "asteroid"

sax /saks/ [saks]
- asteroid, planetoid, comet, a naturally occurring solid object orbiting the Sun which is too small to become spherical under gravity;
- (specifically) such a small body located with the cisjovial ring [asteroid belt]

Etymology: 1813, a borrowing from Latin saxum "stone, rock", used as a calque from synonymous tsa'ra in Mashick Arabic. The term was originally used to describe the various apparently-pointlike bodies in the cisjovial ring, which at that time were being discovered by telescope. The first celestial body this word was applied to, Ixion [Ceres], is now known to be spherical under gravity and so is no longer considered to be a sax. In modern usage saxes include comets, although knowledge of comets dates back to antiquity.

Theorist prevein un collijon par sax d'an 2026.
/θauˈrɪst preˈvin ɪn ˌkɔ.liˈʒɔn par saks dan du mɪl vint sij/
[ðɐuˈʀɪst pʀɪˈvin ɪn ˌkɔ.lɪˈʝɔn pɐː saks dan du mɪl vint sɪi]
scientist foresee-3p indf collision by asteroid of=year 2026
Scientists predict an asteroid impact in 2026.

165.4: or bon "alright"

or bon /ɔr bɔn/ [ʊːˈbɔn]
- alright, OK, cool, sure, an interjection indicating acknowledgement or acceptance;
- so, anyway, look, see, hey, an interjection used after a pause to introduce a new topic

Etymology: phrase comprising or "well, however" and bon "good, correct". The particle or (now archaic in isolation) descends from Old Borlish or "now", either straight from Latin (hāc) hōrā "in (this) hour" or via synonymous (a)ore in Old French. The adjective bon comes directly from Latin bonus "good, right".

Or bon, tenau a le javigar.
/ɔr bɔn | teˈno a le ˌʒa.viˈgar/
[ʊːˈbɔn | tɪˈno a le ˌʝa.vɪˈgɐː]
well good | hold-1p.sbj at 3s.acc trawl-inf
Alright, let's keep searching.

165.5: The 1910s

collected notes on various happenings in the decade 1910 to 1919.

Loðaç Berxon (b. 1865) led the Borland chapters of the Outland Arcabil Association from 1913 until 1918. Berxon had emigrated to the capital city of Damvath from her birthplace in the Arcabil [Caribbean] a decade earlier, due to the disruption of the Millstone War. She was an established author, best known for her first work L'Askouð Pyrrhaz (The Firekeeper's Stronghold), published in 1910. The Outland Arcabil Association was a collection of societies working for the benefit of the Arcabil diaspora across the globe.

The first then-called "house of odyssey" [cinema] to sell tickets to the public on a regular basis was established in Boxa [Novi Sad, Serbia] in 1912. One of the venue's first great successes was a recording of a ballet concert accompanied by the St Hurroco Youth Orchestra of Furlain [Friuli].

Un Seir Deura Soffire (One Evening Will Have to be Enough) was a 1913 work in the masquira genre by Roun author Josephene Foilliers. Its riproaring execution of the classic masquira plot structure of schemes and opulence galore made it an instant success across the Drengot Collusion and beyond; this work was the first book to sell more thna a million copies in its first year.

The literary genre of social comedy has its origins in the late 1910s, with authors like Dorotha Quistack and Judeta Barracin adapting elements of prior genres like lovetales and adolescences. Social comedy is characterised by plots with low stakes, an emphasis on personal friendships and enmities, and generally either rural or low-class urban settings.

166.1: The Ceres Gambit

excerpt in translation from 1952 spycraft trevold The Ceres Gambit (originally published in Borlish as Vellisqment: Ixion), written by Joron Aldaxinte. She was born in the industrial Borlish town of Neuvort, the daughter of a clerk and a minor functionary in the local government.

Caye crevoscr cos tost l'oc jorn. Y ray gaster d'un lun decaint trencan tras ranscel spars e yemal.
Dusk had fallen early that day. The ghost-light of a waning moon cut through sparse, wintry branches.

Sceye veil ney com manton sur y tar dy forest, piestað dessur pall'ombr de pas a toð asmuth.
Old snow blanketed the forest floor, trampled upon with footprints in every direction.

Un hom er le sevent. L'idea parvenoy lon prevart ben motivaçon.
She was being followed. The thought arrived without warning or justification.

I s'interromoy entr y taisc visnous de dou casner antic, cant sy respir fayen dragon nell'aer, eð i da cur all'ouç paçent ny bosc.
She paused between the gnarled trunks of two ancient oaks, her breath dragoning in the air, and took in the woods' patient silence.

Con un maldicçon soçavaver i se commoveu cos lejar y pis, e de sell'azig i sgranfeyau y crost de glaç sou y neyanç.
With a whispered oath she shifted her weight slightly, her boots crunching faintly on the crust of ice beneath the snow.

I s'ortelle y man cos lent vars y nuivr dy glay a sy cegntur eð i se torcheu y doit atorn dell'ans frottað ne cogr.
Her hand moved slowly to the hilt of the blade at her belt and her fingers curled around the worn leather grip.

166.2: fren "brake"

fren /frɛn/ [fʀɛn]
- bit, piece of metal placed in a horse's mouth and connected to the reins;
- brake, device used to slow or stop a vehicle usually via friction;
- deceleration, slowdown, reduction in speed;
- ritenuto, ritardando, (in music) reduction of tempo;
- restraint, reserve, tendency to act with caution or prudence

Etymology: originally in the first sense, via Old Borlish directly from Latin frēnum "bridle, harness, curb, bit". The word was extended metaphorically some centuries before it was reapplied to physical devices on other vehicles. In music the word is calqued from Willem Dutch afrem "slow down (imp.)", potentially also due to phonetic resemblance.

J'ay hougr y fren de my rað sein inovrant.
/ʒe hɔir i frɛn de mi raθ sin ˌi.nɔ.vrant/
[ʝe hɔ.jæ‿ʀi fʀɛn de mi ʀah sin ˌi.nʊˈvʀant]
1s=have.1s fear df brake of 1s.gn bike be.sbj-3p out.of.order
I'm worried my bike's brakes are broken.

166.3: fougl pavarrot "tabloids"

fougl pavarrot /fuil ˌpa.vaˈrɔt/ [fwɪl ˌpa.vɐˈʀɔt]
- tabloids, newspapers considered to be more commercial and less prestigious than "high-brow" journalism;
- gutter press, yellow press, sensationalist reporters or newspapers in general;
- sensationalism, puffery, hype, the practise of exaggerating things for attention

Etymology: nineteenth-century phrase coined as an insult, literally meaning "little cash pages"; compare equivalent Merch term "bit-sheets". The noun fougl "leaf; page, sheet" descends via Old Borlish fouȝl from Latin folium "leaf". The noun pavarrot is a diminutive of pavar "poppy", here referring to a particular small coin used on Borland in the early modern period and reintroduced with a different denomination in the late twentieth period. The word descends from synonymous papāver in Latin, of unknown further origin.

Y fougl pavarrot l'evolgaurn prell'aubon.
/i fuil ˌpa.vaˈrɔt ˌle.vɔlˈgorn̩ ˌprɛ.loˈbɔn/
[i fwɪl ˌpa.vɐˈʀɔt ˌle.vʊlˈgoːn ˌpʀɛ.lʊˈbɔn]
df leaf poppy-dim df=leak-pst.3p before-df=morning
The tabloids got the story out overnight.

166.4: ouger "host"

ouger /uˈʒɛr/ [ʊˈʝɛː]
- landlord, landlady, proprietor, innkeeper, the person who owns a public building (especially a bar or lodging house);
- host, one who receives or entertains guests;
- emcee, moderator, the person running an event;
- presenter, anchor, the face of a programme on radio, TV, etc.

Etymology: from Middle Borlish ouger "landlord/lady", altered from louger via rebracketing of the definite article. This is an agent derivative of now-obsolete lousc "shelter; inn", borrowed from Old French loge "shelter; covered walkway, hut, small room", via synoymous laubia in Medieval Latin from the Classical German root laubam "leaf, foliage". The word has been applied also to other host roles since the seventeenth century.

L'es un ouger sobottal cay set annað.
/lɛz ɪn uˈʒɛr ˌso.bɔˈtal ke sɛt aˈnaθ/
[lɛz ɪn ʊˈʝɛː ˌso.bʊˈtal ke sɛt ɐˈnah]
3s=be indf host radio fall seven year
He's been a radio host for seven years.

##

166.5: The North Wind and the Sun

The Borrhatic League is a collection of charitable organisations and political action groups with a focus on laic governance, education and (in recent decades) also pacifism and objection. The League grew from collaboration between working-class groups of minority faiths across Northern Europe in the early nineteenth century; the name derives from the Attic Greek Βορρᾶς • Borrhâs "the North Wind". The League first rose to prominences on the scale of polities during the Second German War of the 1820s and in its aftermath. For instance, Hilgart and Michael Bervisson were influential in Borland's Borrhatic League at this time, especially with regards to calls for religious tolerance.

Although the Borrhatic League and the contemporaneous Deviance movement has (occasionally explosive) disagreements, both are known to have contributed verbiage to the 1850 Laic Declarations in Belgrade. Later in the nineteenth century the Borrhatic League funded orphanages and schools across the region, such as the Borrhatic School of History in the south-eastern Borlish city of Combert, which exists to this day.

I Macchine di Helio (The Machines of Helios) is a marble sculpture created by Lorenzo dell'Acchedia in the 1550s, during the regions Revitalist period. It was carved in Acchedia's workshop in Rome and displayed in that city for the first decades of its existence. The work is a stylised depiction of the Greek god Helios "the Sun" with the six known planets gyring around him. The notion of a Sun-centred cosmos that inspired the work may have been transmitted to Acchedia via his close friend Martèl fi Bacchero, mathematician at the library of Saint Jerome, who is recorded to have debated the issue in public fora as early as 1552.

167.1: Astraphor

notes in translation on the subject of astraphor [electricity].

Astraphor (tan dignant forç barric) es y cougl d'occorrenç alligað con y presenç eð y locomoçon de soustanç plentivous, ben y nis harneisabr des tal locomoçon.
Astraphor (also called barric force) is the set of phenomena associated with the presence and movement of plentiful [charged] substances, or the thrift [energy] that one can harness from such movement.

Y conjogntur profont cas theory entr astraphor e lumner dene splorað cos minuçous ny siecr novoç a plaç meg; y magn ouvr de titr lon ingeniostað Astraphor e Lumner scaut par y theorist Markesc Wexter Hathwall acavau a y mechanism d'astraphor descreir cos enter coll'un equaçon soul.
The deep theoretical connection between astraphor and light was explored thoroughly in the mid-nineteenth century; the unimaginatively titled magnum opus Astraphor and Light by Merch theorist Wexter Hathwall managed to fully characterise the mechanics of astraphor in a single equation.

Temporane, y sar campaner preluyent a gonfan e lucern sta a mesur de denir destarrið par eç sar barric.
At this time, the earlier flag-lamp steeplemesh [telegraph] was in the process of being displaced by barric meshes.

Region lon doujug a gonfan e lucern stant effus e sceint surcourn larc cas rapidessem por y sar barric adoptar; com bustr, d'an 1870 y lign barric y lonchessem ny mont tras heilant afferjarau y lonctumn de Mendeva Bassem.
Places without a pre-existing extensive flag-lamp system were in many cases faster to adopt the barric mesh; for example, by 1870 the world's longest wired post line on land spanned the length of Lower Mendeva [Central America].

167.2: spanjon "spread"

spanjon /spanˈʒɔn/ [spɐɲˈʝɔn]
- expansion, growth, spread, increase of size, territory or influence;
- elaboration, explanation, further description;
- extension, addition, putting more pieces or sections onto something;
- generalisation, broadening, applying something to new contexts

Etymology: noun derivation from spandr "expand, spread, broaden, explain" or directly from Latin expansio "an instance of spreading out". In either case these derive from Latin root verb pandō "spread, unfold, narrate". The metaphorical senses of expansion are partially modelled after use of the term in Scholastic Latin.

167.3: dob "nickname"

dob /dɔb/ [dɔb]
- honour, accolade, epithet, title, cognomen, a descriptor conferred upon someone as a status symbol;
- term, name, signifier, word, lexeme, a descriptor of any concept (especially one from a specialised area of knowledge);
- byname, nickname, moniker, sobriquet, a familiar form of address for someone or something;
- handle, username, a string of characters used to identify an account on a digital system

Etymology: originally in the first sense, a deverbal noun from dobar "confer knighthood upon, dub". This is a borrowing of Old French adober "equip, arm; dub", which appers to come from a German root related to Classical German dubilas "peg, dowel". In extended use the word is seen from as early as the fourteenth century; the first attestation of the last sense is from 1964.

Who'd use a real name as a username?

167.4: salubr "virtuous"

salubr /saˈlɪbr̩/ [sɐˈlɪ.bɐ]

167.5: Chemical Etymology (cont. 3)

further excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary of Alchemy, a reference quire compiled by Rotcham University Primers [1].

calamine /ˈka.lɐ.məin/ [calamine] conventionalised name for the chalk [carbonate] of jast [zinc], a mineral known since antiquity, used in the smelting of brass and the treatment of rashes. 1645 < Scholastic Latin calamīna < sporadic alteration of Classical cadmīa "calamine; slag, dross" < Ancient Greek Κᾰ́δμος • Kắdmos "Cadmus, legendary founder of Thebes".

od configure /ˈɔd ˈkɔn.fɪˌgjəuə/ [diastereoisomer] one of two or more configures [stereoisomers] of a substance which cannot be superimposed upon each other or upon each other's mirror images. Contrast with a mirrored pair of even configures [enantiomers]. 1922, compound of od "unpaired, indivisible by two" and configure "shape, arrangement". The first < Early Merch odde < Old Norrish [Norse] oddi "third; odd" < oddr "sharp point; triangle" < Classical German usdas "sharp point; position". The second < Scholastic Latin cōnfigūra "moulding, shape" < Classical cōnfigūrō "I mould" < figūrō "I form, shape" < figūra "shape, form".

palaquate /ˈpa.lɐˌkwɛːt/ [oxalic acid] the simplest twice-acid oil [dicarboxylic acid], containing only two atoms of coke [carbon] and being a colourless and crystalline substance found in plants. 1834 < Scholastic Latin palaquātum < Sanscrit पालक्यावत् • pālaciāvat or its Gurjat [Gujarati] reflex પાલકવાડો • pālacvād̦o "characterised by spinach" < Gurjat પાલક • pālac "spinach" < Sanscrit पालक्या • pālaciā "beet, leafy vegetable". The substance was first extracted from the leaves of spinach during the Long Peace period.

[1] a publishing house based in the city of Rotcham [Rochdale, Greater Manchester] and affiliated with the local university.

168.2: pegr "lazy"

pegr /pijr̩/ [ˈpi.ʝɐ]
- idle, inactive, motionless, not engaged in any activity;
- asleep, on standby, (of a device) in a mode with the power on but not in active use;
- lazy, indolent, slothful, averse to work or exercise;
- slovenly, unkempt, having an untidy appearance;
- careless, negligent, sloppy, messy, with a lack of attention or precision;
- pointless, inane, silly, occurring to no particular purpose;

Etymology: from Old Borlish peȝr "unintelligent; idle; lazy", a semi-learned descendant of Latin piger "dull, lazy, sluggish; loth, averse". Use of physical appearance is attested from the sixteenth century; in the latter more general senses the word is seen from the early nineteenth century.

168.3: paramontað "supremacy"

paramontað /ˌpa.ra.mɔnˈtað/ [ˌpa.ʀɐ.mʊnˈtah]
- supremacy, dominance, primacy, precedence, the quality of having power or priority;
- liegedom, suzerainty, the political arrangement inverse to vassalage in which one polity has legal control over the governance of another

Etymology: nominal derivation from paramont "supreme, primary". This is a borrowing from Old French, a univerbation of par amont "by upward", from Latin per "through" and ad montem "to a mountain; upwards". The word was originally used in the thirteenth century to describe the relation of the Drengot Emperor over the kings in his demesne.

Il affirmn y paramontað de rigteç sur ley.

They assert the primacy of ethics over law.

168.4: pereð "bulkhead"

pereð /peˈrɛθ/ [pɪˈʀɛh]
- bulkhead, a vertical separator dividing the hull of a ship into separate compartment, often made watertight;
- an inner wall in a building;
- partition, any structure that divides an area into sections;
- (anatomy) septum, a biological structure analogous to a partition and often specifically the nasal septum

Etymology: via Old Borlish pereð, paired "bulkhead" from Latin pariēs "wall". This was outcompeted outside nautical contexts by the descendant of Latin mūrus "wall (orig. of a town or city)". The word's anatomical sense is first attested from the seventeenth century in translation from Scholastic Latin.

L'ec voç de nossy felau echovan tras y pereð.
/lɛk vɔts de nɔˈsi feˈlo ˌe.koˈvan traz i peˈrɛθ/
[lɛg vɔs de ˌnɔ.sɪ fɪˈlo ˌe.kʊˈvan tʀaz i pɪˈʀɛh]
df=p.px voice of 1p.gn mate resound-ipf.3p across df bulkhead
Our mates' voices carried through the partition.

168.5: And Good And Gay

excerpt from the 1986 work Birds Yet Sing, a popular account by Ivainchuque fi Cap (originally published in Vascon as Ja Cantan Aucèis) of the history of the Household Renovation in the late nineteenth century. This was a precipitous societal shift in attitudes to marriage, family and the role of children, as to the ultimate causes of which there has been much speculation.

…origin of the word "tov" [gay] itself may seem to be evident. The term is attested from the 1810s in the underground tovaric communities of the Riverine Cities [1], and is notable for being (unlike so many similar words) a self-descriptor used to signal ingroup membership, instead of an insult hurled by offended outsiders or the avenging law (whatever it may be avenging). This initial covertness can be seen in the somewhat confused definition given in Manjurich's 1823 work The Vernacular of Boxa [Novi Sad, Serbia] as "a loving salutation between brothers…avoided in polite company".

The existence of the synonymous "tovaric" certainly suggests that "tov" is simply a clipping of e.g. Zahid Russian това́риш • továrish "friend, companion" or one of its cognates, and indeed this connection appears to have been consciously reinforced through the nineteenth century. By the time of the Household Renovation, academic works had further adapted the root, borrowing words like "tovarism" [homosexuality] into dozens of languages.

A closer look into the religious and social dynamics of the Riverine Cities, however, reveals tantalising alternative etymologies. The Riverine Cities were also a hotbed of the Deviance movement due to the presence of significant religious minorities and the entwining of the Church with (resented) local and baronial authority. In particular, there was a significant connection between tovaric circles and the Jewish quarters of cities like Pojon [Bratislava]. Use of the phrase קערל טוב • karl tov "good chap" (the noun coming from German) between Jewish men is attested in correspondence from the mid-eighteenth century.

Another more prosaic idea is that the word "tov" is a clipping in the other direction, a rebracketed form of the patronymic suffix -ov from surnames like Kotov or Soldatov, but…

---

[1] an alliance-federacy of small independent states along the Danube River and its tributaries linked by treaty and trade in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

169.1: Trapped

excerpt in translation from the children's tale of adventure Joke Tawyer and the Emeralds in the Castle, written (originally in Merch) in 1964 by an unidentified member of the Kilshaw writers' collective.

Jo pogn y pujoncr des y moð moglastr par un resmargenç baurous d'energy.
I snatch the knife from the damp earth with a desperate surge of energy.

Sy pis suet m'interman un hormesc consolant ny scompigl.
Its familiar weight is a comforting anchor in the chaos.

Y lamn fay trenc mordent par y cabr gros dy sar cos fagl, cant casc coup hastous spein un cascat a cort se cardonant com y torjon d'un sarpent.
The blade bites through the net's coarse fibers with ease, as each swift cut releases a cascade of ropes that unwind like the coils of a serpent.

Jo me sent n'impisantour tras demy de pousson pre jo plombet par gringr lon graç; my corp liesc vars y makisaç con martelment oc mell'os peyaçant eð y respir volant des my poumon.
I feel weightless for half a heartbeat before I plummet in a graceless tumble, my body crashing into the undergrowth with a thud that jars my bones and knocks the breath from my lungs.

Fougl e bac jagotn mell'accostur, eð un stig parfignt fay gavlot ne my spal, ma no scey alcun hour por commorar ne malestr.
Leaves and twigs snag my clothes, and a sharp pain lances through my shoulder, but there's no time to linger in discomfort.

169.2: sacr "wicked"

sacr /ˈsa.kr̩/ [ˈsa.kɐ]
- (formal or poetic) sacred, sainted, holy, hallowed, characterised by solemn religious ceremony or religious use;
- essential, vital, key, crucial, pivotal, of extreme importance;
- (colloquial, dated) cool, wicked, awesome, very interesting or impressive in an exciting way

Etymology: originally in the first senses, a Middle Borlish reborrowing from Latin sacer "sacred, holy". With these meanings the words is mostly confined to idioms, collocations (y Bibr Sacr "the Holy Bible") and poetry, supplanted by words like sacrað and sagntað "holy". In the last senses the word was briefly popular in the mid-twentieth century and it is occasionally still used (alongside the comparative sacherrem which saw similar use somewhat later) to evoke the period.

Saðour sialler seraun sacr sy seucq saufgardant.
/saˈður sjaˈlɛr seˈron sakr̩ si sauk ˌsof.garˈdant/

Rye farmers will be vital to securing his legacy.

169.3: compeðour "candidate"

compeðour /ˌkɔm.peˈður/ [ˌkɔm.pɪˈðʊː]
- competitor, contender, a person or team taking part in a competition;

- option, alternative, one of the candidates for (originally) an elected position or (colloquially) any responsibility or requirement

The word has been used in political contexts since the late seventeenth century, although it only became widespread a hundred years later.

169.4: scavlar "ape"

scavlar /xaˈvlar/ [xɐˈvlɐː]
- mirror, reflect, to produce a reflection of;

169.5: Time for T

collected notes on four features of the Boralverse alternate history that begin with the letter T.

Tewis Camigner (fl. c16) was a botanist from Willemy during the Revitalist period, sometimes called the father of farm theory. His writings in experientia include the first reference to the high sugar content of beet syrup, which would go on to inspire the 1730s Pentrose survey. This was a search for a domestic alternative to sugarcane which resulted in the braxoch, a hybrid of Silesian and Cassuvian beets with a characteristic gold colour and the ancestor of almost all modern sugar beets.

Tightrope Walking: a Linguistic History of Borland (originally in Napolitan as Funamblisme: n'Istorio Lingual d'e Isule Bural) is a scholastic quire written by Ghendaline Cecchino and published in 1991 by the Edizore Università Napule. The work chronicles how the Borlish language has changed from the Roman period until the modern day.

Tolose is a city and region in the south of Gaul [France], formerly an independent polity. It was a march (and then a duchy) vassal of the First Drengot Empire in the eleventh and twelfth centuries, bordering the kingdom of Barcelon to the south. However, the region maintined significant independence, with its own standing army. Following the collapse of the First Drengot Empire, Tolose became a hotly contested border region. It was conquered by Vascony from the west in the fifteenth century (see Prince Mark of Tolose, heir to the Vascon throne who predeceased his father in 1453). In the first decade of the sixteenth century, Barcelon conquered Tolose from Vascony, and the region has been territory belonging to the kingdom of Barcelon since (barring some brief exceptions).

Tuscany is an Italian polity on the Tyrrhene Sea, bordering Jeans [Genoa], Lombardy and Rome. Its capital city is Florence. Between the tenth and thirteenth centuries it was ruled by the Pisan dynasty, including the renowned Duchess Matilda (r. 1102-1146). The Italian language of Tuscany has contributed many loanwords to European languages due to the prestige and trade wealth of the region.

##

170.1: Wales in the Wars

excerpt in translation on the subject of Wales during the Wars of Fealty, and on the Battle of Rexam (1483) in particular.

Y Reyaum a Brittan joun naðusc (compos par Cambry e sy taleð fragossau, cosogr Cornou e Sodric) broucau nell'enç un eðegl de forç, e l'acavau a bempart concession stragr des Marclont durant l'annað primal dy rix.
The relatively new Kingdom of Britain (formed of Wales and its outlying tallaths [provinces], along with Kernow [Brittany] and Sodrick [Man and the Hebrides]) started from a position of strength, and managed to extract many concessions from Markland in the early years of the wars.

L'ec fey ersteigon par un victoir consecter ag Battagl a Car Vantel, yon fo y Duc a Castr final occeut.
These culminated in a decisive victory at the Battle of Rexam, where the last Duke of Chester was killed.

Posc l'oc battagl, Brittan sceu auteç durabr garantir dy region atorn de Car Vantel (ma contrig y gazou sur y citað a Castr pog apres se cou offiruð).
After this battle, Britain was able to take lasting control of the area around Rexam (though the attack on the city of Chester shortly thereafter was rebuffed).

Y polity acavau soulor a se refusar deur y conflict continuant dy Rix cas Fieltað; y ligt entr y polity n'Albion volen remanir jannestað entarn tras trent annað aposc.
The polity then managed to recuse itself from the continued conflicts of the Wars of Fealty; the rest of the polities of Albion would remain embroiled for another thirty years.

170.2: dithyramb "rant"

dithyramb /ˌdi.θiˈramb/ [ˌdi.θɪˈʀamb]
- (historical) dithyramb, a raucous and ardent choral hymn sung in ancient Greece in honor of the god Dionysus;
- ode, ballad, any of various poetic or musical forms characterised by the communication of intense emotions;
- diatribe, rant, tirade, polemic, an impassioned oration or piece of writing (often with positive affect)

Etymology: originally in the first sense, borrowed in the early modern period via Latin from δῑθῠ́ρᾰμβος • dīthŭ́rămbos in Ancient Greek. In poetic use the word has never denoted any particular metre or form; its intentional vagueness has allowed poets to use the term for a diverse array of works. In the last senses the term is attested from the nineteenth century.

Sy dithyramb s'ubicqfey cas sar.
/si ˌdi.θiˈramb ˌsi.bɪkˈfi kaz sar/
[si ˌdi.θɪˈʀamb ˌsi.bɪkˈfi kaz sɐː]
3s.gn rant rf=make.viral wrt net
Her tirade's gone viral online.

##

170.3: souquondar "lurk"

souquondar /ˌsu.kwɔnˈdar/ [ˌsu.kwʊnˈdɐː]
- lurk, hide, skulk, to lie in wait out of sight;
- prowl, sneak, to move stealthily to avoid detection;
- be dormant, bide one's time, to appear to be inactive while waiting for the best opportunity;
- (botany) of a bulb, to remain underground over winter;
- (medicine) of a disease, to be asymptomatic but still contagious;
- stake out, case, to conduct surveillance upon a location

Etymology: Middle Borlish, derivation with the prefix sou "under, below" from the root aquondar, covondar et al. "lie in wait, ambush". This appears to reflect an unattested Vulgar Latin adjective *accupābundus "lurking, hiding, hunting animals", which would be a confused form influenced by Classical aucupor "I catch birds or bees" and occupō "I occupy, seize, anticipate".

The botanical sense is attested from the seventeenth century, and the medical sense from the nineteenth. The last senses appear to have arisen in journalistic circles within the past few decades.

Toð y volcan sur Istr Boral souquondn tras millenner.
/tɔθ i vɔlˈkan sɪr ɪstr̩ boˈral suˈkwɔndn̩ traz ˌmɪ.lɛˈnɛr/
[tɔ‿ði vʊlˈkan sɪː‿ˈʀɪ.stɐ bʊˈʀal sʊˈkwɔn.dɐn tʀaz ˌmɪ.lɪˈnɛː]
all df volcano on isle Borland lurk-3p through millennium
Borland's volcanoes have all been dormant for millennia.

##

170.4: theu "habit"

theu /θau/ [θau]
- wont, habit, custom, practice, way, MO, one's usual manner of doing things;
- will, willpower, free will, the capacity to act and make decisions to carry out one's wishes;
- persistence, wilfulness, headstrongness, stubbornness, the quality of refusing to change one's opinions or actions

Etymology: direct descendant of Old Borlish theu, thau "wont; behaviour", borrowed from synonymous þēaw in Old English. In the last senses the word usually has positive affect, unlike otherwise comparable words like obstinaç "obstinacy". Puns on this word with the name Theo are attested from the eighteenth century, possibly as soon as the words became homophonous in many Borlish dialects.

Rumorar no's y theu de mey.
/ˌri.moˈrar nɔz i θau de mi/
[ˌʀi.mʊˈʀɐː nɔz i θau de mi]
gossip-inf ng=be df wont of 1s.dj
I don't usually spread gossip.

170.5: Decim(alis)ation

excerpt from the 1st July 1975 edition of the Scavlour (Reflecter), a workdaily paper from Borland which focuses on political news.

…impractical to import astraphor [electricity] from Portingale.

GOVERNMENT ANNOUNCES FIRST DECIMATION IN FIFTY YEARS

In a long-anticipated move, the Ministry for Wealth has confirmed that all four conditions of the '15 Food Prices Act have been met. The gemma (⍚), which has been the base unit of Borlish currency since 1925, is to be first supplemented and eventually replaced with a coin worth 10⍚.

Minister Gottart has expressed his intention that new coin and notes denominated in the new currency will enter circulation on David's Day of 1977. For the next four months the ministry is accepting public input on the name and designs of the new coinage, although calls for a popular vote on the final name have been rejected (perhaps due to the unfortunate example of Burgundy, which went through its own decimation three years ago). No timeline has yet been confirmed for the deprecation of the gemma, but exchange schemes are likely to be available for at least a year after gemma-denominated coins are no longer legal tender.

This will be only the third currency in Borland since the polity moved to a decimal system of coinage upon its 1894 incorporation into the Drengot Collusion. The process of so-called "decimation" is common to all Drengot successor states and has been taken up by several others through the twentieth century. It obtained its violent name as a cod-Latin pun and insult by Sarzan Dawkinholm, one-time Outland Minister in Markland and one of the most vociferous opponents to decimation.

The necessity of decimation has been questioned by trade theorists, especially given that many parts of the world seem to have no issue spending hundreds or thousands of the local currency on (say) a loaf of bread, but…

171.1: Maritime Cards

notes in translation on the subject of the Maritime deck of cards, which have five suits: gold, bucklers, staves, jewels and arrows.

Doutr allors, magn entr y blad aun cas ustol un dob desjognt deur lorry step eð ensign—com bustr, y dou de verc dign y Duel, cant y set de jovel es connuð com y Constellaçon.
Many of the cards furthermore have conventional titles separate to their rank and ensign—for example, the deuce of staves is called the Duel, while the sept of jewels is known as the Stars.

Tras asc y composson sull'ec blad son ençað a l'ec aspect noçonal sousumir.
Over time the artwork on these cards has come to incorporate these thematic elements.

Ne joy yon certan blad contrdontn toð autr, l'ensign d'aur luïsc cos usual l'oc sona, interim pieç joy modernessem se sarviraun dy blad "dobað" soumont amont cossy.
In games where some cards trump the rest, the gold ensign typically takes this role, but some more modern games will use the aforementioned "named" cards in this way.

Y benoç d'un pachet Maritim por y ventur preveir scavr bempart autr poið d'arveiðrostað, ma meðes l'issar occult e modern n'aun lorrell'origin for ny siecr novoç primal.
The use of a Maritime deck for divination mirrors many other sources of randomness, although the modern occult practices only date back to the early nineteenth century.

171.2: vancar "loot"

vancar /vanˈkar/ [vɐŋˈkɐː]
- loot, pillage, plunder, snatch, to get possession of underhandedly;
- catch, secure, nail, nab, apprehend, seize, to get hold of and prevent from leaving one's grasp;
- win, to receive as a reward

Etymology: early Modern Borlish, verbal derivation from vanc "catch, haul; loot, plunder". This was borrowed from Willem Dutch verb vangen "to catch", a descendant (modelled after the preterite forms) from Classical German fanhō "I take, seize". In the last sense the word is attested from the early twentieth century.

Vancheu toð vençabr dell'oc vessondry.
/vanˈkau tɔθ vɛnˈtsabr̩ dɛˈlɔk ˌvɛ.sɔnˈdri/

loot-1p.sbj all sell-pt of-df=s.px clothier
Loot this clothes shop of anything we can sell.

171.3: visnous "gnarly"

visnous /vɪˈznuz/ [vɪˈznuz]
- wizened, rugged, made rough by age or exposure;
- gaunt, haggard, emaciated, looking severely ill and malnourished;
- gnarly, knotty, knobbly, bumpy, shaped like wood with many knots

Etymology: Middle Borlish, adjectival derivation from now-obsolete verb visnar "to wither". This descends from an Old Borlish borrowing from Old English wisnian "dry up, shrivel". The arboreal senses (literally or figuratively) are now the most current, with a noun visn "knot in wood" having been backformed from the adjective.

Il ern zaquesc visnous a tatover pascent.
/ɪl ɛrn zaˈkwɛx vɪˈznuz a ˌta.toˈvɛr ˈpa.xɛnt/
[ɪˈlɛːn zɐˈkwɛx vɪˈznuz a ˌta.tʊˈvɛː ˈpa.xɐnt]
3p cop.imp-3p snack gnarly at potato eat-p.prs
They were eating knobbly potato snacks.
