171.4: ne minemini "eeny meeny miney moe"

ne minemini /ne miˌne.miˈni/ [ˌne.mɪˌne.mɪˈni]
- (law) the presumption of innocence, the legal principle that an accused party is innocent until they are found guilty;
- benefit of the doubt, an appeal to this principle in more general settings;
- eeny meeny miney moe, an (essentially) meaningless phrase at the beginning of any of various children's rhymes which involve pointing at people or things in turn with the goal of picking one

Etymology: fourteenth century in legal Latin as nē minēminī "do not threaten, do not accuse", from the prohibitive particle nē and the second-person plural subjunctive of deponent verb minor "I threaten, accuse". Its original denotation was closer to a admonition against obtaining confessions by duress or threats, only attaining its modern meaning in the seventeenth century. Shortly thereafter the phrase appears in nursery rhymes, presumably more for phonetic reasons than any semantic connection. Nonetheless, some have dubiously linked these rhymes to the act of picking a scapegoat for a crime.

Nos orruð stou le fornir con ne minemini.
/nɔz ɔˈrɪθ stu le fɔrˈnɪr kɔn ne miˌne.miˈni/
[nɔz ʊˈʀɪh stu le fʊːˈnɪː kɔn ˌne.mɪˌne.mɪˈni]
1p seem must 3s.acc furnish-inf with presumption.of.innocence
She seems worth the benefit of the doubt.

##

171.5: Novomundine Landfall

The Novomundine Landfall (Borlish Abanc Novomondin) occurred in 1471 N, when a ship that was part of a New Navarre Enterprise fishing expedition in the North Atlantic sighted and made landfall on the island of Brasil [Newfoundland]. It marks the start of prolonged contact between the Vetomund [Afroeurasia] and the Novomund [Americas] (notwithstanding evidence of sporadic Norrish [Norse] contact with the region), and the first century following the Landfall is known to historians as the Intertwining Century.

The terms Novomund and Mendeva [North America] date to this voyage; a surviving map from the Landfall voyage itself is marked terrae mendevalensis, after the Vask [Basque] mendeval "west".

The Landfall occurred at the height of the so-called Vascon Ascendancy, when Vascony [N Spain, SW France] reached its territorial maximum under Ambrose III, and the trade opportunities that arose over the following decades were just as beneficial for the polity. Ambrose's rival, Munir al-Hamdawi of Morrack [Morocco], quickly redirected the efforts of his presciently-named New World Company westward (having previously maintained trade routes to the East), leading to the discovery of the faster southern route to the Novomund and the islands of the Arcabil [Caribbean].

The first Vetomundine royal to set foot in the Novomund was King Ambrose's elder sister Princess Alexandra of Vascony, who visited the new settlement of Paratzon [St John's, NL] in the 1490s. It is unknown why she (and several female attendants) undertook the voyage, although her second husband's various deficiencies and scandals have been implicated. Her visit is remembered for advancing understanding of scurvy (the chemical sandrine [vitamin C] is named in her honour), although it would take over a century and experiments with guy-conies [guinea pigs] before ships could come close to effectively preventing the malady.

##

172.1: Hatfell Honours

notes in translation on the subject of a coveted artistic accolade.

Honour de Hatfell son veðrdon plusour soupleyað de posc y siecr veintem primal a artejan ne sce divers y Collujon Drengoçan hamtant (e, posc ig l'oç alleyanç-federaç sfondrau d'an 1961, l'entertað de Gal e l'eç Istr Norðovester).
Hatfell Honours refer to several prizes awarded since the early twentieth century to artists in various fields across the Drengot Collusion (and, after that alliance-federacy collapsed in 1961, across all of Gaul and the Northwestern Isles [Ireland, GB, Borland]).

Y dou Honour ne literatur e ne dram son abrangið par y cougl original de veðrdon, cant novel art ern admis tan recent com y dezein 2010.
The Honours in literature and drama are among the original set of prizes, while new arts have been admitted as recently as the 2010s.

L'ec Honour prenn y nom de Hatfell, un toun norðer ny stat citaðer de Londr jos y tarmn contr Marclont stant y mojol d'un communtað d'autour parnommað ny siecr novoç.
The Honours are named for Hatfell [Hatfield, Hertfordshire], a northern town in the city-state of London near the border with Markland which was home to a collective of renowned authors in the nineteenth century.

D'an 1918, y scrittour Dorotha Quistack gajannau un Honour de Hatfell por un entr sell'adolescenç.
In 1918, the writer Dorotha Quistack won a Hatfell Honour for one of her coming-of-age novels.

172.2: allocquar "address"

allocquar /ˌa.lɔˈkwar/ [ˌa.lʊˈkwɐː]
- address, speak to, to communicate with by means of speech;
- affect, touch, impact, to have some sort of relevance to or effect upon;
- (dated) court, woo, romance, to endeavour to gain someone's affections

Etymology: Middle Borlish, borrowed (with regularised conjugation modelled after collocquar "converse") from Latin alloquor "I address, greet", derived from the root loquor "I speak". The term is seen in metaphorical use from the eighteenth century, and in romantic contexts from around the same time.

Lor rou y diac ouð y ley vel y taus terren allocquar.

then ask df journo q df law will.sbj df rate of.land address.inf
The journo then asks if the law will affect land tax.

172.3: incombir "loom"

incombir /ˌɪn.kɔmˈbɪr/ [ˌɪŋ.kʊmˈbɪː]
- behove, befit, benefit, suit, to be proper or advantageous for someone to do;
- incite, impel, urge, provoke, to provide an impetus to do;
- press, overlay, to put pressure upon from above;
- loom, tower, to stand tall nearby (usually in a threatening manner)

Etymology: originally in the first senses, a Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin incumbō "I lie upon, I recline". The physical senses are attested later and may be based on the Latin (or may show influence from related descombr "go to bed, lie down to sleep).

T'incombisce te leyar tostessem.

You should have got up earlier.

172.4: ostendar "blog"

ostendar /ˌɔ.stɛnˈdar/ [ˌɔ.stɪnˈdɐː]
- exhibit, display, to show for public consumption;
- publish, to have (usually a work of writing) publicised via some outlet;
- blog, post, to write (or otherwise create content) and publish on the pistol mesh [Internet]

Etymology: early Modern Borlish, a borrowing (probably via a French or Italian language) from Latin ostendō "I expose to view, reveal". In journalism the term originally connoted commercial writing as opposed to actual news. In the context of the mesh there are attestations from the earliest meshfora in the late 1960s.

Ðe n'aun nien ostendað tras dou meis.

[ðe non njɛn ˌɔ.stɪnˈdah traz du miz]

They've posted nothing in two months.

##

172.5: How to spell Borlish

I've finally started a proper reference work for Borlish; I've finished the orthography section!

Here are the twenty-seven letters of the standard Borlish alphabet, along with their letter names.

The character ‹ w ›, which is used in foreign words and some names (like Willaum ‘William’), is pronounced like ‹ v › and called vescon ‘second-vee’. There are also some compound characters. The ligatures ‹ æ œ ›, primarily used in Classical loanwords, are called æsc and œthel respectively and pronounced as if written ‹ e ›. The character ‹ ï › is referred to as i jammel ‘twin i’ and pronounced as if written ‹ yi ›.

In the following we will consider ‹ y › to be a vowel when written between consonants and/or word boundaries, and a consonant otherwise.

Consonants

The following letters regularly denote a single phoneme.

Of these, the letters ‹ b d f l m n p r › may appear doubled, which usually does not affect their pronunciation.

    abbað joddy affis ollom commet bannir çoppin arrum
    /aˈbaθ ʒɔˈdi aˈfɪz ɔˈlɔm kɔˈmɛt baˈnɪr tsɔˈpɪn aˈrɪm/
    abbot cuppa tip relic ban start toffee cosine

The only exception to this is that ‹ mm nn rr › may denote a single consonant followed by a syllabic consonant. This is the reading when ‹ mm nn rr › occurs word-finally or before a consonant.

    yem-m grin-n car-r
    /ˈjɛm.m̩ ˈgrɪn.n̩ ˈkar.r̩/
    get-1p judge-3p seek-inf

The letter ‹ ð › is pronounced /θ/ word-finally and /ð/ otherwise; the letter ‹ x › regularly denotes the phoneme sequence /ks/.

Consider the final six letters ‹ c g h s t y › when they occur alone (not part of a digraph). In this case, the letters ‹ t y › regularly denote /t j/ respectively. The letter /t/ may be doubled, without any effect on its pronunciation.

    tien yoc cattin
    /tjɛn jɔk | kaˈtɪn/
    yours husband kitten

The letter ‹ c › is pronounced /ts/ before ‹ e i y › and /k/ otherwise. The doubled ‹ cc › is pronounced /kts/ before ‹ e i y › and /k/ otherwise.

By contrast, the letter ‹ g › may be pronounced as either of /g ʒ/ before ‹ e i y › and is pronounced /g/ otherwise (and similarly for doubled ‹ gg ›).

    cigl cuivr bac | gevou genoil tenguð
    /tsajl ˈkajv.r̩ bak | geˈvu ʒeˈnɔjl tɛnˈgɪθ/
    darling copper twig | (watch out) knee bauble

The letter ‹ h › is either pronounced /h/ or is silent (the latter only in some vocabulary inherited from Latin and after vocalic ‹ g ›); The letter ‹ s › is pronounced /z/ in coda position or between vowels, and /s/ otherwise or when doubled.

    heu hom augher | bevis bosaç bustr bossir
    /hau ɔm oˈjɛr | beˈvɪz boˈzats ˈbɪst.r̩ bɔˈsɪr/
    mien person tumbler | note gunfire example gent

Consonant digraphs

The six letters ‹ c g h s t y › combine with other graphemes to form digraphs. The sequences ‹ sc ch th › regularly denote the phonemes /x k θ/. The potentially ambiguous sequence ‹ sch › is read /sk/. The sequence ‹ cq › is pronounced /k/.

    sclar chym thral schol jalicq
    /xlar kɪm θral skɔl ʒaˈlɪk/
    lightning lymph slave school tuxedo

The graphemes ‹ g y › only form digraphs when combined with vowels, for which see below.
Vowels

Divide written vowels into two groups. Free vowels are either wordfinal or separated from the next vowel in the word by a single consonant grapheme (or one of ‹ sc ch th ›).

    choma epu idiocy nothe
    /koˈma eˈpi ˌi.djoˈtsi noˈθe/
    gnome express stupidity illegitimate

Checked vowels are either in a final closed syllable or separated from the next vowel in the word by at least two consonant graphemes.

    commun ambasctour sincer
    /kɔˈmɪn ˌam.baxˈtur sɪnˈtsɛr/
    ordinary emissary genuine

Now consider the letters ‹ a e i o u y › when they occur alone (not part of a digraph). When they are free, ‹ a e i o u y › when they occur alone (not part of a digraph). When they are free, ‹ a e i o u y › are pronounced /a e i o i i/.

    cla vige bro cru try
    /kla viˈʒe bro kri tri/
    key wealthy dude raw turn

When they are checked, ‹ a e i o u y › are pronounced /a ɛ ɪ ɔ ɪ ɪ/.

    vindron vampyr effus
    /vɪnˈdrɔn vamˈpɪr ɛˈfɪz/
    vintner vampire extensive

Between a consonant and one of the vowels ‹ a e o u ›, the graphemes ‹ i u › denote the semivowel ‹ j ›. The grapheme ‹ u › denotes the semivowel /w/ specifically after ‹ q ›.

    diac suet quelt
    /djak sjɛt kwɛlt/
    mic familiar dinner

Vowel digraphs

The digraphs ‹ au eu ou › are pronounced /o au u/ respectively. The rarer ‹ ao eo › share their pronunciation with ‹ eu ›.

    taur teun tout | paon theory
    /tor taun tut | paun thauˈri/
    bull scant everything | peacock science

The digraphs ‹ ai ei oi ui › and ‹ ay ey oy uy › are pronounced /e i ɔj aj/ respectively. Intervocalically, ‹ y › does double duty, simultaneously affecting the previous vowel as stated and acting as an onset ‹ j ›.

    deit joivr | rayon huyaç
    /dit ˈʒɔjv.r̩ | reˈjɔn haˈjats/
    finger frost | sunbeam corruption

The vast majority of coda ‹ g › and some other ‹ g › before consonants form vowel digraphs. Here, the digraphs ‹ ag eg ig og ug aug oug › may be pronounced /ɛj ɪj aj ɔj aj oj uj/ respectively.

    bag deg rig pog tug faug voug
    /bɛj dɪj raj pɔj taj foj vuj/
    berry ten queue few passion sickle wrong

However, there are cases where a ‹ g › in one of the above environments is read consonantally.

    magr magr | migrar scigrar
    /ˈmag.r̩ ˈmɛj.r̩ | mɪˈgrar xajˈrar/
    rash scarce | migrate redistrict

##

173.1: Nicolas of Avignon

notes in translation on the subject of Nicolas of Avignon (Provincial Nicolà s Avignon /ni.koˈlɔ sa.viˈɲũ/, fl. 1347).

Nicolas d'Avignon sta un architect Borgond parnommað.
Nicolas of Avignon was a renowned Burgund architect.

L'es cos primer æternað desig i condugheu y reconstroinç eð y spanjon dy Cathedral de Sant Sophia ne Stamboul, y citað caver nell'Empir Roman Dovem.
He is principally remembered for leading the renovation and expansion of Saint Sophia's Cathedral in Stamboul, the capital city of the Second Roman Empire.

Rumorað es ig sy benoç de lodrignað experiencer por y dom central basfeyar ayen y corp principal enter dy cathedral rent precartaðer cos minuscr.
His use of experimental techniques in supporting the central dome are alleged to have rendered the entire main body of the cathedral slightly unstable.

Deut all'oc i dign parveg e cos joculant y dobanç de "l'architect dy ruin dell'Empir", la sceint y sfondranç tragic dell'edifiç a mesur d'un ceremony de coronnaç aval de tre cent annað ayent gran part ag dynasty imperial occeut (jos larc cent ec may) e l'insorgenç akirtað volent l'Empir rasgattovar jug.
For this reason he is sometimes jocularly referred to as the "architect of the Empire's demise", given the tragic collapse of the building during a coronation ceremony three hundred years later that killed most of the imperial family (and hundreds more) and sparked the unrest that would end the Empire for good.

173.2: entrquïscoir "break room"

entrquïscoir /ˌɛntr̩ˌkwajiˈxɔir/ [ˌɛn.tɐˌkwajˈxɔ.jɐ]
- break room, a space in a workspace set aside for staff to spend short periods away from work to e.g. eat or talk;
- (metaphorically) respite, a brief interval of rest or relief between times of some unpleasant experience

Etymology: mid-twentieth century, place derivation (using the suffix -oir < -ōrium in Medieval Latin) from the verb entrquïr "pause, stop work". This is a late medieval borrowing from Latin interquiēscō "I rest briefly", adapted to native prefix entr- "between" and verb quïr "to put out, turn off".

Y soucorsour all'entrquïscoir dy piscin teyen catr.
/i ˌsu.kɔrˈsur aˌlɛntr̩ˌkwajiˈxɔir di piˈxɪn tiˈjɛn ˈkatr̩/
[i ˌsu.kʊːˈsʊː‿ʀɐˌlɛn.tɐˌkwajˈxɔ.jɐ di pɪˈçɪn tjɛn ˈka.tɐ]
df lifeguard at-df=break.room of-df pool number-ipf-3p four
Four lifeguards were in the pool's break room.

173.3: contrdontaçon "downfall"

contrdontaçon /ˌkɔntr̩ˌdɔn.taˈtsɔn/ [ˌkɔn.tɐˈdɔn.tɐˈtsɔn]
- downfall, fall, doom, demise, defeat, a loss that is particularly noteworthy or spectacular;
- disgrace, humiliation, a sudden nosedive in public opinion of someone or something

Etymology: noun derivation from the verb contrdontar "foil, stymie, thwart". This is a pleonastic extension of now-obsolete dontar "thwart, defeat", which descends from Latin domitō "I tame, I vanquish".

Cay descreuçon dy contrdontaçon dy Reyaum ag Danau.
/ke ˌdɛ.xrauˈtsɔn di ˌkɔntr̩ˌdɔn.taˈtsɔn di riˈjom ɛi daˈno/

fall description of-df downfall of-df kingdom at.df Danube
It describes the downfall of the Danube Kingdom.

173.4: mesaventoresq "shambolic"

mesaventoresq /ˌme.zaˌvɛn.toˈrɛsk/ [ˌme.zɐˌvɛn.tʊˈʀɛsk]
- farcical, clownish, slapstick, comprising a series of ridiculous goings-on;
- shambolic, pell-mell, haphazard, with a complete lack of sensible organisation;

Etymology: nineteenth century, a blend of two preexisting words. The first is mesaventur "mishap, accident", which comprises the prefix mes- "badly" (from Germanic) and the obsolete noun aventur "event, chance"; the second is aventoresq "swashbuckling, gleefully adventurous", a borrowing via Parisian from synonymous avventoresco in Tuscan.

Smars sta un cont mesaventoresq e stendiscent.

173.5: American Toponymy

    excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary o'Mendevan Placenames, a reference quire in the Merch language compiled by Rotcham [Rochdale] University Primers.

Ax /aks/ [~SW Alaska] a peninsular polity in northwestern Mendeva [North America], along with the surrounding mainland region and an extended chain of islands leading west into the northern Lovaqua [Pacific]. 1780 < French l'Axe < poss. Vascon or Portingale l'Axa, a Axa < early 18C Arabic الأَقْصَى • al-Aqśá "the Furthest" < folk etymology from Oranger [Aleut] alaxsxaq "mainland", influenced by its northerly location and sheer distance from Mashick [Mexico]. Originally referring specifically to the peninsula, the term was extended to the island chain itself by the Morrack [Moroccan] surveyors who first recorded the term in a Vetmundine [Afroeurasian] language.

Bahassassin /ˌba.hɐˈsa.sɪn/ [Mississippi River] the longest and most voluminous river in Mendeva at over twenty hundred leagues, flowing south into the Gulf of the Arcabil [Gulf of Mexico] through Hasiny. 1704 < Mid 17C Welsh Bahassassin < Carovacian [Caddo] báhassássin "mother of rivers".

Cocain /kʊˈkəin/ [Cuba] the largest of the islands of the Arcabil [Caribbean], or the polity that occupies this region and part of mainland Mendeva. 1530, repurposing of the word's previous meaning of "an imaginary land of folklore with an abundance of food, drink and other pleasures". This dates back to the late 14C < French Cocagne, Lombard Cuccagna, of uncertain further origin. The term has been connected to Willem Dutch cúkye "small cake" < Classical German cōcoō "cake" and to Old Irish cucann "food ration" < Latin coquīna "kitchen", but both have issues of provenance.

174.2: de sanc ðus "horny"

de sanc ðus /de sank ðɪz/ [de saŋk ðɪz]
- hot-blooded, hot-tempered, heated, easily provoked to anger or excitement;
- passionate, ardent, zealous, fervent, given to strong expression of emotions;
- horny, lustful, torrid, beset by sexual feelings

Etymology: idiom attested from the seventeenth century, coined approximately at the same time as de sanc freit "cold-blooded, emotionless", literally meaning "of burning blood". The noun sanc "blood" descends directly from Latin sanguis "blood" (albeit from a Vulgar oblique form like sanguem rather than Classical sanguinem). The adjective ðus "on fire" is the past participle of now-archaic verb ðurr "burn (tr.), set on fire", which reflects Latin adūrō "I kindle, set fire to". In the last senses the phrase is attested from the nineteenth century.

I stima vos fosseð un hom troç e de sanc ðus.
/i stiˈma vɔz fɔˈsɛθ ɪn ɔm trɔts e de sank ðɪz/
[i stɪˈma vɔz fʊˈsɛ‿ðɪn ɔm tʀɔts e de saŋk ðɪz]

He thought you were fierce and hot-blooded.

174.3: bland "interesting"

bland /bland/ [bland]
- suave, debonair, urbane, affable, charming, of smooth and sociable demeanour;

- interesting, entertaining, compelling, engaging people's attention;

Etymology: Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Latin blandus "pleasant, agreeable; fawning, flattering". In the first senses the word originally had a somewhat negative or insincere connotation; by the eighteenth century the word is mostly seen in uncomplicatedly positive use.

174.4: plentivous "brimming"

plentivous /ˌplɛn.tiˈvuz/ [ˌplɛn.tɪˈvuz]
- brimming, awash, flush, overflowing, in such an abundance as to be almost too much;
- (in physics) charged, having an electrical charge;
- suspenseful, tense, thrilling, expectant, filled with the tension of awaiting an uncertain outcome or event

Etymology: late Middle Borlish, borrowed from French plentiveus "flush, rich". This is a derivation from plentif "abundant" and plenté "abundance", via Latin plēnitās "fullness" from plēnus "full". The emotional senses, attested from the seventeenth century, appear to evoke the danger of an overfull vessel. In scientific use the word is modelled on prior plentað "fullness; (physic) electric charge" (compare the analogous plentiful "charged" in Merch).

Sceye un ouç plentivous cant alcun hom parolau.

there.be-ipf indf silence awash when no person speak-pst
There was a tense silence before anyone spoke.

174.5: False Friends (cont.)

some more completely arbitrary dictionary entries from the Concise Onomatory o'Merch (fifth edition), a reference work published in 1961 and compiled by the Utcheter Lexical Association.

cockapple [/ˈkɔkˌa.pəl/ "apricot"] n. a stone fruit resembling the passock [peach] and in the plum group, with pink-yellow flesh and downy skin; the tree which bears this fruit; a colour or dye in the colour of this fruit. Late 17C, variant rationalised to usual Merch compounding patterns < late 15C applecock, variant by analogy to "apple" of apricock, abrecock < French abricoc < Barcelon abrecoc, albercoc < Morrove البرقوق • al-barqūq < Malchassian βερικοκκία • bericoccía < Latin (mālum) praecoquum "early-ripening apple".

handiwork [/ˈhan.dɪˌwɔːk/ "surgery"] n. the medical practice of using incisions to remove, replace or repair an internal part of the body; such an individual procedure; (archaic or jocular) any manual labour, work that is done by hand. 16C in the modern sense, possibly influenced by synonymous Welsh łodrinneth "hand-treatment" < Old English handȝeweorc "manual labour; handcraft, something made by hand", a compound of hand "hand" and ȝeweorc "piece of work".

ough [/uːf/ "bad"] adj. of low quality or standard; incorrect or mistaken; sickly or unwell; faulty or dysfunctional, clumsy or unskilled. Early Merch wough, woȝ [woːx] "wrong, incorrect" < Old English wōh, wōg "crooked, bent; wrong".

penguin [/pɪnˈgjəwɪn/ "pangolin"] n. any of several species of long-tailed and scaly ferents [mammals] found in tropical Africa and Asia; a game of cards played for money which originated in Bengal. Early 18C via earlier attestations in other European languages < Bāsan [Malay] penguwing "one who rolls". In the second sense, the word is a calque from Bengal bonoro "penguin, apparently named for a deck which featured art of a pangolin on some of the cards.

175.4: yemal "cool"

175.5: Stillian

collected notes on the subject of King Stillian, a medieval Borlish ruler.

Stillian of Borland (r. ca. 790–823 N, Borlish Stiglan /stajˈlan/) was king of Roman Borland in the late eighth and early ninth centuries. This so-called First Kingdom of Borland had grown out of the sub-Roman Diocese of Boral in the early medieval period, having become a monarchy in tandem with (and possibly influenced by) the new petty kingdoms settled by Germanic peoples in the west and south of the island of Borland.

Like all kings of Roman Borland, Stillian claimed to be descended from Victor Rossetus, the semi-mythic figure who united much of the land once external Roman authority receded in the fifth century. The name Stillian descends from Latin Hostīliānus, attested also as the name of a Roman emperor who ruled briefly in 251 N.

Stillian is primarily remembered for actions which put an end to the perennial Tripartite Wars and unifed the island under one polity for the first time since the Roman Empire. This term refers to a centuries-long series of conflicts over territory and fealty, principally between Roman Borland and the kingdoms of Southbar and Angland; by the eighth century these three powers controlled the vast majority of the island. Kings of Borland had made temporary alliances before with either of Southbar and Angland.

In 803, Stillian's son Marc was married to Alfegh of Angland's only child (variously recorded as Raunilt or Raunvig, likely from Old English hræfn "raven" and a name element like hild or wig "war, battle"). The two royal dynasties had been connected by marriage before, and this wedding allowed both kingdoms to claim continuity with the new unified polity. Approximately seven years later, Southbar was forced to pledge fealty to the new kingdom after the Battle of Fendal.

176.1: New Urban Mesh (cont.)

additional notes in translation on the subject of the New Urban Mesh, an alliance of autonomous cities in Northwest Europe in the nineteenth century.

Y citað ny Sar son alligað lonc y gentagl con y politic dell'entrlaçorant, tan com y benoç aggressionner e mondial de spionnaç. Interim, outrvaluð cos plausibr es diçr alcot y Sar aye (com bustr) y capabiltað de gournment nell'Aust dirigir por gra de lorry commarç.
The cities of the Mesh are popularly associated with wheeling-and-dealing policy, as well as aggressive and global use of espionage. However, the extent to which the Mesh was (for example) able to steer politics in the East to their trade benefit is likely overestimated.

Ny siecr novoç nuverrem, Londr amenau y Sar vars union cos politic con y Collujon Drengoçan, oc stant temporane un alleyanç smargent dy polity Fransc de Cantuer Norman, Paris e Borgogn. Ou vrayessem es digr ig y Sar denoy sousunt ny Collujon, ben ig y Sar broucau auteç dy Collujon, interman un souject closnautr de disputaçon ðus. 
In the late nineteenth century, London led the Mesh to unite politically with the Drengot Collusion, which at the time was a nascent alliance of the French polities of Norman Kent, Paris and Burgundy. Whether it is more correct to say that the Mesh was subsumed into the Collusion, or that the Mesh took control of the Collusion, has long been a topic of heated debate.

Sr Desarden, Prinç Nuçal (1968), un lasc font ayent des y scandal d'an 1887 atorn de James Desarden, l'ambasctour Londresc a Nacon Day. Creut cos general es ig l'oc affer aye raçon politic e se produghe des stancoranç prose par y Sar.
Mr Desarden, Prince Consort (1968), a film based on the 1887 scandal around James Desarden, London's ambassador to Nackon Day [~Thailand]. The affair is widely thought to have been politically motivated and a product of direct meddling from the Mesh.

176.2: n'impisantour "carefree"

n'impisantour /nɪmˌpi.zanˈtur/ [nɪmˌpi.zɐnˈtʊː]
- weightless, in freefall, accelerating due to gravitional forces alone;
- unencumbered, unburdened, not carrying any load;
- carefree, untroubled, unconcerned, not feeling any worry;
- insouciant, blithe, nonchalant, ignoring any potential concerns (perhaps recklessly or impolitely);

In extended use the word is attested from the late nineteenth century, with the slightly disparaging connotation established shortly thereafter.

176.3: jom "cobalt"

jom /ʒɔm/ [ʝɔm]
- cobalt, the corporal [element] with twenty-seven mora [protons] and which is a hard and lustrous silver-grey metal;
- deep blue, a colour produced from the ash [oxide] or chalk [carbonate] of this corporal (or a similar hue of any origin)

176.4: gevrment "circuitry"

gevrment /ˌgɛvr̩ˈmɛnt/ [ˌgɛ.vɐˈmɛnt]
- wiring, circuitry, a system of electrical components and their connections within a particular device;
- nitty-gritty, nuts and bolts, the (possibly figurative) inner workings of any object or concept;
- minutiae, intricacies, the (often trivial) tiny or precise details of a situation

Etymology: derivation with the gestalt suffix -ment < Latin -mentum from the noun gevr "electrical wire". This is a borrowing via synomous guèvre in Parisian from Welsh guivr "wire". In turn this appears to have been borrowed from Old English wīr "metal thread", likely influenced in form by guevr "amber" due to the latter's electrical properties. In metaphorical use the term is seen from the mid-twentieth century.

Don't be distracted by minutiae.

##

176.5: The Light that Casts a Thousand Shadows

The Light that Casts a Thousand Shadows (originally published in Borlish as Un Flam, Mil Ombr "1 Flame, 1000 Shadows") was a 2017 N work of pop history, economics and philosophy written by Ollamec Vamncoury and published by a subsidiary of the Peujon Rous (Red Dove) media guild.

Her book chronicles the duelling ideologies of Ubiquity and Vicinity, whose rivalry defined many of the greatest conflicts of the twentieth century and which together form the basis for most modern schools of political though. In broad strokes, Ubiquity stands for equality, universalism and homogeneity, while Vicinity valourises liberty, localism and diversity.

Despite various administrations' propaganda, neither ideology holds the undisputed moral high ground. Vicinity has been linked to the flourishing of regional languages and to the freedom to pursue nontraditional familial structures; it has also been used to justify the formation of ghettos and even ethnostates. Ubiquity has led to the toppling of truly oppressive hierarchies in the name of egalitarian redistribution of wealth and power; it has also marginalised and attempted to extirpate elements of society that do not fit into one of the many visions for society that leaders have propounded.

However, the point of Ollamec's work is in fact to complicate the idea that these two frameworks are naturally opposed and completely contradictory. She achieves this in part by noting the many times that similar policies have been justified by appeals to both Ubiquity and Vicinity in different times or places. For example, the modern Runeplate Body headquartered in Lengrod [Lviv] determines the global standard for glyphs in almost all known writing systems. This centralisation is undoubtedly Ubiquitous in nature, yet the inclusion of such a diversity of scripts is a far cry from post-Millstone Mashick [Mexico] and their ambitions of "one world language".

177.1: Laic Declarations

notes in translation on the Laic Declarations.

Y Declar Laic intermanen un series de document traitancer prodoit par un consegl tras tarmn de delegaçon des doçan plusour de polity ne Belgrad d'an 1850.
The Laic Declarations were a series of diplomatic documents produced by an international committee of delegations from several dozen polities in Belgrade in 1850.

L'ec document forgaurn un ossatur de lodrignað por religion statuer desjovar deur y foncçon administraçonnal de polity, e por y stat cas ley de gent a fieltað mendrancer.
These documents outlined procedures for uncoupling established religions from administrative state functions, and the legal status of people with minority faiths.

All'oc epoc, Belgrad sta sodal ny Citað Floyan, un alleyanç-federaç de picq polity autonom lonc y Floy Danau e sy confluyenç.
At this time, Belgrade was one of the Riverine Cities, an alliance-federacy of small independent states along the Danaw River and its tributaries.

L'ec citað ern leyað des y cendr dy Reyaum Danavan, oc stant sfondrað de façon spectacler posc y Var Theudesc Dovem ny dezein 1820.
These cities had risen from the ashes of the Kingdom of the Danaw, which had collapsed in spectacular fashion after the Second German War of the 1820s.

Cossy scient, Belgrad sta un amaçgat ðescant primal por doctrin novel cas religion e ley, ant un çaucr Promethean parnommað alligað ag commouð Desveyant eð un communtað tovaresc meg ovart.
As such, Belgrade was an early hotbed of new religious and legal thinking, with a renowned Promethean club associated with the Deviance movement and a semi-public tovarick [queer] community.

177.2: ubicqfeyar "promote"

ubicqfeyar /ˌi.bɪk.fiˈjar/ [ˌi.bɪkˈfjɐː]

177.3: soucorsour "lifeguard"

soucorsour /ˌsu.kɔrˈsur/ [ˌsu.kʊːˈsʊː]
- (historical) bodyguard, attendant, someone who protects a dignitary (often a monarch) from direct harm;
- lifeguard, lifesaver, an expert swimmer employed to rescue people at risk of drowning;
- (by extension) saviour, hero, someone who has just saved the speaker from a dangerous or embarrassing situation

Etymology: Middle Borlish, an agentive derivation from verb soucorrir "rescue, go and help, come to the aid of". This descends from Latin succurrō "I help, aid, succour", adapted synchronically to the etymological sou- "under" prefix and corrir "run" root. The historical sense had been out of use for approximately two centuries before the modern senses appear, and so the latter are presumably an independent rederivation.

Vos souspectað y soucorsour ou cas y vol?
/vɔz ˌsu.spɛkˈtaθ i ˌsu.kɔrˈsur u kaz i vɔl/
[vɔz ˌsu.spɪkˈta‿ði ˌsu.kʊːˈsʊː‿ʀu kaz i vɔl]
2p suspect-2p indf lifeguard q wrt df theft
Do you suspect the lifeguard of the theft?

##

177.4: destourmar "demob"

destourmar /ˌdɛ.sturˈmar/ [ˌdɛ.stʊːˈmɐː]
- demobilise, demob, to release from military service;
- decommission, sunset, shelve, to cease supporting the use of or to replace with an updated version;
- (jocular) let go, axe, fire, to dismiss from a position of employment

Etymology: early modern Borlish derivation from the root tourm "troop; barracks", which conflates contemporary French tourme "platoon" and Dutch torem "fort". The word has been used metaphorically of products since the mid-twentieth century, and is seen in jocular use from around the same time.

Jo me cou destourmað n'Avril d'an 1909.
/ʒo me ku ˌdɛ.sturˈmaθ naˈvrɪl dan mɪl nuf tsɛnt nuf/
/ʝo me ku ˌdɛ.stʊːˈmah nɐˈvʀɪl dan mɪl nuf tsɛn nuf/
1s rfl get.pst demob-p.pst in=April of=year 1909
I was demobbed in April 1909.

##

177.5: C is for Chronology

collected notes on features of the Boralverse alternate history that begin with the letter C.

Coscatl bint Inám (fl. 1869) was a Mashick [Mexican] astronomer. She was born in the then-young city of Moshtar [~San Francisco]; she received her further education at the University of Anawack [~Mexico City] and the nearby observatory at Chapel Hill [Chapoltepec]. As an astronomer, bint Inám is remembered for discovering and helping to name several astronomical objects. These include the moons of Mars, Dimus [Phobos] and Phobus [Deimos], and most famously the eighth-most distant planet of Janus [Neptune]. Furthermore, her calculations of the perceived timing of the jovial phares [Galiliean moons] in their transits of Jupiter helped to pin down the speed of light.

Crain (Bavarn /krɑːn/, Borlish Carniol /karˈnjɔl/) is a region of Central Europe, east of Furlain [Friuli] and north of Crovatia [Croatia]. During the Second Tetrarchy of the eleventh and twelfth centuries it was a march in the southeasternmost part of the German Empire, initially automonous but later subordinate to the Kingdom of Bavarn. It was prosperous at this time mostly due to trade into its coastal city of Trieste. During the German Secession of the thirteenth century, when many polities broke ties with the Roman Pope in favour of the (hastily established) Augsburg See, the then-duchy of Crain supported the Roman Papacy. This was likely more from pragmatism than religious fervour, as its western and southern neighbours were both partisan of Rome. Nonetheless, the region become an important Roman stronghold, and the base from which it undertook the Baptism of the North.

Cuonrat Aihuosc (fl. c8?, name often Latinised to Corradus Aevoscus) was the dubiously historical founder of the noble house of Avosche and namesake of the region of Avosche in Willemy [~Lotharingia]. His surname is of obscure origin; the first element presumably reflects Classical German ehu- "horse", while the second may be from suffix -iscas "-ish" (though the vowel is problematic).

178.1: The Romantic Wars

notes in translation on the Romantic Wars.

Y Rix Romannesc intermanen un cougl circonscreut cos flois de var, de smout e d'autr conflict tras Europ ec ayent loy fis a mesur atorn dy mojol dy siecr settoç.
The Romantic Wars were a loosely-circumscribed collection of wars, uprisings and other conflicts across Europe which took place through the middle of the seventeenth century.

Com un entertað il son cossirað parveg com y derran conflict vecinabr veram, dec ny siecr sevent tal rix de magntumn comportant volen y Novomont envouvr, e tan volen alleyanç abrangir entr y possenç n'Europ, Africa eð Asia cos parey.
As a whole they are sometimes considered the last truly localised conflicts, since by the next century wars of similar scales would begin to involve the Novomund, and would feature alliances between the powers of Europe, Africa and Asia alike.

L'ec an des 1640 vars 1670 afferjarn l'eç conflict 'central' dy Rix Romannesc, con tan certan abatment peripherallessem fonn paravent ben apres.
The years 1640 to 1670 cover the 'central' conflicts of the Romantic Wars, although some more peripheral fights may spill earlier or later.

L'envou d'Istr Boral cas y Rix Romannesc no sta limitað for an envajon imparyent den (ersteigon faint ag Capitulaçon a Haukirç d'an 1623), jos concort commotual con polity collindant sur auxigl militer por lorry concarnç.
Borland's involvement in the Romantic Wars was restricted to a failed invasion (culminating in the Hawkirch Surrender of 1623), along with unstable arrangements with neighbouring polities regarding military aid in their conquests.

178.2: locomoçon "travel"

locomoçon /ˌlo.ko.moˈtson/ [ˌlo.kʊ.mʊˈtsɔn]
- locomotion, motion, movement, the act or capability of changing position by going from one place to another;
- travel, the activity of going from place to place (usually when in a vehicle like a car or train);
- (physics) displacement, the vector quantity measuring the difference between two points in space

Etymology: sixteenth century, borrowed from Scholastic Latin locomōtiō "movement from place to place", from Classical Latin noun locus "place" and verb moveō "I move". The word is sometimes in technical contexts contrasted with moçon "motion of parts of a body relative to other parts". Its mathematical sense is attested from the eighteenth century as the vector counterpart of scalar lonctumn "length, distance".

Augrimeð y locomoçon entr y dou termin dy camin.
/ˌo.griˈmɛθ i ˌlo.ko.moˈtsɔn ɛntr̩ i du terˈmɪn di kaˈmɪn/
[ˌo.gʀɪˈmɛ‿ði ˌlo.kʊ.mʊˈtsɔn ˈɛn.t‿ʀi du tɪːˈmɪn di kɐˈmɪn]
compute-sbj.2p df travel between df two endpoint of-df way
Find the displacement between the path's endpoints.

178.3: malestr "discomfort"

malestr /maˈlɛstr̩/ [mɐˈlɛ.stɐ]
- unease, disquiet, concern, worry, a dissatisfaction with how things are unfolding;
- discomfort, soreness, irritation, issues with how one is physically feeling;
- bad mood, gloom, pessimism, a tendency to see things in the worst possible light;
- snit, moodiness, sulk, a propensity to displays of bad temper and impatience

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish malestre "discomfort". This was a compound of mal "bad", which descends from synonymous malus in latin, and estre "being, state" (a former infinitive of "be" since replaced by star), which descends from Latin essere "to be". The word has extended to cover various bad or unpleasant emotions, competing for space with hougr "fear, annoyance, discontent" < Latin augurium "omen, warning, foreboding".

No sceye l'hour por commorar ne malestr.
/no xiˈje lur pɔr ˌkɔ.moˈrar ne maˈlɛstr̩/
[no çiˈje lʊː pɔː ˌkɔ.mʊˈʀɐː ne mɐˈlɛ.stɐ]
ng there.be-ipf df=time for tarry in unease
There wasn't time to linger in discomfort.

178.4: y voç se hoccovar "clear one's throat"

y voç se hoccovar /i vɔts se ˌhɔ.koˈvar/ [i vɔts se ˌhɔ.kʊˈvɐː]
- clear one's threat, harrumph, to cough in order to make it easier to speak or to attract people's attention to you

Etymology: idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally "to cough the voice". The noun voç "voice" descends directly from synonymous vox, vocis in Latin. The verb hoccovar "cough" is a derivation from noun hocco "cough, ahem, hem-hem", thought to be of onomatopoeic origin.

Tu te hoccovau y voç e cou ouç.
/ti te ˌhɔ.koˈvo i vɔts e ku uts/
[ti te ˌhɔ.kʊˈvo i vɔts e ku uts]
2s 2s.obl ahem-pst df voice and fall-pst silence
You went "ahem" and silence fell.

##

178.5: Campottonì and Gorram

some notes on a pair of cities in New Provence, situated across a bay from each other.

Campottonì (Doccian /kãˌpɔ.tuˈni/; Merch /kɐmˈpɔ.tʊ.ni/) is a coastal city on the southern bank of the Guittoc [Delaware] river, in the Nappejoquin[1] region of New Provence. Founded in the late seventeenth century as a Provincial staddomain, it was intended to be a major trading port and to control the flow of goods along the Guittoc.

The second half of the placename reflects the Nappe term [Unami] utaney "city"; the first half is of obscure origin (clearly adapted to Doccian camp "field") but may be related to Nappe necama "first". In this case the toponym likely means "mother-city, home city"; compare the similar formation of μητρόπολῐς "metropolis" in Ancient Greek. 

The settlement languished through the eighteenth century due to unfavourable marshy terrain and the better harbours across the river and further inland. Fortunes changed in the nineteenth with an influx of funds: a major shipping canal across the peninsula (connecting the Guittoc to the wealthy Esquanna [Susquehanna] river system) was dug, and the marshlands surrounding Campottonì were drastically canalised and drained. Further widening of the canal took place into the twentieth century.

Briefly known as the "Venice of Mendeva [North America]", Campottonì gained a fashionable reputation during the Good Game Period [late 19C] and by the modern day had risen to become a cultural and economic powerhouse.

Gorram (Doccian /guˈram/; Merch /ˈgɔ.ɾəm/) is a coastal city on the northern bank of the Guittoc [Delaware] river, in the Nappejoquin region of New Provence. It had extremely humble beginnings as a single Provincial farmhouse or possibly a collection of pastures.

There are Provincial dialect terms gorra "goat" and gorram "herd of goats" cognate with cavra and cavram in standard Doccian—the suffix -am forming collective nouns descends from -(ā)men in Latin—and this is generally agreed to be the origin of the placename; compare the similar formation of Gotham (Merch /ˈgɔ.təm/), a village in Markland.

For a time in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, Gorram became by far the most important city on the river, having a better natural harbour. It also participated in the convoy [train, rail] craze of the mid-nineteenth century, being the terminus of an arterial line to the northeast.

Even into the twentieth century Gorram was a major hub of industry on a par with Campottonì. However, by the modern day a lack of infrastructural investment in its own drained land and an inability to deindustrialise gracefully had led the city to become much poorer than its counterpart across the bay.

[1] approximately the watersheds of the Delaware and the lower Hudson.

179.1: The Duke of Dark Corners

excerpt in translation from The Duke of Dark Corners (originally published in Welsh as Dug y Gilfah Dowł, meaning the same thing), an 1884 work of historical parachthony [speculative fiction] by author Taguen ah Owain. Her alternate version of the Medieval Imperia (a period of European and circum-Mediterranean centralisation in the eleventh and twefth centuries) features an entirely fictitious set of empires ruled not from Paris, Bardwick, Stamboul and Cairo [1], as in reality, but instead from Damvath [capital of Borland], Florence, Tanger and Kiew.

Y nievr mattin se penen sur y pil n'ollem dy havan cant Fraðr Aldric folla un camin tras y rout bassem ny citað caver.
The morning mist clung to the harbor's elmwood quays as Brother Aldric made his way through the lower streets of the capital.

Le dessur, y gran tour cas y cancelry imperial faye gavlot ny ciel gris com un aguil ne pieðr, sy gonfan drappeyan sou y vent saleyað souvolant ne haut des ec aug Rustighan.
Above him, the great tower of the imperial chancery pierced the grey sky like a stone needle, its banners snapping in the salt wind that swept up from the Rustigh waters.

A cost dell'oç edifiç imposant, yon autr annað y pentis de pescour ayen y rif parsemnað, sceyen aglon sdroy plen de seð Toscan e d'arom Morrou, ant ossatur d'egnam fosc des ançantað e roçon a mar.
Beside that imposing edifice, where once fishermen's huts had dotted the shoreline, now stood warehouses filled with Tuscan silk and Morrove spices, their timber frames dark with age and sea-spray.

Un marcant ne vestið Flamesc er travodant a haut voç contr un maistr de quarf sur y pisantour de sy carc.
A merchant in Flemish cloth was loudly haggling with a dock-keeper over the weight of his cargo.

Aldric tirau sy rob broun a sarraðessem atorn dy spal e tenoy a descendr sur peyan sdruçollabr.
Aldric pulled his brown robe closer about his shoulders and continued downhill over slick cobblestones.

===

[1] The Medieval Imperia, or Second Tetrarchy, comprised: the First Drengot Empire ruled from Paris; the German Empire often ruled from Bardwick [Bardowick, Lower Saxony]; the Second Roman Empire ruled from Stamboul [Istanbul]; the Single Caliphate ruled from Cairo.

179.2: martelment "thud"

martelment /ˌmar.tɛlˈmɛnt/ [ˌmɐː.tɪlˈmɛnt]
- hammering, pounding, the act of hitting something with a blunt implement;
- thud, thump, whack, knock, the sound made by a blunt collision;
- emphasis, accent, stress, focus, drawing attention to something particular

Etymology: noun derivation from martellar "hammer, pound; emphasise, accentuate", which itself comes from noun martel "hammer". This descends from Late Latin martellus "hammer", a variant diminutive of synoymous marculus in Classical Latin. This term developed its metaphorical senses in tandem with the verb, during the late Middle Borlish period.

J'ama y martelment sur huyaç nell'oraçon.

179.3: çosc "stubby"

çosc /tsɔx/ [tsɔx]
- stubby, notably short and thick;
- shortened, docked, cut short, stunted, made shorter or prevented from growing longer;
- squat, stocky, (of a person) short and solidly built;
- thick, broad, relatively great in extent across its shortest solid dimension

Etymology: adjectival use of Old Borlish noun çosc "stump of a tree", which was a variant (likely borrowed from çoche in Old French) of native cognate çoc "stump". These descend from Vulgar Latin tsucca "stump, trunk", though to come via Gaulish from Classical German stuccas "stick, beam; stump". The word was replaced in its noun use by taisc "stump", possibly from Latin taxeus "made of yew wood".

Jo fey pat ag cla con deit çosc.
/ʒo fi pat ɛi kla kɔn dit tsɔx/
[ʝo fi pat ɛi kla kɔn dit tsɔx]

I fumbled the key with stubby fingers.

179.4: indagour "sleuth"

indagour /ˌɪn.daˈgur/ [ˌɪn.dɐˈgʊː]
- investigator, detective, sleuth, a person employed to discover things that are unknown or hidden;
- tracker, tracer, a person or tool that keeps an eye on where someone or something is;
- analyser, scanner, any tool that extracts information from a source

Etymology: agentive derivation from verb indagar "track, investigate, scan, analyse", which is a sixteenth-century borrowing from Latin indāgō "I track, trace; I investigate". The word was used only for people until the late nineteenth century, when the word was extended to various devices able to autonomously track or analyse things.

Nos ayau l'indagour scos ne sell'azig.

We'd hidden the tracker in his shoe.

180.1: The Kernovan Conjuring

notes in translation on the subject of the 1029 Kernovan Conjuring, by which Normandy  conquered Kent.

Con tan alcun bustr tesmogn d'un concort scaut sein survescuð, presunt es ig y Majon de Cornou soloy droug a Normandy par lorry gimmolt ag thron Cantuer com troc contr denir y novel dynasty regnant sur Magn Dorogn.
Although no references to a written treaty have survived, it is presumed that the House of Kernow aided Normandy in their bid for the Kentish throne in exchange for support in becoming the new ruling dynasty of Greater Devon.

L'oc squid er mantenuð, ma cayen for un per de dezein pre Magn Dorogn denoy un vassal sou y Preu Empir Drengoçan.

L'er coronnað com Emperour Roger I durant l'oc spanjon cas eiðel d'an 1038.

180.4: alçor "advanced"

alçor /alˈtsɔr/ [ɐlˈtsɔː]

180.5: 19th Century Novels

summaries of a few works of fiction set in the nineteenth century.

The Red Man (originally in Bulgar as Мaжaт вЧервено "The Man in Red") is a fright tale written by Petcov in 1830s Sreddies [Sofia] and set a decade earlier. This is the aftermath of the Second German War and the concomitant disintegration of the Kingdom of the Danaw [Danube]. The book features newly-independent Boxa [Novi Sad], the recovering shell of Stamboul [Istanbul], and many of the cities of the region which would eventually band together to form the so-called "Riverine Cities". The Red Man has heroes trying to decipher the mysterious figure known as Zechariah, a vampire; this work codified many of the tropes of the vampire, such as fire, blood and butterflies.

Rasgatto (originally in Zahid Russian as Разгадто "Unknotting") is a mystery romance of the 1870s written by Olexi Harchenko in Boxa. The work was sufficiently popular that its title was borrowed into Venise Italian to mean "resolution of a mystery" and later simply "dénouement"; subsequently the term made it into many European languages.

Flaxen Hearts (originally in Mostara as Querdos Llineros "Flaxen Hearts") is a 1919 sensation trevold [novel] in the nascent genre of social comedy popularised by the lovetales of Clarissa Bellamy and the adolescences of Dorotha Quistack, among others. The author Judeta Barracin wrote the work after returning from living for many years in the Arcabil [Caribbean]. It is set in the early nineteenth century and follows the petty dramas of a group of siblings in Cordova [Cordoba].

Earthly Scene (originally in Vascon as Vista Terrena "Landscape") is a trevold first published in 1809 by Antòin Herrel in the Vascon city of Santander. It was almost immediately banned on charges of obscenity, and only survived due to Herrel's flight to Portsmouth, where he published the word in Kentish under his new appellation Tony Smith (presumably aided in the translation by his companion Hal Brennan). The original manuscript was eventually published in 1870, some years after his death.

181.1: Political Address

excerpt in translation from 2023 diplomatic thriller Follow Suit (originally in Borlish as Pengovin Pardr "Losing at Bezique"), written by author Jan Bervisson (better known for host roles on several TV and radio shows).

"Houm", ençau y directour, oc clugnant sou y lamp ny scenoir.
"Uh," the president began, blinking under the studio lights.

"Lonc y contris derran des y foncçondry, l'oc droughanç porçonmenter se tien fagl entr y tarmn dy Cartr. Y grinment de rebondisc dy Minister a Feu indic cos clar ig scerraun meglfacçon cas aðoinç a lonc mesur."
"According to the agency's latest report, this fiscal intervention remains well within the Charter's terms. The impact review from the Minstry for Land clearly indicates future improvements in long-term growth."

Jo le remarcau cant y Scavin Yara se commoveu, ant un min illeibr. Plausibr i sta a desaiç, noc obstroint i s'alignaus ac cos usual.
I noticed Councillor Yara shift in her seat, her expression unreadable. She was likely concerned, despite her typical alignment.

Le dereðr, y reu de novel colau par ouç tras y mur: racont d'un kerel cas collujon de hamtaçon e dell'evolganç de pistol des l'ambit n'Ausbagn.
Behind her, the newsstream scrolled silently across the wall: stories of a housing compact dispute and leaked correspondence from the Axbane office.

Un jurist quidam oc l'administraçon astuçant cos actual s'entrjey; par sy vagscrit soutil i digna Vellamn.
Some attorney currently advising the administration spoke up; his unobtrusive nameplate read Vellamn.

"Nossell'empory es monfeyant, or zizania entr Feu e Famigl apportn ja lorry vandy. Scey bustr tesmogn d'irruniscabiltað—stant parcanç outrley."
"Our economy is growing, but conflict between Land and Family does present issues. There’s evidence of irregularities—possibly criminal."

Un scavour jos ados hellovaçau, "Toll'oc no's for plouçastr d'annað a slecçon ou?"
A journalist near the back called out, "Isn’t this just election-year theatre?"

181.2: alligar "relate"

alligar /ˌa.liˈgar/ [ˌa.lɪˈgɐː]
- associate, relate, link, connect, to note resemblances or relevance of one thing to other things;
- compare, set against, juxtapose, to examine the similarities and differences between;
- match, correlate, to make the parts of two things or collections correspond

Etymology: Middle Borlish, borrowed from Latin alligō "I bind to, tie, fetter". Thus, this word is a doublet of inherited alleyar "ally, collaborate, partner". Formerly used for physical ties and links (as related ligar "bind, bandage" still is), but now restricted to abstract usage.

Ma comoscon l'oc alligar con melodram?
/ma ˌko.moˈxɔn lɔk ˌa.liˈgar kɔn ˌme.loˈdram/
[ma ˌko.mʊˈxɔn lʊ‿ˌga.liˈgɐː kɔn ˌme.lʊˈdʀam]
but however df=s.px link-inf with musical
But how does this relate to musicals?

181.3: harneisar "exploit"

harneisar /ˌhar.niˈsar/ [ˌhɐː.nɪˈzɐː]
- equip, wield, take up, wear, to pick up and affix to one's grip or person somehow;
- exploit, use, make use of, utilise, to put to some employment to one's or another's advantage

Etymology: Middle Borlish verbal derivation from harneis "equipment, gear, tackle". This descends via Drengot French from Old Norrish hernest, a compound of herr "army" and nest "provisions". As such, the word was restricted to military contexts until the sixteenth century.

Nos harneisaum graivet e gant.
/nɔz ˌhar.niˈzom greˈvɛt e gant/
[nɔz ˌhɐː.nɪˈzom gʀɪˈvɛt e gant]
1p use-pst-1p greave and glove
We put shinpads and gloves on.

181.4: sgranfeyar "crunch"

sgranfeyar /ˌsgran.fiˈjar/ [ˌzgʀaɱˈfjɐː]
- crunch, crush, to put pressure on and thus cause to make a diffuse noise of breaking;
- grind, pulverise, to reduce to small pieces with noise and often violence;
- munch, chew, chomp, to eat noisily

Etymology: seventeenth century, derived from the root gran "grain, seed" with the somewhat-pejorative prefix s- < Latin ex- "out" and the factitive suffix -feyar < Latin -ficō "I make". The word was first used to refer to eating a century after its first attestation.

J'er un pom sgranfeyant cos pegr.
/ʒɛr ɪn pɔm ˌsgran.fiˈjant kɔz pijr̩/
[ʝɛː‿ʀɪm pɔm ˌzgʀɑɱˈfjant kɔz ˈpɪ.jɐ]
1s=cop.ipf indf apple crunch-p.prs adv idle
I was idly munching on an apple.

##

181.5: Chronicles of Kilshaw

The Kilshaw writers' collective were a group of Merch authors who all lived in or around Kilshaw [Culcheth], a village in the northwestern part of Markland. The group was active through the middle decades of the twentieth century, and is remembered mainly for several long-running series of children's books. These, including the Joke Tawyer adventures, the Emma and Matt mysteries and the Samborn Sisters fancies, helped to redefine the landscape of children's publishing in Markland and beyond. The Kilshaw series have been translated into dozens of languages, and many have been adapted to formats such as sobot [radio] or phasm [television].

A brother and sister pair, Kenna and Holcroft Strong, began collaborating on stories in the early 1930s. They, along with author friends picked up in university and later from literary circles in Safford, would go on to form the Kilshaw collective.

Stories from Kilshaw made an industry of aping, parodying or homaging trends and fads in adult literature, telling tales in genres like masquira, social comedy or voidtale that happen to feature child protagonists. Originally played mostly for comic effect or as entertainment for parents, later works tended to take their premises more seriously and (especially in books aimed at older children) explored more realistic consequences of their events.

Kilshaw is one of the smaller settlements in the intercity borough of Makerfell [Makerfield], west of Safford [Salford]. Its variable pre-reform spellings (including Kilchath and Culshet) point to its etymology in British Celt terms cul "narrow" or cil "corner" and coed "woodland". This makes the placename a likely cognate of other toponyms like Colquiet in Devon and Culgod in Hasiny. The village has become a minor tourist destination for families or for the literary-minded, with a museum and regular fetes themed around Kilshaw characters (costumes, reenactments, etc).

182.2: broðoquin "gibberish"

broðoquin /ˌbro.ðoˈkwɪn/ [ˌbʀo.ðʊˈkwɪn]
- gibberish, gobbledegook, nonsense, babble, double Dutch, speech without meaning;
- bullshit, tosh, balderdash, poppycock, blatant falsehoods

Etymology: fourteenth century with various spellings, originally meaning "the language of non-Borlish speakers on Borland, especially of the northern Norse speakers". Both Norse and English languages had been spoken for several centuries on the north and west of the island, respectively. The word is presumed to be an adaptation of the Borland Norse phrase broð oc vin "bread and wine" (the alternative broðr oc ven "brother and friend" is considered less plausible).

Jo vay noc a l'ec broðoquin scoutar.
/ʒo ve nɔk a lɛk ˌbro.ðoˈkwɪn xuˈtar/
[ʝo ve nɔg a lɛg ˌbʀo.ðʊˈkwɪn xʊˈtɐː]
1s go ng to df=p.px BS listen-inf
I don't have to listen to this bullshit.

182.3: pat fair "fumble"

pat fair /pat fer/ [pat feː]
- fumble, paw, to handle with clumsy hands;
- bungle, botch, mishandle, to deal with (a situation) poorly;

Etymology: idiomatic phrase attested from the fifteenth century, literally "to do paws" in reference to the unsuitability of many animal's paws for holding things. The noun pat "paw; (colloq.) hand, foot" descends from Vulgar Latin patta "paw", a borrowing from Frankish related to English "pad". In metaphorical use the phrase is seen from the seventeenth century.

L'agathin a pat fait sad ag tourf.
/ˌla.gaˈθɪn a pat fet sad ɛi turf/
[ˌla.gɐˈθɪn a pat fet sad ɛi tʊːf]
df=minister have paw do-p.pst badly to.df riot
The minister mishandled the riot.

182.4: mensc "politeness"

mensc /mɛnx/ [mɛŋx]
- (obsolete) honour, dignity, the state of being worthy of esteem;
- (archaic) mercy, kindness, relenting from causing or forbearing to cause harm;
- (dated, poetic or jocular) politeness, etiquette, manners, courtesy, decorum, appropriate social behaviour

Usage note: nowadays principally in the idiom sy mensc eð y mansc tenir "have it both ways".

Etymology: from Old Borlish mensc "praiseworthiness, repute, fame". This was borrowed from Old Norrish mennska "humanity", a descendant of Classical German manniscas "human". The semantic shift via honourable actions to general good behaviour was complete by the seventeenth century. The modern phrase literally means "to keep one's manners and one's food", in reference to being a good host while not actually offering anything to eat. It is first attested in a book of proverbs by an anonymous author of the late eighteenth century.

Orruð i crey poðir sy mensc eð y mansc tenir.
/ɔˈrɪθ i kri poˈðɪr si mɛnx ɛθ i manx teˈnɪr/
[ʊˈʀɪ‿ði kʀi pʊˈðɪː si mɛŋx ɛ‿ði maŋx tɪˈnɪː]
seem 3s believe can-inf 3s.gn manners and df food hold-inf
He seems to think he can have it both ways.

##

182.5: Writing in the 1880s

notes on several works of writing published during the 1880s.

Pasti Mezziterreni is an 1880 mealbook which compiles recipes from around the Middlesea [Mediterranean]. It was authored by Josforo Sant'Angelo (or at least on his behalf), a traveller from Tuscany who had already garnered significant renown due to his travels, including a near-fatal circumnavigation. The book doubles as an itinerary of a continuous sunward journey along the Middlesea coast from Tarifa in Andalus to X̀r l Joas in Morrack [Ksar es-Seghir, Morocco]. Dozens of translations were published over the subsequent years, including a bilingual Kernish–Wessern [minority Welsh and English languages] version by Iscombe Editors in 1892.

Cludor ncar Vantel "A Postman in Wrexham" is an 1882 trevold parachthon trevold [SFF novel]. It chronicles the misadventures of the titular postman who becomes trapped experiencing the same week over and over. It is notable for being the origin of the Welsh phrase speid dolenu "time loop, lit. coiling timespan", which has been calqued into many other language (compare e.g. liesc bouclant in Borlish).

Dug y Gilfah Dowł "The Duke of Dark Corners" is an 1884 word of historical parachthony by Taguen ah Owain. Set in the twelfth century, she depicts a fictious tetrad of empires controlling Europe and the circum-Middlesea, ruled respectively from Damvath [Borland's capital], Florence, Tanger [Tangier] and Kiew [Kyiv].

L'Aragn "The Spider" is an 1887 play written by Borlish playwright Osctra Jeichey, which has had several touring productions and adaptations to film. The play is about a group of people manipulated by a genius mastermind whose plots eventually collapse in dramatic fashion. A notable version of the play is the 1930 New Provincial version La Rogna, a loose retelling which swapped the sex of many of the characters. The protagonist remained a woman, giving the film tovaric [gay] subtext rather unusual for New Provence at this time.

The first installments of Monstres per Mans "Man-Made Monsters" were published in 1888 by Carmel fi Domenc. This was a serial work of parachthon and fright fiction which would continue until 1903. The episodes appeared in the Santrafew [~Boston] periodical Arcans Exumaz "Revealed Mysteries", which Carmel fi Domenc also co-owned with her brother Jered.

Murro Mendeva "The Making of Mendeva" is a historical textbook which narrativises the early exploration and settlements by Vetomundine [Old World] groups in Mendeva [North America]. Written in 1888 by In mac Harlach, an Irish Welshman, it has been roundly criticised as an inaccurate and blinkered polemic against the concepts of alliance and integration with the original Mendevan peoples and nations. It reveals the influence of a resentful bloc in Britain which saw the rise of Hasiny as a threat.

183.2: teun "scant"

teun /taun/ [taun]
- scant, scanty, meagre, not in any great quantity;
- insufficient, paltry, not at all enough;
- rare, scarce, very uncommon;
- rarefied, thin, (of a gas) of low density

Etymology: via Old Borlish tiun, tieun "thin" from Latin tenuis "slight, weak". Thus, this word is one of the only pieces of evidence as to the development of post-stress /-w-/ (following a non-velar consonant) from Latin into Borlish. The semantic shift to senses relating to insufficiency is evidenced from the early Middle Borlish period.

L'oc aer es teun neðan nos respireu.
/lɔk ar ɛz taun neˈðan nɔz ˌrɛ.spiˈrau/
[lʊˈgɐː‿ʀɪz taun nɪˈðan nɔz ˌʀɛ.spɪˈʀau]
df=s.px air be scant lest 1p breath-sbj.1p
This air's too thin for both of us to breathe.

183.3: gaviscenç "festivities"

gaviscenç /ˌga.viˈxɛnts/ [ˌga.vɪˈçɛnts]
- festivities, celebration, gala, party, a social gathering for entertainment and fun;
- revelry, merrymaking, mafficking, frolic, the act of having fun at such an event

Etymology: sixteenth century, a noun formation from the verb gavir "rejoice, have fun". This descends from Latin gaudeō "I make merry". Originally the word often referred specifically to the celebration of religious holidays or feast days.

Vos vouð uncos special accommettr por y gaviscenç ou?
/vɔz vuθ ɪnˈkɔz speˈtsjal ˌa.kɔˈmɛtr̩ pɔr i ˌga.viˈxɛnts u/

183.4: nis tenir "be at fault"

nis tenir /nɪz teˈnɪr/ [nɪz tɪˈnɪː]
- be responsible, take responsibility, to be the ultimate cause of something;
- be at fault, be liable, take the blame, to have something bad attributed to one;
- more generally, to be the origin or driving force behind something

Etymology: idiom from the seventeenth century, originally seen in legal contexts, literally "to hold effort". The noun nis "effort, vigour; force; obligation; attention" comes from Old Boral nis, neȝs, niȝs et al. "effort, vigour", which descends uncomplicatedly from Latin nīxus, nīsus "strain, forward momentum". This is the participle of deponent verb nītor "I lean on, advance, strive, contend".

Cu tendra nis ac?
/ki tɛnˈdra nɪz ak/
[ki tɪnˈdʀa nɪz ak]

183.5: Defining the Dime

excerpt from the work Pa's Hyd Raf? "How Long is a Piece of String?", written in 2026 as a series of freely available posts on the mesh by Łew ab Ennis, which delves into the history of the development of systems of weights and measures.

…originally defined the "second" simply as the eight-and-sixty-four hundredth part of the mean solar day, but by the end of the nineteenth century it had been observed that this period would vary by as much as a few hundred scant (10⁻⁸). In search of a stabler value, the Secular Second Undertaking set several astronomical groups worldwide to record the precise length of the tropical year from the summer solstice of 1900 until that of 1901, and defined the "(secular) second" to be the 3155,6926th part of this timespan.

While time has always had a single fundamental base in the dime measure system, other quantities are less simple. The dime principle that all quantities should be related by factors of ten did not prevent a proliferation of standards. Length has four basic units in common usage: a league is a hundred chains, a chain a hundred feet, a foot ten inches. Units of area and volume are defined by squares and cubes of the base lengths. For example, the farthing (formerly defined as one quarter of an acre) is equal to a square chain.

In the first decades of the twentieth century, the foot was still officially defined as the length of a particular rod of iron-baxon [nickel] alloy kept in Tammombay [Mumbai]. In 1946 the foot was redefined in terms of the second, so that the normal speed œ [lightspeed] would be precisely 10,0000,0000 feet per second. This locked the precision of the foot to that of the second. Subsequent refinements have primarily come in the form of particular sources of light, whose spans [wavelengths] or equivalently cadences [frequencies] can be pinpointed extremely accurately.

The basic units of heft [mass] in the dime measures—the scruple, ounce, tabre and ton—were originally defined in terms of the density of water. To wit, the ounce was set as the mass of a cube of distilled water of side length one (dime) inch; this was later refined to specify that the water should be at its threshold point [triple point]. In practice, due to the difficulty of operationalising the water-based definition to more than a hundred-scant precision, by the 1920s the tabre (100 ounces) was fixed to a particular joracker [platinum] alloy puck weighing a tabre (one hundred ounces)…

===

Real-life comparisons:
1 dime second ~= 1 second - 0.84 nanoseconds

1 dime foot ~= 29.98 centimetres, 0.9836 feet

1 farthing ~= 0.08988 hectares, 0.2221 acres

1 dime ounce ~= 26.94 grams, 0.9502 ounces

1 tabre ~= 2.694 kilograms, 5.939 pounds

184.1: North America in the 19th Century

notes on British Mendeva [a region of NA which formed much fo the northern edge of the Gulf of Mexico].

Mendeva Brittanesc sovra Brittan cas pouvlanç e laboriostur durant l'eç annað final ny siecr novoç.
British Mendeva overtook Britain in population and industry in the latter years of the nineteenth century.

Nentamen, jusc hour entarn Brittan poðe un eðegl de vry cultural vardir.
Nonetheless, for some time Britain retained a position of cultural cachet.

Soumis es paravant ig l'oc dau impet all'adopçon hastous ne Mendeva Brittanesc dy moraltað dy Renovellaçon Famigler (ne comparaçon contr Nou Provenç e Mascic magn mejoncherrem, com bustr) nell'oc epoc.
It has been suggested this contributed to British Mendeva's rapid adoption of the ethics of the Household Renovation (as compared to much more ambivalent New Provence and Mashick, for instance) during this time.

Impar nell'eç siecr ançan, ny siecr novoç sceye tramigraçon remarcabr dy select entr Mendeva Brittanesc e Brittan, tan com mariðaç entrig magn monfeyað.
Unlike earlier centuries, the nineteenth century saw significant transmigration of the élites between British Mendeva and Britain, as well as much more intermarriage.

Cos parçal se poð l'oc ascreir a nuvr alcot sta un select autochthon sceint ovest dell'Atlantic, ma majortaðer l'oc se mantien for deut a vascel raudessem e donc aðendr magn abrejað.
In part this can be attributed to the newness of an autochthonous élite west of the Atlantic, but mostly this is simply due to faster ships and greatly-reduced travel times.

184.2: veðrdon "prize"

veðrdon /ˌvɛð.r̩ˈdɔn/ [ˌvɛ.ðɐˈdɔn]
- prize, award, honour, a reward striven for in a competition or which may be won by chance;
- trophy, cup, an object (often a statuette or vessel) commemorating one's victory in a competition;

Etymology: the descendant of Old Borlish veðerdon "payment, reward", which comes from synonymous widerdōnum in Medieval Latin. This is a borrowing from Germanic (cf. Old English wiþerlēan "recompense", literally "counter-reward"), which the second part calqued as Latin dōnum "gift". Compare the Old French cognate guerredon "payment; spoils, booty, loot", whose first element was also adjusted to guerre "war". Conflation with unrelated Borlish veðr < Latin vitrum "glass" may have influenced the traditional concept of a trophy as made of glass or crystal.

I tenoy sy veðrdon n'oc ort e soureyeu.
/i teˈnɔj si ˌvɛð.r̩ˈdɔn nɔk ɔrt e ˌsu.riˈjau/
[i tɪˈnɔj si ˌvɛ.ðɐˈdɔn nʊˈgɔːt e ˌsu.ʀɪˈʝau]
3s hold-pst 3s.gn prize in=s.px rise and smile-pst
She held up her trophy and grinned.

184.3: adolescenç "bildungsroman"

adolescenç /ˌa.do.leˈxɛnts/ [ˌa.dʊ.lɪˈçɛns]
- adolescence, teenagerhood, the period of life between childhood and adulthood;
- coming of age, maturation, the process or event of becoming an adult;
- sweet sixteen, quinceañera, bat/bar mitzvah (etc.), any of several customary ceremonies performed in various cultures to mark a person coming of age;
- bildungsroman, coming-of-age story, a genre of tales about the growth (in several senses) of characters from children to adults

Etymology: Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Scholastic Latin adolēscentia "maturation, growing up", nominal derivative of Classical verb adolēscō "I grow up, become an adult". In the meaning of a type of tradition, the word is a clipping of former phrase rit d'adolescenç "coming-of-age rite". The term was first used for the literary genre in the early 20C to describe the works of London author Dorotha Quistack.

Cay un adolescenç a them d'alumn ne Tecamau.
/ke ɪn ˌa.do.leˈxɛnts a θɛm daˈlɪmn̩ ne ˌte.kaˈmo/
[ke ɪn ˌa.dʊ.lɪˈxɛns a θɛm dɐˈlɪ.mɐn ne ˌte.kɐˈmo]
fall indf teens at topic of=schoolkid in Tecamaw
It's a coming-of-age tale about Tecamaw schoolkids.

184.4: dom "dome"

dom /dɔm/ [dɔm]
- dome, cupola, the architectural feature of a hollow upper half-sphere on the roof of a building;
- (mathematics) hemisphere, the surface of half a sphere;
- pate, crown, the top of the head (especially when hairless)

Etymology: originally in the first sense, from Middle Borlish dom "dome; stately building, edifice" (now obsolete in the latter senses). This comes from the conflation of Italian duomo "cathedral", from Latin domus ecclēsiae​ "meeting-house, church", with French dosme "dome", which comes via Late Latin dōma "roof" from Greek δῶμᾰ "house, housetop". The merger, which had likely already occurred in Middle French before the term entered Borlish, was aided by the prominence of domes on Italian cathedrals.

Com s'augrim y stent a starn d'un dom lonc sy ray?
/kɔm soˈgrɪm i stɛnt a starn d'ɪn dɔm lɔnk si re/
[kɔm sʊˈgʀɪm i stɛnt a stɐːn dɪn dɔm lɔŋk si ʀe]
how rf=calculate df area at outside of=df dome along 3s.gn radius 
What is a hemisphere's surface area in terms of its radius?

184.5: A Worldwide Web

various features of the Boralverse beginning with W.

War without Walls is a textbook of military history by Ajamarn [~Rajasthani] scholar Indvar Vijarrania, written in the early twentieth century during his tenure at the University of Udjén [Ujjain]. He chronicles the development of military strategy in the wake of the advent of cannon and other explosives, and in particular how these technologies obsoleted the formerly dominant strategy of defence via walled fortifications.

Wessern (Merch /ˈwɛ.sɐn/, Wessern Wesseron /wəsˈsɛɾən/, Welsh Sasneg /sɐˈznɛg/, Borlish Wessaxon /ˌvɛ.sakˈsɔn/) is the language of the English minority living in Britain [~Wales, etc], primarily in eastern Devon and the downstream Severn. It is the third-most spoken English language on Albion [Great Britain], after Merch and Kentish, although it also has significant populations of speakers abroad in British Mendeva [NA] and elsewhere. Wessern features geminate consonants and the simplification of coda clusters (compare Merch dark /daːk/ to Wessern darick /ˈda.ɾək/ "dark"), as well as fricative voicing between vowels and at the start of words.

Winchester Scholastic Primers are a publishing company which have operated in Kent since the early twentieth century. They have produced works principally of academic or educational interest, with several works used regularly in schools. Books from this publishing house include:
- The Alphabetical Albion (1920), by a consortium including Lucas Osborne
- A Comprehensive Cyclopædia of Pre-Fracture Europe (1937), written by Martin and Elisabeth Forman and illustrated by Goffrey Jordan
- In Sickness and in Health: Medicine in pre-Arnoutszen Europe (2nd ed. 1961), by Andrew Knowles with foreword by Dr Laura Norris

Wolfston the Younger (fl. ca. 930 N) was the last English king of Northumber before the rump state was folded into the Dane territory ruled from Yorwick [York]. Northumber had controlled lands as far south as Yorwick until the ninth century, when that city became the first major settlement in England conquered during the Dane Supremacy. According to the Carlile chronicle, Wolfston's short reign ended ignominiously and without issue at the fortifications in Edinbrough, when those too were captured by Dane forces.

185.2: pestriçon "formation"

pestriçon /ˌpɛ.striˈtsɔn/ [ˌpɛ.stʀɪˈtsɔn]
- formation, development, emergence, creation, genesis, the process during which something comes into being;
- assembly, arrangement, shape, form, configuration, structure, layout, the manner in which something is physically composed in space

This is a direct descendant from Vulgar Latin pistriō "I knead", from Classical Latin pistor "baker, miller". 185.3: a cascun "respectively"

a cascun /a kaˈxɪn/ [a kɐˈçɪn]
- each, apiece, (e.g. of a price) for an individual item from a set;
- per head, per capita, (of a statistic) divided by the population of the region in question;
- respectively, corresponding in the order given when comparing two lists of things;
- pointwise, (in mathematics) occuring or true independently for each point in a set

Etymology: literally "to each one", in idiomatic use attested from the twelfth century. The pronoun cascun "each one" descends directly from Vulgar Latin cascūnum "each one", a conflation of Classical quisque ūnum and Late Latin cata ūnum "each one". The phrase's use extended beyond financial and census-taking contexts through the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

185.4: bastegl "bulwark"

bastegl /baˈstɪjl/ [baˈstɪjl]
- fortress, fortification, a strongly built and defended military structure or enclosure used in warfare;

- bulwark, defence, something that serves as a shield or protection against danger or attack;

##

185.5: England

notes on the geographical region of England.

England (Merch /ˈɛn.glənd/, Norman Engleterre /ˈɛ̃ng.tɛʀ/, Welsh Łoegr /ˈɬoː.gə/, Borlish Larry /laˈʀi/) is the name of a loosely demarcated region of Albion [Great Britain]. In the modern day England may be defined politically to be the territory of Northumber, Markland, London and (Albic) Kent; it may also be defined linguistically to be the part of Albion inhabited by communities of speakers of English languages. The latter definition is more expansive, due to the many Wessern speakers in eastern Devon and Merch speakers in eastern Wales.

The majority of languages not listed above refer to this region by some borrowing or adaptation of Medieval Latin Anglōnia "England". This was formed by analogy to e.g. Saxōnia "Saxony" from the root Anglī "Angles", one of the German peoples who populated the region in the sub-Roman and early medieval period. The exceptional Welsh and Borlish toponyms are presumably cognate (see Old Borlish variant form Laȝr "Englishman"), reflecting a hypothesised Classical Kelt word laecor "warriors".

There are (according to mainstream analysis) four English languages spoken on Albion; in order of number of speakers these are Northumber, Wessern, Kentish and Merch. The polity of Northumber extends from the Humber to Edinbrough along the eastern side of Albion, but its local tongue, which has more Norse influence than other Englishes, competes for use there with the more prestigious Merch. Wessern is predominantly spoken in Britain [Wales, Devon, etc], where it enjoys co-official status in some tallaths [~provinces] but a decidedly subordinate role. Wessern features geminate consonants and the simplification of coda clusters (compare Merch dark /daːk/ to Wessern darick /ˈda.ɾək/ "dark"), as well as fricative voicing between vowels and at the start of words.

Kentish is one of the two languages of Kent along with Norman. Kent is a polity divided by the Kentish Channel [English Channel], both geographically and linguistically. Nonetheless, Kentish has had much more French influence over the past millennium than other Englishes, which continues to this day. For example, Kentish is the only English language within the so-called "roral ambit", having a uvular rhotic.

Merch is by some way the most-spoken English language, official both in Markland and London. The London standard of the language, while fully mutually intelligible with the Markland form (to a much greater degree than between different English languages), has several differences, notably in spelling—London did not particpate in the 1870 reforms which somewhat rationalised Merch orthography.

186.1: Global Workshop

notes in translation on the subject of the Global Workshop period.

L'epoc dell'Atelier, ben l'Atelier Mondial, interman y dezein entrpos dy siecr novoç.
The Workshop period, or the Global Workshop, refers to the middle decades of the nineteenth century.

L'oc se descrey par y spanjon e defasment veloç de laboriostur atras dy mont.

Se poð y rebondisc dell'epoc dell'Atelier veir par nuton cas art, con un locomoçon deur trevogt e vars (ny preu paum) depegnt mesmeristic dy ranc trevaglour ne laboriostur e (contrig) postulaçon mallovicher sur fanglanç cas clað alcant aposc.
