186.5: False Friends (cont. 2)

some more completely arbitrary dictionary entries from the Concise Onomatory o'Merch (fifth edition), a reference work published in 1961 and compiled by the Utcheter Lexical Association.

Awry [/ˈəu.ɾi/ "Hungary"] n.pr. a polity of Europe inhabited principally by the Majoric people, located east of Crain and Crovatia and west of Halich and Vallack. 10C Old English, allied with contemporary French Avrie, Saxon Aweri, Bavarn Awaren < Medieval Latin Avaria "the Avar Empire". This early medieval empire was erroneously conflated in Latin sources with (or perhaps merely repurposed as a geographical term for) the subsequent Majoric principality after their conquest of the region in the ninth century.

boss [/bɔs/ "gun"] n. a handheld weapon which fires a bullet using some explosive substance. 16C < Willem Dutch bósz, armbósz "boss" < early Dutch armbaust "crossbow" < Old French arbaleste < later Latin arcuballista "crossbow".

guy-coney [/ˈgəiˌkʊ.ni/ "guinea pig"] n. (also guy) a small, tail-less glire of Cappatia [South America] raised for meat or as a hearth animal. 17C, a borrowing in sense from Vascon conill guy (the second element altered in pronunciation to match the name) < 16C Morrove Arabic قنية قُوِي • (qnia qui) < Run'allo [Quechua] qowi "(female) guy-coney". For the coney element: 12C early Merch < reformed singular of Norman plural conis "coneys" of conil < Latin cunīculus "coney; burrow, warren; mine".

sicker [/ˈsɪ.kə/ "certain"] adj. free of any doubt or possibility of being incorrect; confident of one's correctness. Direct descendant of Old English sicor "safe, certain" < western Classical German sicur < Latin sēcūrus "unconcerned; fearless; safe".

187.1: Stopping Scurvy

notes in translation on efforts to prevent scurvy.

Jusc y siecr cinqueç nuverrem e seç primal, cosogr y veyaç geoscopic magn stendiscendessem ne souc dell'Abanc Novomondin d'an 1471, gimmolt por scurvog coïr denoirn quichessem.
By the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries, with the much longer geoscopic voyages following the Novomundine Landfall of 1471, efforts to prevent scurvy became more active.

Com bustr, Rey Ambrosc III a Vascony ("l'Ascenent") corporalleyau y Decret Sandrin d'an 1485 yon ag vascel voloisn stovir fruit issugt e scarob bacagettar.
For example, King Ambrose III of Vascony (the "Ascendant") instituted the Sandrine Design in 1485 by which ships would be required to stock dried fruits and syrups.

However, such schemes did not have lasting effects.

Cos parçal l'oc se deye a careç ma magn moulosessem, ag defait de comprenjon cas y method comoscon fruit poðen scurvog coïr.
This was partly due to expense but much more significantly, due to the lack of understanding of the mechanism by which fruit prevented scurvy.

Cossy, fruit stan conservað par mejan lorry matier sandrinal eliminant (ig inclus, par lou boglir ben par tas ne cuivr benoçar) e moðnaut nanciscen scurvog toð cas, oc colluy menant vars y sdroyaçon de fruit lingr total.
Thus, fruit would be preserved in ways which removed their sandrine content (for example, boiling or use of copper vessels) and sailors would suffer scurvy anyway, leading guilds to abandon stocking fruits altogether.

187.2: feurðon "decare"

feurðon /faurˈðɔn/ [ˌfa.wɐˈðɔn]
- rood, vergée, a traditional unit of land area equal to one quarter of an acre;
- decare, a modern metric unit of land area defined as ten thousand square feet

Etymology: originally in the first sense, part of the traditional system of area measures used on Borland along with the acr "acre" (also called the jur in the east). The word reflects Old Borlish feorðon, forðin "rood", from Old English féorðing or Old Norrish [Norse] fiórðungr "quarter, fourth part". The word was redefined in the nineteenth century with the adoption of dime [metric] units, being the numerically closest measure available (compare the Turk دونوم • dönüm or the Nivoner [Japanese] たんぶ • tambu, units which were similarly adjusted to this new dime measure).

187.4: skillet "chip"

skillet /skɪˈlɛt/ [skɪˈlɛt]
- chip, fragment, shard, piece, a small part broken off a larger whole;

Etymology: early modern Borlish, apparently from Kernish askleut or Devoner skylot "chips, shavings, splinters". 187.5: The Void

notes on three things which are somehow related to outer space.

The Superdraconic Apocalypse (Borlish Apocalyps Surdraconic /aˌpo.kaˈlɪps sɪrˌdra.koˈnɪk/) refers to the fall of a cisjovial sax [asteroid from the asteroid belt] approximately sixty-six hundred myriad years ago, probably during the northern spring. It was followed by the eradication of roughly three-quarters of all animal species, including all dragons [dinosaurs] bar the ancestors of modern birds. The name of this event, coined in the nineteenth century as a hypothetical (several decades before evidence of the impact was actually discovered) to explain the extinction in the fossil record, refers to its location—temporally at the end of, and therefore geologically on top of, the Draconic Age (2.5–0.66 great myriad years ago).

The waveform display [Fourier transform] (Borlish despley ondatim /dɛˈspli ˌɔn.daˈtɪm/) is the presentation of a mathematical function as the sum of vatre and arrhumb [sine and cosine] functions. This technique was developed in the eighteenth century as a way to help compute celestial orbits, in part by Barcelon mathematician Raymond al Mustafa.

The Auroric Anomaly of 1859 (Borlish Anomaly Auroric /aˌno.maˈli ˌo.roˈrɪk/) was a collection of phenomena associated with an intense sunstorm, including auroras and—most famously—malfunctioning barrick steeplepost [electric telegraph] equipment. Various operators reported sparks, fires, and even being able to sporadically use wires to transmit when they weren't powered. The first tachygraph [typewriter] capable of sending messages on the steeplemesh was tested by Tomas Vilmanas on Michael's Day, less than a month after the Anomaly. However, despite later dramatisation, there is little evidence that the two events are connected.

188.1: Millstone War

notes in translation on the subject of the Millstone War (1897–1908).

Malgrað noc tout entr y var envoluð la afferjarausn l'oncein d'annað enter, ðe son tout descreut par un inereðm fondaminal: manouvr costojal ayen machinaçon gazovar survaluð, e donc tarmn de front tras y mont quaglaurn ne bastegl a fos ceu avançabr.
Though not all of the wars involved spanned the entire eleven years, they are all characterised by a fundamental asymmetry: defensive tactics had outstripped offensive technology, and so front lines worldwide ground to barely-moving trench fortifications.

Par y Var a Couð se munc y fin dell'epoc Bel-Joy; ne sy faughanç sceye un rallignment abrangent dy doujug alleyancer paravant.
The Millstone War marks the end of the Good Game period; its aftermath saw a comprehensive realignment of the previous system of alliances.

Nell'eç annað final dy Var a Couð sceye y preu benoç militer de nau aeral, tan com bombaçon des aer de citað ig inclus Marsegl ne Provenç.

Political tensions rose globally in the decades after the Millstone War, as the inadequacy of the post-war settlements became apparent.

188.4: sborreyar "dishevel"

sborreyar /ˌsbɔ.riˈjar/ [ˌzbɔ.ʀɪˈʝɐː]
- dishevel, tousle, ruffle, to render (hair, clothes, etc.) untidy or disordered;
- disarray, disorganise, to throw into chaos more generally;
- tangle, entangle, knot, snarl, mat, to mix up (e.g. strands) so that they cannot be easily separated (also metaphorically);
- shuffle, to change the arrangement of (in the manner of cards or other game pieces)

Etymology: early modern Borlish, borrowed from northern dialect. The word is a verbal derivative of rural term borr "tuft, burr, clump", which descends from Latin burra "ragged garment, coarse fragment". The prefix s- < Latin ex- is somewhat pejorative; the verbal ending comes from -idiō in Vulgar Latin.

Stou a casc lusour y pachet fort sborreyar.
/stu a kax liˈzur i paˈkɛt fɔrt ˌsbɔ.riˈjar/
[stu a kax lɪˈzʊː‿ʀi pɐˈkɛt fɔːt ˌzbɔ.ʀɪˈʝɐː]
be.needed at each player df deck well dishevel-inf
Each player should shuffle the deck well.

##

188.5: The Second Millennium

notes on various names ordered chronologically.

Damian VI "the Wise" (r. 1199–1208; Damianus Sagāx) was a Pope in Rome during the tail end of the period known as the Medieval Imperia or the Second Tetrarchy. He was the first Roman Pope elected from the membership of the Brethin religious order, a Kelt monastic organisation dedicated among other things to record-keeping. Like others of his papal name, he honoured the twin saints Cosmas and Damian, third-century martyrs. Damain VI is remembered well, mostly in comparison to his successor Pope Just's numerous catastrophes.

The San Tomé (Portingale /sãw tuˈmɛ/ "Saint Thomas") was a myton [a type of merchant ship] of the Vascon trade fleet; as with many such ships, it was nominally the personal property of one of the powerful Vask noble families enirched by Atlantic fishing. Logs of its voyages have by happenstance been well-preserved. During one of its regular routes, from Cale [Oporto] to Damvath in September of 1492, the log records being unable to make port at Bournemouth due to battle in the city and harbour (part of the Wars of Fealty).

Gudmund and Rebecca Scradder (fl. 1677) were a married couple of Dane astronomers. In the 1670s they undertook a voyage to Seldiva [Sri Lanka] as part of a global scientific effort to observe a predicted transit of Mercury. Their observations helped to compute the mean distance from the Earth to the Sun.

Cadogan Torrior (fl. 1890) was an author from Nadacow [a city on the banks of the lower Mississippi] in Hasiny. Of relatively minor account during his life, his works of masquira like the 1890 trevold Men of Jet and Diamond have attained greater popularity through the mid-twentieth century. This was thanks to successful film adaptations, such as the New Provincial 1950 production Blanc Sabaje "Jet White".

##

189.1: Disappearance of the Redstone Chair

notes in translation on the subject of the Redstone Chair, containing the (alleged) block upon which the Elved Marriage between a princess of Markland and the ruler of Dane Northumber was solemnised.

Certan historicour aun l'apponment scas ig Preu Ðurnç a Londr d'an 1290 fos cos parçal motivað par un vellisqment vars y Caðer emposseïr; accont son discrepant cas y facçon envoluð.
Some historians have conjectured that the First Burning of London in 1290 was in part motivated by a plan to acquire the Chair; the responsible party varies in the telling.

Lonc y tesmogn costumner, l'intermane un kerel sur y plaçment dy Caðer ne Pieðr Roug ayent y Rix cas Fieltað akirtað, ec durant pres un cinquantein d'annað tras y torn ag siecr seç eð ec ayent pres toð y polity sur Albion jannestað.
According to the traditional account, it was a dispute over the location of the Redstone Chair which sparked the Wars of Fealty, which lasted almost fifty years over the turn of the sixteenth century and which embroiled almost all the polities of Albion.

Cos infeliç, y Caðer denoy repars a milloy dy tourf cosogr y rix a plaç entarn entr d'an 1505 e 1509.
Unfortunately, the Chair was lost in the tumult of the wars at some point between 1505 and 1509.

Noc obstroint javig monfeyað e dou sovembr ag mendrem, y Caðer n'a jamay erref se caut, eð y recordaçon modern de sy pariscenç se plaç cos enter sur depegnt ne pieç portrait e belem de coronnaç.
Despite several searches and at least two hoaxes, the Chair has never been recovered, and the modern understanding of its appearance rests entirely on depictions in a few portraits and coronation scenes.

189.2: greim "lap"

greim /grim/ [gʀim]
- lap, the upper legs of a seated person;
- skirt, apron, the part of a garment that covers this part of the body;
- bosom, embrace, affection, care, the figurative position of being nurtured or protected by someone

Etymology: direct descendant via Old Borlish from Latin gremium "lap; bosom; embrace". The term has been used in tailoring from the thirteenth century. The metaphorical sense may continue the similar usage in Latin, but is more likely to be an independent innovation of the early modern period.

Y cociner le tirau des un cromn de greim.

The cook took it out of an apron pocket.

189.3: lasdr "pathetic"

lasdr /ˈlaz.dr̩/ [ˈla.zdɐ]
- (archaic) leprous, infected with one of the diseases known as leprosy;
- pitiable, pitiful, pathetic, wretched, arousing feelings of sympathy or pathos;
- contemptible, despicable, deplorable, arousing feelings of scorn or disdain;
- ineffectual, impotent, occurring to little useful effect

Etymology: Middle Borlish borrowing from contemporary French lasdre "n. leper, wretch; adj. leprous, wretched". This descends from Late Latin Lazarus, in reference to a beggar in the New Testamement who was traditionally understood to have been a leper.

Caye gimmolt lasdr a y smoutour ðescar.

It was a pathetic attempt to egg on the riots.

189.4: movaç "pout"

movaç /moˈvats/ [mʊˈvats]
- pout, moue, an expression of displeasure via protruding lips;
- pet, brood, sulk, huff, mood, a fit of sullenness as characterised by pouting

Etymology: eighteenth century, pejorative noun formation from movar "pout, sulk". This reflects earlier moar, a borrowing from Old French verb moer and noun moe "grimace", each from a Frankish form reflecting Classical German mauvō "sleeve; protruding lip".

Sy figl reloy sur y hayennaç con un movaç.

His kid continued the homework with a pout.

##

189.5: The Three Rs

notes on three features of this alternate history setting which begin with the letter R.

Radulf "the Kite" (Borlish Radolf y Buttr /raˈdɔlf i ˈbɪt.r̩/, r. 951–) was the last English king of the rump Northumber, ruling from the castle at Edinbrough. He was wed to a woman referred to in the chronicles as one Atre of Cheswic, who may have been a daughter of King Roderick of Dunclothe [Strathclyde, Cumbria]. His reign ended with the expansion of Dane lands up and across from Yorwick [York]; by the turn of the millennium the entirety of the Neck was under Dane authority.

Ricardo Ivarrachezurí (fl. 1824) was a farm theorist from Vascony [SW France, N Spain], who fought as a mozardisto during the Second German War. Ivarrachezurí was the first theorist to record the ability of copper to kill sperm, noting in 1824 that “the seed of the bull, the ram and the stallion alike are made impotent in storing them for some hours in a syringe of copper”. He recognised that this was the same mechanism by which copper prevented infections. Although this sterilising property of copper would later be productively used in contraceptives, Ivarrachezurí treated it as a problem for farmers attempting to artificially breed livestock.

The Runeplate Body (Borlish Corp a Runment /kɔrp a rɪnˈmɛnt/) is a charitable organisation with multinational funding, headquartered in the Kiewan city of Lengrod [Lviv, Ukraine]. Its stated purpose is to compile information on all the writing systems of the world and to recommend standard encodings of glyphs for use on e.g. grimmers [computers]. The organisation, formally established in 1942, grew out of several small groups interested in writing systems, either on an amateurish basis or affiliated with various higher education establishments. The word "runeplate" originally referred to a sheet of metal into which the shapes of writing have been etched.

190.1: Tell Me, Telmy!

    excerpt in translation from children's educational book Tell Me Everything About the Solar System, part of the Tell Me, Telmy! series originally written by Adamara Godwilham.

Tandic evolgað stan y novel dy descovart dy preu corp celest cos vray insuet posc millenner, gent orðenjaurn plusour nom poll'ec pharī Iovis "balis de Jou".
As word spread of the first really new celestial bodies to be discovered for thousands of years, people came up with lots of names for these pharī Iovis “lighthouses of Jove”.

Certan gent desiran ou lorry patron, segnour ben eiðel glorfeyar.
Some people wanted to bring glory to their patrons, lords or lands.

Autr gent tornan cur vars renarranç de legend classic lor stant all'eutað.
Others reached to retellings of Classical legends which were in fashion.

L'ustol ayent l'ec an durað cas y lengaç European, e stant mantenuð jug candon nos eu fort may de picq lun Jovial trovað a mesur dy siecr derran, interman ig y gyrour de Jou nommar lonc dy prosequent mortal.
The convention that has lasted in European languages, and which has been maintained since we have found many more small Jovial moons in the last century, has been to name Jupiter’s gyrers [satellites] for his mortal descendants.

Nos eu l'issar parey accommis cas y dou lun de Mars, Dimus e Phobus, stant nommað lonc sell'heir jammel e pedisecq.
We have done the same with the two moons of Mars, Dimus [Phobos] and Phobus [Deimos], which are named for his twin sons and attendants.

190.2: barrougl "wheelbarrow"

barrougl /baˈrujl/ [bɐˈʀʊjl]
- wheelbarrow, handcart, a small one-wheeled cart with handles used for transporting small loads;
- trolley, cart, a conveyance for carrying groceries or other items around a shop;
- buggy, pram, stroller, a small carriage in which an infant or toddler sits or lies and is pushed around

Etymology: via Old Borlish beroȝl "handcart, trolley" from synonymous birocla in Vulgar Latin. This reflects birotula, a diminutive from late Latin birota "two-wheeled cart" which comes from bi- "double" and rota "wheel". Compare Tuscan baroccio and Old French beroue, brouette, both meaning "cart". The term was likely influenced by the unrelated Old English bearwe "basket, handcart". In more general use the term is comparatively recent, only seen from the late ninteenth century.

I sta quemant com babe ne barrougl.
/i sta kweˈmant kɔm baˈbe ne baˈrujl/
[i sta kwɪˈmant kɔm bɐˈʀʊjl ne bɐˈʀʊjl]
3s be.ipf cosy as baby in cart
He was as snug as a bug in a rug.

##

190.3: ðejar "tuck"

ðejar /ðeˈʒar/ [ðɪˈʝɐː]
- tuck, insert, fit, wedge, stick, lodge, to push into a confined or secure position;
- to place underneath something else;
- ram, shove, to drive with some force;
- compact, compress, to cause to be in a more convenient shape or configuration;
- (reflexive) fold up, curl up, to bend onself and hold onto one's legs; 
- (reflexive) fit, be neat, to be suited to taking up some particular space

Etymology: disputed. The word is often presumed to be a metathetic reflex of Old Borlish (a)ieðar [(a)dʒiˈðar] "ram, drive, push forward". This descends from Latin arietō "strike, batter", a verbal derivative from ariēs "ram; battering ram". However, this verb is last attested over two centuries before the first evidence of ðejar in the Middle Borlish period.

The alternative with the most backing is that the word reflects Latin adiciō "I throw at; I attach, augment", which has semantic and phonetic plausibility, although no intermediate forms are in evidence. Other suggestions, like a first-conjugation variant of Latin adigō "I drive, hurl, compel" or a Norrish [Norse] verb like þjá "force" or þeisa "thrust, rush", have rarely been credited.

Jo ðejau y pie neðan y port closisceus.
/ʒo ðeˈʒo i pje neˈðan i pɔrt ˌklo.ziˈxauz/
[ʝo ðɪˈʝo i pje nɪˈðan i pɔːt ˌklo.zɪˈxauz]
1s tuck-pst df foot lest df door close-ipf.sbj
I wedged the door open with my foot.

190.4: lan "wool"

lan /lan/ [lan]
- wool, the hair of sheep or other animals which is shorn to make clothing;
- curls, human hair which is notably curly;
- stuff, paraphernalia, junk, gear, undifferentiated possessions or objects in general;
- waffle, blather, meaningless or indecipherable speech or writing

Etymology: uncomplicated descendant of Latin lāna "wool". For human hair the word is attested sporadically from early Middle Borlish, with a resurgence in the twentieth century. The generic senses appear to descend from an obsolete slang use of the word to mean "cash, coins", which was briefly current in the early modern period.

Y barvier portan lan des lorrell'ovegl meðes.
/i barˈvjɛr pɔrˈtan lan dɛz lɔˌrɛ.loˈvijl meˈðɛz/
[i bɐːˈvjɛː pʊːˈtan lan dɛz lʊˌʀɛ.lʊˈvɪjl mɪˈðɛz]
df shepherd wear-ipf-3p wool out.of 3p.gn=sheep even
The shepherds wore their own sheep's wool.

190.5: Multiple Choice Quiz

excerpt from the 2025 book Everything Under the Sun, published by the Royal Tommarth Castinghouse, a publisher based in the capital of Markland. It made use of the branding and popularity of a puzzle-book series begun by Merch couple Anna and Ralph Highwater in the 1930s. This collection of questions concerns the Drengot Collusion (1800s–1961), an alliance-federacy of northwest Europe.

History 22: The Drengot Collusion (answers on sheet 532)

-1. Which of the twenty-four ministeries which made up the Drengotian administration was established last, set up in 1932 under the aegis of Runcibal Sawyer Boon?
- the Minstry for Consequences
- the Ministry for Family
- the Ministry for Information
- the Ministry for Wealth

-2. Which of the following four trevolds [novels] was the first publication confirmed to have sold over one hundred myriad copies across the Collusion in its first year?
- A Door, Once Opened (1920) by Clarissa Bellamy
- Command That I be Healed (1914) by Honorine Maignard
- One Evening Will Have to be Enough (1913) by Josephène Foilliers
- The Day We Let the Chaos In (1921) by Martha and Dean Armstrong

-3. The Drengot Collusion only gained that name in the late nineteenth century, after it expanded to absorb which political entity?
- Borland
- Markland
- the New Urban Mesh (also colloquially 'Greater London')
- Willemy

-4. Which of these theoretical inventions was not developed at the Gomster Atellier in the first half of the 20th century, the partially state-owned development wing of the Hathwall Magna astraphor guild [electric company]?
- CMM veronic [vinyl] 
- Glass-light [fibre optic] communication
- Immortal [stainless] steel
- 'Tommy' pills [ibuprofen]

191.1: The Vanilla Manoeuvre

excerpt in translation from the 1992 trevold The Vanilla Manoeuvre (originally published in Merch under the title Tashban Tacks), written by Vendetta Boon, the granddaughter of Lord Runcibal Sawyer Boon, one-time Minster for Consequences in the Drengot Collusion. Of middling success, this spycraft work owes more to the film adaptations of the classics of the genre than to those classics themselves.

Y contris alandau n'un descovannet mejoncr, fait impacent sdruçollar tras y tabr.
The dossier arrived in a nondescript folder, shoved impatiently across the table.

Cattridge l'ovreu varsant eð examinau l'icon y quagl depegntant: un domn eld y carantein ant un sourey picq sousonnant a secret massem.
Cattridge flipped it open and studied the photograph of the target: a woman in her forties with a small smile that hinted at larger secrets.

Tre agent mort a mesur de tan semman, verim detaxionnað des fæx sougl—no se poðe l'oç panel mesveir.
Three dead agents in as many weeks, poisons derived from threshold dross—the pattern was unmistakable.

"I sera vos attenent ag fest cas l'ambasctour," dis y harvougl de Cattridge, ne sy jalicq vert cos martellað yauvnant.
"She'll be expecting you at the embassy reception," Cattridge's handler said, adjusting her aggressively green waistcoat.

"L'ambasctour Napolitan fay recougl de jarry d'Istr Boral pre-classic. Val l'eç effojaçon ne Çadrosc svoccar. I vil l'esc mordr."
"The Napolitan ambassador collects pre-Classical Borland ceramics. Mention the Çadrosc excavations. She'll take the bait."

Cattridge encromnau y fougl. A starn, doutr fenestr angost e meg argentfeyað, y ployot automnal ne Tommarth fey nuot a nimb teun dy lampader.
Cattridge pocketed the pages. Outside, through narrow and half-mirrored windows, Tommarth's autumn drizzle blurred the streetlamps into wan halos.

Allors, a plaç autr ny citað, un domn er se preparant por un fest yon i nole surveur.
Elsewhere, across the city, a woman was preparing for a party she wouldn't survive.

191.2: gentagl "riffraff"

gentagl /ʒɛnˈtɛjl/ [ʝɪnˈtɛjl]
- populace, population, inhabitants, demos, the people of a region (especially of a nation or polity);
- masses, rabble, riffraff, hoi polloi, the common people as opposed to the elite (often with pejorative affect)

Etymology: Middle Borlish derivative of gent "people, nation" and -agl, an unproductive instrumental or collective suffix. The noun descends straightforwardly from Latin gēns "clan, tribe, people"; the affix from Latin thematic vowel -ā- and suffix -cula "tool, instrument". Attestatations of gentācula (with a first-declension variant of the suffix) "common people" in Scholastic Latin are likely modelled after the vernacular Romance forms.

Nuvr soð vos melle faint con y gentagl.
/ˈnɪv.r̩ sɔð vɔz mɛˈle fent kɔn i ʒɛnˈtɛjl/
[ˈnɪ.vɐ sɔ vɔz mɪˈle fent kɔn i ʝɪnˈtajl]
new be.2p 2p ton do-p.prs with df demos
You've been mixing with riffraff recently.

191.3: entrlaçour "hustler"

entrlaçour /ˌɛnt.r̩.laˈtsur/ [ˌɛn.tɐ.lɐˈtsʊː]
- wheeler-dealer, hustler, schemer, a shrewd or unscrupulous operator in politics or commerce;
- swindler, sharpster, grifter, con artist, racketeer, someone running scams;
- pedlar, huckster, a small-time or itinerant merchant of (usually poor-quality) goods

Etymology: nineteenth century, borrowed (probably via intermedaries) from Sicilia ntrlazzaturi "swindler, racketeer". This is an agentive derivation from the noun ntrlazzu "scam, racket", which reflects Latin inter- "between" and laqueus "noose". Specialisation to politics probably occurred before the word entered Borlish, although there was no shortage of corruption in contempory governance on Borland to inspire the shift.

Jo broiðau l'entrlaçour coll'outrley.
/ʒo brɔjˈðo ˌlɛnt.r̩.laˈtsur i ˌlut.r̩ˈli/
ʝo bʀʊjˈðo ˌlɛn.tɐ.lɐˈtsʊː‿ʀi ˌlu.tɐˈli/
1s blur-pst df=hustler and df=outlaw
I mixed up the scammer and the outlaw.

191.4: hoðic "reeve"

hoðic /hoˈðɪk/ [hʊˈðɪk]
- reeve, headman, official, village leader, a person with authority in a small community;
- chief, chieftain, the leader of a clan or tribe;
- councillor, alderman, a member of a local governmental body

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish houðic, hoðinc "village leader; esp. leader of a Norse settlement in the north of Borland". This is a borrowing from Old Norse hǫfðingi "chief, lord", which is a derivation of hǫfuð "head". The term was first used for elected positions in town or city councils in the fifteenth century.

Y bourg deleu l'oc hoðic ne souc d'un courstray.
/i burg deˈlaw lɔk hoˈðɪk ne suk dɪn kurˈstre/
[i bʊːg dɪˈlaw lɔk hʊˈðɪk ne suk dɪŋ kʊːˈstʀe]
df town delete-pst df=s.px reeve in wake of=indf affair
The town fired this councillor due to an affair.

##

191.5: Blue Trans-Willem War

The Blue Trans-Willem War (Willem: Blaw Trans-Willemsk Órlog, Borlish: Var Tras-Willem Blau) was one of a series of wars in the early modern period which principally involved French and Dutch [German] polities (that is, those powers located on either side of the territory of Willemy [~Benelux, Lorraine]) and which were de facto waged over control of said territory.

Though the sporadic flare-ups of hostilies are difficult to divide into discrete wars without some arbitrariness, modern historiography usually works with the chromatic periodisation of nineteenth-century writer Andrysk de Santer. Her system, based either (depending on the account) on the colours of the victors' standards or on alchemical symbolism, has the Blue war as the penultimate conflict, ending in the late seventeenth century. Some historians, though not de Santer, have classified the Blue war as part of the broader collection of Romantic Wars of the mid-seventeenth century.

As a coup de grâce following a series of smaller humiliations in earlier decades, the kingdom of Burgundy was formally dissolved after the Blue Trans-Willem War, with its territory partitioned between Provence and the kingdoms of France and Bavarn. For example, the duchy of Far Suebia was created as a vassal of Bavarn as a gift from King Frederick to the margrave Thorsten Villingen; the former Burgund capital of Geneva became a subordinate city in this new realm.

The duchy of Avosche and its seat at Axton [Aachen], which after a stable sixteenth century as a French vassal had changed hands five times in recent decades, was returned to French control as part of French Guillenne in the aftermath of the Blue Trans-Willem War.

192.1: Vector Geometry

excerpt in translation from Drawing in the Sand: the History of Calculation, a collaborative reference book originally published 1954 in Napolitan as Scheme ne Rene: a Storia d'Amiradanza by the Agenza Scholaria Fodgesa.

Nell'oc strait, nos indagau y defas dy "method a bout" com annexment de geometry Euclidean.
In this section, we chart the development of the "dart method" as an extension of Euclidean geometry.

Par toð y theorem dy codex Element, reconnuð no's alcun autranç entr un lign AB e sell'envarjon BA.
In all the theorems of The Elements, no distinction is made between a line AB and its reverse BA.

Caye for durant y siecr cinqueç yon scholer ig inclus Barclythe e da Treviso ençan a asmuth ascreir a lign.
It is only in the late fifteenth century that scholars like Barclythe and da Treviso begin to assign directions to lines.

Pall'oc affixion pariscent petty es ig geometour denoirn poðir dou cos signfeyant complir.
It was this seemingly trivial addition that enabled geometers to do two important things.

Primer, ðe errevn quantað ablat destr a dessou dy nimb a convenibiltað cas mathematic European.
First, they brought negative quantities into the realm of respectability in European mathematics.

Con tan l'idea de "mendrem a zefr pom" fos incossirabr, alcun hom no'r vexað par y noçon d'un sojorn bouclant ag pognt iniçal par aðendrar des A vars B, e soulor des B vars A.
Although the idea of "fewer than zero apples" was absurd, no-one was perturbed by the concept of returning to one's starting point by travelling from A to B, and then from B to A.

##

192.2: oðig "especially"

oðig /oˈðaj/ [ʊˈðaj]
- (literary) especially, particularly, to a greater extent than is usual;
- to wit, i.e., viz., namely, that is, expressed in other words;
- or even, if not, moreover, but also, introducing an additional property or fact;
- (interjection) sure, just so, right, I see, expressing that something is (now) clear or a more general agreement

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish oðiȝ "truly, certainly", which reflects Latin adverb utique "in any case, at least, in particular". The term in its adverbial use is now restricted to very formal writing, and the clarifying sense is also more of the written than spoken register.

The final two sets of senses are sometimes held to be an unrelated compound, comprising Old Borlish o, oð, ou, ouð "whether" and iȝ "there". These come from Latin aut "or" and ibi "there" respectively.

L'oc defey sera dur oðig inacavabr.
/lɔk deˈfi seˈra dɪr oˈðaj iˌna.kaˈvab.r̩/
[lɔg dɪˈfi sɪˈʀa dɪː‿ʀʊˈðaj ɪˌna.kɐˈva.bɐ]
df=s.px test be.fut-s hard or.even infeasible
This challenge will be hard or even impossible.

##

192.3: egnam "lumber"

egnam /ijˈnam/ [ɪjˈnam]
- timber, lumber, wood from trees used for construction;
- plank, a long and thick piece of timber;
- beam, post, rafter, a heavy piece of wood used to provide support for some part of a building;
- (colloquial, dated) idiot, dumbass, pillock, simpleton, somebody stupid;
- (vulgar, usually jocular) dick, cock, a penis

Etymology: Middle Borlish, rebracketing of earlier legnam "timber" reinterpreting the initial <l-> as the definite article. This is a borrowing from some Romance language's cognate of Medieval Latin lignāmen "timber"; it cannot be a direct descendant because native words reflect -āmen as -amn, cf. eramn "bronze", scamn "swarm". The word is no longer current as a personal insult except in one-off comparisons of somebody to a literal plank; in vulgar use the term is attested from the 1970s but may be much older.

Dou carpenter son egnam de casn coupant.
/du ˌkar.pɛnˈtɛr sɔn ijˈnam de ˈkaz.n̩ kuˈpant/
[du ˌkɐː.pɪnˈtɛː sɔn ɪjˈnam de ˈka.zɐn kʊˈpant]
two carpenter be.3p timber of oak cut-p.prs
Two carpenters are cutting oak planks.

##

192.4: pentis "bivouac"

pentis /pɛnˈtɪz/ [pɪnˈtɪz]
- hut, shed, outbuilding, a small structure built as storage or shelter;
- annex, extension, a further interior section added to a building;
- lean-to, an attachment onto the outside of a building;
- bivouac, an improvised overnight shelter

Etymology: Middle Borlish, borrowed from contemporary French apentis "appendage, attached building". This reflects appendicium, a Medieval Latin variant of Classical appendix "supplement, addition". In the last sense it was originally restricted to military encampments.

Y gardinner apportau un pal des y pentis.
/i ˌgar.dɪˈnɛr ˌa.pɔrˈto ɪn pal dɛz i pɛnˈtɪz/
[i ˌgɐː.dɪˈnɛː‿ˌʀa.pʊːˈto ɪm pal dɛz i pɪnˈtɪz]
df gardener bring-pst indf spade out.of df hut
The gardener got a shovel out of the shed.

##

192.5: Borlish Adjectives

Borlish adjectives have two forms: a base form and a comparative form. The comparative is formed by adding a suffix, which shifts stress to the penultimate syllable.
Regular Comparative in -essem

The regular comparative suffix is -essem, which replaces or follows the final segment of the adjective and attracts penultimate stress.

    ‹leger legeressem›
    /leˈʒɛr ˌle.ʒeˈrɛ.sɛm/
    'light lighter'

Several orthographic adjustments may occur when the suffix is added. Before the vowel-initial suffix, ‹ç› becomes ‹c›, while ‹c› becomes ‹ch› to preserve the /k/ pronunciation.

    ‹lavaç lavacessem | starc starchessem›
    /laˈvats ˌla.vaˈtsɛ.sɛm | stark starˈkɛ.sɛm/
    'wasteful {more wasteful} | strong stronger'

After a final orthographic ‹-q›, a linking ‹-u-› is inserted.

    ‹picq picquessem›
    /pɪk pɪˈkwɛ.sɛm/
    'small smaller'

The final consonant may be doubled in the comparative form to maintain the checked quality of the preceding vowel. This occurs most commonly with final ‹-l›.

    ‹boncop boncoppessem›
    /bɔnˈkɔp ˌbɔn.kɔˈpɛ.sɛm/
    'cheap cheaper'

The final consonant may be voiced in the comparative form. This is seen most commonly in present participles ending in ‹-nt› (which form comparatives in ‹-ndessem›) and in adjectives ending in fricatives, though only final ‹-f› reflects this orthographically as ‹-vessem›.

    ‹tart tardessem | braf bravessem›
    /tart tarˈdɛ.sɛm | braf braˈvɛ.sɛm/
    'late later | brave braver'

Adjectives ending in a written ‹-Vu› diphthong form the comparative in ‹-Vvessem›.

    ‹blau blavessem›
    /blo blaˈvɛ.sɛm/
    'blue bluer'

Certain historically long vowels in the final syllable of an adjective may shorten in the comparative form. This occurs most commonly with adjectives ending in ‹-ous›.

    ‹fatuous fatuosessem›
    /faˈtjuz ˌfa.tjoˈzɛ.sɛm/
    'clumsy clumsier'

Adjectives ending in ‹-e› form the comparative in ‹-eyessem›.

    ‹idone idoneyessem›
    /ˌi.doˈne ˌi.doˈnjɛ.sɛm/
    'convenient {more convenient}'

Adjectives in Syllabic -r

Adjectives ending in syllabic ‹-r› show several patterns. Occasionally they form regular comparatives in ‹-ressem›.

    ‹jundr jundressem›
    /ˈʒɪn.dr̩ ʒɪnˈdrɛ.sɛm/
    'junior {more junior}'

Some adjectives, most notably those ending in the suffix ‹-abr› "-able", form comparatives in ‹-lessem› rather than ‹-ressem›.

    ‹stabr stablessem | sengr senglessem›
    /ˈstab.r̩ staˈblɛ.sɛm | ˈsɛn.gr̩ sɛnˈglɛ.sɛm/
    'steady steadier | simple simpler'

The majority of adjectives ending in syllabic ‹-r› form the comparative with the suffix ‹-errem›, which replaces the final syllabic consonant and is stressed penultimately. The same adjustments that affect ‹-essem› may also affect ‹-errem›.

    ‹nuvr nuverrem | diçr dicerrem›
    /ˈnɪv.r̩ niˈvɛ.rɛm | ˈdɪts.r̩ diˈtsɛ.rɛm/
    'fresh fresher | great greater'

    ‹allagr allagherrem | leur leverrem›
    /aˈlɛj.r̩ ˌa.lɛˈjɛ.rɛm | ˈlau.r̩ leˈvɛ.rɛm/
    'happy happier | free freer'

Irregular Comparatives

A few adjectives show irregular stem changes in the comparative.

    ‹brey bressem›
    /bri ˈbrɛ.sɛm/
    'short shorter'

Several common adjectives have fully suppletive comparative forms.

    ‹bon ottem | mal pessem | gran maissem›
    /bɔn ˈɔ.tɛm | mal ˈpɛ.sɛm | gran ˈme.sɛm/
    'good better | bad worse | big bigger'

##

193.1: Simon Monçating

notes in translation on the subject of Borlish nobleman Simon Monçating.

Segr Simon, y sest Baron Monçating (n. 1770) sta un panditour, un quomodolibet notoir cas y melle ne Damvað, eð un partejan primal por Theology a Desveyanç n'Istr Boral.
Lord Simon, the sixth Baron Monçating (b. 1770) was an intellectual, a notorious libertine of Damvath high society, and an early proponent of Deviance Theology in Borland.

L'aye un orin Waranesc par y linaç de sy maðr.
He was of Warnine [Guaraní] descent through his mother.

Sy famigl sta notoir tras dezein jusc oy deut an rix legal stendiscent entr sy paðr e sy cosvour scon stemn poll'auteç dy Barony a Haubrath.
His family had been notorious for decades due to a protracted legal battle between his father and second cousin over the Barony of Haubrath.

Pre l'aye eld ogtoç Simon poðe parolar ne Latin, Teudesc (e lonc y teurfeyour den, Waranesc), eð i save clavir frottar e torriot hoissar.
By the age of eighteen Simon could speak Latin, Dutch (and according to his defamers, Warnine), and he could play the clavier and the bassoon.

Posc un quoncein de sanc ðus ne Damvað, sy sojornaçon afferjaraurn y mont, ig inclus sy feu gradual sur y rimmot auster ne Cappatia.
After a fiery young adulthood in Damvath, his travels took him across the world, including to his titular fief on the eastern coast of Cappatia [South America].

193.2: mejoncr "mid"

mejoncr /meˈʒɔnk.r̩/ [mɪˈjɔŋ.kɐ]
- mid, mediocre, middling, average, OK, decent, of only moderate quality (usually disappointingly so);
- indifferent, lukewarm, unenthusiastic, not showing much excitement or optimism;
- unremarkable, forgettable, failing to make a strong impression;
- safe, cautious, risk-averse, avoiding extremes or deviation (of choices or behaviour);
- ambivalent, mixed, neither clearly good nor bad

Etymology: alteration of Middle Borlish mejocr "middling" under the influence of unrelated words like coroncr "impostor" and pujoncr "dagger" (whose endings descend from the diminutive suffix -(un)culus in Latin). This was borrowed directly from Latin mediocris "mediocre", a possible compound of medius "middle" and ocris "rugged mountain" (as to suggest "halfway up").

I da empley a xiphar mejoncr naðusc.
/i da ɛmˈpli a ksiˈfar meˈʒɔnk.r̩ naˈðɪx/
[i da ɪmˈpli a ksɪˈfɐː mɪˈʝɔŋ.kɐ nɐˈðɪç]
3s give job to sabre mid a.bit
She employs rather mid mercenaries.

##

193.3: desjovar "uncouple"

desjovar /ˌdɛz.ʒoˈvar/ [ˌdɛz.ʝʊˈvɐː]
- unyoke, uncouple, unlink, to remove from a yoke or harness;
- detach, disengage, unfasten, separate, to cause to be apart;
- liberate, free, to deliver from oppression or imprisonment;
- (colloquial, reflexive) divorce, to end a marriage;
- unplug, disconnect, to sever the link between an electrical appliance and the mains

Etymology: Middle Borlish, derivative of jovar "yoke, tie together, match; (later) plug in". This is either a direct descendant of Latin iugō "I join, yoke" or more likely a re-verbing via jou < Latin iugum "yoke". The term was used metaphorically almost at once, especially in religious contexts. In both the colloquial and electrical senses the word is first attested in the nineteenth century.

Skig sdroyet desjovar cant moustr se migrn.
/skai sdrɔˈjɛt ˌdɛz.ʒoˈvar kant mus.tr̩ se ˈmɪg.rn̩/
[skaj zdʀʊˈʝɛt ˌdɛz.ʝʊˈvɐː kant ˈmu.stɐ se ˈmɪ.gɐn]
refrain stock-dim unlink-inf when data rfl migrate-3p
Do not unplug drives during file transfer.

193.4: outrvalir "overestimate"

outrvalir /ˌut.r̩.vaˈlɪr/ [ˌu.tɐ.vɐˈlɪː]
- overrate, inflate, to imagine to be better or greater in some respect than in truth;
- highball, overestimate, to make a guess at a value that is too high;
- (reflexive) overween, boast, swagger, brag, vaunt, to act in an arrogant or conceited manner

Etymology: early Modern Borlish, derivation of valir "be worth" < Latin valeō "I am strong" with the prefix outr- < Latin ultrā "beyond" (compare independent Borlish words outr "complete, utter" and doutr "beyond"). In reflexive use the word is attested from the Long Peace period at the turn of the nineteenth century.

L'oç bougr s'outrval cos outr.
/lɔts ˈbug.r̩ ˌsut.r̩ˈval kɔz ˈut.r̩/
[lɔs ˈbu.gɐ ˌsu.tɐˈval kɔz ˈu.tɐ]
df=s.dt guy rfl=inflate adv total
That chap's an utter braggart.

##

193.5: Aqueous Axton

Axton (Parisian French Grand-Aix /gʀãˈdɛiks/, Willem Dutch Aughen /ˈɔ.xn̩/) [Aachen] is a major city in the polity of Willemy and the municipal centre of the region of Avosche. It is located on the Worm river, which flows via the Rudder [Rur] into the Maze [Meuse].

The name of the city derives from post-Classical German *Ākā "Axton", attested in late Old English as Aces tūn "*Ākā's town". This in turn was borrowed from Latin aqua "water", in reference to the local thermal springs. The placename was pluralised in most Dutch languages, while in French languages the placename acquired the descriptor grand- "great" to distinguish it from other towns named Aix for their bathing waters. Compare the Borlish city of Axbane, from the Latin Aquis Balnei "to the bathing waters".

The city was of mostly ceremonial importance through the second millennium, as the seat of the county (then the march, then the duchy) of Avosche within Willemy. Roger Nassow, first duke of Avosche in the early sixteenth century, oversaw the construction and expansion of the Nassow palace complex in the foothills of the Eiffel range which overlooked the city. During this time, the city was in the territory of French Guillenne.

Axton grew dramatically into an industry town around the turn of the nineteenth century and through the Global Workshop period. This was made possible by the advent of transport of freight by convoy [train] instead of by water, since the Rudder and Worm rivers are not navigable by large ships. The city also became a hub for learning, with the Axton Benet School rising in prominence under the stewardship of professors such as mathematician Nicolas Defechet/Niclás de Feght.

##

194.1: Biography of a Mercenary

continued translation from the beginning of [real-life] book The Henchmen of Zenda by KJ Charles, a 2018 pastiche of the 1894 romp The Prisoner of Zenda.

Me reman un lonc veyaç par convey a souvar, un veðr a brandvin sou man, eð un facsimile inscaut cos effus e hortumnesc dy descovan de Rassendyll a cost mey.
There is a long railway journey ahead of me, a glass of brandy to my hand, and a heavily and obscenely annotated copy of the Rassendyll manuscript by my side.

Jo preten a lou cascun benoçar por y vertað digr.
I intend to use them all to tell the truth. 

Jo dign Jasper Detchard. J'er nað com ceyon d'un famigl vige ny bandlau de—o bon Deu, me stou vray?
My name is Jasper Detchard. I was born to a well-off family in the outskirts of—oh dear God, must I?

Nell'ec cont costumner es y histoir linacer dy racontour recitar ant detagl minuçous lonc tre generaçon, ma jo's enter scur ig my leyour es, ða possibr, infruniscendessem meðes par my granmaðr agnat a sey jo.
It is customary in these accounts to rehearse one’s family history in vast detail over three generations, but I am quite sure my reader is, if possible, even less interested in my paternal grandmother than I am.

Ag diabr con. My nom no's Japser Detchard. Quippe l'oc no's i.
To hell with it. My name is not Jasper Detchard. Obviously it is not.

Jo digna un autr nom autr annað, ma jo le teurfeya ny leiçoir par delit divers, ec ersteigon faint par un temertað gra aðief por ig my parent refusaurn l'occajon me parmettr de tan me cavir ablegað d'universtað, e me deleurn par meyan dy Centuir e d'un offiçment ne Hind.
I had another name once, but I stained it at school with various crimes, culminating in a sufficiently serious indiscretion that my parents declined to give me the opportunity of being thrown out of a university too, and disposed of me via the Army and a posting to India.

##

194.2: ou "whether"

ou /u/ [u]
- a particle forming polar questions placed directly after the constituent being interrogated;
- whether, if, whether or not, introducing clauses that are in doubt;
- either, introducing the first of two or more options

Etymology: Old Borlish o ou, "or; question particle", a direct descendant of Latin aut "or". In the last sense, the term was originally used for all the options in a list, but in the modern language the latter options are introduced by ben "or" < Latin bene "well". In the second sense it alternates with ig "that" < Latin ibi "there", which introduced realis clauses; the prototype examples are jo saif ig X "I know that X", jo saif noc ou X "I don't know whether X".

This word is unrelated to homographic ou "egg" < ōvum in Latin.

Se poð ou scadom ben ugnlac accatar.
/se pɔθ u xaˈdɔm bɛn ainˈlak ˌa.kaˈtar/
[se pɔθ u xɐˈdɔm bɛn ɐjnˈlak ˌa.kɐˈtɐː]
rfl can q tomato or onion buy-inf
You can buy either tomatoes or onions.

##

194.3: farau "never mind"

farau /faˈro/ [fɐˈʀo]
- oh well, never mind, no big deal, no sweat, it's OK, an injunction not to worry about something;
- hang in there, c'est la vie, so it goes, a reassurance that things will turn out well despite a setback

Etymology: early Modern Borlish, a clipping of the phrase (still occasionally seen in full) tal farau nos "such is life", literally "so we fare". The verb farar "fare; exist (in a given state)" was borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English faran "go, travel; fare". The expression originally represented commiseration (a sense which it partially retains as a self-directed expletive); in its modern senses it is seen from the nineteenth century.

J'ignoy hayennaç assignar, ma farau.
/ʒajˈnɔj ˌhe.jɛˈnats ˌa.sajˈnar | ma faˈro/
[ʝɐiˈnɔi ˌhejˈnats ˌa.sɐiˈnɐː | ma fɐˈʀo]
1s=forgo.pst homework task-inf | but nvm
I forgot to set homework, no big deal.

##

194.4: skighar "refrain from"

skighar /skaˈjar/ [skɐˈʝɐː]
- avoid, abstain from, to not interact with in some way (as of food, vice, etc);
- eschew, shun, ostracise, exclude, to refuse to associate with (a person or idea) due to fear or moral rectitude;
- refrain from, not do, to stop oneself from performing some action (especially in the infinitive)

Etymology: Old Borlish iskiȝar "to flee, escape"; compare synonymous eschiver in Old French and sċīen "fear, recoil, startle" in Old English, all descending from Classical German sciuhas "frightened, timid, shy". The last senses are now by far the most common, originally a colloquial alternative for prohibitive constructions but now ubiquitous.

Val y signal ou "Abseïr Jug" ben "Skig Acceir"?
/val i sajˈnal u ˌab.ziˈjɪr ʒaj bɛn skaj akˈtsir/
[val i sɐjˈnal u ˌab.zɪˈʝɪː ʝaj bɛn skaj ɐkˈsɪː]
should df sign q be.absent-inf ever or not.do access-inf
Should the sign say "Keep Out" or "No Entry"?

194.5: False Friends (cont. 3)

some more completely arbitrary dictionary entries from the Concise Onomatory o'Merch (fifth edition), a reference work published in 1961 and compiled by the Utcheter Lexical Association.

coke [/kuːk/ "carbon"] n. the corporal [elements] whose atoms have six mora [protons], found in innumerable substances vital for life, as well as multiple inanimate forms like pencil-coke and diamond; any of several black substances which remain after the burning of wood, principally comprising coke. 17C, singular of cokes, colks < northern dialect term colk "apple core; heartwood; lump of coal". Further origin uncertain. Possibly allied with Frise colk "hole, socket", though the semantic connection is tenuous.

iliad [/ˈəi.ʒad/ "glance"] n. the act of directing the gaze towards someone in an attempt to communicate something without words; such an act intended as a flirtation or amorous advance; any act of non-verbal communication esp. with flirtatious intent. 16C in various forms < Roun French uilliad "ogle" < uil "eye" < Latin oculus "æq."; formerly often eyliad or similar by analogy to ey [eye].

oakcorn [/ˈoːkˌkoːn/ "acorn"] n. the fruit of the oak tree; a suit in the Danaw [Danube] deck of cards; vulgarly, the head of the penis or burris [clitoris]. Folk formation from early Merch akern < Old æcern "oakcorn, tree-mast"; in sexual use from the 15C.

urchin [/ˈoː.tʃɪn/ "hedgehog"] n. a small mammal characterised by its spiny back and habit of rolling up into a ball; in military use, an arrangment of spikes scattered across the ground as an obstacle. Alteration of early Merch irchon [/irˈtʃun/] < Drengot French irechon < Vulgar Latin ērīciō < Classical Latin ērīcius "urchin". Displaced contemporaneous iel < Old English iġil "urchin".

195.1: Iron Age Borland

notes in translation on Borland in the Iron Age.

L'Asc de Far inceveu sur Istr Boral a veg temporane cos approximað coll'autr Istr Norðovester ny siecr nouf aN.
The Iron Age began on Borland at approximately the same time as on the other Northwestern Isles [Ireland, GB] in the ninth century aN.

Argutað es l'identiað dy preu forgour ne far n'Istr Boral e tan rent convoluð par ont coincident de tramigraçon, ma tandem l'ec hom denoy Kelt cos identifeyabr.
The identity of the first Borland ironworkers is debated and is made complicated by overlapping waves of migrations, but eventually they became identifiably Kelt.

Y derran signfeyant entrell'ec ont intermane parolour de Brythonic primal sur Albion instançant sur Istr Boral des l'ovest ny siecr catr aN, stant ancestr dy picq reyaum de fortalleç colliner l'istr afferjarant all'hour dell'envajon Roman ny siecr un N.
The last significant such wave was of early Brythonic speakers on Albion settling Borland from the west in the fourth century aN, the ancestors of the small hill-fort kingdoms which covered the island at the time of the Roman invasion in the first century N.

Scein costroinç palæochthon plusour sur Istr Boral ec y migraçon de Kelt preluïscent ma rebenoçað par y Kelt ne lorry rit.
There are several archaelogical structures on Borland which predate the Kelt migrations but which the Kelts repurposed for ritual use.

Y parnommaðessem entrell'ec plaçment es un "labyrinth" noncupað se situant sur Vrug a Çadrosc ny norðovest dell'istr.
The most famous of these sites is a so-called "labyrinth" located on Çadrosc Heath in the northwest of the island.

Scein tan bempart muðel temp dað nell'oc asc, oy "pieðr sarzin" nommað.
There are also many cairns dating to this period, now called "sarzin stones".

195.2: sdroyet "drive"

sdroyet /sdrɔˈjɛt/ [zdʀʊˈʝɛt]
- (archaic, historical) étui, toolbox, a miniature (often ornamental) case for holding small items like needles or other utilitarian things;
- drive, card, a device for storing digital data;

Etymology: diminutive of noun sdroy "depot, warehouse, stockpile", first attested in Middle Borlish isdroȝ "freight, goods transported by water". This was borrowed via synoymous zdruog in contemporary Saxon, likely from Polish zdroi "spring, small stream; origin, source". The historical and modern senses are presumed to be independent derivations; the latter first appears over a century after the former became practically obsolete.

L'a echo vardið ny sdroyet por reðrtien.
/la eˈko varˈdɪθ ni sdrɔˈjɛt pɔr ˌrɛð.r̩ˈtjɛn/
[la ɪˈko vɐːˈdɪθ ni zdʀʊˈʝɛt pɔː ˌʀɛ.ðɐˈtjɛn]
3s=have copy keep-p.pst in-df drive for backup
She's got backup copies on the drive.

195.3: oistr "wedlock"

oistr /ˈɔjs.tr̩/ [ˈɔi.stɐ]
- (poetic) marriage, wedlock, matrimony, the state of being married;
- unity, agreement, consonance, harmony, compatibility, the condition of fitting well together

Etymology: borrowed in the early modern period from old northern dialect term oistre "wife", which descends directly from synonymous uxor in Latin (compare Old French uissor "wife"). The shift in meaning appears to be due to the poet Bautrmeu, who introduced the term to standard Borlish in her work Mornç a Morn "A Piece of the Action". It is presumed that she misinterpreted the (even then archaic) northern idiom prendr n'oistr "to wed, lit. to take as wife" as "to take in wedlock".

Noc saif no's oistr eld ogtoç.
/nɔk sef nɔz ˈɔjs.tr̩ ɛld ɔjˈtɔts/
[nɔk sef nɔz ˈɔj.stɐ‿ʀɛld ʊjˈtɔts]
ng wise ng-be wedlock aged eighteen
Marriage at eighteen is unwise.

195.4: foncçondry "agency"

foncçondry /ˌfɔn.ksɔnˈdri/ [fɔŋ.ksʊnˈdʀi]
- agency, business, establishment, an entity engaged in commerce (usually in the service industry) or the building in which it is located;
- department, office, an administrative unit of a government or its headquarters;
- (in particular, euphemistically) intelligence agency, an organisation for gathering information relevant to national security and defence

Etymology: eighteenth century, derivation via the gestalt-forming suffix -ry from noun foncçon "purpose, use". In turn this was borrowed from Latin fūnctiō "performance, execution (of a task)". The governmental sense is original; in commercial use compare similarly-formed words like vessondry "clothier" and govondry "canteen". In espionage the word is seen from the twentieth century, originally as in-house slang.

Ðe disrn empley broucar n'un foncçondry.
/ðe ˈdɪz.rn̩ ɛmˈpli bruˈkar nɪn ˌfɔn.ksɔnˈdri/
[ðe ˌdɪ.zɐn ɪmˈpli bʀʊˈkɐː nɪɱ ˌfɔŋ.ksʊnˈdʀi]
3p say.pst-3p job have-inf in=indf agency
They said they had jobs at an agency.

##

195.5: Borland in the FIrst Millennium

questions and commentary from the August 2025 edition of an Insular History scitation [exam] taken by many Borlish school students at the age of fifteen.

…rulers of the First Roman Empire personally stepped foot on Borland, and what were the contexts of their visits?

Most students correctly named Claudius and Hadrian; almost all cited the former's role in orchestrating the conquests of Britain and Borland and incorporating them into the Roman Empire, and the latter's tour leading to the creation of a Borlish province (Īnsula Borālum or occasionally Borālia) separate from Britain. Common mistakes included later emperors like Septimius Severus and Constantius Chlorus, who fought in Britain; by the third-century the territory of Borland was much more secure than Britain, having been conquered in its entirely and thus requiring fewer fortifications against incursions. Another mistaken inclusion seen repeatedly was Diocletian, likely due to the curriculum mentioning the creation of the Diocese of Borland (from the former Borlish province) during the administrative reforms of his reign.

4. Describe the process by which the post-Imperial Diocese of Borland became a hereditary monarchy (the First Kingdom of Borland) by the turn of the seventh century.

Answers tended either to parrot the pat narrative of a century ago or, more promisingly, to mirror the state of current scholarship. There are relatively certain historical facts regarding Victor Rossetus (r. ca. 420–?) that most could recall, being the first ruler of a re-cobbled-together Diocese of Borland after the island was abandoned by the state apparatus of the First Roman Empire around the year 400 N and while the west and south of the island were being settled by German peoples. At the other end, the genealogy of the so-called Rosseð dynasty, first royal house of the First Kingdom of Borland (who claimed descend from Victor Rossetus), only becomes more plausible than semi-mythical around 620 N. The two intermediate centuries are frustratingly ill-documented, but the best student responses managed to…

196.1: The Superdraconic Apocalypse

notes in translation on the subject of an event in the geologic record.

L'Apocalyps Surdraconic fornisc nom ag cug d'un sax cisjovial ayent se prodoit cos approximað deur segsant seg cent murðon d'annað, cos plausibr durant y prinvir norðer.
The Superdraconic Apocalypse refers to the fall of a asteroid from the asteroid belt approximately sixty-six hundred myriad years ago, probably during the northern spring.

Ne sy souc sceye l'extirpaçon de tre cart tanc entr toll'orn d'animal, toð dragon abrangent sauf ig l'ancestr d'aucel sceint.
It was followed by the eradication of roughly three-quarters of all animal species, including all dinosaurs bar the ancestors of modern birds.

Y nom dell'oc cainç, oc orðenjað ny siecr novoç com un dob apponmenter (dezein plusour pre scerra y descovart d'evidence concret dy quinment) por l'extirpaçon ny gravatoir reliquyer motivar, jay soumoin a sy zon—temporal ag fin, e donc chthonic a dessur, dell'Asc Draconic (2.5–0.66 gran murdon d'annað paravant). 
The name of this event, coined in the nineteenth century as a hypothetical (several decades before evidence of the impact was actually discovered) to explain the extinction in the fossil record, refers to its location—temporally at the end of, and therefore geologically on top of, the Draconic Age (2.5–0.66 great myriad years ago).

196.2: entrjair "interpose"

entrjair /ˌɛn.tr̩ˈʒer/ [ˌɛn.tɐˈʝeː]
- interpose, insert, wedge, jam, tuck, to place between two things or in the midst of something;
- (reflexive) intervene, mediate, to involve oneself in a situation;
- (reflexive) interrupt, interject, pipe up, to say something as an interruption

Etymology: Middle Borlish, from now-archaic jair "throw" and prefix entr- "between" or directly from Latin intericiō "I throw between" (with remodelling after the Borlish words). Nowadays the word is mostly seen in its reflexive senses.

Dou alumn pagl ny preu rig s'entrjeirn.
/du aˈlɪm.n̩ pɛjl ni prau raj ˌsɛn.tɐˈʒi.rn̩/
[du ɐˈlɪ.mɐn pɛjl ni pʀaw ʀaj ˌsɛn.tɐˈʝɪ.jɐn]
two pupil blond in-df first row rfl=interpose.pst-3p
Two blond schoolkids at the front piped up.

196.3: irruniscabiltað "contradiction"

irruniscabiltað /ɪˌri.niˌxa.bɪlˈtaθ/ [ɪˌʀi.nɪˌxa.bɪlˈtaθ]
- contradiction, paradox, incongruity, inconsistency, unresolvable conflict between two or more parts of something;
- abnormality, oddity, something unusual;
- irregularity, a violation of bureaucratic rules or procedure especially as evidence of a crime

Etymology: noun from irruniscabr "contradictory", itself formed from runir "reunite; reconcile" with the potential suffix -abr and negative suffix ir-, from -ābilis and ir- in Latin. The verb runir comes from Medieval Latin reūniō "I reunite", from ūnus "one". In concrete use describing a particular contradictory thing, the word is attested from the early twentieth century.

Y lat de dou ascreir quocent produg irruniscabiltað.
/i lat de du aˈxrir kwoˈtsɛnt proˈdaj ɪˌri.niˌxa.bɪlˈtaθ/
[i lat de du ɐˈxʀɪː kwʊˈtsɛnt pʀʊˈdaj ɪˌʀi.nɪˌxa.bɪlˈtaθ]
df root of two assign-inf rational cause paradox
Supposing √2 is rational leads to a contradiction.

196.4: droughanç "contribution"

droughanç /druˈjants/ [dʀʊˈʝants]
- intervention, interference, participation, the action of getting involved to affect something;
- contribution, input, something given or offered that adds to a larger whole;
- gesture, act, something done (especially when intended to help)

Etymology: Middle Borlish, noun from droughar "join in, help out, contribute, interfere". This was borrowed from Old English drēogan "to do (a duty)", initially used principally in religious contexts, as of providing Christian charity.

Nos deyeu vos benaular por vossy droughanç.

1p owe-1p 2p thank-inf for 2p-gn contribution
We must thank you all for your contributions.

...hosted Tuesdaily from the 17th for a course of twelve weeks at the Kit and Toad; single contestants will be admitted to teams for the cost of a round of drinks.

The programme will include a suite of excerpts from Cráyenschot's opera Ad Pentaculum, as well as a medley of Merch film music through the decades.

197.2: aðm "treasure"

aðm /ˈað.m̩/ [ˈa.ðɐm]
- treasure, jewel, gem, something extremely valuable;
- darling, dear, sweetheart, a term of endearment for someone one loves;
- lover, mistress, cicisbeo, paramour, beau, an (illicit, unofficial or at least sub-marital) sexual or romantic partner;
- (media) MacGuffin, an object the pursuit of which drives the plot but whose precise identity and qualities are unspecified or irrelevant

Etymology: from Old Borlish aðm "concubine, paramour; (poss.) treasure" (the object sense is contemporaneously unattested, but later use suggests a retention), alteration of presumed *maðm via rebracketing with Old Borlish m(e) "my". It was borrowed from Old English māþm "precious object, jewel". Until the advent of the last sense in the twentieth century, the word had usually been restricted to possessive constructions.

Y duc nos dau l'acconnosc de sell'aðm.
/i dɪk nɔz do ˌla.kɔˈnɔx de sɛˈlað.m̩/
[i dɪk nɔz do ˌla.kʊˈnɔx de sɪˈla.ðɐm]
df duke 1p give-pst df=meeting of 3s-gn=lover
The duke introduced us to his mistress.

197.3: plouçastr "theatre"

plouçastr /pluˈtsas.tr̩/ [plʊˈtsa.stɐ]
- pretence, charade, deception, a faked appearance or series of events;
- pantomime, harlequinade, a clowning and fantastical theatrical performance;
- farce, sham, a ridiculous or inane show;
- theatre, lip service, tokenism, window dressing, pointless actions taken entirely for the look of the thing

Etymology: nineteenth century, pejorative derivation from plouç "screen, disguise; façade, persona". This is a descendant of Latin pluteus "railing; screen", possibly via Old French. The term was originally used in the playhouse senses to describe a style of theatre imported from Saxony. In the last senses it dates to the 1940s in political criticism.

Schol aun lorrell'alumn amenað all'oc plouçastr.
/skɔl on lɔˌrɛ.laˈlɪm.n̩ ˌa.meˈnaθ aˈlɔk pluˈtsas.tr̩/
[skɔl on lʊˌʀɛ.lɐˈlɪ.mɐn ˌa.mɪˈnaθ ɐˈlɔk plʊˈtsa.stɐ]
school have.3p 3p-gn=pupil bring-p.pst to-df=s.px farce
Schools have brought classes to this pantomime.

- publication, spread, trending, the process of something becoming public knowledge;

197.5: Landmarks and Legends

notes on various aspects of the Boralverse alternate history setting which begin with the letter L.

Laurent Burnows (Merch /laːn ˈboː.nəz/, fl. 2002–) is an author from Markland. He rose to fame in the first decade of the 21st century with Back to Front, a series of children's books about a partsicular school class going on time-travel adventures with their teachers. His first foray into a more mature style was the 2015 trevold [novel] The First Thing That Went Wrong, debuting the series An Incovenient Armageddon; the series proved a great success with the audience—now teens and adults—who had grown up with his children's stories.

The Library of Sobjan (Majoric [Hungarian] Sobiani Cønvtár) has a claim to the title of Europe's oldest continuously-operating library, having been commissioned by King Jambor of Awry [Hungary] and built during his reign in the twelfth century. The city of Sobjan [Pécs], close to the Crovatian border, was an early Majoric capital and remains to this day a centre for arts and culture. Notably old items found in the Library include a copy of a 1261N liber numerorum (translated to Latin from Arabic works written in the Single Caliphate) incorporating a computed table of arrhumb [cosine] values, as well as a copy of the first folio of the mysterious Mysarnos Codex (whose rediscovery in 1939 proved that the Codex was written in a form of Greek).

Lux Æterna: The First Century of Threshold Force (Willem Dutch Onslackbar Vlay: Drampelstøweth tÿdes har Rést Ew) is a 2002 work of documentary history by Cawen ba Dirxen, a scholar at the Varonøw [~Vitória, ES] Higher Edifice. It chronicles the theoretical developments necessary for threshold force [nuclear power], as well as the technology's political, economic and social effects over time. The book was commissioned to mark the centenary of the discovery of the atomic nux [nucleus] in 1902 at the city's Nÿstad Atellier.

198.1: Lexember 2025 - 1: offiçar "set"

offiçar /ˌɔ.fiˈtsar/ [ˌɔ.fɪˈtsɐː]
- appoint, nominate, select, elect, to formally name to a particular rank or position of responsibility;
- designate, assign, allocate, to bestow a role or duty upon;
- post, set, emplace, station, deploy, to place at a particular location to perform a particular task

Etymology: late Middle Borlish, a derivation either vernacularly or within Scholastic Latin from noun offiç "office, position; duty, responsibility, task", from synonymous officium in Classical Latin. The term was originally most common in military and ceremonial contexts, and has broadened significantly to many technical settings.

Vos val joddy offiçar ag costosc dy bauglment.
/vɔz val ʒɔˈdi ˌɔ.fiˈtsar ɛj kɔˈstɔx di bojlˈmɛnt/
[vɔz val ʝʊˈdi ˌɔ.fɪˈtsɐː‿ʀɛj kʊˈstɔx di bʊjlˈmɛnt]
2p worth nightwatchman set-inf at defence of-df campsite
You should set watchmen to guard the camp.

Kilshaw Collective

notes in translation on the subject of a group of Merch children's authors.

Y communtað scrittour a Kilshaw sta un çaucr d'autour Markesc toll'ec veunt ne ben jos Kilshaw, un hamblot ny region norðovester de Marclont.
The Kilshaw writers' collective were a group of Merch authors who all lived in or around Kilshaw [Culcheth], a village in the northwestern part of Markland.

Y çaucr sta floriscent durant y dezein meg ny siecr veint, e l'es reconnuð cos principal par lorry ranc plusour editað tras lonc de stoir por ivan.
The group was active through the middle decades of the twentieth century, and is remembered mainly for several long-running series of children's books.

Y ranc de Kilshaw aun se caut tradoit vars eç doçan de lengaç, e bempart son denuð phthongað ne form ig inclus sobot ben phasm.
The Kilshaw series have been translated into dozens of languages, and many have been adapted to formats such as sobot [radio] or phasm [television].

Stoir de Kilshaw affustaurn l'art de scavr, narreyanç ben mensc faint all'eutað eð a nuton ne literatur adult, racont scaunt ne spaiðoir com masquira, comedy soiçal ben trevogt ec heros joun protagoneyant par surcresc.
Stories from Kilshaw made an industry of aping, parodying or homaging trends and fads in adult literature, telling tales in genres like masquira, social comedy or voidtale that happen to feature child protagonists.

Y hamblot es denuð un mojolon cogmaðer petty por famigl joun ben poll'eç envoluð cas livr, ant un relicquat e feir frequent panelleyað de character de Kilshaw.
The village has become a minor tourist destination for families or for the literary-minded, with a museum and regular fetes themed around Kilshaw characters.

198.2: Lexember 2025 - 2: entisar "set"

entisar /ˌɛn.tiˈzar/ [ˌɛn.tɪˈzɐː]
- tighten, tauten, to cause to be under tension;
- strain, stress, to apply force to;
- stiffen, starch, to make rigid via some artificial means;
- lay, set, set up, prepare, arm, (of a trap) to make ready to function via some mechanism;
- cock, ready, prime, to bring a spring (etc.) under tension in advance of firing;
- (esp. reflexive) brace, poise, marshal, steel, to steady or prepare (a person, equipment) for sudden or violent action;
- engage, to bring (a mechanism or device) into a state of readiness or interlock

Etymology: Old Borlish, verbal derivation from tis, tes "taut, stretched". This descends from synonymous tēnsus in Latin, past participle of tendō "I stretch; I strive". The senses pertaining to traps and weaponry, first attested in the fourteenth century, derive from the action of arming a trap or crossbow by placing a string under tension. More general mechanical senses are attested from the seventeenth century, along with the reflexive usage.

L'entisau un traccart ny bosc entr dou casn.
/ˌlɛn.tiˈzo ɪn traˈkart ni bɔx ˈɛn.tr̩ du ˈkaz.n̩/
[ˌlɛn.tiˈzo ɪn tʀɐˈkɐːt ni bɔx ˈɛn.tɐ du ˈka.zɐn]
3s=tauten-pst indf trap in-df wood between two oak
He set a trap in the woods between two oaks.

198.3: Lexember 2025 - 3: beyollir "set"

beyollir /bjɔˈlɪr/ [bjʊˈlɪː]
- set, insert, fit, embed, to affix into a recess or opening (as of a jewel);
- install, build in, to put into a dedicated position during construction;
- slot into, plug in, to place (an outward facing part) into (an opening which it is designed to fit into)

Etymology: Middle Borlish, derivation via the change-of-state suffix -ir, -isc < Latin -ēscō "I become _" from noun beyol "socket, cavity; dimple, divot". This appears to be an Old Borlish backformation from short-lived abiolar "to form a cavity, ?to awl", via Medieval Latin albiolō from Classical alveolus "small hollow; trough, basin". The word has been used for forming electrical connections since the late nineteenth century.

Veleð l'oc smaraut beyollir ne my çondr.
/veˈlɛθ lɔk smaˈrot bjɔˈlir ne mi ˈtsɔn.dr̩/
[vɪˈlɛθ lɔg zmɐˈʀot bjʊˈlɪː ne mi ˈtsɔn.dɐ]
will.sbj-2p df=s.px emerald set-inf in 1s.gn pendant
Please set this emerald into my pendant.

198.4: Lexember 2025 - 4: scið "set"

scið /xɪθ/ [çɪθ]
- known, understood, familiar, recognised, being within one's understanding;
- ordained, determined, having been decided upon by some authority;
- set, fixed, no longer subject to alteration;
- possible, feasible, permissible, being among the options one can or may choose from

Etymology: from Old Borlish scið "known, determined", a direct descendant from Latin scītus "learnt, known, appointed". This was the perfect participle of both sciō "I know" and scīscō "I learn". The last senses reflect the word's Borlish use as the suppletive past participle of poðir "to be able to", whose past tense, imperfect subjunctive and past participle were replaced with forms from sciō in the Old Borlish period. In early use the "fixed" sense was used principally to refer to certain Christian feast days and canonical hours.

Cain entrquïsc n'hour scið par y liesc quic.
/ken ˌɛn.tr̩.kwaˈjɪx nur xɪθ par i ljɛx kwɪk/
[ken ˌɛn.tɐ.kwɐˈʝɪç nʊː çɪθ pɐː‿ʀi ljɛç kwɪk]
fall-3p break in=time set by df term active
Breaks are at set times during the workday.

198.5: Lexember 2025 - 5: orisontment "set"

orisontment /ˌo.ri.zɔntˈmɛnt/ [ˌo.ʀɪ.zʊntˈmɛnt]
- (astronomy) set, the passage of a celestial body below the apparent horizon;
- conclusion, wrap-up, dénouement, the process of something coming to a close;
- (poetic) old age, dotage, the latter years of life;
- (mathematics) convergence, the property of a sequence or analogous object approaching a particular value

Etymology: Middle Borlish, originally a term of art for the first sense, noun derivation from orisontar "set, pass below the horizon". This comes from orisont "horizon; range, limit, ambit" (since displaced in the first sense by lovacq "horizon", from Arabic), via Latin from Greek ὁρῐ́ζων • horízōn "horizon". In mathematics the term is seen from the eighteenth century.

Cain minut alcot prell'orisontment Jovial?
/ken miˈnɪt alˈkɔt prɛˌlo.ri.zɔntˈmɛnt ʒoˈvjal/
[ken mɪˈnɪt ɐˈgɔt pʀɪˌlo.ʀɪ.zʊntˈmɛnt ʝʊˈvjal]
fall-3p minute how.much before-df=set Jovian
How many minutes is it until the set of Jupiter?

The Thirteenth Century

collected notes on various features of the thirteenth century.

Wilhelm Brüz (fl. 1225) was mayor of the city of Augsburg for at least a decade in the first half of thirteenth century. He was a personal friend of Paul von Burchadt, the future first Pope of the Augsburg See, and Brüz's personal ambitions for his city are thought to have influenced some of the religious policy outlines in the Pauline Denuncations of 1225. Brüz was portrayed by Hunter Noteworthy in the 1961 Merch-language film With the North Star to Guide Us, a dramatisation of the events of the German Secession. A magnified statue of Brüz (not based on any extant description or depiction of the man, since none exists) was erected in 1975 outside Augsburg's town hall.

Ivan of Cartaw (fl. ca. 1280) was a lord of Cartaw [Cardiff] who, during his reign, undertook the conquest of the Devon peninsula. Devon had become formally independent from the kingdom of Kernow [Brittany] some decades prior, ruled by a cadet branch of the latter's royal house. Ivan of Cartau's conquest appears to have initially been without the assent or support of his liege King David; nonetheless, the king treated the campaign much like Wales's other territorial gains of the thirteenth century, creating the Tallath of Devon and awarding its rule to Ivan's son Marduth (Ivan having died of an illness shortly after the conquest's completion).

On Unknown Areas Scribed by Arcs (written ca. 1211)  is a work by Tal of Murcia. Containing little original work by the author, it is primarily a translation and compilation of earlier advancements in geometry from Cairene mathemticians. It contains the first attestation of the term mozate "two-dimensional, planar" in its Latinate form muzātus, borrowed from Arabic مُسَطَّح • (musaṭṭaḥ) "flat, even, level".

##

198.6: Lexember 2025 - 6: despondr "set"

despondr /dɛˈspɔn.dr̩/ [dɪˈspɔn.dɐ]
- arrange, organise, set up, to put in useful positions;
- prepare, lay, set, to make ready for use by placing things on or around it in a particular arrangement;
- incline, mind, dispose, prime, to make (someone) more likely to act in a particular fashion;

198.7: Lexember 2025 - 7: ereðmfeyar "set"

ereðmfeyar /eˌrɛð.m̩ˈfjar/ [ɪˌʀɛ.ðɐmˈfjɐː]
- synchronise, sync, to cause to occur at the same time;
- set, wind, regulate, to adjust (a timepiece) so that it displays the correct time;
- align, line up, right, coordinate, harmonise, to position in a symmetric arrangement or (more generally) to cause to take a convenient or aesthetically pleasing form;
- regularise, normalise, standardise, to make more consistent or unexceptional; 
- superimpose, overlap, to place one atop another so that particular parts are in alignment

Etymology: Middle Borlish derivative of ereðm "symmetry; coincidence; happenstance" with the factitive suffix -feyar < Latin -ficō "I make _". The noun descends from Old Borlish eredme "alignment, order, regularity", of uncertain origin. The word has traditionally been connected to Latin rhythmus "rhythm, cadence", ignoring the phonetic problems and the lack of cognates in other Romance languages, mostly due to a dearth of other options. Jasper Detchard's Military Career

continued translation from the beginning of [real-life] book The Henchmen of Zenda by KJ Charles, a 2018 pastiche of the 1894 romp The Prisoner of Zenda.

L'oc me convene fort, con ja Larry es petty demay por mell'arveiðr e demastr demay por my gost.
This [my family disposing of me to India via the Army] suited me well, since England is too small for my fancy and too moralistic for my tastes.

Cos infeliç, y Centuir galau Larresctað cosogr, eð all'envou d'un stoir stendiscent e scur scandalous abrejar, jo me cof depoussað.
Unfortunately, the Army brought Englishness with it, and to cut a long and doubtless shocking story short, I was cashiered.

Jo saleu dy Centuir ant veðrdon nombrous por scrim, un destourm lon mensc, un parnommanç de duvar a joy de blad (just dignað), un autr por broucanç par y fout noc osant se nommar (cos parey), eð un rekest de my famigl por ig jo reconnoscray plu my parenç con lou, dec ðe desiran alcun con mey. 
I left the Army with numerous prizes for swordplay, a dishonourable discharge, a reputation for cheating at cards (fairly earned), another for indulgence in the fuck that dare not speak its name (ditto), and a request from my family that I no longer claim kinship with them, since they wanted none with me.

Jo lour dau l'oç obeïscenç e me nommau Detchard, lonc y toun yon primer jo favuau un segr, e Jasper, par raçon ig ða y fortun dy við an hom es denir un beuscr dy Bel Joy, val aðief y joy luïr toð vars y nuivr.
I did them that service and named myself Detchard, after the first town where I sucked a man off, and Jasper, because if one’s lot in life is to be a Victorian villain, one might as well play the game properly.

- set, to compose a piece of sung music for (a given text);

Unresolved Linguistic History

excerpt in translation from 2004 article A New History of Rust (originally in Borlish as Un Histoir Novel de Rougl), an academic overview of the linguistic history of sub-Roman Borland (approximately, the time after Latin ceased to be regularly written on Borland outside monasteries and before the first surviving longform vernacular texts).

…summary, the chronology of the following changes from Vulgar Latin to Old Borlish: (1) /au/ to /o/, as in Latin causa and Old Borlish cos "matter, thing"; (2) /alC/ to /auC/, as in Latin alter and Old Borlish autre "other"; (3) /al[ə]C/ > /alC/, as in Latin calidus and Old Borlish calt "hot", is irreducibly blurry on the margins. Even if in general these are supposed to have taken place in this order, re-classicisations like taur "bull" (earlier tor) from Latin taurus and mere exceptions like unproductive adjectival suffix -autr from Latin -aliter must be accounted for.

We turn to the question on the early Old Borlish lexicon about which perhaps the most scholarship has been written. Since the Merch linguist Buthick Morstan first suggested the existence of an Insular Latin word *urum "man" in 1909, data supporting her theory has continued to trickle in, while never becoming overwhelmingly convincing. Moreover, even if the majority of experts accept the existence of this word, the field is split on whether it is simply a phonetic variant of Classical Latin virum "man", or else a borrowing from Borland Kelt vurum, urum "man" (compare Brythonic guur, whence Welsh gwr "man").

Morstan was aware of potential surviving traces of this term, such as dialect terms like orrel "penis" and orjan "scarecrow", as well as personal names like Orrin, but she was writing before the discovery of Roman-era…
