Ruritania

collected notes on the small Central European polity of Ruritania.

Ruritania (Borlish Rurtagn, Bavarn Rürzen, Boham Ruravsko) is a minor polity and one of the easternmost European states which primarily speak some variety of German. It is located to the east of Bavarn [Bavaria], to the south of Bohamy [Bohemia] and to the north of Crain [~Slovenia, southern Austria]. Its capital city is Strelsau, located on the banks of the Danaw [Danube].

Toponymy

The traditional account of the origin of the name Ruritania, as a placename derivative of Latin rūs, rūris "countryside", runs into chronological difficulties. Roman control of the region as the province of Noricum shows no evidence of this toponym, and the earliest attestations of the name in the eleventh century do not appear to be Classically inspired (although the modern form <Ruritania> is almost certainly a folk-etymological classicisation based on this account).

In general, linguists expect that there is a Germanic or Slavic origin for the Rur- root. The Rugii, a Germanic tribe who settled the area in the sub-Roman period, are a tempting proposition, although their short-lived Rugiland cannot explain the second -r- in the name. It is also possible that one of the Danaw's tributaries in the region once had a name like Rur (compare the Rure and the Rudder to the northwest), which lent its name to a valley and eventually a state. Multiple Slavic etyma such as rogozi "reeds, rushes" have also been proposed.

The capital is more tractable, being almost certainly a compound of a Slavic root strēla "arrow" and the Germanic placename suffix -au "meadow, floodplain" (the -s- likely representing a Germanic genitive), thought to be in reference to the straightness of the Danaw in the vicinity of Strelsau.

##

200.6: Lexember 2025 - 20: tas "set"

tas /taz/ [taz]
- bag, satchel, waterskin, a smallish cloth or leather container carried on one's person;
- pouch, pocket, a small and soft compartment for carrying things (also the natural pouch of a marsupial);
- vessel, container, any means of carrying anything (in full generality);
- saucer, bowl, a small and shallow piece of crockery;
- divot, hollow, a recess in a surface for holding small items;
- (mathematics) set, the abstract notion of a structure of which things may or may not be elements

Etymology: the conflation in early Modern Borlish of two words with unrelated etyma. Partially a borrowing from Dutch tas, tasch "bag, pouch", which descends straightforwardly from Classical German tascon "purse, pocket". Partially via French from Mostara tasa "bowl, vessel", a borrowing from Arabic طَاس • ṭās "cup". In the mathematical sense from 1831, in translation from Dümmeyer's 1827 work Sammel und Sendungen "Sets and Functions".

Apar cogleu nos y tas de v ne V yon v.m=x.
/aˈpar kɔjˈlaw nɔz i taz de ve ne ve jɔn ve dɔt ɛm val ɛks/
[ɐˈpɐː kʊjˈlaw nɔz i taz de ve ne ve ʝɔn ve dɔt ɛm val ɛks]
through gather-1p 1p df set of v in V where v.m worth x
Thus we get the set of w in W with m(w)=x.

200.7: Lexember 2025 - 21: assignar "set"

assignar /ˌa.sajˈnar/ [ˌa.sɐiˈnɐː]

201.1: Lexember 2025 - 22: niveu "set"

niveu /niˈvaw/ [nɪˈvaw]
- set, track, stream, a subdivision of students formed into a subject class on the basis of aptitude;
- (by extension) tier, echelon, rank, position in an administrative or military hierarchy

Etymology: late 19th century, borrowed from Roun French nivew "level, tier" during educational reforms in the Drengot Collusion (of which Borland was a part). some of-df set four be.3p df writing of musical study-p.prs
Some in the fourth set are learning musical scriptwriting.

Ricardo Ivarrachezurí

notes in translation on a nineteenth-century agricultural scientist.

Ricardo Ivarrachezurí sta un theorist ðaral de Vascony, oc combat faint com mozardist durant y Var Theudesc Dovem.
Ricardo Ivarrachezurí was a farm theorist from Vascony, who fought as a mozardist during the Second German War.

Ivarrachezurí surcay y preu theorist a parcevir ig cuivr sceus sperm occeir, remarc scaunt d'an 1824 ig "y semn dy taur, dy veð ben y stoðr toð parey dienn impossent par mejan de lou vardir tras pieç hour n'un spuit ne cuivr".
Ivarrachezurí was the first theorist to record the ability of copper to kill sperm, noting in 1824 that “the seed of the bull, the ram and the stallion alike are made impotent in storing them for some hours in a syringe of copper”.

I connoy ig l'oc concorda ag mechanism comoscon cuivr coïsce contamen.
He recognised that this was the same mechanism by which copper prevented infections.

Degnant ig l'oc natur poçonnant de cuivr vole alcant aposc benoç sarvent yembr ne contrgentour, Ivarrachezurí le traita com problem por saðour attenent a piver pollenir cos artifiçal.
Although this sterilising property of copper would later be productively used in contraceptives, Ivarrachezurí treated it as a problem for farmers attempting to artificially breed livestock.

Etymology: borrowed from Vascon jahesment "contraption", a derivative of jahès "harness, rig". This in turn was borrowed from Arabic جَهَاز • jahāz "gear, utensil", from a root meaning "to prepare". 201.4: Lexember 2025 - 25: Suthocq "Set"

Suthocq /siˈθɔk/ [sɪˈθɔk]
- Set, Seth, Sutekh, an Egyptian deity with dominion over the desert and foreigners;
- Puck, Robin Goodfellow, a recurring trickster figure in various folk/fairy tales;
- an avatar of Christmas jollity in various parts of northern Europe and Mendeva, representing defiance, glittering frost and brightness in the dark

In the last sense, compare Har Suthock /haː ˈsʊ.ðʊk/ "(lit.) frost Set" in Merch, and Nacho Suthoc "(lit.) little-brother Set" in Ambrosian Vask [Basque].

Etymology: 18th century, originally in translation from Arabic سُتُخ • Sutuch "Set". This in turn comes from the very new (and still somewhat inaccurate) decipherment of hieroglyphs, leading to a surge in interest in Egyptian mythology, reflecting the name now usually transcribed as /suː.tiç/ (whence Coptic ⲥⲏⲧ /seːt/).

The transfer of the name from Egyptian mythology to general folktales is the fault of Dutch writer Ton Cráyenschot, who in the early 19th century repurposed the names of deities of various traditions for the supernatural characters in his short stories. The puckish figure of Har Suttock spread into the culture at large far more successfully than most of his inventions, and had become associated with winter festivals in general and Christmas in particular by the turn of the 20th century.

Y Grec identfeyan Suthocq e Typhon.
/i grɛk ˌi.dɛntˈfjan sɪˈθɔk e tiˈfɔn/
[i gʀɛk ˌi.dɪnfˈfjan sɪˈθɔk e tɪˈfɔn]
df Greek equate-ipf-3p Set and Typhon
The Greeks conflated Set and Typhon.

201.5: Lexember 2025 - 26: bot "set"

bot /bɔt/ [bɔt]
- sheaf, bundle, bunch, a group of thin objects held together by wrapping or tying;
- bale, a quantity of hay (straw, etc) compressed and tied up for transport;
- (attributive) set, package, (of e.g. a menu or something else bought) comprising several items bundled into a single purchase

Etymology: Middle Borlish, borrowed from contemporary Dutch bote "bundle of flax; tuft". This is likely a derivation from the verb bóten "beat", a descendant of Classical German bautō "I beat, knock, push". In attributive use the word is seen from the late nineteenth century, originally in hotels as a calque from Welsh scub seggo "set menu, (lit.) bundle of dishes".

Y desc bot teyen boncoppessem sur ig l'aus hougr.
/i dɛx bɔt tjɛn ˌbɔn.kɔˈpɛ.sɛm sɪr aj loz huj.r̩/

The set menu was cheaper than she'd feared.

False Friends (cont. 4)

some more completely arbitrary dictionary entries from the Concise Onomatory o'Merch (fifth edition), a reference work published in 1961 and compiled by the Utcheter Lexical Association.

glade [/glɛːd/ "sunbeam"] n. a ray, a columnar shaft of sunlight as cast through clouds or canopy; further, a moment of optimism during bleakness or of insight during confusion; a phenomenon of light in the sky near the poles due to the interaction of solar dust with air (also aurorick glade). 15C, early Merch glade, glode "ray of sunlight; sunny place", poss. < unknown Old English glǣd~glād "brightness" related to known glæd "shining, bright". Emotional uses are seen 17C; celestial use from 18C.

jackareigh [/ˈdʒa.kə.ɾɛʃ/ "alligator"] n. either of two large swimming reptiles related to the cockadrills [crocodiles] and native to the Novomund and the Chinas. 17C, from Kentish [-/ri/], via Welsh or Willem Dutch from Yengatow [Tupi] yacaré "jack-a-reigh". Final element adapted to reigh "skate [ray]", partly from Old English reohhe "skate" and partly from Old French raie "skate" (the two are probably related).

toward [/ˈtuː.əd/ "future"] adj. still to come, not yet existing or taking place; of a period of time, next or impending; n. times yet to come, as opposed to now or to times which have already passed. Direct descendant of Old English tōweard adj. "still to come", stressed initially in opposition to homographic tōweard prp. "in the direction of" (modern Merch toward [/twaːd/] "facing").

yuckle [/ˈjʊ.kəl/ "mend"] v. to restore to a state of correct or normal operation; to make whole as by the process of healing; to reattach separated pieces of something broken. 14C early Merch yokelen "reattach", frequentative or diminutive of yoken "yoke, harness", from Old English gegeocian "yoke". Probably unrelated to Old English gēocian "preserve, rescue, save".

201.6: Lexember 2025 - 27: ormal "set"

ormal /ɔrˈmal/ [ʊːˈmal]
- quiver, quiverful, a container for arrows (bolts, darts, etc) or the contents of such a container;
- (obsolete, vulgar) vagina, the sex organ connecting the vulva and the cervix;
- salvo, volley, an instance of concentrated fire from artillery;
- programme, set, the scheduled list of pieces of music that are to be played at a concert (or a similar timeline of discrete events)

Etymology: an Old Borlish borrowing from Old Norse ǫrmalr "quiver". This is a compound of ǫr "arrow" and malr "case"; the former is from Classical German arhuō "arrow", while the latter is likely allied with malhō "leather bag" (although the change of declension is unexplained). The vulgar sense was current in the Middle Borlish period and enjoyed a brief resurgence in the 19th century due to conscious use in historical novels. The musical senses are attested from the 1920s, originally in reference to recorded music played over the radio.

L'ormal dy baðrment fey commet par vrolliscour.

201.7: Lexember 2025 - 28: uscar "set"

uscar /iˈxar/ [ɪˈxɐː]
- usher, lead, to accompany someone (as from the entrance of a building to the approprioate place inside);

Andalus

Notes in translation on the early history of the polity of Andalus.

Andalus es un polity ag souð dy peninsol Spagnart. Y lengaç d'Arabic Morrou e de Spagnart Mostaral se paroln y dou cos lað ny region.
Andalus is a polity in the south of the Spanish peninsula. The languages of Morrove Arabic and Mostara Spanish are both widely spoken in the region.

N'Andalus dy siecr nouf sceye y floriscment de fanglanç theoretic. Cos particuler, machinaçon por veðry produgr acceleran cos veloç dec l'yeul den des l'aust s'istra, oc menant all'enascment lavaç de "veðr zajadau" noncupað.
Ninth-century Andalus saw the flowering of theoretic advancements. In particular, glassmaking techniques accelerated rapidly due to a cut-off of supply from the east, leading to the prodigious export of so-called "jackdaw glass".

L'orn religious dy Brethin respane ny zon de pouvlanç chrestan majortaðer n'Andalus des y norð durant y siecr onç e doç.
The Brethin religious order spread into the Christian-majority areas of Andalus from the north during the eleventh and twelfth centuries.

Nell'oc epoc atorn Andalus parde un sunt signfeyant d'eiðel ag norð e l'aust ne man de polity chrestan, tal com y Reyaum de Barcelon nou stablið.
Around this time Andalus lost significant territory in the north and east to Christian polities, such as the newly-established Kingdom of Barcelon.

- array, lay out, to put into an orderly arrangement (especially to form into rows);

202.3: Lexmber 2025 - 31: se corruð "set"

se corruð /se kɔˈrɪθ/ [se kʊˈʀɪθ]
- sitting pretty, made in the shade, set for life, living on easy street, having a comfortable or certain supply of money or resources;
- made, set, happy, having removed any obstacles and anticipating smooth sailing from here on in;
- in the clear, home free, out of the woods, past the hard slog and properly equipped for future challenges;
- bulletproof, watertight, on solid ground, having made oneself completely secure;
- ready, prepared, good to go, locked and loaded, shipshape, having sorted out any issues and fully able to proceed

Etymology: past participle of se corrir "make it, survive, get through, succeed", the reflexive of corrir "run". This descends directly from Latin currō "I run". Idiomatic use of this phrase is seen from the fifteenth century poetry of Manuel Kigman. The phrase appears to have originally referred to simply being well-off or comfortable; semantic association with the verb has more recently given the idiom connotations of past struggle and present battle-readiness.

Posc resoum nos y fastig, nos arreu se corruð contrell'yarn.
/pɔx reˈzum nɔz i faˈstaj | nɔz aˈraw se kɔˈrɪθ ˌkɔn.trɛˈljarn/
[pɔx ʀɪˈzum nɔz i fɐˈstai | nɔz ɐˈʀaw se kʊˈʀɪθ ˌkɔn.tʀɪˈljɐːn]
after fix-1p 1p df roof | 1p have-fut {set} against-df=winter
Once we fix the roof, we'll be set for winter.

202.4: mornç a morn "piece of the action"

mornç a morn /ˈmɔr.n̩ts a mɔrn/ [ˈmɔːns a mɔːn]
- piece of the action, foot in the door, an opportunity to take part in some activity;
- percentage, cut, commission, share, a portion of the monetary (or otherwise) gains produced by some venture

Etymology: idiom from the early modern period, literally meaning "bite at a carrot". The phrase was coined by the poet Bautrmeu as the title of her 1654 compendium of works. The word mornç "bite" is a noun from verb mordr "bite", which descends from Latin mordeō "I bite"; the word morn "carrot" was borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English moran, plural of more "carrot, parsnip".

Casc toun ajos son un mornç a morn flagitant.

each town nearby be.3p indf bite at carrot demand-p.prs
Each suburb is demanding a piece of the action.

202.5: Braxoch beet

excerpt from a page from the distributed library on the Markland vicine mesh, about the braxoch beet.

…variously also named golden beet, gilt beet, manegold, sweetbeet, is a variety of beet (plant ✾2.1.17.1) which is characterised by the golden flesh and high sugar content of its root. Cultivation of braxoch beet is responsible for a significant fraction of sugar production in many temperate polities: as of 2025 it originated over four parts in five of sugar consumed everywhere on Albion. 

The name braxoch first enters the Merch language in the 1740s, via Borlish and Polish from Cassuvian braxoch "fine beet", an augmentative of brac "beet", which reflects Medieval Latin borāgō "borage" (further origin disputed).

History

The Willem [~NE France, NW Germany, Benelux] botanist Tewis Camigner, who was active during the Revitalist period in the sixteenth century, offers the first surviving written sources noting the high sugar content of beet, describing the billrod [cochineal red] hue and sweetness of a syrup he extracted from natural beets. However, the low concentration of sugar (perhaps one part in eighty) and the presence of other untasteful substances in the syrup made it no substitute for the sugarcane increasingly cultivated in the Novomund [Americas] over the following two centuries.

This changed with the Pentrose survey of the 1730s. Borland having recently been severely limited in its access to Novomundine trade, the state coordinated with the University of Pentrose to locate productive or otherwise useful cultivars of many plants. The survey's crowning glory was the development of the braxoch, which seems to have been a hybrid of Silesian and Cassuvian stock. 

Alchemy

The golden colour and high sugar content of the braxoch beet are intimately connected. The clause [gene] which instructs beet to produce its red pigments is located in the same heredian volume [chromosome] (volume II), very near a clause regarding the production of a sugar tinderbox [enzyme]. It is believed that beet breeding led to miscopying of this volume which simultaneously broke the red pathway (causing yellow pigments to predominate) and triggered a much higher rate of sugar production in the root.

Altering volume II also led to a thinner, more brittle skin, which would usually leave such beet more vulnerable to fungal infection during growth (partially explaining, in an Iscovalian sense, why this presentation is absent in the wild). However, braxoch beet exhibits another, independent alteration; it produces a non-functional iron marker [sensor]. This causes it to remain stuck in a low-iron regime, producing a much higher concentration of oromarynx [riboflavin; vitamin B₂], a yellow-orange substance and aqueous essence [water-soluble vitamin]. Oromarynx, which gleams under surblavic [UV] light, also has counterzoic [anti-microbial] properties which are activated by exposure to such light.

Hence, alterations which are individually costly become…

203.1: Saxony

notes in translation on a German polity.

A mesur dy Scon Tetrarchy, y Reyaum a Saxony intermane un stat vassaler majour nell'Empir Teudesc administrað des Bardovic, e plusour ne lour dynasty de Hohenbrocken regnaurn sull'empir enter.
During the Second Tetrarchy, the Kingdom of Saxony was a major vassal state of the German Empire administered from Bardwick, and many of their Hohenbrocken dynasty ruled the empire outright.

Y Reyaum a Saxony deneu toccað par y sfondranç dy Scon Tetrarchy ny siecr treç.
The Kingdom of Saxony was affected by the collapse of the Second Tetrarchy in the thirteenth century.

Y Stadbond smargent de citað marcander ag norð secedeu eð abascau Saxony vars sell'eðegl amont a Magdbourg e Lepcy.
The nascent Stadbund of mercantile cities in the north seceded and reduced Saxony to its lands upstream in Maidburg and Lepzi.

Cossirað es ig Saxony a y plurem dy vajot vancað des y Var Theudesc Primer; ny souc den y polity gourna may d'eiðel a alcot seyon posseut n'aucun hour de sy histoir.
Saxony is considered to have profited most from the First German War; in its aftermath the polity controlled more territory than it had at any point in its history.

Durant y siecr novoç, y Çaucr Azur Marian (oc instaurað a Lepcy) tarromoy commouð vars reform cas ley de heritanç e de dreit slecçonal.
In the nineteenth century, the Blue Marian Society (which was founded in Lepzi) spearheaded movements for reform to inheritance and suffrage laws.

203.2: cug "fall"

cug /kaj/ [kaj]
- fall, drop, descent, motion downward;
- decrease, decline, reduction, the lessening of a value;
- downfall, defeat, loss, doom, an (especially precipitous) erosion of status;
- slide, flume, chute, slope, a structure along which things are made to travel from a higher to a lower position;
- (poetic) passing, death, the end of a person's life;
- (legal) nullification, repeal, the act of invalidating something (especially an act of law);
- (specifically) annulment, the dissolution of a marriage on the grounds that it was never formally valid

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish cauȝ, cuȝ /kaˈyɣ ~ kyɣ/ "fall, descent", which reflects Latin adjective cadūcus "falling; doomed; futile; (law) lapsed". The word is seen in metaphorical use almost at once; for physical downward slopes it may have been influenced by Norman cute "fall; chute". Poetic and legal usages are both attested from the late Middle Borlish period.

L'intermane un cug de sy caldour corpore.
/lɪnˌtɛr.maˈne ɪn kaj de si kalˈdur ˌkɔr.poˈre/
[lɪnˌtɛː.mɐˈne ɪŋ kaj de si kɐlˈdʊː ˌkɔː.pʊˈʀe]
3s=compose-imp indf fall of 3s.gn heat bodily
It was a decrease in her body temperature.

203.3: lat "root"

lat /lat/ [lat]
- side, edge, a one-dimesional segment of the surface of a shape;
- root, a number which when raised to a given power yields a particular quantity (especially the square root);
- cusp, precipice, an abrupt boundary between two relatively smooth planes;
- verge, brink, threshold, an edge or margin before a sudden or dramatic change

Etymology: Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Latin latus "side, flank". Originally used in geometry, and extended to the arithmetic usage by analogy to the example of a square's area and side-length. Senses referring to metaphorical sudden boundaries are attested from the eighteenth century.

Y lat vorpal de cinq cent e doç val ogt.

203.4: vry "prestige"

vry /vri/ [vʀi]
- prestige, status, cachet, fame, esteem, the state of being well-thought-of by people;
- power, influence, the ability to effect one's will or to have people consider one an authority;
- kudos, acclaim, accolades, praise, credit for one's achievements

Etymology: nineteenth-century borrowing from a lenited form of Welsh bri "prestige, honour". This descends from pre-Classical Kelt brīgos "importance, weight", though to be cognate with Latin gravis "heavy". Originally a somewhat déclassé slang term, the word had passed into the ordinary register by the mid-twentieth century. A brief period of use as a approbatory interjection was over outside ironic mimicry by the 1980s.

Un Honour de Hatfell gajannar gal vry moulous.
/ɪn oˈnur de hatˈfɛl ˌga.ʒaˈnar gal vri muˈluz/
[ɪn ʊˈnʊː de hɐtˈfɛl ˌga.ʝɐˈnɐː gal vʀi mʊˈluz]
indf honour of Hatfell win-inf escort kudos hefty
Winning a Hatfell Honour carries great cachet.

##

203.5: Through the Ages 2

more collected notes on a variety of background figures in Boralverse history, listed in chronological order.

Nadàlla fi Carol was an influential figure in the early years of the city of Santrafew [~Boston, MA], one of the first trading posts in Mendeva [NA] established by Provence. She was raised as the eldest daughter of town reverend Carol Zancoud, and as an adult she helped to author the 1621 Becouin Treaty which defined the amicable relationship of the traders with the local Mastòiset [Massachusett] people for several decades. She is rumoured to have carried on an affair with the runaway heir to the Avosche duchy in her youth, although she makes no mention of such a relationship in her surviving diaries.

Dorothe Shock was the original proprietress of the De Marnoshring emporium in the early nineteenth century, which over the following two hundred years would become a quasipolitic guild [multinational corporation] controlling much of the market for children's toys and various material hobbies. She ran a store in the Saxon city of Miszen [Meissen], originally alone but from 1813 alongside her younger brother.

Agathe Bisset (d. 2025) was a French politician and author. Born in Blois during the latter years of the Drengot Collusion, she held various background positions in parliaments of France in the decades following its dissolution, only attaining wider recognition via her works of popular fiction from the 1990s onward. Her most successful work, 2003's Hommes en Noir (Men in Black), chronicles stories of spycraft and espionage from ancient times to the modern day; her mother's alleged position as a mid-century spy at the Ministry for Information may have been the source for some of Bisset's more recent accounts.

##

204.1: Campottonì

notes on the New Provincial city of Campottonì.

L'instançment vivota a mesur dy siecr ogtoç deut ag terrentað merscous e contrsalubr e tan all'eç ottem havan dereðr dy floy e sceindessem derim.
The settlement languished through the eighteenth century due to unfavourable marshy terrain and the better harbours across the river and further inland.

Sy fortun cambisceu ny siecr novoç cosogr l'alant de moneð: caye fosseyað un canal de sdroy majour trenc faint tras y peninsol (eð y Guittoc vars y doujug lucraðeu a Squanna conjognent), eð y merscaç ag maugr de Campottonì deneurn canalfeyað e darfað cos drastic.
Fortunes changed in the nineteenth with an influx of funds: a major shipping canal across the peninsula (connecting the Guittoc to the wealthy Esquanna [Susquehanna] river system) was dug, and the marshlands surrounding Campottonì were drastically canalised and drained.

Slargiscment ancour dy canal figheu loy a plaç entarn dy siecr veintem.
Further widening of the canal took place into the twentieth century.

Reconnuð cos brey com y "Venis a Mendeva", Campottonì accareu un parnommanç d'eutað durant l'epoc Bel Joy e fo nell'asc modern sorguð vars denir un aucoum forcer cas cultur eð empory.
Briefly known as the "Venise of Mendeva [North America]", Campottonì gained a fashionable reputation during the Good Game Period [late 19C] and by the modern day had risen to become a cultural and economic powerhouse.

##

204.2: quil çaveyour "feather bed"

quil çaveyour /kwɪl tsaˈvjur/ [kwɪl tsɐˈvjʊː]
- feather bed, a soft mattress filled with down;
- (metonymically) easy street, comfort, well-being, security, the concept of a comfortable life;
- mod con, amenity, some device or feature that makes one's life more convenient

Etymology: phrase attested from the early modern period, literally "cushioner bed". This is an early example of a compound-forming construction, much more prevalent in the modern language, which uses agent nouns as modifiers. The noun quil "bed" descends directly via Old Borlish quil, coil "bed, cot" from Latin cubīle "bed, couch; lair, kennel"; the verb çaveyar "cushion, soften; sugarcoat, sanitise" is a derivative of çaveyal "pillow", descending from synonymous cervīcal in Latin. Use as a mascot for easy living is seen from the nineteenth century, and has persisted likely due to its use in some evergreen folk songs.

Jo dout ouð y quil çaveyour vel lou incombir.
/ʒo dut uθ i kwɪl tsaˈvjur vɛl lu ˌɪn.kɔmˈbɪr/
[ʝo dut u‿ði kwɪl tsɐˈvjʊː vɛl lu ˌɪŋ.kʊmˈbɪː]
1s doubt whether df bed cushioner will.sbj 3p.acc befit-inf
I doubt life on easy street would suit them.

##

204.3: alant a haun "homecoming"

alant a haun /aˈlant a hon/ [ɐˈlant a hon]
- landfall, the end of a sea voyage;
- homecoming, the act of returning to one's home;
- (by extension) safe habour, deliverance, sanctuary, respite, the attaining of a position of safety after an extended period of danger or uncertainty

Etymology: collocation originating in Kigman's fifteenth-century poetry, literally meaning "docking at a haven". The noun alant "landfall" is a deverbal from alandar "arrive, turn up, dock"; this was borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English ġelendan "approach, arrive". The noun haun "haven, port" was borrowed from Old Norse hǫfn "harbour".

The phrase was used by Kigman already to mean a return to a metaphorical homeland; it had become synonymous with safe places more generally by the end of the following century.

Nos coum alant a haun posc tan semman.
/nɔz kum aˈlant a hon pɔx tan sɛˈman/
[nɔz kum ɐˈlant a hon pɔx tan sɪˈman]
1p get.pst-1p landfall at haven after so.much week
We made landfall after so many weeks.

204.4: ne traiscn "late"

ne traiscn /ne trex.n̩/ [ne ˈtʀe.xɐn]
- slow, behind, (of a timepiece) showing a time earlier than the true time;
- late, delayed, occurring after the scheduled time due to unforeseen events or inefficiencies;
- laggy, buffering, responding slowly due to high latency

Etymology: originally horological jargon used by clockmakers, attested from the seventeenth century, literally "in lag". The noun traiscn "lag, delay" is a deverbal from traiscnar "trail, drag behind, lag", which reflects a Vulgar Latin verb traxinō "I drag, pull, tug" which extends the verb trahō in Classical Latin. The word has been extended from clocks to public transportation and then to computing in the modern era.

Casc phasmet tienn ne traiscn coll'oc emblemat.
/kax faˈzmɛt ˈtjɛn.n̩ ne ˈtrex.n̩ kɔˈlɔk ˌɛm.bleˈmat/
[kax fɐˈzmɛt ˈtjɛ.nɐn ne ˈtʀe.xɐn ˌkɔ.lʊ‿ˌgɛm.blɪˈmat]
each clip hold-3p in lag with-df=s.px mosaic
Every video keeps buffering at this resolution.

204.5: Mathematical Etymology (cont. 2)

more excerpts from the Veriloquace Glossary o'Mathematics, a reference quire in the Merch language compiled by Rotcham [Rochdale] University Primers.

covrend adj. [/ˈkʊ.vɾənd/ "surjective"] that given W → X : m, for every x in X there is some w in W sent there; considering m as a portioning of W + X, that no ~!x is empty. 1831 < translation of Saxon deckend in Dümmeyer (1827), participle of decken "cover" < Classical German thaciō "I cover" (cognate with Merch thatch).

horizontal adj. [/ˌhɔ.ɾɪˈzɔn.təl/ "convergent"] that there is a value where, no matter which neighbourhood of the value is chosen, a given sequence or analogous object is eventually contained within that neighbourhood. Around 1750 < Scholastic Latin horizontālis, adjectival derivation of horizō "horizon; [limit]" < Greek ὁρίζω • (horízō) "divide, separate, mark out".

mirthon num. [/ˈmeː.ðʊn/ "ten thousand"] a quantity of ten thousands or one hundred hundreds. Around 1400 < slightly earlier mirth (possibly influenced by e.g. Kentish or Norman) < Middle Welsh myrð "mirthon" < Latin mȳriadēs "many thousands" < Greek μῡρίος • (mūríos) "countless". Originally and still poetically for any large quantity.

sevrend adj. [/ˈsɛ.vɾənd/ "injective"] that given W → X : m, for every x in X there is at most one w in W sent there; considering m as a portioning of W + X, that no ~!x has two distinct members. 1831 < translation of Saxon sondrend in Dümmeyer (1827), participle of sondren "separate" < Classical German sundrō "I separate".

zeffergoer n. [/ˈzɛ.fəˌgu.ə/ "root"] a value which a given W → X : m sends to zeffer [zero]. 1897, compound of numeral zeffer and verb go; the former from Arabic صِفْر • ṣifr "empty, void" (see entry for further detail) and the latter from Classical German gō "I go".

205.1: Detchard in the Demimonde

continued translation from the beginning of [real-life] book The Henchmen of Zenda by KJ Charles, a 2018 pastiche of the 1894 romp The Prisoner of Zenda.

Alor sceye jo la, desracinað, sgarant, rebateyað n'un við novel lon famigl ben histoir.
So there I was, rootless, wandering, rebaptised into a new life without family or history.

Jo fey regres des Hind vars l'ovest par my blad, faur, e spað, ma jo skighau alcun feu Larresc ðocar.
I worked my way back from India using my cards, wits, and blade, but did not trouble England’s shores.

Y tarmagn d'Europ es un jagat accoglendessem por y semblant de mey: aventurer, nomad, gentilhom volour e gentilhom stoccour, domn dy jorn e dy noit, hasardour e vlangr e dragoman de rumour, aristocrat rent abascað, routuron ne cognit s'enhautiscent cos precartaðer.
The Continent is a more welcoming place for my sort of people: adventurers, wanderers, gentleman thieves and gentleman thugs, ladies of the day and night, gamblers and fences and information brokers, aristocrats brought low, masquerading commoners reaching dangerously high.

Nos sodal dell'oç tribu cougln e soun við e lengaç e païs, com un confraðreç teun d'outrley ant un glonscel de fieltað e d'enmigtað ancour teunessem, e se poð un parson parey encontrar a mesur d'annað n'un madrugour a Berlin, un palaç a Praug, eð un gajon a Rom.
We of that tribe drift in and out of lives and languages and countries, a loose fraternity of rogues with a looser tangle of loyalties and rivalries, and one may see the same face over the course of years in a Berlin nightspot, a Prague palace, and a Roman gaol.

Par mejan de bustr solter: j'er ne Vien cant primer j'encontrau un domn Fransc magn bonet eld settoç svingað com aðm par un trocour mentaç eld tre vey maissem.
To give a single example: I was in Vienna when I first met a very pretty Frenchwoman of seventeen flaunted as mistress by a dishonest stockbroker three times her age.

Jo l'encountrau aval prose cant jo cof laur com batman an bosty reloð e condonant a strem a Dresden yon la luïsce sona d'ouger sull'eudæmony.
I next encountered her when I was hired as bravo at an extremely elegant and accommodating brothel in Dresden where she presided over the festivities.

La me reconnoy incommorant—oc bogr ðesmal, dec j'aye sy preu patron occeut avant luy—ma la retenoy min douç cos absoluð a them de toll'affer, my time destarriscent n'affirmant ig l'aye lo stimað ennoyant com aye l'eç ayent hur me dað oc por.
She recognised me at once—unsurprisingly, as I had killed her first protector in front of her—but she was utterly charming about the whole business, assuring me that she had found him as tiresome as the people who had hired me to do it.

205.2: harvougl "earwig"

harvougl /harˈvujl/ [hɐːˈvwɪl]
- earwig, any of various winged insects with elongated bodies and rear-pointing pincers;
- earbud, a small speaker placed into the ear canal;
- (intelligence) handler, someone at a base who remotely directs an intelligence asset in the field

Etymology: originally in the first sense, from Old Borlish horvoȝl, erveȝl "earwig". Thought to be partially from Vulgar Latin forficula "small scissors", diminutive of forfex "scissors", and partially from Old English ēarwicgel "earwig". The development of the initial consonant is unexplained, but compare Vascon horveix "earwig". Folklore connecting the insect to ear-burrowing influenced the modern senses, first attested in the twentieth century.

Me soupren ig ja n'ay jo l'ec harvougl pars.
/me suˈprɛn aj ʒa ne ʒo lɛk harˈvujl parz/
[me sʊˈpʀɛn aj ʝa ne ʝo lɛk hɐːˈvwil pɐːz]
1s.obl surprise cmp yet ng=have.1s 1s df=p.px earwig lose.p.pst
I'm surprised I haven't lost my earbuds yet.

205.3: vrolliscour "crowdpleaser"

vrolliscour /ˌvrɔ.liˈxur/ [ˌvʀɔ.lɪˈxʊː]
- entertainer, performer, one who puts on a show for an audience;
- crowdpleaser, someone or something that is (reliably) entertaining for an audience

Etymology: nineteenth century, agentive derivation from verb vrollir "please, entertain, cheer, gladden". This itself is a backformation from noun vrollisc "entertainment, fun", borrowed in the early modern period from a Willem or Saxon Dutch adjective like vrolic, frolich "merry, cheerful". In the modern period, when referring to a person, the word often denotes someone who has an online audience.

Y vrolliscour er pildr entisour cirteyant.
/i ˌvrɔ.liˈxur ɛr ˈpɪl.dr̩ ˌɛn.tiˈzur tsɪrˈtjant/
[i ˌvrɔ.lɪˈxʊː‿ʀɛː ˈpɪl.dɐ‿ˌʀɛn.tɪˈzʊː tsɪːˈtjant]
df entertainer cop.imp pill stiffener peddle-p.prs
The influencer was hawking boner pills.

205.4: barricheyar "electrify"

barricheyar /ˌba.riˈkjar/ [ˌba.ʀɪˈkjɐː]
- power, hook up, to connect to a source of electricity;
- electrify, charge, to power by means of electricity;
- galvanise, energise, thrill, excite, to render delighted or eagerly anticipatory;
- shock, zap, to cause electricity to pass through (as to cause pain or death)

Etymology: nineteenth century, verbal derivative with the causative suffix -eyar < Latin -idiō, -izō "I make _" from adjective barric "electric" (formerly also a noun, now displaced by astraphor "electricity", from Greek). This in turn entered Borlish during the previous century, originating in Arabic رْق • barq "lightning". In metaphorical or emotional use the word is attested almost at once.

Y visn brasser ag port me barricheyau y man.
/i ˈvɪz.n̩ braˈsɛr ɛj pɔrt me ˌba.riˈkjo i man/
[i ˈvɪ.zɐn bʀɐˈsɛː‿ʀɛj pɔːt me ˌba.ʀiˈkjo i man]
df knob brass-adj at.df door 1s.obl zap-pst df hand
The brass doorknob gave me an electric shock.

205.5: The Alphabet

excerpt from near the end of the Concise Onomatory o'Merch (sixth edition), a reference work published in 2001 and compiled by the Utcheter Lexical Association.

…a clouded wine fermented from rice, brewed across Asia from northeastern Hind [India] to Nivon [Japan]. Around 1700 as zito < Napolitan zito, zuto "rice wine" < Tenivian [Angami] ʐúthó. Respelt in the nineteenth century in line with the possible cognate in Greek ζῦθος • (zûthos) "an Egyptian barley beer".

Afterwords

1. Th'Alphabet

a ba ce dy e ef ge,
hake i jot, kea el em;
en o pa qua ro es te
u va win, ex wy zed.

The letter names in Merch are a mixture, some descending from Old English futhork runes and others from Old Northern French names for the Latin letters.

The vowels a e i o u [/ɛː iː əi uː jəw/] reflect Latin; four from early Merch long vowels [/aː eː iː oː/] and the last from the adaptation of ONFr [/y/] to [/juː/]. The name of the half-vowel y [/wəi/] is of unclear origin, but usually supposed to be a combination of the names of u and i (compare ONFr ui and modern Borlish oy "Y").

The inverted names ef el em en es [/ɛf ɛl ɛm ɛn ɛs/] come via ONFr from Latin, unusual for ending with their associated sound instead of starting with it. The names of kea ex zed [/kɛː ɛks zɛd/] also come from Latin for lack of any corresponding rune (although some scholars suggests that the ill-attested elhs "elks" rune may have contributed to "X").

Other borrowings via ONFr from Latin are ce ge hake te [/siː dʒiː hɛːk tiː/]; alternatively, the name for "T" may stem from a rebracketing of tue < OE tiw as te + u due to the following u in the alphabet.

Descendants of OE futhorc include dy ro win [/dəi roː wɪn/] < OE dæg rād wynn. The "R" name showcases final-consonant deletion, which also happened to ba pa qua [/baː paː kwaː/] < OE berc perþ cƿerþ in the early modern period as a form of regularisation.

The final two letters are jot and va [/dʒɔt vaː/]; the first is an early Merch borrowing via Latin iōta from Greek ιῶτα • (iôta) "iota" used to distinguish the consonant j from the vowel i, and the second is an alteration of earlier vaw (likely by rebracketing with the following win) borrowed in the early modern period via Latin vau from (presumed) Greek ϝαῦ • (waû) "waw".

2. The Numbers

one two thre…

206.1: Borrhatic League

notes in translation on the Borrhatic League.

L'Alleyanç Borrhatic es un congeries de colluy indrec e de band por gest politic oc caglou irrayant sur gournment laïc, condoçment e (ne dezein recent) tan promoçon de paç e de reclam.
The Borrhatic League is a collection of charitable organisations and political action groups with a focus on laic governance, education and (in recent decades) also pacifism and objection.

L'Alleyanç se macquau des collaboraçon entr communtað de creinç minortaðer ny clas ovrer tras Europ Norðer ny siecr novoç primal.
The League grew from collaboration between working-class groups of minority faiths across Northern Europe in the early nineteenth century.

L'Alleyanç denoy primer prominent ag taug de polity a mesur dy Var Teudesc Dovem ny dezein 1820 e par y souc den.
The League first rose to prominence on the scale of polities during the Second German War of the 1820s and in its aftermath.

Com bustr, Hilgart e Michel Bervisson broucan influyenç nell'Alleyanç Borrhatic n'Istr Boral lor, cos particuler cas hortaminanç vars soffrisc religious.
For instance, Hilgart and Michael Bervisson were influential in Borland's Borrhatic League at this time, especially with regards to calls for religious tolerance.

Malgrað ig l'Alleyanç Borrhatic eð y commouð a Desveyanç contemporane son discrepað (cos occajonal conflagrant), reconnuð es y dou aun parol contriboit ny Declaraçon Laïc d'an 1850 ne Belgrad.
Although the Borrhatic League and the contemporaneous Deviance movement have had (occasionally explosive) disagreements, both are known to have contributed verbiage to the 1850 Laic Declarations in Belgrade.

206.2: aðaun "as one"

aðaun /aˈðon/ [ɐˈðon]
- (archaic, poetic or dialect) as one, together, at the same time or place or doing the same thing;
- (legal) in agreement, united, unanimous, without any dissent;
- in unison, in chorus, tutti, acting together in e.g. playing music or singing;
- (interjection) let's go, now, an exhortation to simultaneous action

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish aðaun, extended variant of synonymous aun "together, at the same time". This comes either from a Late Latin phrase ad ūnum "at one" or from a deverbal of adūnō "I unite". Current in the language until the early modern period, it has fossilised in legal and musical uses; the interjection appears to have been reborrowed in the twentieth century from rural dialects that retained the term.

Y torriot hoissaurn ag preu gran entrjainç aðaun.
/i tɔˈrjɔt hɔjˈsor.n̩ ɛj prau gran ˌɛn.tr̩ˈʒents aˈðon/
[i tʊˈʀjɔt hʊiˈsoːn ɛj pʀau gʀan ˌɛn.tɐˈʝens ɐˈðon]
df bassoon blow-pst-3p at.df first big section tutti
The bassoons played in the first big tutti section.

206.3: çondr "pendant"

çondr /ˈtsɔn.dr̩/ [ˈtsɔn.dɐ]
- pendant, a piece of jewellery which hangs down as an ornament (as attached to a necklace or earring);
- locket, such an ornament which can be opened to store some item of sentimental value;
- charm, amulet, bead, medallion, trinket, a small item attached to e.g. a bracelet especially as having notional protective properties

Etymology: Middle Borlish, via contemporary French from Tuscan ciondolo "pendant, charm". This is a deverbal from ciondolare "dangle, swing", which is thought to reflect a Vulgar Latin exundulō "I sway", from unda "wave". The Borlish term has broadened to cheaper and less precious ornaments than its cognates in other languages.

Catr çondr sur sy boucr dreçn "ðurr".
/ˈkat.r̩ ˈtsɔn.dr̩ sɪr si ˈbuk.r̩ ˈdrɛts.n̩ ˈðɪr.r̩/
[ˈka.tɐ ˈtsɔn.dɐ sɪː si ˈbu.kɐ ˈdʀɛ.tsɐn ˈðɪː.ʀɐ]
four pendant on 3s.gn loop spell-3p burn-inf
Four charms on his bracelet spelt "burn".

206.4: erref "rescue"

erref /ɛˈrɛf/ [ɪˈʀɛf]
- retrieval, recovery, restoration, return, salvage, the act of getting something back that was lost;
- rescue, salvation, liberation, relief, delivery, the saving of something or someone from danger;
- redemption, reformation, changing of one's character for the better

Etymology: Middle Borlish, deverbal from errevir "rescue". This reflects Old Borlish erever, erevre "save, redeem", from Latin ēripiō "I set free; I remove", related to rapiō "I grab, seize". In early use the term often had religious connotations, referring to the redemption of the world by Jesus Christ.

Jamay n'a y Caðer ne Pieðr Roug erref se caut.
/ʒaˈme na i kaˈðɛr ne ˈpjɛð.r̩ ruj ɛˈrɛf se kot/
[ʝɐˈme na i kɐˈðɛː ne ˈpjɛ.ðɐ ʀʊj ɪˈʀɛf se kot]
never ng=have df chair in stone red return rfl get.p.pst
The Redstone Chair has never been recovered.

206.5: The Scathe of Saint Sophia

excerpted from 2014 popular history textbook The Fourth Burning of London, and other Screwups: the Eventful History of Things Going Wrong, written in collaboration with the Faculty of Domain History at the University of Huzatre [~Bayonne] by writer (formerly and more famously of historical lovetales) Galarça fi Molhomé, who undertook her studies there.

…by Nicolà sAvignon, who in the fourteenth century led the renovation and expansion of Saint Sophia's Cathedral [the Hagia Sophia] in Stamboul [Istanbul], which had stood mostly unchanged since its construction in the sixth century during Justinian I's reign. It has been suggested that the expansion was commissioned in order to cement the cathedral as the largest one in all Christendom; challengers in Valencia and Augsburg were in the process of being built at that time that would have surpassed it if not for sAvignon's redesign.

There is a popular theory that sAvignon is responsible for the Scathe of Saint Sophia—despite the fact that this calamitous building collapse (which killed Emperor Theosthenes, much of his family, and dozens of dignitaries) occurred in 1651 N, over three hundred years after his reconstruction project was completed. The theory appears to have originated in 1890 via Jordan hixPasqual's popular history work The Last Years of the Last Roman Empire, in which he contends with little evidence that sAvignon employed experimental and faulty techniques in reinforcing the great central dome of the cathedral, weakening the structure over the centuries until the eventual disaster.

Of course, it is difficult to know which precise modifications were made to the cathedral in the 1340s, but most historians agree that the bulk of the changes were in extending the complex, not rebuilding supports. Nonetheless, the dramatic quality of the Scathe of Saint Sophia, along with the narrative that it led directly to the Empire's final collapse less than a decade later, have led this theory to become…

##

207.1: Blue Trans-Willem War

notes in translation on the Blue Trans-Willem War

Y Var Tras-Willem Blau sta l'un entr un ranc de var nell'epoc modern primal ec polity Fransc e Teudesc envouvent cos principal (oc a digr, l'eç polity l'eiðel de Willemy parlocant) eð ec stan a gest accommis a fin auteç broucar sull'oç eiðel.
The Blue Trans-Willem War was one of a series of wars in the early modern period which principally involved French and Dutch [German] polities (that is, those powers located on either side of the territory of Willemy [~Benelux, Lorraine]) and which were de facto waged over control of said territory.

Noc obstroint ig defagl sey l'akirtanç sporadic de combat porçonnar com var n'eç cahut lon un poy d'arveiðrostað, scaunç historic ne nostrell'epoc benoçn y periodeyaçon par colour lonc y scrittour dy siecr novoç Andrysk de Santer.
Though the sporadic flare-ups of hostilies are difficult to divide into discrete wars without some arbitrariness, modern historiography usually works with the chromatic periodisation of nineteenth-century writer Andrysk de Santer.

Sy model, concreut ou (lonc y tesmogn) des y colour sur y gonfan dell'eç victour ben des l'ongit de symbol alchemic, attriboy y var Blau com y rix pænultem, oc cessant ny siecr settoç nuverrem.
Her system, based either (depending on the account) on the colours of the victors' standards or on alchemical symbolism, has the Blue war as the penultimate conflict, ending in the late seventeenth century.

Certan historicour, ma noc de Santer, aun ag var Blau y spaiðoir ascreut d'un kynous entr y coglenç abrangendessem de Rix Romannesc ny siecr settoç mejan.
Some historians, though not de Santer, have classified the Blue war as part of the broader collection of Romantic Wars of the mid-seventeenth century.

##

207.2: gouth "pushup"

gouth /guθ/ [guθ]
- pushup, press-up, a bodyweight exercise resting on hands and toes and pushing away from the floor;
- bounce back, comeback, rally, a return to form after some sort of setback;
- rebound, a romantic partner one dates in order to get over the end of a relationship

Etymology: late nineteenth century, during an early instance of the many physical exercise fads of the modern period. The term was borrowed from Welsh gwth "push, thrust, shove". The metaphorical uses (principally in gouth dar "to make a comeback, to attempt to get over someone by dating; lit. to give pushups") are seen from the 1970s.

T'orruð ou le day gouth cosogr mey?
/tɔˈrɪθ u le de guθ koˈzɔj.r̩ mi/
[tʊˈʀɪθ u le de guθ koˈzɔ.jɐ mi]
2s.obl=seem q 3s give.sbj pushup dating 1s.dsj
Do you think I'm a rebound for him?

##

207.3: nougl "distaff"

nougl /nujl/ [nwɪl]
- distaff, a device storing natural fibres to be spun;
- spinneret, the organ with which a spider spins its web;
- spinning, fibrecraft, the art of making things like textiles or rope;
- (regional, poetic) cattail, teasel, mullein, foxtail, or various other herbs and reeds with distaff-shaped flower spikes or seedheads

Etymology: from late Old Borlish noȝl "distaff". This is though to conflate two earlier forms: (1) conoȝl "distaff" < synonymous conucula in Late Latin, dissimilatory derivative of Classical colus "distaff"; (2) rocle "distaff" < synonymous rokkill in Old Norse. Dialects differ greatly on which particular plants may be referred to by this term; its meaning is not clarified by its indiscriminate use in poetry.

L'oç mersc verdeya de nougl spinous.
/lɔts mɛrx vɛrˈdja de nujl spiˈnuz/
[lɔs mɛːx vɪːˈdja de nwɪl spɪˈnuz]
df-s.dt marsh abound-ipf of distaff spiky
That bog was full of spiky bulrushes.

207.4: yedic "vinegar"

yedic /jeˈdɪk/ [ʝɪˈdɪk]
- vinegar, a sour liquid formed from the fermentation of alcohol;
- acetic acid, the principal acidic component of vinegar;
- (attributive) irritable, narky, testy, responding nastily to any interaction

Etymology: descendant of Old Borlish iedic, edic "vinegar", borrowed from synonymous edic in Old Dutch. This is apparently a metathetic variant coming from late Classical German aceda, acita "vinegar", a borrowing from Latin acētum "vinegar" possibly influenced by related acidus "sour". The Borlish word is attested as an adjective in the modern sense from as early as the twelfth century.

Tanniscað casc ugnlac sou yedic.
/ˌta.niˈxaθ kax ajnˈlak su jeˈdɪk/
[ˌta.nɪˈxaθ kax ɐinˈlak su ʝɪˈdɪk]
preserve-2p.sbj each onion under vinegar
Pickle all the onions in vinegar.

208.2: a to-rutto "single file"

a to-rutto /a ˌto.rɪˈto/ [ɐˌto.ʀɪˈto]
- single file, in a line or queue one person wide;
- in a row, sequentially, one after another, successively, located in a linear span across space or time;
- one at a time, individually, occurring in discrete instances

Etymology: attested in various forms since the late Middle Borlish period, an ideophonic idiom used to refer to single-file sorts of arrangement or motion. The phrase is hypothesised to originate in farmers' livestock-counting numerals, which may be reflected by the modern appearance of to-rutto in counting-style nursery rhymes. These rural tally-like systems (e.g. an, to, ry, bo, bum, ...), which are present across Borland, derive from Germanic or Celtic numbers.

Veleð aular a to-rutto lonc y forcul.
/veˈlɛθ oˈlar a ˌto.riˈto lɔnk i fɔrˈkɪl/
[vɪˈlɛ‿ðʊˈlɐː‿ʀɐˌto.ʀɪˈto lɔŋk i fʊːˈkɪl]
will.sbj-2p walk-inf at single.file along df pass
Cross the mountain pass in single file.

208.3: lon theu "accidentally"

lon theu /lɔn θau/ [lɔn θau]
- idly, carelessly, thoughtlessly, mindlessly, unintentionally, without much or any conscious drive;
- accidentally, by accident, by mistake, happening due to some misapprehension or lack of knowledge;
- by chance, unexpectedly, coincidentally, spontaneously, for no apparent reason

Etymology: phrase meaning "without will", attested from the Old Borlish period. The preposition lon "without, lacking" is thought to descend from Latin adverb longē "far away, for a long time". The noun theu "will, habit" was borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English þēaw "wont, behaviour". Extension to happenstances and mistakes is seen from the early modern period.

Y stuðant er y scaumel maneyant lon theu.
/i stiˈðant ɛr i xoˈmɛl maˈnjant lɔn θau/
[i stɪˈðant ɛː‿ʀi xʊˈmɛl mɐˈnjant lɔn ˈθau]
df student cop.imp df pen handle-p.prs w/o will
The student was idly fidgeting with the pen.

208.4: foyer figr "settle down"

foyer figr /fɔˈjɛr ˈfaj.r̩/ [fʊˈʝɛː ˈfa.jɐ]
- put down roots, settle down, to establish a long-lasting home in a particular community (especially via marriage and children);
- take root, take hold, to become established in some form

Etymology: idiom from the early modern period, literally "to set (a) hearth down". The noun foyer "hearth, fireplace; (fig.) homestead" is a direct descendant of Vulgar Latin focārium "hearth", an extension of synonymous focus in Classical Latin. The verb figr "put down, lay, place" reflects Latin fīgō "I fasten, fix".

Comoscon fig mesnoçon foyer?
/ˌko.moˈxɔn faj ˌmɛ.snoˈtsɔn fɔˈjɛr/
[ˌko.mʊˈxɔn faj ˌmɛ.znʊˈtsɔn fʊˈʝɛː]
however put.down mis-idea hearth
How do misconceptions take hold?

209.2: cirteyar "peddle"

cirteyar /tsɪrˈtjar/ [tsɪːˈtjɐː]
- peddle, hawk, solicit, flog, to travel around (e.g. from door to door) in order to sell;
- (archaic) sojourn, itinerate, peregrinate, tour, to travel from place to place;
- (reflexive) importune, bother, pester, mither, disturb, to harass with e.g. persistent requests;
- (reflexive) come on to, proposition, to make amorous advances

Etymology: originally in the first sense, an extension from early old Borlish ceȝrtar "peddle, itinerate" with a causative suffix. This in turn descends from Late Latin circitō "I peddle, frequent", from circō "I traverse, wander through". In reflexive use the word is attested from the early modern period.

Mame me dis de plu luy me cirteyar.
/maˈme me dɪz de pli laj me tsɪrˈtjar/
[mɐˈme me dɪz de plo laj me tsɪːˈtjɐː]
mum 1s.obl say.pst of no.more 3s.dat 1s.obl peddle-inf
Mum told me to stop mithering her.

209.3: encromnar "scarf"

encromnar /ˌɛn.krɔmˈnar/ [ˌɛŋ.kʀʊmˈnɐː]
- pocket, to put into a pouch or pocket;
- stow, put away, lodge, to place something in a space-saving manner;
- (slang) wolf, scoff, scarf, to eat (especially an impressive amount or with impressive speed)

Etymology: Middle Borlish, verbal derivation from cromn "pocket, purse, small bag". This descends uncomplicatedly from Latin crumena "pouch for carrying money". Metaphorical extension of this word is seen from the fifteenth century; in the slang sense it most recently became popular in recent decades.

Y soldart encromnn mansc com louf famiscent.
/i sɔlˈdart ɛnˈkrɔm.nn̩ manx kɔm luf ˌfa.miˈxɛnt/
[i sʊlˈdɐːt ɪŋˈkʀɔm.nɐn maŋx kɔm luf ˌfa.mɪˈçɛnt]
df soldier pocket-3p food like wolf starve-p.prs
The soldiers scarf food like starving wolves.

209.4: protagoneyar "star in"

protagoneyar /proˌta.goˈnjar/ [pʀʊˌta.gʊˈnjɐː]
- star in, lead, to be or perform as the main character of (a piece of media);
- dominate, predominate, drive, to be the main factor or influence in (some process or condition);
- to be the main topic of conversation during (a period of time), often of people involved in viral events or scandal

Etymology: nineteenth century, verbal derivative based on the noun protagonist "lead actor, dominating factor". This is an early modern borrowing via Scholastic Latin from Greek πρωταγωνιστής • (prōtagōnistḗs) "lead actor". The word is attested in non-dramatic usage from the early twentieth century.

Jo le memour noc cu protagoney l'oç lasc.
/ʒo le meˈmur nɔk ki proˌta.goˈni lɔts lax/
[ʝo le mɪˈmʊː nɔk ki pʀʊˌta.gʊˈni lɔs lax]
1s 3s.acc remember ng who star.in df=s.dt film 
I can't remember who stars in that film.

210.2: çut "battery"

çut /tsɪt/ [tsɪt]
- cell, battery, a device used to power electronic equipment which maintains a potential difference between two contacts;
- (by extension) any notional store of physical or mental energy;
- reserves, stockpile, assets set aside for contingencies;
- potential, capacity, a person's yet-untapped ability or resources

Etymology: eighteenth century, borrowed from Vascon çut "waterwheel, weir; electric battery"; the latter sense was clipped from earlier çut barric "electric weir", cells being seen as analogous stores of useful work. This in turn is a rebracketed form of original açut "waterwheel, dam", which is allied with Leon açud and Portingale açude; it was borrowed from Arabic السُّدّ • as-sudd "the dam, the dike".

La brouc un çut tal plen cas music.
/la bruk ɪn tsɪt tal plɛn kaz miˈzɪk/
[la bʀuk ɪn tsɪt tal plɛn kaz mɪˈzɪk]
3s.f enjoy indf battery such full wrt music
She has a lot of musical potential.

210.3: time "qualm"

time /tiˈme/ [tɪˈme]
- qualm, misgiving, reservation, scruple, doubt, a feeling of unease or uncertainty regarding a course of action;
- timidity, shyness, diffidence, self-effacement, a lack of courage or confidence; 
- con, disadvantage, drawback, a weakness or undesirable feature of something

Etymology: derived from earlier adjective time "doubtful; shy, timid", a borrowing from Scholastic Latin timeus "frightened, cowrdly". This comes from the root verb timeō "I fear, I am afraid". The word is seen as a noun from the seventeenth century, and as a disadvantageous quality of something (as opposed to something felt by a person) since the mid-nineteenth century.

Me stove y vajot eð y time grindr.
/me stoˈve i vaˈʒɔt ɛð i tiˈme ˈgrɪn.dr̩/
[me stʊˈve i vɐˈʝɔt ɛ‿ði tɪˈme ˈgʀɪn.dɐ]
1s.obl must-ipf df perk and df qualm grade-inf
I had to weigh the pros and cons.

210.4: mogn "low"

mogn /mɔjn/ [mɔjn]
- low, low down, situated close to the ground;
- short, squat, having little vertical extent (esp compared to other dimensions);
- trifling, trivial, petty, of no particular importance;
- silly, unserious, provoking amusement through foolishness

Etymology: direct descendant of Old Borlish mogne /moɲə/ "low down", of disputed further origin. Probably not related to Old French moins "less", despite use of the word in parallel comparative constructions in dialectal modern Borlish. The most secure lead is Kernish [Breton] monn "oaf", connected with Old French moing "someone mutilated" to a proposed Gaulish munniō "blunt", although the semantics are somewhat tenuous.

Jo cogleu l'aujon des y tabr mogn.
/ʒo kɔjˈlau loˈʒɔn dɛz i ˈtab.r̩ mɔjn/
[ʝo kʊiˈlau lʊˈʝɔn dɛz i ˈta.bɐ mɔin]
1s gather-pst df=magazine out.of df table low
I picked the mag up off the low table.

211.2: a tug "for fun"

a tug /a taj/ [a taj]
- for fun, for the love of the game, done for one's own enjoyment or other intrinsic desire to do so;
- friendly, penny-ante, (of a game) without serious stakes;
- voluntarily, intentionally, by one's own free will;
- (conjunction) so that, in order to, with a desire to bring about (some result)

Etymology: Middle Borlish idiom, literally "to passion". The noun tug "passion, fervour, enthusiasm" descends from Old Borlish tuȝ "inclination, impulse, drive". This was borrowed from Old English tyge "a pull, a draw", which is related to the verb tēon "pull, drag, lead". As a conjunction (attested from the sixteenth century) the construction requires someone's explicit agency in a way which the near-synonyms por and a fin do not.

Masctig por cors a tug teyen boncop.
/maxˈtaj pɔr kɔrz a taj tjɛn bɔnˈkɔp/
mɐxˈtaj pɔː kɔːz a taj tjɛn bʊŋˈkɔp/
ticket for race to passion cost-ipf-3p cheap
Tickets for friendly games were cheap.

211.3: lon mensc "dishonourable"

lon mensc /lɔn ˈmɛnx/ [lɔm ˈmɛŋx]
- (military) dishonourable, due to conduct that is considered reprehensible;
- without a reference, without a character, not being entitled to an employer's testimony when applying to a new job;
- (by extension) cold turkey, abruptly and without consideration for comfort

Etymology: originally in legal expressions such as destourm lon mensc "dishonourable discharge", the phrase literally means "without honour". The preposition lon "without" reflects Latin longē "far away"; the archaic noun mensc "honour; mercy; courtesy; decorum" was borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old Norse mennska "humanity". Extension to non-miltary and non-employment contexts occurred in the mid-twentieth century.

L'es attenent a caffay salir lon mensc.
/lɛz ˌa.teˈnɛnt a kaˈfe saˈlɪr lɔn mɛnx/
[lɛz ˌa.tɪˈnɛnt a kɐˈfe sɐˈlɪː lɔm mɛŋx]
3s=be try-p.prs to coffee leave-ipf w/o honour
She's trying to quit coffee cold turkey.

211.4: haval fair "play pretend"

haval fair /haˈval fer/ [hɐˈval feː]
- play pretend, make believe, role-play, to engage in imaginative activity;
- feign, dissemble, put on an act, to perform insincerely;
- go through the motions, to do something perfunctorily or without conviction

Etymology: idiom from the sixteenth century, literally "do dolls". The noun haval "doll, puppet" was originally a southern dialect term out of Pentrose, borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from Welsh haval "likeness, image; doll, effigy". Extension out of the realm of childhood play is seen from the nineteenth century.

Y joun ern haval fayent ny gardin.
/i ʒun ˈɛr.n̩ haˈval fɛˈjɛnt ni garˈdɪn/
[i ʝun ɛːn hɐˈval fɪˈʝɛnt ni gɐːˈdɪn]
df young cop.inf-3p doll do-p.prs in-df garden
The children were playing pretend in the garden.

212.2: routuron "commoner"

routuron /ˌru.tiˈrɔn/ [ˌʀu.tɪˈʀɔn]
- commoner, plebeian, proletarian, a citizen who holds no noble title or rank;
- (with plural agreement) hoi polloi, masses, rank and file, people considered as opposed to the elite

Etymology: Middle Borlish derivative of routur "vulgarity, working-class quality" (compare late Medieval Latin ruptūrō "freeman"), which originally referred to a small quantity of land as might be granted to or owned by a common farming household. This descends from Latin ruptūra "fracture, rupture, breach; (later) a division of land". Outside of historical texts, the term is usually metaphorical or jocular.

Lorrell'heir desir un routuron mariðar.
/ˌlɔ.rɛˈlir deˈzɪr ɪn ˌru.tiˈrɔn ˌma.riˈðar/
[ˌlɔ.ʀɪˈli.jɐ dɪˈzɪː‿ʀɪn ˌʀu.tɪˈʀɔn ˌma.ʀɪˈðɐː]
3p.gn-df=son want indf pleb wed-inf
Their son wants to wed a commoner.

212.3: quoncein "young adulthood"

quoncein /kwɔnˈtsin/ [kwʊnˈtsin]
- (strictly) twenties, the decade when a person is aged between 20 and 29 inclusive;
- young adulthood, a nebulous period of one's life which follows childhood and lasts approximately a decade;
- prime, trial run, Arcadia, a period in the existence of something which has any of various similarities to a person's young adulthood (the precise sense depending heavily on the speaker)

Etymology: twentieth-century calque of Willem quonzerád "young adulthood", an abstract derivation from southern dialect quonze "twenty" (standard twinte); the second element was replaced with the Borlish suffix -ein denoting a number of years (as in dezein "decade", carantein "a period of forty years"), which descends from Latin -ennium "years". Metaphorical extension of the word usually refers either to inexperience and naïveté or to a pinnacle of performance and flourishing.

La passau y quoncein par y Novomond aðendrar.
/la paˈso i kwɔnˈtsin par i ˌno.voˈmɔnd ˌa.ðɛnˈdrar/
[la pɐˈso i kwʊnˈtsin pɐː‿ʀi ˌno.vʊˈmɔnd ˌa.ðɪnˈdʀɐː]
3s.f spend-pst df twenties by df new.world tour-inf
She spent her twenties travelling the Americas.

##

212.4: benoyour "medium"

benoyour /ˌbe.nɔˈjur/ [ˌbe.nʊˈʝʊː]
- medium, spiritualist, a person who attempts communication with the dead;
- shaman, witch doctor, a member of a community representing or speaking for the spiritual realm and often also acting as a healer

Etymology: agentive derivation from now-obsolete benoïr "to receive blessings; (specifically) to receive communications from the deceased". This verb was formed in the early Middle Borlish period by analogy with bendigr "to bless" (itself obsolete by parallel beneïr, both from Latin benedīcō "I commend, praise; I bless") from the root oïr "to hear" < Latin audiō "I hear". The word enjoyed some use in lay Christian practice before dropping out of use in the Revitalist period of the early sixteenth century; it was revived in reference to non-Christian roles as well as to rites of the Novomundine "Prodigal Faiths" during the nineteenth century.

Y souspect patronneyau l'oc benoyour je Mart.
/i suˈspɛkt ˌpa.trɔˈnjo lɔk ˌbe.nɔˈjur ʒe mart/
[i sʊˈspɛkt ˌpa.tʀʊˈnjo lɔg ˌbe.nʊˈʝʊː ʝe mɐːt]
df suspect visit-pst df=s.px medium day.of Tuesday
The suspect visited this medium on Tuesday.

213.2: dragoman "interpreter"

dragoman /ˌdra.goˈman/ [ˌdʀa.gʊˈman]
- interpreter, translator, a person who translates speech to enable people without common languages to communicate;
- communicator, PR person, someone whose job is to convey technical information to the public;
- broker, mediator, middleman, intermediary, a person who liaises between two or more parties in order to achieve some outcome (especially the buying and selling of goods)

Etymology: originally in the first senses and in particular with reference to interpreters of Arabic and Turk languages. The word was borrowed in the Middle Borlish period via Latin from Malchassian Greek δραγομάνος (dragomános) "interpreter"; this in turn came via Arabic and Syriac from Acadian 𒅴𒁄 (targumannum) "interpreter". Later semantic development was influenced by the suffix -man "-monger; seller, shop".

Cascif eð vos hur dað an dragoman voscon inconfeyabr?
/kaˈxɪf ɛθ vɔz hɪr daθ an ˌdra.goˈman voˈxɔn ˌɪn.kɔnˈfjab.r̩/
[kɐˈçɪf ɛ vɔz hɪː daθ an ˌdʀa.gʊˈman vʊˈxɔn ˌɪŋ.kʊɱˈfja.bɐ]
why have.2p 2p hire give-p.pst to-indf interpreter 2p.agt ng-trust-pot
Why did you hire an interpreter you don't trust?

213.3:
